Problem: Retaining wall is shifting and leaning due to drain pipe clog and overflow.
Solution: Once drainage issue is solved, have someone look at the structural integrity of the retaining wall and determine if it will continue to shift and lean or if it will be fine now that the water infiltration issue is non-existent. Determine the right course of action.

Problem: Underground drain piping for gutters has been clogged and backing up. Water is not flowing to the end of the drains. Causing erosion and the retaining wall to shift and lean (see next repair for Retaining wall repair details).
Solution: Cap off old drains. Dig trenches and install new drain piping connected to the downspouts. Install downspout screens.

Problem:
Roof shows signs of leaking especially near the chimney.

*** Past volunteer group had come an installed the shingle roofing and did not properly flash the chimney and the roof vents are not installed to drain water properly.
Solution: Complete roof replacement.

Problem: Furnace pipes are leaking. When the boiler furnace is on Ruth can not get hot water in the shower..Heat throughout the house is not consistent.
Solution: Homeowner hired a professional to take a look at the complicated system in Ruth's basement and was not able to find a solution to fix her issues. Install new efficient heat hump.

Problem: Windows are old (Installed in 1967). Some glass is cracked, caulking is aged and falling out, latches don't latch due to wood shrinking over the years, drafty in winter.
Solution: Replace windows and/or install weatherization kits.

Problem: No Air Conditioning, no air flow in the summer months. Late husband had installed a vent fan in the ceiling of the hallway, but when Ruth used it it pulled in moisture causing a mold issue.
Solution:
Determine an appropriate way to bring cool air into the home, possibly install a window AC unit.

Remove ceiling vent unit and install an access panel or, staircase to the attic.

Problem: Ceiling caved in in laundry room due to roof leak.
Solution: After roof issue has been fixed, remove the temporary plastic the has been hung to stop water from infiltrating the laundry room. Cut away any ceiling material that is necessary to put up a piece of drywall to fill the remaining gap. Spackle the seams and paint.

Problem: Vinyl flooring is peeled up and a chuck is missing in the hallway near the bathroom
Solution: Remove the rest of the old vinyl flooring and replace with one continuous piece of vinyl flooring, remember to use flooring adhesive. Add metal thresholds at the seams of the 2 different types of flooring between the kitchen, hallway and bathroom.

Problem: Holes in the wall in bathroom
Solution: Patch the drywall and paint. Install door stop (either near floor or wall mounted)

Problem: Missing trim around bathroom door, main entrance and on the wall entry way into kitchen, drywall is also damaged.
Solution: Install new trim board and patch drywall as needed.

Problem: 3 Smoke detectors don't seem to be working, some have batteries missing. ***They are wired in, but still don't work.
Solution: Replace the batteries, Replace Smoke Detectors with Smoke/CO Combo's if needed.

Problem: Septic needs to be pumped. Home owner had it estimated, cost was $350
Solution: Have someone come and pump the septic.

Problem: Roof is leaking over the laundry roof and in the living room. Roof is soggy when walking on it in several places. It looks like it has been patched with tar on both ends of the roof, but only in-between the shingles (see photos).
Solution:
Have a professional do an in-depth assessment of the damage. Remove shingles as needed, remove and replace roof sheathing. Check rafters for rot. Replace any rotten rafters as needed. Replace roofing material.

  

*** They had someone come out a quote the repair about a year ago for $6000

Problem: Soft flooring, three spots: two in kitchen, one by bar and one near stove. One in laundry area near washer. It used to leak, it doesn't anymore.
Solution: Investigate extent of damage. This repair has not been assessed yet. It was reported over the phone by Wilma Orr. Make a plan for repair.

Problem: Underpinning is makeshift and not proper material
Solution: Install proper underpinning

Problem: Clay pipe that was installed to go from the stove pipe to the chimney cracked
Solution: Remove broken piping. Install insulated metal stove piping from stove to chimney

Problem: Front porch has missing support posts and is half missing. Concrete steps in the front are starting to crumble.
Solution:
***Sharon has a bunch of PT lumber under a tarp on the front lawn***

Remove the current concrete steps. Build a deck and either low rise stairs or a ramp.

Sharon requested a ramp because her mother visits frequently

Problem: Roof shows signs of leaking on the interior ceiling in multiple places. Upon assessing the roof itself, it is very old 5V metal roofing, pinned down with nail, and raised at the seams where the metal overlaps in a lot of different places. The metal over the front porch is very old and rusted.
Solution: Replace roofing metal (**There is no knowing what is under there, this is a very old home**) Rafters may also need replacing. Make sure that new roofing is put down using roofing screws.

Problem: Siding is very old, possibly original. There is also exposed foam board insulation on the side exterior wall and old exposed plywood on the rear.
Solution: Remove any rotten material and properly sheath and side the house.

Problem: Girder under the floor in the center of the house is made of old 6x6 and has bowed causing the floor system to shift.
Solution: Install a new Girder along the entirety of the floor system using doubled up PT 2x12 to re-level and strengthen the floor system.

Problem: Very soft flooring underneath the carpeting in the Grandson's bedroom
Solution: Remove carpeting, remove any rotten subflooring material, inspect floor joists, replace as needed, either reinstall carpeting or install new roll out vinyl flooring

Problem: Wall in Grandson's bedroom is unfinished where addition was built.
Solution: Insulate and install plywood wall sheathing, paint

Problem: Ceiling in bedroom and kitchen is finished using roll out plastic
Solution: Replace with think plywood or luan

Problem: Rear gutter is damaged and failing
Solution: Run 80ft continuous piece of gutter with 2 down spouts and slash blocking. Run corrugated drain piping away from house to day light.

Problem: water dripping into basement from kitchen, near wall where dishwasher and sink is. Not a lot but unsure what's going on.
Solution: Need a plumber to investigate where the leak is coming from.

Problem: Gutters are full and the house has a lot of leaves around the base, especially in the back near the road
Solution: Clear gutters and rack up leaf debris

Problem: Hole at the bottom of the wall in the rear of the trailer below the electrical box. Can see all the way to the ground. Lets rats and other critters in. ***Has been temporarily sealed with steel wool and taped shut.
Solution: Remove the wall sheathing/dry wall, fill with insulate, replace with wall with plywood, paint

Problem: Loose wire hanging from the wall above the stove in the kitchen
Solution: Have the electrician mentioned in previous repair cap this off to make out safe.

Problem: Light in kitchen when turned on makes a static electrical sound, smokes and smells like burning wires.
Solution: Hire a professional electrician.

Problem: Kitchen vinyl flooring is bubbling down the center. It feels as though the subflooring ply wood is coming apart where the seams are.
Solution: Take up the vinyl flooring (try to salvage if possible, it may not have been glued down) assess the subflooring and joists, replace as needed. Reinstall vinyl flooring if possible or replace vinyl flooring if needed.

Problem: Hole in the living room floor. Damaged subflooring and vinyl flooring.
Solution: Remove old vinyl flooring and subflooring wherever needed. Remove trim (salvage as much as possible) Assess the floor joists. Replace any if needed. Replace subflooring. Install roll out vinyl flooring. Clean mold on the wall with vinegar.

Problem: Clients ramp is falling apart. It is the main entry way, as Thomas is in a wheel chair. ***Client said he has someone coming to repair/rebuild this, but I am adding it here so we can check in with Thomas to make sure it has been taken care of at a later date***
Solution: Contact Thomas and see if his ramp has been taken care of.

Problem: Client had a tenant living here at one point and they said that at least one of the outlets in the upstair living area began smoking after using a hair drier. Thomas and his care-taker have not noticed any smoking themselves. They did have a friend who is a handy man and another person, on two separate occasions, who was possibly an electrician come out and were advised that the home would need to be rewired.
Solution: Hire an actual Electrician to assess the house holds safety and determine the appropriate path to remediate any dangerous electrical issues if they exist.

Problem: Hole at rear of home where critters are entering
Solution: Patch up hole, maybe with deterrents like steel wool or an alternative

Problem: Client needs a ramp for mobility concerns as he has surgery on both hips, knees and arthritis issues.
Solution: Install ramp on the from porch area of the house leading to the drive way for easy access.

Problem: Covered back porch is inaccessible due to old cardboard boxes and other stored items currently. Underneath this area the plywood decking is rotten. Ply wood rotten at access point to the yard due to rain overflow off of the roof.
Solution: Remove plywood decking and replace with decking boards or rough sawn 1x6 and Paint/stain. (Also, see other repair for gutter install)

Problem: Rear portion of the house have exposed OSB on the exterior walls. Susceptible to water damage and rotting.
Solution: Paint with exterior paint, install siding over ply wood, install trim around windows.

Problem: Water from roof infiltrating the back porch.
Solution: Install Gutter on the back section of roof over hanging the entrance of the porch.

Problem: Left side of house water coming off of roof goes into the basement (Home owner says he already has all the piece for guttering, actual materials would need to be more intimately assessed. We have also indicated for a French drain in another repair)
Solution: Assess the actual components on hand. Install gutter system. Run down spouts and drain water away from the yard and basement.

Problem: Water infiltrating the basement of the home.
Solution: Install a true French drain where there is a ditch currently. Drain water away from the house

Problem: The front left rafter of the roof (if looking at the house from the front) has lifted off of the plate several inches due to the exterior electrical being installed through the trim board and pulling loose during heavy snowfall.
Solution: May need to have the electrical company come out to unhook and reattach the wiring to a more secure location on the house. Replace trim board, paint

Problem: Client said she has 2 Propane heaters in her basement (1 small and 1 large) that are not functioning right now, may need propane tanks. Client has the desire to run piping up into the house and utilize propane instead of oil.
Solution: Install Propane tanks and run piping up to the living area or the house to utilize propane heaters.

Problem: Driveway gravel washed away in storm/flood
Solution: Lay new road bond on the driveway.

Problem: Roof seam over the elevator leaks badly when it rains. Clients have to use an umbrella due to the amount of water that comes down from the seam.
Solution: Install new clear plastic corrugated roofing that has an overlap of 12 inches or more.

Problem: Chimney pipe has fallen in heavy winds in recent storms. The wire brace holding the chimney is rusting.
Solution: Clean and Re-install chimney pipe. Replace wire supports with something stronger.

Problem: Roofing screws are rusted and coming loose. Client says the roofing is coming loose as well. ***I was unable to get up on the roof with the "20ft" ladder, so I could not inspect the side of the roof with the chimney on it. We will need a larger ladder, and someone comfortable with being on high roofs***
Solution: Replace and screws as needed. Put adhesive in any joints that are loose and not laying flat against each other.

Problem: Septic pipe from the tank to the leech field was damaged by the recent storms/floods. Septic is draining into the creek. Client had to turn off the septic pump due to the damage.
Solution: Replace the piping, and the protective covering, across the river. Possibly work out a better long term situation or positioning for the piping.

Problem: Homeowner says she has a Well that is not very deep, Approximately 40ft (Unsure if this is accurate) and the Water comes out of the pipes dark with sediment. Client says there is standing water near where the well is when it rains and she thinks the ground water is getting down into her well. The well is located just beneath a small hill just off the road. It is surrounded by large stones and thick grass. She says her filter was installed 5 years ago, not sure if it's ever been replaced.
Solution: Replace Filter. Create a swale at the bottom of the hill to catch and divert water away from and prevent water from infiltrating the well.

Problem: Kitchen sink drain clogged, but not in trap, further out
Pressure tank buried, should not be.
Solution: Exhume tank and relocate to more appropriate, accessible area

Problem: Mold where roof has been leaking (Master bedroom closet, above front door, back porch, bathroom and bedroom (bath and bed have been repaired)
Solution: Clean, and paint with Killz

Problem: Mold occurring in the home from conduction. No vapor barrier in the crawl space or insulation under the floors.
Solution: Install Vapor barrier and Insulation under the floor in the crawl space.

Problem: Gutters are over filled and Damaged in multiple places
Solution: Clear out gutters. Replace broken sections of gutter. Install down spouts and drain pipes, to drain water away from the house.

Problem: Rear of house, which is nestled at the bottom of a hill on 3 sides, with multiple springs coming out of the hill, is very damp with standing water that gets in under the home during rain events. Home owner says there is a French Drain, but it can't handle the water load.
Solution: Clear all trees and brush on hillside behind home. Create multiple swales in the hillside. Install vegetation that will help catch water before it can make it way down to the low point behind the house. Install a larger French drain or other drainage system that can handle the water-load. Divert water down the hill into the ditch along aside the road.

Problem: Foundation is cracking in the front left corner causing cracks in the exterior wall and interior plaster wall and ceiling.
Solution: Have a specialist assess the extent of the damage and ability to repair.

Problem: Old wiring (black fabric wrapped) causing 'surges' and dimming lights when electric heater is turned on. There is not a sufficient amount of outlets per room. Home owner has to plug multiple things into one outlet. In crawl space home owner says the wire sheathing deteriorating and it makes her nervous.
Solution: Replace old wiring with Romex wiring.

Problem: Roof is leaking in multiple areas. Has been patched in 2 places. Shingles are falling out and very old. Current shingle roof was installed on top of old shingle roof. Some rafter tails and sheathing are visibly rotten over the front porch, may have more rotten areas.
Solution: Remove both layers of old shingle roofing. Examine roof sheathing. Replace any rotting roof sheathing. Remove rotting rafter tails and install new lumber, either replacing entire rafters, as needed, or creating a partial rafter replacement that will solve the problem and be structurally sound. Install new roofing (metal).

Problem: There is carpet through out the Living room, Hallway, Bathroom and Bedrooms. Shirley as Asthma and the old carpets are exacerbating her condition. Doctor says she needs to get the carpeting out. She also has 3-4 dogs that spend a lot of time indoors.
Solution: Remove Carpeting. Prioritize the Living room, Hallway, Bathroom and Main Bedroom, but Removing all carpeting would be best. Install Roll Out Vinyl Flooring. Replace trim as needed.

Problem: Toilet Cracked
Solution: Replace toilet (when redoing bathroom flooring)

Problem: Bathroom: Flooring is rotting around the tub
Solution: Remove Carpeting in Bathroom, Remove Subflooring as needed, assess structural needs, Replace Floor Joists as needed, Replace Subflooring and Flooring with Roll out Vinyl Flooring, Reseal tub edges, Replace and paint any trim that needs to be removed.

Problem: Front Porch handrail is falling apart and unsafe. Stairs are old.
Solution: Replace front porch Stairs and handrails

Problem: Small mold spot about 8ft inside the front door to the right, possibly from leaking siding.
Solution: Investigate deeper to find cause of leak or moisture infiltration and seal as needed

Problem: Underpinning is rotten most of the way around the trailer. Rodents are getting in and tearing out insulation.
Solution: Reinstall/Replace any insulation as needed, Remove and replace any underpinning, paint.

Problem: Roof is rusty. Roof leaking where an old vent is above the bathroom, water dripping from fan/light fixture in bathroom.
Solution: Kool seal entire roof. Seal area around the old vent properly and adequately.

Problem: Shower is damaged and leaking, has been repaired with duct tape.
Solution: Replace shower stall and any piping that needs replacing.

Problem: Water damage in Bathroom, Hall and Bedroom. Toilet is sunken into the floor. Soft spots in the Bathroom, Hallway, and Bedroom.
Solution: Remove all flooring and subflooring where ever there are signs of deterioration. Replace Subflooring as needed and flooring with roll out vinyl flooring, replace trim AS NEEDED.

Problem: Furnace is having trouble igniting, client has to hit it to get it to ignite sometimes. Says that sometimes it still wont light.
Solution: Hire a specialist to either repair ignitor or replace furnace (see photos for label details)

Problem: Ceiling in kitchen is falling in from where a past tenant went up in the attic and stepped through.
Solution:
Remove old ceiling tiles, fix any structural ceiling material, replace ceiling tiles.

  

***Client says he has more of the ceiling tiles

***Full material list will need to be evaluated, and a deeper inspection will need to be done.

Problem:
There are old single pane windows throughout the home, some of which are broken, window cills and interior framing of windows is rotting. Front windows and basement windows are cemented in. Client says that the cold air infiltration in the winter is causing very high heating bills.

**Client said he spoke to someone at Anderson windows and they quoted him $20,000 to remove old windows and install all new ones, including fixing any broken and rotten framing.
Solution: Remove old windows, Remediate any rotten framing and replace, install new windows.

Problem: Crack in chimney
Solution: Repair/patch cracks in chimney

Problem: Auxiliary buildings (i.e shed, barn and small storage shed) have several issues (i.e cracked foundation, soffit board rotting, gutter metal rotting, window broken, termite damage on sheathing, foundation rotting (small storage shed)
Solution: Repair foundation issues, replace damaged portions of sheathing, Replace window, Replace soffit boards and gutter, repair foundation (small storage shed)

Problem: Old wiring throughout house causing very limited access to power. Some wiring is dead and does not work at all.
Solution: Run new wiring through home, or run external wiring in conduit to necessary places in the house.

Problem: Side window cill rotting, window broken (36" W x 39" H)
Solution: Replace window and re-trim, paint, caulk

Problem: Paint peeling through out the exterior of the house.
Solution: Scrape old paint and prime and repaint, caulk edges

Problem: Gutters are full and damaged in some areas causing rain water to drain in inappropriate places and add to the infiltration issue. Down spout in the rear of house is draining directly into the foundation.

Problem: Exterior walls damp and rotting ***Water comes in to the house from behind the dryer in the bedroom, there has also be significant water infiltration in the living room due to improper construction of the addition and insufficient drainage in the backyard***
Solution: Remove/Replace sheathing (or bottom portion of the sheathing), install proper flashing/seal the bottom of the wall appropriately to keep out water, install siding, paint. (Once the sheathing is removed assess the framing) Remove rotten framing and sister new boards on to the salvageable parts of the wall. ***Make sure to brace the roof properly if any of the wall framing does need to be removed***

Problem: Cement floor in bedroom is not sealed, rough and holds moisture. Cement floor in the living room has a crack.
Solution: Seal the cement floor with Masonry seal, fill crack with appropriate product.

Problem: Shower is rotting very badly, water control handles damaged. Stacey has a Nuerological condition and has a hard time getting in and out of the shower due to the tub style base.
Solution: Bathroom remodel is needed, this bathroom is in very poor condition. Install handicap access shower with safety railings.

Problem: Roof damaged in several places. Roofing metal is very old. Water stains on ceiling in bedroom, was recently painted in the last 2 years, so it's know to be a new stain.
Solution: Roof may need to be replaced with new metal roofing. Sheathing may also need to be replaced as well.

Problem: Water pipe burst under the house, near the water filter. Water is turned off.
Solution: Hire a plumber to go out and assess the extend of the damage and repair.

Problem: Back deck rotten and caving in in some places
Solution: Remove old deck and replace with approximately 10' x 10' deck with railing

Problem: Front porch support beams are rotting.
Solution: Support Roof with temporary roof brace (2x6 cut to a length that you can fit a bottle jack under it, with a 3ft piece of 2x6 making a T shape). Remove current roof supports. Replace current beams with 6x6 posts. Remove and replace any other wood that may need to be replaced. Add an extra support on the left side of the front stairs. Paint Supports.

Problem: Hole in back bedroom floor beneath carpet. It's in a walking area. They keep this room shut off for safety reason.
Solution: Could use this room as one of the children's bedroom but it is currently unsafe with hidden hole beneath carpet. Need to address severity. Remove carpet (potentially permanently and lay down laminate), repair hole.

Problem: Bedroom window missing one of the pains of glass, causing cold conditions in the winter
Solution: Replace glass and/or Window, or Install weatherization kit

Problem: Front door doesn't seal fully, creates cold drafts in winter
Solution: Install new weather stripping, Install trim around the door frame, paint trim

Problem: Livingroom wall rotting, floor failing below window (window may be the cause of water leaking)
Solution: Remove current flooring ***SALVAGE if possible*** Replace window, Replace sub-flooring, Re-Install current flooring

Problem: Bathroom floor caving in
Solution: Replace sub-flooring, Replace vinyl flooring

Problem: Kitchen sink plumbing is poor, inside cabinet is damaged from past leak.
Solution: Replace plumbing as needed, Replace of cover base of the interior of cabinet with plywood, trim interior of cabinet, paint plywoods base

Problem: Roof is in poor (and declining) condition, The sheathing under the shingles is soggy in some places when you walk on it. It is causing leaks in multiple areas in the house (Master Bedroom, Bedroom, hallway, bathroom).
Solution:
Replace roof sheathing (if needed) and roofing with metal roofing.

**Possibly install purlins and roofing metal if approved by contractor***

Problem: Master Bathroom: Sink is leaking causing water damage. Countertop is cracked and damaged. Toilet seat covering is damaged. Interior of the sink cabinet and the flooring/ Sub-flooring are water damaged. Window (16" W x 41" H) glass is broken.
Solution: Bathroom Remodel. Replace sink, counter top and cabinet. Replace toilet. Fix plumbing as needed. Replace sub-flooring & flooring as needed. Replace window.

Problem: Flooring is damaged and/or missing
Solution: Replace flooring as needed

Problem: Trash and maybe some hoarding in and around the house
Solution: Remove trash, and help with removing trash from the home if Nancy is open to the assistance.

Problem: Driveway has been washed out by heavy rains causing severe erosion and stagnant wetness around the trailer.
Solution: Install French drain around the perimeter of the trailer at the base of the hill. Drain the water down and away from the house. Grade and repair driveway. Install guard rail drains intermittently, in appropriate places for drainage, down the driveway.

Problem: Missing and broken underpinning
Solution: Replace broken and missing underpinning

Problem: Floor in addition has caved in.
Solution: Take up flooring (save if possible), and sub-flooring. Inspect for reason for floor failing. Reframe with new joists and sub-flooring, reinstall flooring if able, or install new flooring.

Problem:
Water is run to the trailer, but not hooked up, has no water heater

***There is a functional water heater in the house in front of the trailer that can be moved***
Solution: Transfer water heater from house to trailer, hook up water

Problem: Front porch and stairs are old and rotting
Solution: Replace porch and stairs with new wood construction

Problem: Holes in drywall in various places

Problem: No finish flooring in hallway and bedroom, old flooring in bathroom and kitchen.
Solution:
Install roll out vinyl flooring in kitchen, bathroom, hallway and bedroom as needed. Reinstall toilet.

***Client is also requesting carpets for the kitchen and living room***

Problem: Large window in living room is broken
Solution: Replace with a mobile home window, may need some framing work around the perimeter of the window.

Problem: Exterior Stone Stairs are coming apart. Retaining Wall are "caving in", being pushed out by the hillside?.
Solution: Either repair the stone stairs, or Redesign a set of wooden stairs that can be fit into the space where the existing stairs are. This would require removing the existing stone stairs to an extent that makes the new stairs able to fit in the space and sit un a sturdy way, unobstructed by the existing steps. Also, Repair or remove the Stone wall so it doesn't fully collapse.

Problem: Freezer in basement showing signs of rust and mold
Solution: Paint freezer

Problem: Water in basement, including a strange leak that left a black-ish remanence
Solution: Inspect foundation more fully (initial assessment did not show signs of damage)

Problem: Corner of porch was raised back in 2017 when the stairs were built, causes water to pour over the gutter
Solution: Adjust the gutter or lift and lower the porch back to its original position

Problem: Missing shingles on the rear corner of house, and along the back edge
Solution: Remove 2 layers of shingles and replace with new shingles, reflash chimney, needs 3 sheets OSB

Problem: Membrane roof has nails that are tearing through on the edge and 1 nail in the middle that is raised and will eventually poke through
Solution: Remove failing nails, Lift membrane and remove nails underneath, Install Termination bar

Problem: Wall heater in the bathroom only blows cold air
Solution: Replace heater

Problem: Basement stairs are very steep and have a very shallow tread depth
Solution:
Replace basement stair treads and increase the tread depth using wider pieces of lumber and possibly add kick plates to extend the treads out more. May also need some added lumber for increased structural integrity.

  

***Over all these stairs are in good shape otherwise.***

Problem: Exterior side porch steps tread boards are getting loose and Railings are wobbly.
Solution: Replace needed section of the porch to create safe entry.

Problem: Rotten Door
Solution: Replace door

Problem: Leaking roof
Solution: repair or replace

Problem: Windows not sealed in
Solution: Seal in windows add trim and paint

Problem: Water heater leaked all over kitchen floor
Solution: Pull up floor replace joists as needed. Lay new sub floor and floor down

Problem: Paint on newly built deck
Solution: Get a high quality deck paint or stain to protect her deck from the elements

Problem: Rotten back porch.
Solution: Rebuild with a 4x4 deck and low rise stairs

Problem: Gutter is damaged on front of trailer, No gutter on rear of trailer
Solution: Replace and Install new gutters

Problem: Furnace pipe may be rotten (It is located somewhere behind the underpinning under the trailer on the back side)
Solution: Locate furnace pipe, Find any leaking and replace that portion of piping if possible, or replace entire pipe line from furnace to house.

Problem: Insulation under trailer has fallen down and gotten torn up, potentially by critters
Solution: Remove old insulation as needed, Reinstall whatever can be salvaged. Install new Insulation and vapor barrier. Install 6mm plastic Vapor barrier ground sheet.

Problem: Missing interior door to guest room
Solution: Replace door (estimated 27" wide)

Problem: Guest bedroom flooring damaged
Solution: Replace flooring as needed

Problem: Mud and water under trailer, Trailer is built on a hill
Solution: Install French drain on the back side of the trailer. Install Vapor barrier under trailer.

Problem: Soft floor in bathroom
Solution: Replace rotten flooring and/or subflooring

Problem: Doors rotting
Solution: Replace doors

Problem: Master bath wall rotting
Solution: Remove and Replace wall material

Problem: Hallway floor is rotting due to Plumbing leak from the washing machine.
Solution: Fix/Replace any old and failing pipes

Problem: Kitchen floor rotting under Deep Freezer and Fridge.
Solution: Remove Appliances and replace any flooring and/or subflooring as needed.

Problem: Ceiling shows signs of damage from leaks in roof in multiple places, especially around the wood stove pipe.
Solution: Reseal roof with Koolseal, Re-Tar/Through-The-Roof all vents and pipes on roof, Fix/patch up broken ceiling materials

Problem: Water flowing down the 'access road' to the upper field washes out the driveway. Road-way ditch is deep and then gets shallow nearing the end of the driveway causing heavy rain to flood and wash out the driveway.
Solution: Dig significant ditches to channel water in a manageable way that doesn't destroy the landscape.

Problem: I am going to add this here for now, this home is in major disrepair, with a likely failing foundation causing major structural issues throughout the house, as well as moisture issues. Will need to be talked about in Client Triage/Review.
Solution: Possible New Home

Problem: Back door is damaged and leaky.
Solution: Replace back door with a conventional home door and install a new lockset keyed to the front door.

Problem: Rat infestation
Solution: Hire Terminix to come quarterly for a year to address rat and other pests.

Problem: Water Heater filled with sediment
Solution: Replace with new energy efficient water heater

Problem: Broken Asphalt Shingles on Roof
Solution:
Replace shingles as needed

**Billy Hyden recommended replacing roof as shingles are very brittle, he can patch for now if need be, but will likely old hold out a few more years before needing replacing**

Problem: Back porch roofline against the house and where the gutter is is leaking
Solution:
Remove gutter, trim rafters on the gutter side, reinstall gutters.

Adjust flashing, and/or install new flashing between house and porch roof.

Problem: Back stairs are old, rotting and becoming dangerous. Deck boards are splintery and the paint is worn. Railings near stairs are failing and not attached in the safest way for a client with mobility issues.
Solution:
Remove old staircase, deck boards and railings. Rebuild Staircase with low rise and deeper treads (5 1/4" Rise, 16 1/2" Depth), Railing and Replace decking boards.

**We will have to remove old 4x4 railroad ties that line the walk way leading to the stairs and I suggest replacing them with bigger railroad ties, because the current lumber is rotten and the walkway could use some reinforcement from errosion. This is necessary due to the new stairs coming a significant distance more off of the deck than the original stair.

Problem: Very little power. French Broad said they needed a new box.
Solution: Get an electrician out to assess and fix the issue.

Problem: No water
Solution: Investigated by Chris Watson on 8/9/21. Pressure tank switch needs replacing.

Problem: Ceiling shows signs of slight leaking of the roof. Vivian and her son have Kool Seal-ed the roof multiple times, but water seems to be getting in somewhere.
Solution: Client is requesting help with putting a new roof over her trailer.

Problem: Rear porch addition rotten.
Solution: Demolish, Install railing on original deck

Problem: Corner of the front of the trailer was damaged in a wind storm, potential water infiltration area.
Solution: Refasten and seal siding and/or roof as needed

Problem: Roof has been Kool Sealed 2 years ago, and Juanita told me they Kool Seal it every 6 years.
Solution: Eventually a new metal roof should be installed, because Kool Sealing multiple times is not recommended.

Problem: Special needs child needs fence for safety reasons.
Solution: Install fence.

Problem: Piles of things on porch.
Solution: Donate and/or bring to the landfill.

Problem: No water pressure. Seems that Juanita's well pump may need to be replaced.
Solution: Inspect Well pump and/or other potential reason for a lack of water pressure. Hire plumber to assess the situation.

Problem: Toilet water keeps running, in order to stop this Juanita has to turn her entire water system off, to ensure her septic doesn't over fill with water.
Solution: Install a cut off valve at the toilet

Problem: Front stairs are dangerous and falling down
Solution: Replace front stairs and railings with a set of low-rise gently sloped stairs. With 5 - 5 1/2" rise and 12 - 16" tread depth

Problem: Underpinning is slightly caving in due to erosion and possible deterioration of support framing.
Solution: Take off underpinning material. Check the framing to see if it needs to be replaced. Dig a trench and form a concrete erosion barrier/wall under the under pining. Replace/reinstall any necessary framing. Reinstall underpinning material.

Problem: Pocket doors not functioning properly
Solution: Chris Lord will go investigate

Problem: Addition is sagging
Solution: Addition needs to be reframed, at least in part.

Problem: Bathroom is completely unfinished
Solution: Install Drywall, install flooring, Reposition toilet and re-plumb as needed

Problem: Sill plate along the entire building has been eaten up by termites
Solution: Cut out the bottom portion of the wall, about 36" up, cut out the bottoms of the studs and remove the sill plate, Replace sill plate and replace the bottom of the studs/sister onto existing studs. replace drywall and re mud and sand and finish walls.

Problem: Soffit and fascia has been remove due to rot. Rear porch had to be re framed. Rafters have been sistered on to replace the rotten rafter tails.

Problem: Front door framing is rotted out by termites (**has been treated**)

Problem: Likely that logging company destroyed Caroline's water lines. Water is not flowing and clay is visible in the filter. Water flows backwards back out of the system when water is turned off due to very low pressure.
Solution: Dig up water pipe connection and cut to see if it's flowing. Dig a new ditch and run water lines to the house.

Problem: Roof is unfinished and being damaged by weather
Solution: finish the rest of the roofing. (**Caroline has the roofing metal already**)

Problem: Floor in kitchen is rotting (**Washing machine pipe broke and spilled water onto the pre-existing issue making it worse.)
Solution: Replace subfloor and any framing necessary. Replace laminate flooring. Fix plumbing for washing machine.

Problem: Electrical work needed in order for septic pump to function
Solution: Jeremy Wallin is the only one able to get out there in a short time frame. Matthew of MWS said the family could go about a week and a half before septic pump will need to work.

Problem: Septic keeps backing up into home. Inspected by MWS and Env Health. Someone drove over pipe and crushed. System is old, but rigged to function for now. Will need completely new area for repair/replace.
Solution: After much back and forth with family that owns land near family cemetery behind Beulah's, we have a repair area, it perced, Env Health approved and new septic installed. IRP to pay for this directly to MWS.

Problem: Living room windows leak and have loose trim
Solution: Caulk and or re-seal living room windows and fix trim

Problem: Agnes is hoping to have a small porch built off the front of the camper in order to have a place to sit and enjoy her from yard.
Solution: Build an approximately 6' x 8' porch with a roof that covers the entry way to prevent some rain from entering the camper through the door.

Problem: Hole above the fridge snakes get in, temporarily sealed with cardboard and tape, hole below fridge where rats get in
Solution: Properly, or more permanently, seal both areas. Seal old vent on roof to prevent snakes from entering the camper.

Problem: Wind and water come in through the gaps between the door and the door framing
Solution: Install weather stripping

Problem: Agnes has most of her belongings stored/piled up in her camper in the bedroom. She said she is going to get a storage shed, but it will need a floor build to install it on top of.
Solution: Clear a space beside the camper and build a floor suitable for the dimensions of the shed she is buying. Assemble shed and install.

Problem: Son-in-law undid the water tank under the bed without draining it first, it leaked a lot of water all over the floor in the bedroom causing floor damage. Also, half of the floor in the kitchen and living room area has temporary partial board repair.
Solution: Install new sub flooring and flooring throughout camper

Problem: Light switches near rear door are broken off
Solution: Replace light switches

Problem: Floor is rotting from a previous shower leak in the auxiliary bath in the master bedroom.
Solution: Install 1/2" - 3/4" subfloor/plywood through out the bedroom, install flooring

Problem: Ceiling is rotting and deteriorating in Master bath and main bath from roof leaking
Solution: Carefully tear out rotten and moldy ceiling, replace with sheet rock.

Problem: Roof was Kool-sealed about 2 years ago, it was very rusty. The roof now leaks above the master bedroom bath and the main house bath.
Solution: Install new metal roof over top of the existing mobile home roof. Reseal all vent pipe areas. Cut out skylight and seal it flat, so it will be under the new roof.

Problem: NO WATER
Solution: investigate source of issue and repair

Problem: Ceiling in the kitchen has a big hole in it, possibly from roof leak, but it was dry at the time and didn't show signs of water damage (It looked like 1 or 2 pieces of the roofing metal have been replaced directly above where this damage is in the house, **see photos)**
Solution: Replace ceiling drywall, check the roof for potential water infiltration

Problem: Piled up trash on porch and in yard
Solution: Do a yard and porch clean-up

Problem: Foundation on addition has settled and has some separation in the cinderblocks
Solution: Patch foundation

Problem: Kitchen window glass has been broken
Solution: Replace window

Problem: Front door doesn't seat correctly, doesn't have correct hardware for it to stay shut without being locked. It is also an interior door used as an exterior door that Diana's brother installed.
Solution: Replace with functional exterior door, retrim the door in the threshold.

Problem: Driveway access is getting washed out by rain.
Solution: Create a swale at the bottom of the hill next to the driveway, Install drainage across the driveway, make sure the water has somewhere to go on the other side of driveway, create a drain field if necessary and spread ballast rock to fill in the crater created by the rain water, cover with road bond.

Problem: Door in addition is deteriorating and leaking cold air in the winter
Solution: Remove door and frame in a window. Put sheathing and siding where door was.

Problem: Vent in the bathroom is not functional
Solution: Install new combo light/vent in bathroom

Problem: 3 Windows were replaced by Erma's son, they are unfinished and poorly installed and leak cold air in the winters
Solution: Finish window installation, seal windows where needed, install trim inside and out.

Problem: Paneling in the living room is halfway finished replacing (Homeowner has the paneling already)
Solution: Replace and Install wall paneling

Problem: Floor in rear bedroom is sinking in the corner, flooring is separating
Solution: Replace any rotten floor joists and re-stabilize any failing supports under the house, replace flooring as needed and trim in bedroom

Problem: Rear sliding door does not slide and leaks air in the winter
Solution: Replace rear door.

Problem: Old Furnace (It is a dual Furnace for heat and AC) Doesn't Work for Heat. They have been using Propane heat as an atlernative, but it doesn't heat the whole house.
Solution: Replace Furnace

Problem: Carolyn's bedroom windows paint is peeling and wood is rotting.
Solution: Either Strip and Repaint windows or replace them.

Problem: Windows in kitchen, and storm door in rear addition and front door leak air in the winter through cracks where the weather stripping has rotted.
Solution: Seal air gaps with weather stripping and/or Great Stuff spray foam (or equivalent) where appropriate, in window gaps. Install weather stripping on doors and felt stripping on doors.

Problem: Driveway needs gravel
Solution: Put gravel down on driveway

Problem: Front windows Trim and framing is rotting, New screens (possibly 42"x32")
Solution: Replace trim and any framing that is needed, replace screens

Problem: Client needs a storage area for firewood
Solution: Construct wood shed

Problem: Gutters are full of debris and over flowing in big rain events
Solution: Clear gutter

Problem: Wall/Floor is unfinished in bathroom causing damage to occur due to water exposure. Also in the same bathroom, the floor sinking in the adjacent hallway is causing the sink to separate from the counter top causing water that spills to run in-between the crack and into the cupboard area. Cracks in the floor tile.
Solution: Finish the bathroom wall and floor, Patch tile where needed, Reseal sink to counter top (and fix the sinking floor in the hallway)

Problem: Doors: Side door doesn't seal correctly, leaving a gap at the bottom that is causing unwanted wild guests to enter the home (snakes, mice, etc.). Rear door doesn't have a plate on the wall side of the closure, The handle has also broken off on one side of the door, James says that sometimes the door will blow open on its own. Interior door is falling off the hinges and pulling the screw out.
Sink seems to be dripping from a failing seal close to the drain, causing water to rot out the bottom of the cabinet.
Solution: Fix drain seal (and any other seals that may also be failing), replace if any piping that is found to be broken, Replace framing and base of cabinet.

Problem: Rear wall sheathing is buckling. (was replaced/fixed by a mission group sometime in the last 3 years)
Solution: Refasten sheathing to the wall

Problem: Floor is sinking in multiple places (in kitchen and in the hallway near one of the bedrooms and the bathroom), Air is coming in through a crack in the floor (in the hallway near the bath room)
Solution: Go under trailer and assess the damage, Re-level the trailer and any footers/blocking underneath, Replace any rotten or damaged lumber and install new flooring system, sub flooring and finish flooring in damaged areas where necessary, Seal any gaps with "Great Stuff" spray foam.

Problem: Client is requesting to have old cinder block stove flue removed
Solution: Remove stove flue and patch wall

Problem: Water from the spring to the reservoir is getting clogged with silt and muck and water is not flowing to the cistern causing the elderly client to try and dig it out frequently and blow out the pipe.
Solution: Rebuild the form/stone frame around the spring

Problem: Septic tank is full and over flowing only a few weeks after being pumped out
Solution: May need to have a new septic tank installed. Contact professional to fully assess the solution.

Problem: Josh's electric bill has been astronomical. He called FBEMC and they said something occurred on 3/25/21 that caused him to start using a lot more kw/hr than usual. He recalls a storm and believes his pump in his septic is malfunctioning.
Solution: Josh has done some narrowing down and investigating and feels confident the septic pump is the issue. Send out a pro to verify and try to fix, or if need be, replace pump.

Problem: Gutters are poorly installed and are leaking causing rot on the Exterior walls
Solution: Replace/Adjust and Reinstall Gutters and Facia board. Reuse what part of the gutter we possible can. Seam and seal Gutter where able. Re attach down spouts and run drainage to appropriate places.

Problem: Water is coming off of the roof and down the back door, coming in the backdoor and possibly the main cause of floor rotting inside back door.
Solution: Design and implement the best way to redirect waterway from the back porch area. Possibly installing a gutter system that runs water down a drain pipe and away from the house.

Problem: Floor has soft spot inside near the back door which seem to be unsafe and stimulates fear in the home owner.
Solution: Remove Subfloor and any rotten Flooring, replace with Advantek or equivalent subflooring, install vinyl/ linoleum flooring.

Problem: Porch stairs are covered in plywood that created a Ramp for Leona's husband while he was alive. It is beginning to rot and is becoming dangerous.
Solution: Remove plywood ramp and repair and/or replace stairs.

Problem: Porch screen is makeshift, makes the front porch and front entrance nearly unusable. It also lets the carpenter bees in and they are chewing up the lumber.
Solution: Screen in front porch and install screen door.

Problem: Underpinning is falling off and/or broken in some places around the perimeter of the home
Solution: Replace Underpinning

Problem: railings and one stair tread in bad shape, Janice reported this over the phone when I spoke with her 6/2/21
Solution: need to check it out and come up with best solution

Problem: Windows drafty in the winter
Solution: Refer to Community Action for Weatherization

Problem: Kitchen Sink leaking from Pipe near the drain (Pipes are very old and have been re-sealed with some sort of adhesive)
Solution: Replace and reseal plumbing piping

Problem: Overhead Light in Living Room fan works but the light does not. (bulbs have been replaced. light still doesn't work)
Solution: Replace Fan/Light fixture

Problem: Porch Roof is Leaking
Solution: Apply "Through the Roof"

Problem: Cement Spring Reservoir is suspected to be leaking through the ground and running under the back porch causing the decking to rot.
Solution: Inspect the Reservoir to determine where the leak is coming from, repair or replace cement reservoir. Replace Decking boards.

Problem: Deck and ramp, as well as back stoop and steps, need to be stained to protect from the elements.
Solution: Using a good waterproof stain, potentially adding some grit/sand for texture and to prevent slipping, apply a healthy coat to all newly installed pressure treated lumber.

Problem: Roof Leaking sagging on the exterior corners due to suspected rafter rotting, also leaking into the den (there are signs of water infiltration on the interior ceiling)
Solution:
Roofing metal and trim will likely need to be removed to assess the overall damage and decipher the best course of action.

I suspect that some framing/rafters will need to be replaced (no telling how many without pulling up the roofing first) and all of the roofing screw should be replaced (they have been sealed over with tar, flex seal, and silicone according to Beatrice's Grand Daughter)

The flashing between the main house and the addition may need to be replaced, or salvaged and just resealed after the roofing is reapplied.

The metal trim/flashing on the edges along where the roof is sagging may need to be re-examined and redesigned and install better material that covers entire rafter, or paint the end rafters very well to ensure they don't rot out from water exposure again.

  

Replace current support posts with 6x6 posts

Problem: New Insulation and Siding on rear of house was never installed, has makeshift patches that need attention to prevent leaking and to help keep home warm.
Solution: Install foam board insulation and siding on the unfinished portion of the house.

Problem: Foundation blocks are separating, creating clacks for rodents and water to enter underneath the home
Solution: Seal cracks

Problem: "Underpining" plywood is rotting causing air infiltration in winter and a place for rodents to entire the underside of the home.
Solution: Replace plywood and paint (or replace with something that wont rot with ground contact)

Problem: Neighbor's creek overflows during heavy rain, it runs down the hill up under the house (Norman has dug the best ditch he can, by hand with a mattock, to catch the water and direct it away from the house, water still gets past and infiltrates the underside of the house)
Solution: Dig a 2ft wide by 3ft deep trench where Norman has already dug a small ditch and fill it with gravel and large stones,(possible do a French drain)

Problem: Front stairs are rotting and hand rails are not secure
Solution: Replace front stair case

Problem: Current tub/shower is caving in/rotting and hard to access.
Solution: Replace tub/shower with a walk-in shower with sliding door and a grab rail for safety.
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Floor in hallway has soft spot, master bedroom has a soft spot about the size of a basketball (could be more, had a lot of personal belongings in the area, could not get to the entire area) and in master bathroom soft floor around the toilet
Solution:
***This could be a complicated fix, you will not know what is wrong until you can either tear into the current floor system or get under the trailer.

Pull up the old flooring, replace the rotten floor joists, insulation, subfloor and flooring where needed.

(client said the toilet in the bathroom is new and would like to keep it in tact and reuse)

Problem: The front half of roof was replaced/covered with new metal, the back half of the roof was never done and when it rains water runs into the small addition off the back of the mobile home, which is an area they use for food storage.
Solution: Install new roofing on back half of house, including over the storage area.

Problem: Culvert at the bottom of the driveway is blocked up and causing damage to the driveway to occur.
Solution:
Unclog the covert and asphalt/tar patch the driveway.

 **?(Christi said her neighbor may have volunteered to help get this issue resolved)**

Problem: Garage Foundation has cracks.
Solution: Contact a structural engineer to assess the severity overall threat.

Problem: Garage window was broken and temporarily fixed with plexiglass. The window locks aren't functioning. There is a fear of safety from intrusion.
Solution: Find out manufacture of window and order a replacement bottom section.

Problem: Master shower is leaking and causing damage to the floor, starting to deteriorate the sub floor and linoleum is starting to peel. This is causing them to not be able to use this bathroom, which is the most easily accessible bathroom in the house given that both Christopher and Christi have had multiple surgeries.
Solution: Find the problem area where water is breaching the shower, seal cracks/holes and/or fix any damaged areas

Problem: There is a slippery grassy walking path up to the read deck stairs
Solution: Create set of landscaped/terraced stairs in the hill that lead up to the back deck stairs

Problem: Rear porch steps are very steep and hard for Christopher and Christi to access especially in the winter.
Solution: Replace existing stairs with a low rise/ less aggressive stair design

Problem: Porch posts, handrails and stair treads on front and back porch rotting.
Solution: Fix and replace rotting posts, hand rails and stair treads.

Problem: Floors are sagging and damaged, have been fixed previously, but are still failing.
Solution: Fix broken flooring, install sturdy flooring and covering (i.e vinyl or linoleum)

Problem: Rook leaking, ceiling is damaged and caving-in in the living room. Vents on the roof have cracked sealant around them, gutters are leaking and front is falling off.
Solution:
Replace roof/Install roofing over existing roof

Fix gutters, replace if necessary.

Problem: Front deck is failing, had inadequate access and handrails
Solution: Replace deck with functional design for easy access and mobility, with added safety features such as lower rise stairs and full wrap around hand rails.

Problem: Roof leaking down the center ridge, signs of water on bedroom wall and in kitchen above stove (water damaged microwave oven, Wanda has removed). Some shingles had blown off in high winds (Wanda has replaced)
Solution: Repair roof ridge for proper water proofing and repellent and secure any noticeably loose or damaged shingles.

Problem:
Wanda has requested to have a roof put over her front porch, her sons explained to me that it is very hot in the front of the house, and it would improve Wanda's quality of life significantly to have a shaded area to spend more time outdoors in the warmer months.

  

***Update** Wanda has the materials for this, just needs someone to construct the Roof.
Solution: Constructs a roof over Front porch area.

Problem: 2 windows were broken and replaced with storm windows but Wanda couldn't afford the entire window, may be causing an issue
Solution: Fix/repair windows

Problem: Loose Flooring (in the living room and in the hallway and in small bedroom)
Solution: Repair loose flooring

Problem:
Roof is old and Rusting and has never been sealed

5/24 - Roof has began leaking, showing signs near furnace
Solution: Kool seal roof to prevent issue from becoming more serious

Problem: Front stairs are steep and starting to sink, giving them more of a pitch and making it difficult and dangerous for Wanda to access her home, especially in the winter months.
Solution: Replace steps with a longer set of stairs, replace railing, repair decking as needed.

Problem: Master bath is hard/inaccessible due to bodily issues.
Solution: Replace existing tub with a walk-in shower with sliding doors

Problem:
* Main Bathroom Tub seal degrading
  * Possible leaking shower head in Master bath
  * Broken fixtures on Master bath tub
Solution: * Hire Plumber to appropriately assess the issue and come up with s proper strategy to solve it.

Problem: Leaking windows in Bedrooms and Livingroom
Solution: Refer to Community Action or other Appropriate Resource that helps with window repairs

Problem:
* "Bus" Fuse blows when using the heat
  * Outlets don't work throughout the home
  * Fan/Light malfunctioning in sons room
Solution: Hire Electrician or other appropriate professional to assess the electrical/heating issue.

Problem:
Leaking plumbing under kitchen sink

Dishwasher connection may be leaking
Solution:
* Hire Plumber to figure out the source of the leak
  * Rebuild shelving under kitchen sink

Problem: Rear Porch and stairs degrading
Solution:
* Resurface deck
  * Rebuild stairs
  * Stain entire porch

Problem:
* Roof Has Multiple Leaks
  * Front porch roof leaks into living room window
Solution: Build roof on top of existing structure

Problem: Mold in Master Bedroom Closet
Solution: Clean mold, Replace wall if needed, paint with Kilz.

Problem: Roof Leak
Solution: Repair and/or Seal roof

Problem: Rats
Solution: Call Pest Control

Problem: Pipes leaking under Kitchen sink
Solution: Find where it is leaking repair plumbing

Problem: Broken sink in 2 Bathrooms
Solution: Replace sink

Problem: Flooring in Kitchen and Bathroom have broken tiles
Solution: Replace tiles and/or fill cracks

Problem: Holes in walls throughout the home
Solution: Patch, sand and paint

Problem: Guest room light switch faulty
Solution: Replace light switch

Problem: Front door warped
Solution: Replace with new mobile home door

Problem: Needs New Back Door
Solution: Replace with new mobile home door

Problem: Septic backs up on occasion and overflows out into the yar
Solution: Tank needs to be pumped out

Problem: Roof is leaking on back corner near the driveway. Since the roof is the original roof from the 1990's and the rest of the home is in such immaculate shape it would be worth putting a metal roof on her home.
Solution: Install a metal roof over the original roof using furring strips, tuff rib metal and install new boots/flashing

Problem: toilet in guest half bath runs constantly and takes forever to fill up
Solution: replace toilet and supply line in guest bath

Problem: Laser heater is not working
Solution: Hire a technician to troubleshoot and repair the laser heater before next winter

Problem: Really Old Furnace
Solution: Replace Furnace

Problem: Finish drywall repair job on the ceiling inside the home after roof issues are solved
Solution: Prime/paint, finish drywall on the ceiling of the home after roof issues are addressed

Problem: Repair/Replace portions of T1 - 11 siding that are rotten or unfastened. The gable side of the house near the driveway has a portion of siding that has come unfastened. Paint and seal exterior of home.
Solution: Remove any rotten sheets of T1-11 and repaint/restain the house to match

Problem: Roof is leaking due to flashing and fastener issues. Roof decking has rotten underneath the metal - extent of damage is unknown
Solution: Metal on the roof still has a lot of life left in it and just needs new fasteners. Remove metal roofing and replace any portions of rotten decking, reinstall metal roofing using new fasteners, properly flash the chimney and replace all plumbing boots

Problem: Septic system is failing due to clog - not able to locate the tail lines
Solution: Replace septic system for a 3 bedroom home

Problem: Basement stairs need safety railings and new stringers for the stair landing constructed out of pressure treated lumber.
Solution: Install safety railings for basement stairs and replace rotten stair stringers/treads that come off the landing at the bottom (will need pressure treated lumber for this).

Problem: Front Porch needs safety railings
Solution: Construct safety railings on front porch out of pressure treated lumber

Problem: Back deck stairs needs railings
Solution: construct railings to code using pressure treated lumber

Problem: Back door rusted at bottom, can't lock door
Solution: For now Paula is going to see about putting a board at the bottom of door and changing out doorknob, but she would benefit from a new backdoor

Problem: Mold growth inside the home needs to be remediated because Jenifer has breathing issues and is on oxygen.
Solution: Hire a mold remediation specialist to assess what needs to happen in the home and provide an estimate.

Problem: Roof is leaking in several areas on the asphalt shingle portion. There is not a lot of grit left on the shingles and they appear to have been from several different manufacturers (different colors). Roof is not flashed properly in several areas. Also roof decking is very soft in several areas most notably along the back side of the home facing Water Shed Road. Also, exposed rafter tails - no soffit.
Solution: Tear off asphalt shingles and remove any rotten roof decking. Replace roof decking with plywood, install new asphalt shingles and proper flashing. On the enclosed porch with the metal roof it will need a membrane roof because of the low pitch. The Upper metal roof above the asphalt shingles is not leaking and does not need to be addressed.

Problem: Kitchen sink is leaking and needs to be torn out and replumbed
Solution: Replumb drain lines under the kitchen sink

Problem: Cody paid to have the roof tarred and it looks pretty good. There are still some spots where water gets through. It's the original 1960s roof that came with the home. They would really benefit from an EPDM membrane roof due to the different pitches of the home. A roof with an overhang would be more ideal if possible.
Solution: Install a new roof on the home

Problem: No electricity in the back bedroom, hallway or bathroom. Cody said someone tested the circuits and said that there were 85 volts in the bedroom and down to 35 volts in the bathroom.
Solution: Hire an electrician or see if an electrician would volunteer to go help Cody. It seems like this is the only thing really holding him back from putting the room back together.

Problem: Soft flooring in center of kitchen, headed toward back door, which is also not closing properly.
Solution: David to take a look and provide solution for potential summer group project.

Problem: Electrical outlet behind love seat hanging out of the wall - has never stayed in the wall always falls out
Solution: Remove old outlet and troubleshoot why it will not stay in the wall

Problem: Sonnie's roof is approximately 30 years old and will need to be replaced in the near future
Solution: Roof is not currently leaking just making a note since it will need to be replaced relatively soon

Problem: Down spout on left side of house does not connect to pipe to carry water away from home
Solution: Reconnect downspout on the left side of the home

Problem: Back stairs are unsafe - no railings
Solution: Remove old stair case and install a low rise (5") set of stairs with a railing all constructed from pressure treated lumber

Problem: Laundry room linoleum flooring is a trip/fall hazard for the client. The washing machine tore up the floor over the years.
Solution: Remove linoleum flooring if possible - floor may be glued directly to subfloor. Install snap lock vinyl flooring system in the laundry room - approximately 120 sqft of flooring

Problem: Sonnie has difficulty going down the front stairs to reach her car
Solution: Install an ADA compliant ramp constructed from pressure treated lumber and install anti slip strips on the decking of the ramp. The ramp will need to be approximately 22' long and the client would prefer a switch back ramp instead of one long ramp out into the middle of the yard.

Problem: Carpet in secondary bedroom is a trip/fall hazard for client
Solution: Tear out carpet, padding and tack strips. If no hardwood flooring is underneath the carpet then install a snap lock vinyl floor system over the subfloor. Approximately 120 sqft of flooring
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Carpet in primary bedroom is a trip/fall hazard for client
Solution: Tear out carpet, padding and tack strips. If no hardwoods underneath the carpet then install a snap lock vinyl floor - approximately 144 square feet of flooring
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Sonnie needs a bathroom modification due to her mobility issues. She has fallen 4 times recently trying to get in and out of the bathtub. She also needs a higher toilet.
Solution: Tear out the tub/shower combo and replace it with a no curb shower. In addition to the new shower she would benefit from a collapsible seat in the shower. Remove the old toilet and install a higher ADA compliant toilet

Problem: Front ramp could use some attention to extend it's life expectancy since Mr. Wong will likely need it if he remains in the home
Solution: Pressure wash the ramp, replace any rotten boards, joists or posts and stain the deck to seal out water. Also add anti slip protection to the ramp boards

Problem: Back deck could use pressure washing and staining. Replace any rotten boards/joists on the deck
Solution: Pressure wash the back deck and replace any rotten boards or joists with pressure treated lumber. Stain the deck to extend the life expetancy

Problem: Front door and back door drags the floor due to settling/swelling. No weather stripping.
Solution: Install new door.

Problem: Bathroom door drags floor due to settling
Solution: Sand or shave the bottom of the bathroom door to prevent it from dragging the floor

Problem: Rats/mice getting into ductwork because it's close to the ground in the crawlspace. Sonny says that his home fills up with dust quickly after cleaning fairly often. He thinks that mice/rats have chewed holes in his ducts and introduced excess dirt/debris into the system.
Solution: Consult with an extermination company to help remediate the rodent issues

Problem: Kitchen floor is deteriorating badly and it's a trip/fall hazard for Sonny. The floor also feels very soft/spongy in a few areas.
Solution: Tear up kitchen floor down to joists, install vapor barrier if none and build the floor back with new snap lock linoleum flooring.

Problem:
Sonny said that Madison County installed his heat pump and it does a poor job keeping him warm. He said his electric bill is outrageous and the downstairs of his home will not go above 67 degrees in the winter. The mini-split upstairs works great but no one lives up there anymore.

The condensate line for the heat pump is too close to the foundation and needs to be extending further out into the yard
Solution: Hire an HVAC contractor to make sure that Sonny's unit was sized appropriately for his home and to troubleshoot the issues that he's having.

Problem: Sonny installed a french drain himself many years ago on one side of the house. He would benefit from having a french drain go across the entire back of his home since there is a negative grade towards his home.
Solution: install a new french drain system behind the house and run it the entire length of the home

Problem: Standing water in backyard behind house during heavy rain events or wetter parts of the year.
Solution: Sonny believes that the pipe from the spring reservoir on the hill behind the house was never terminated correctly. He thinks that the line is still connected at the box and needs to be cut off. Locate the lines at the spring box and terminate them. Cap the pipe at the box at if possible cap the line at the house it may be difficult to locate.

Problem: No interior finishes, running water, electricity or thermostatically controlled heat in the home
Solution: This repair seems to be far beyond the scope of what we could do

Problem: No insulation in the roof of the home.
Solution: Because the roof is not vented there will need to be 2" - 4" of foam added underneath the roof decking to prevent condensation building up on the underside of the roof

Problem: In the event of a wind driven rain the shingles on the edge of the roof are blowing up and allowing water to get underneath the shingles. The shingles are 27 years old and need to be replaced.
Solution: Fredrick wants brown metal to match the color of gutters, 30 pound roofing felt laid on top of the existing shingles. Place 1 x 4 furring strips down on top of the shingles, put metal panels on top of the furring strips, add 6" matching rake trim to the front and sides of the roof. Mr. Maehr would like the plumbing vent cut off and roofed over with metal on the upper shed roof. There is a vent on the lower roof that he would like covered in metal that matches the roof. Each roof is approximately 28' wide x 14' long. It's possible that all of the roof decking on both roofs may need to be removed and replaced due to deterioration over time.

Problem: Home would greatly benefit from a new roof as well as the additions. Front porch needs a new roof as well.
Solution: Tear off 5v and replace with tuff rib metal roofing. Put tuff rib metal on the additions as well.***update 4-30-21: spoke w Etta and roof is actively leaking in at least 2 rooms.

Problem: Etta recently had a chimney fire and stopped using her woodstove completely. The chimney needs to be cleaned
Solution: Hire a chimney sweep to clean her chimney and inspect the flue

Problem: Driveway is in really rough shape and could used shaping/new gravel
Solution: Hire a grading company to shape and regravel the driveway. Driveway from the fork is approximately 620 feet long and will require at least 6 loads of gravel - Road Bond ABCM or ballast

Problem: Hole in kitchen floor
Solution: Patch hole in kitchen floor and keep it from getting bigger

Problem: Deck and back stairs will need to be replaced soon
Solution: Replace deck and back stairs

Problem: No thermostatically controlled heat in the house other than propane space heaters
Solution: Look into installing a thermostatically controlled heat source for the home. The air handler or compressor units would need to be higher than the base flood level.

Problem: Basement floods frequently during heavy rainfall events and the sump pump cannot keep up. Sherry thinks that it's undersized for the amount of water that infiltrates the basement.
Solution: The house in the flood plain and the water table may be very close to the surface of the ground. Investigate and perform more due diligence around their sump pump before replacing the old one.

Problem: 15 amp breaker supplying the kitchen is carrying too much of a load according to Sherry and the breaker trips frequently
Solution: Hire a licensed electrician to diagnose and repair

Problem: Matthew Ponder of Mountain Well and Septic pumped out Sherry's tank and said that the tank was extremely old and failing. Sherry told me that it's an old concrete block tank.
Solution: Remove the old concrete block septic tank and install a new tank

Problem: Hallway bathroom accessibility
Solution: Refer to IL to see if they can help up fit the bathroom and widen the door frame to make it more accessible.

Problem: Primary bathroom sink drain has broken off
Solution: This is one of the many things that Lawrence said he is going to repair on his own when he gets his stimulus check.

Problem: Front stairs are unsafe and need to be replaced
Solution: Replace front stairs with a 5' x 5' landing pad, stairs/handrails and concrete pad. This should only be done after the bigger issues regarding the roof, trash pile, heat and roaches are addressed.

Problem: Massive trash piles around the property. Lawrence said that he's been wanting to get a truck so he can start hauling trash away to the landfill.
Solution: 8 - 10+ Roll off dumpsters and an excavator with a thumb will be required for this clean up. It's a multi day project if volunteers are used to clean up the property.

Problem: No thermostatically controlled heat - their furnace is non functioning. They seem happy with the warmth of the kerosene heater and did not mention wanting to add another heat source or repair the one they have. I am concerned about the safety of the heater they are using. I left them one CO detector, one CO/Smoke detector combo and a fire extinguisher. Lawrence said he would install the CO and smoke detectors right away.
Solution: Work on finding a better thermostatically controlled heat source for them

Problem: Original metal roof from 1998 is leaking
Solution:
Short term solution - Kool seal the entire roof $400 - $500

Long term solution - Install a new metal roof with 8 - 10" of overhang along the edges - $4800

Problem: Out of control German Cockroach infestation
Solution: This will require an exterminator and the infestation is very extensive spanning the entire home. Roaches were all over the ceilings, walls, floors, countertops etc.. during the day time. Cost is really unknown for this type of repair since it will require many follow-up visits.

Problem: Plumbing issues in the home
Solution:
Install a new jet pump at the pressure tank  
Install a new 36 gallon pressure tank  
Install a new pressure switch  
Install a new 40 gallon electric hot water heater with a minimum 10 year warranty installed to the current NC Plumbing code.  
Electric hot water heater shall have a minimum energy factor of 0.92  
Repair/replace exterior hose bib on the southern gable end of the home  
Repair leaks at fixtures and PVC drain lines at kitchen sink and bathroom sink

Problem: Drywall cracks are an eyesore and worrisome for Tammy
Solution: **Make sure a contractor makes a determination as to why this happened - unusual settling/continued settling etc. Repair drywall cracks in the kitchen along the ceiling in between the kitchen and living room. Paint to match the existing color scheme.**

Problem: Bathroom knob is about to fall off
Solution: **Reattach bathroom door knob**

Problem: Tub surround needs to be replaced with an ADA compliant tub/shower combo
Solution: Install a new tub and shower surround with ADA compliant grab bars

Problem: Wood flooring in the bathroom is deteriorating rapidly due to exposure to water
Solution: **Install waterproof sheet linoleum flooring overtop of the hardwood flooring (approximately 40 sqft of flooring). Trim the edges of the floor with quarter round. Seal gap between the tub and flooring with a high quality silicone caulk.**

Problem: Tammy needs a higher toilet she is started to have issues with the lower toilet
Solution: **Remove current toilet and install an ADA compliant elongated white ceramic toilet with a maximum 1.3 GPF rating**

Problem: Bathroom fan needs to be upgraded to an 80 cfm fan w/light kit
Solution:
* Upgrade vent fan to an 80 cfm fan with a light kit and properly vent the fan to the exterior through the roof. Roof penetrations shall be properly flashed with boots and sealants to prevent leaks
  * Vent pipe in the attic shall be rigid pipe and shall vent to the outside. 
  * Vent termination shall be rodent proof

Problem: **Replace all missing lighting globes throughout the home - approximately 8 missing globes on the interior of the home**
**Replace existing smoke detectors with Smoke and Carbon Monoxide combination units**
Solution: **Replace existing smoke detectors with Smoke and Carbon Monoxide combination units**

Problem: Missing sections of vapor barrier in crawlspace
Solution: **Replace missing portions of the vapor barrier with 6 mil plastic sheeting**

Problem: **Install R-19 faced batt fiberglass insulation along the entire bottom of the home in between the floor joists.**
Solution: **Install R-19 faced batt fiberglass insulation along the entire bottom of the home in between the floor joists.**

Problem: **Regrade driveway and re-gravel the entire driveway. Cut back all vegetation from the driveway. Install an address marker at the bottom of the driveway.**
Solution: **Regrade driveway and re-gravel the entire driveway. Cut back all vegetation from the driveway. Install an address marker at the bottom of the driveway.**

Problem: **Replace rotten treads using pressure treated lumber. Stain stair treads using a high quality exterior wood sealant for decks, i,e Behr Advanced DeckOver or CHC approved equivalent.**
Solution: **Replace rotten treads using pressure treated lumber. Stain stair treads using a high quality exterior wood sealant for decks, i,e Behr Advanced DeckOver or CHC approved equivalent.**

Problem: **Replace Globe for front porch light**
Solution: **Replace Globe for front porch light**

Problem: **Replace rotten siding behind the oil storage tank - approximately 10 sqft. Replace with new siding and paint to match.**
Solution: **Replace rotten siding behind the oil storage tank - approximately 10 sqft. Replace with new siding and paint to match.**

Problem: Extremely wet at the back of house due to lack of sunlight and proper drainage
Solution: Install French drain system along the entire rear of the home - approximately 50 feet. French drain trench shall be filled with stone. Disturbed soil shall be seeded and covered with hay and or straw.

Problem: Install a new exterior light fixture at the back door to replace existing broken fixture
Solution: Install a new exterior light fixture at the back door to replace existing broken fixture

Problem: Back door needs to be replaced
Solution: **Replace the back door with a half light door with a new lockset that is keyed to match the front door.**

Problem: Tammy's mobility is decreasing and would benefit from a ramp
Solution:
Construct an ADA compliant handicap ramp made from pressure treated lumber with a maximum 1 in 12 pitch. Ramp shall land on a 5’x5’ concrete slab. Ramp will land near the parking area at the top of the driveway **  
**
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Concrete stairs leading down to basement entrance do not have a handrail
Solution: Install a handrail for the concrete stairs leading down to the basement door.

Problem: Back stairs are extremely unsafe leading down to the sidewalk
Solution: Remove existing stairs and construct a new set of stairs out of pressure treated lumber

Problem: Furnace in the basement is not functioning and does not heat the house. Tamika is not able to use the oil she purchased to heat the house.
Solution: Hire a technician to diagnose and repair the furnace. Cost is unknown for this since the furnace is so old it could need to be completely rebuilt or replaced.

Problem: Wood insects destroying exposed lumber in addition.
Solution: Enclosed exposed rafter tails.

Problem: There was not an address was visible from the road.
Solution: Install new address marker to allow emergency vehicles up driveway if needed.

Problem: House didn't meet current R value for insulation.
Solution: Add insulation to meet code to R 38.

Problem: Water heater full of sediment.
Solution: Install new energy efficient water heater.

Problem: Hole in crawlspace where vent fell out.
Solution: Stucco over it.

Problem: There is a hole in the crawlspace where a vent fell out and small animals are able to get in.
Solution: Stucco over it.

Problem: Water heater full of sediment.
House is not well insulated and does not meet R value.
Solution: Spray insulation to get it up to code R 38.

Problem: Hole in crawlspace where vent fell out.
Solution: Stucco over it to keep rodents out.

Problem: There is a hold in the crawlspace where vent fell out.
Solution: Stucco over hole to keep rodents out.

Problem: Soft floor in primary bathroom near the toilet. Kathy's brother replaced the floor in the bathroom after a previous leak and this new leak made the floor spongy again.
Solution: Tear out floor in bathroom while working on the shower and install a plywood floor instead of particle board.

Problem: Toilet in guest bathroom is too low for Kathy to use and requires a chair. Kathy would like an ADA approved elongated toilet to be installed
Solution: Install an ADA compliant elongated toilet
