Problem: Electrical - Ember says that the wiring in her home is "funky" and acts up on occasion. Ember was struck by lighting through her stove and the plug needs to be replaced or stove needs to be properly grounded. The chain on the light in the pantry gets stuck and needs to be worked on. Switches in the living room are "weird" and don't work properly or have a short. The house does appear to have newer romex wiring and most of it is exposed so troubleshooting should be relatively straightforward for an electrician.
No insulation in floor
Solution: Install R-19+ fiberglass faced batts

Problem: Wood stove - ran out of money and ran out of fire wood
Solution: Have a volunteer delivery a load of firewood. They do have backup propane heat that they're currently using and it's keeping the house warm

Problem: Roof - leaking badly along the union of the two structures and causing mold growth in the home. Nice looking metal roof and not readily apparent where exactly all of the leaks are coming from
Solution: This is a pretty complicated roof system and would be best suited for a roofer with substantial amounts of experience and skill. The roof might need to be completely torn off and redone properly to ensure water does not enter the home through the union of the two structures.

Problem: Tub is loose and really needs to be replaced
Solution: Replace tub with new tub and surround

Problem: Front Door - has a new front door and needs help installing it. It's a fireproof door and does not have the skills or tools needed to make it happen on his own.
Solution: See if a volunteer would be willing to help install the new door

Problem: Oil Furnace - non functioning and Bertha is left without a secondary source of heat. Furnace has a bad smell and sputters she thinks that the rain rusted it out.
Solution: Replace or repair furnace

Problem: Ceiling fan - needs light fixture
Solution: Add light fixture to ceiling fan

Problem: Storm door - needs hinges
Solution: Repair storm door hinges

Problem: Porch and steps - steps/porch are rotting and need to be replaced
Solution: Bertha might benefit from a ramp instead of replacing the stairs and porch. Back stairs also need to be shored up and repaired

Problem: Bathroom plugs - need to be replaced non-functioning
Solution: Replace receptacles with GFI's

Problem: Shower and Tub - leaky and need fixed/replaced. Hard for client to get into bathtub.
Solution: Repair shower and tub or if funds allow, replace with walk in shower.

Problem: Soft floors - hallway and living room
Solution: tear up flooring and replace any rotten subfloor. Replace with carpet or linoleum

Problem: Soft floor under toilet
Solution: Remove toilet and linoleum flooring. Replace rotten subfloor with new plywood and linoleum

Problem: Back door - rusted and leaks
Solution: Needs to be replaced with a higher quality weather-tight door

Problem: Roof - leaking badly and causing major mold/structural issues. There is a skylight in the bathroom that pours water.
Solution: Replace roof

Problem: Low water pressure - Wanda said that a previous volunteer group replaced her 1" water line with either 1/2 inch or 3/4 inch line and she lost her water pressure after this. She said that the waterline replacement was done without her consent and she would really like her water pressure back. She does not want a booster pump installed.
Solution: Consult with a plumber to determine the best course of action to restore her water pressure

Problem: Front steps - rotten and need replacing
Solution:
Replace front steps with a wide tread staircase - consult Wanda first.

Stairs are 22" high

Problem: Gutters - Wanda would really benefit from some new 6" seamless gutters on the front and back of her house along with some snowbrakes. Her gutters are pretty beat up and have low spots in them that allow water to pool and then pour over during heavy rain events. The metal roofing overhangs are very irregular on the front and back. The front of the house does not have an adequate overhang and the back of the house has too much of an overhang that allows the water to jump the gutter. Along the back right corner of the house the excess water is causing the house to sink/settle irregularly.
Solution: Install ~80' of new 6" seamless gutters with new downspouts and snowbrakes for the roof. Install downspouts.

Problem: Moisture issues and Wet Insulation in Basement
Solution: Fiberglass insulation got wet from previous failing copper plumbing - replace with formaldehyde free batts

Problem: Deck - many loose/rotten boards. Deck needs to be overhauled and time should not be spent on it until the septic issue is resolved. Also, fence needs repairing.
Solution: Repair/replace deck. Ramp leading down from the road is very slick and needs an anti-slip surface installed

Problem: Siding - needs repainting
Solution: Hire a painter or locate volunteers willing to tackle this for Steve and Amanda

Problem: Electrical - Lights dim in other parts of the house when others are on (losing a neutral?). The house sat vacant for quite awhile and when they first moved in they had a rodent problem and they're concerned some of the wiring was chewed. There are outlets by the sink and they do not appear to be GFI's.
Solution: Hire an electrician or find a volunteer who is an electrician to further assess their concerns/issues.

Problem: Wood Stove - Firebricks are falling out and need replacing inside the stove and the screen inside the door has ripped off. Concerned about their stovepipe since their chimney sweep said it appears to have scorched in the past. They are also having a difficult time keeping up with wood for their stove since it's currently their only source of heat - extremely cold this week!
Solution: Hire a chimney sweep to further diagnose and repair their wood stove and stove pipe.

Problem: Propane Furnace - currently not functioning
Solution: Steve believes the the igniter blower is the culprit and has asked for professional assistance to further diagnose and repair

Problem:
Plumbing - Concerned about Fecal Coliform Bacteria - They are on a shared gravity fed spring and unsure of the exact location of the reservoir. They are concerned about fecal coliform bacteria and do not drink any of their water. Their water corroded their copper plumbing and Steve replaced (on his own) all of the copper in the home with PEX.

They would also like an outdoor shutoff for the PVC supplyline.
Solution:
They would like some sort of water treatment system - UV, filtration, etc to alleviate their water security fears.

Install a ball valve outside - first need to determine how to turn the water off at the spring or some other location. The other houses all share this spring and communication with all the neighbors will need to happen prior to shutting off the any water lines

Problem: *Septic tanks are shared with neighbor up the hill* Septic pipe is not completely connected and sewage appears to be leaking back into a corner of the basement and it sometimes backs up into the house through the plumbing. The neighbor does not seem to be having any backup issues and they are further up the hill.
Solution: The septic pipe is in a difficult area to reach underneath of the deck on the side of the house. Steve has attempted to make this repair himself and was not able to reconnect the two pieces of PVC. The ground is extremely rocky and a mini-excavator may be required to make the repair. A portion of the deck may need to be removed before the repair can be made.

Problem:
_**Over sized inefficient heat pump**_

The heat pump she is using is massive and costs her a fortune to use in the cold winter months. She has seen electrical bills in the $400+ range per month.
Solution: replace her heat pump with a smaller more efficient unit

Problem:
_**Crawlspace**_

Insulation hanging down in the crawlspace. There does appear to be a vapor barrier under the home and it's skirted by roofing metal. The crawlspace does smell earthy/musty.
Solution: Replace insulation under the mobile home

Problem:
_**Front Deck**_

Front deck is extremely slippery when it rains and rotten in several places. The decks shakes and does not feel sturdy. Angela does have another entrance in the back of the house she can use while the front deck is being replaced. The current deck is 10' x 30' and she wants a new one just like it with a porch roof. I told her that if we replaced it it would be with a smaller deck probably 8 x 10 or 8 x 12 to give her a safe entrance. She seemed pretty disappointed by that and may want to wait until she gets the settlement from her auto accident.
Solution: Demolish large 10 x 30 deck and replace front deck

Problem:
_**Interior Ceilings Need Painting**_

 __Angela has purchased 5 gallons of high quality stain hiding paint for the ceilings in her living rooms and is unable to complete the work due to her car crash injuries
Solution: Hire a painter or get a volunteer group together to paint her interior ceilings.

Problem:
_**Tremendous Amounts of Trash Left By Ex-Husband**_

Angela's Ex-husband left behind a truly excessive amount of trash that needs to be hauled off. There may be two or three dumptruck loads of trash to haul off.
Solution: A volunteer group with pickup trucks/trailers can take care of hauling away the trash. Great NHN project

Problem:
_**Kitchen Sink Window**_

Most of the windows in the home have been replaced by newer higher efficiency windows with the exception of the window over the kitchen sink. The sill is getting rotten and the window leaks.
Solution: Replace the window above the kitchen sink with a window to match the others in the home

Problem:
_**Gutter Issue**_

Back gutter gets clogged up by leaves/debris at the corner and dams up water. The water gets released and goes over top of the gutter and through a hole under the roof and allows water to enter the wall of the addition and the ceiling above the kitchen window where Angela keeps a towel. This issue is ongoing during heavy rain storms or when Angela is not able to keep the gutters cleaned out. There also the possibility that there is a leak where the two roofs meet and water may also be getting in behind the gutter as well.
Solution: Gutter needs to be repitched at the corner union to the back of the house and a downspout added to take away some of the water in the gutter before it reaches the corner. The gutters really need proper overhangs to be mounted on instead of right up against the side of the mobile home. The hole under the roof needs to be flashed and closed up to keep out water, animals and insects.

Problem:
_**Soft Floors**_

The floors are soft in the home due to past or ongoing plumbing issues/leaks

1) Living room floor and kitchen - dishwasher leaked and got the particle board wet in these areas. Also, ongoing gutter/roof leak by the dining room table has ruined the floor

2) Hallway bath - toilet used to leak and leak was repaired by daughter's boyfriend. Floor is very soft

3) 14x14 Addition - floor is very soft in the corner by the door due to a gutter issue and it's the same culprit as the kitchen window.
Solution: Flooring needs to be torn up in all of the areas mentioned above and replaced with new subfloor and floor finish - very large job to do properly

Problem:
_**Roof**_

Original trailer roof was recently coated with a rubber membrane paint and looks pretty good. Trailer roof does not seem to be leaking and the home is dry inside with the exception of a window/gutter issue that will be referenced as a separate repair. There is 14 x 14 addition on the back of the trailer and the roof union between the trailer and addition does not appear to have been done properly. It's flashed with a ton of silicon caulk to keep water out. However, the addition roof does not seem to be leaking. The main issue with the trailer roof is there is no overhang for the gutters on the back of the home and water gets in behind the gutters and has rotted a facia board. Also gutters are missing from several areas around the home such as the front.
Solution: Continue monitor the roof to make sure it's not leaking. At some point the roof will need to be fixed properly with 20 year galvalume metal and overhangs for gutters if the client still wants them.

Problem:
Siding

Siding screws are rusted and loose in areas. Micheal would like all of the siding screws replaced with roofing screws with washers
Solution: remove old screws and install roofing screws with washers

Problem:
Crawlspace

Home would greatly benefit from the installation of a 6 mil+ vapor barrier under the home to assist with moisture control. Several areas of torn insulation should be repaired. Skirting around the home appears OK.
Solution:
Install a 6 mil+ vapor barrier under the home and tape the seams.

Repair insulation and belly liner under the home

Problem:
Kitchen Sink Valves and cabinet

Leaking and need to be replaced. No cabinet doors under the sink - someone purchased some nicer cabinets in the kitchen beside the sink - look great!
Solution: Replace valves and install cabinet doors or replace kitchen cabinet

Problem:
Master Bathroom

Shower drips constantly and needs repairing. Shower needs to be recaulked. No complaints about other plumbing issues in this bathroom. Floor was recently replaced and looks good/solid.
Solution: Repair issues in the master bath - pretty low skill

Problem:
Hotwater Heater Closet

Flooring in the hot water heater area needs to be replaced. Newer hotwater heater works fine and the previous unit leaked on the floor. The floor was not repaired prior to installing the new unit.

Small bathroom

Needs to be replaced. Tub leaks and no cold water is being supplied to the shower. The vanity plumbing works ok and flooring was recently replaced. Floor feels solid in the bathroom.

Mold

Presence of mold is prevalent throughout the home, in closets, ceilings, etc.
Solution: Mold remediation in the home after replacing the roof and installing a vapor barrier in the crawlspace would be highly beneficial

Problem:
Windows

Windows are leaking and condensation from the inside has rotten out the sills and studs in some of the rooms
Solution: Replace single pane windows with more energy efficient windows and replace rotten wooden studs/sills

Problem:
No Heat

Michael is still without heat and cold weather is back in the forecast. He needs a new nozzle on his furnace and needs a new oil tank.
Solution: Replace Michael's oil tank, filters and nozzles

Problem:
Entrances/Exits

Stairs on both front and rear of the home need to be replaced. Stairs on the front of the home are very unsafe and deck boards are rotting
Solution: Replace both front and rear porches. Michael would like the porch on the front of the home to have a ramp instead of stairs.

Problem:
Roof

Leaking along the edges of the home where the small gutters connect. Mold growth is widespread in the home due to excess moisture
Solution: Roof needs to be replaced as soon as possible.

Problem: Outdoor Wood Furnace - James suspects that the thermostat has gone bad and no longer functioning.
Solution: See if we can figure out the make/model of his wood stove to further diagnose the problem. The thermostat is at least $380.00 and it's possible there may be something else wrong with it. James did say that this has happened in the past and he replaced the thermostat then the furnace started working again.

Problem:
_**Leaky faucet**_

The back bathroom faucet near Paul's room is leaking constantly and there is not way to shut it off. It's ruining the bathroom floor that Paul and his brother-in-law recently replaced. Paul is not comfortable making the repair because he's afraid he will lose water in his whole house since he cannot isolate the faucet. The supply lines appear to be made out of polybutylene
Solution: Hire a plumber to further assess and repair the problem

Problem:
_**Light Switch in back bedroom**_

 **S** witch in back bedroom is inoperable and Paul is not able to find a suitable replacement - he said the switch snaps in?
Solution: Hire an electrician to repair/replace or a volunteer that knows electrical work

Problem:
_**Kitchen Floor**_

Air conditioner leaked and ruined part of the wall and subfloor. Paul and his brother-in-law repaired the subfloor and wall. The brother-in-law hurt his back helping Paul and is now out of commission/unable to further assist. The kitchen floor could use some type of finish, i.e. linoleum
Solution: install linoleum or laminate flooring in the kitchen over the sublfoor repair

Problem:
_**Front and Rear Porch**_

The front porch stairs/railings are unsafe and need to be rebuilt. The porch roof is leaking badly and needs to be repaired/replaced

Rear porch has no railings, stairs have fallen off and porch roof is leaking badly.

Does not appear that any joist hangers were used in the construction of both porches. They feel solid right now, but don't seem to be well supported by posts.

**Paul is unable to get homeowner's insurance due to the condition of the porches**
Solution: Repair/replace both porches

Problem:
_**Entrances/Exits**_

Front steps are rotting and the railings are unsafe

Back stairs are becoming unsafe and the railings are loose

Handicap ramp railing is wobbly and loose - may not support much weight and could fail
Solution:
Replace front stairs and railings

Replace back stairs and railings

Replace railing on the handicap ramp (ramp seems solid - it's also 12.5' long and 24" off the ground so much steeper than we build them)

Problem:
_**Plumbing**_

Garbage disposal in the kitchen will not work and is very slow to drain water. It's either extensively clogged up or the motor is burned out

Helen complains that the hot water in the kitchen takes a long time to heat up.
Solution: Hire a plumber to further diagnose and repair/replace the garbage disposal and address the hot water concerns in the kitchen. I told Helen that the kitchen sink may be the last fixture on the line and furthest away from the hot water heater so the water has time to cool off in the line.

Problem:
_**Cosmetic/Low Skill Repairs - Volunteer Projects**_

Helen lives alone and does not have any help. She could use help with the following projects:

\- Changing filter on her well

\- Pressure washing the house/decks/etc

\- Restaining the decks

\- Repairing an interior door so it shuts properly (have to lift up on the door to shut it - Helen is no longer strong enough to do this)

\- Check and clean gutters periodically

\- Build a new ramp into her shed and put in new support under the shed. Torrential rain nearly knocked the shed off it's support blocks

\- Clean the lent out of her dryer and vent (tons of lent being blown out onto the ground under the deck)

\- Paint a bedroom

_**Windows**_

Single pane windows are very inefficient and sashes appear to have lead based paint
Solution: Replace windows with vinyl double pane windows. Need to have a lead certified contractor handle this repair

Problem:
_**Masonite Siding**_

Masonite siding on the side of the house facing the hill is swollen from moisture.
Solution: Replace masonite siding with a better quality product.

Problem:
_Crawlspace_

 __There does not appear to be any vents for the crawlspace to breathe. The block foundation is not letting any airflow under the house and the moisture from the ground is most likely rotting the floor out. I was not able to get entry into the crawlspace the door was sealed pretty well and very small.
Solution: Install crawlspace vents to help with airflow. It's possible that many of the floor joists may be rotten if the house hasn't been able to breathe since it was constructed.

Problem:
_**Trash**_

Marlene has no way to haul off their trash or make donations of clothes etc.
Solution: See if a volunteer would help her and Shasta haul off trash and any donation material

Problem:
_**Living Room**_

The living room was expanded and they closed in the front porch. The block used to construct the front porch appears to have settled considerably and it's evident in the living room with the sloping floor. Lead paint flaking above TV in living room. Doorway in living room is blocked and they currently only have one exit through the kitchen.
Solution: Monitor the house for further settling, clear doorway and covered porch to provide a secondary exit in case of emergency

Problem:
_**_Lead Paint Evidence_**_ __

Lead based paint is suspected through-out the home and any repairs should be handled by a certified professional
Solution: determine the location of lead based paint through-out the home. Asbestos could also be prevalent in some the materials that were used to finish the home - flooring, etc.

Problem:
_**Electrical**_

Electrical system is very old and electrical service is undersized for the load on the house. Marlene mentioned that the washing machine wire burned up when in use one time. The well company will have to upgrade her electrical service to handle the load on the pump. Several of the electrical outlets do not function in the living room.
Solution: Hire a licensed electrician to further assess

Problem:
_**Kitchen**_

I have the opinion that the crawlspace is rotting the floor joists under the home. I did not see where there was any ventilation and the crawlspace door was sealed shut with insulation and screen. The floor is very soft in the kitchen and adjoins the bathroom where the floor joist failed. The sheet rock tape is starting to come apart on the ceiling.
Solution: Tear up the floor in the kitchen and install new floor joists, new 3/4" subfloor and new flooring. Repair/replace the drywall

Problem:
_**No Access to Running Water or Functioning Bathroom**_

 __Marlene has been without running water since last August when her mother passed away. Her sister-in-law cut the water line from the well on her property that was servicing Marlene's home. The bathroom is completely unusable and unsafe - floor has caved in around the toilet and caused the cast iron tub to sink as well.

 __
Solution: Marlene's siblings need to agree on where her 1 deeded acre around the home is located so a well can be drilled. USDA will not drill a well on the property because it's not technically in her name. When the siblings agree on where the 1 acre is located and the survey is recorded/deed updated then USDA can help. Right now there's no need to repair the bathroom until the water/property issue is resolved with the family.

Problem:
_**Windows**_

Windows are very inefficient and have plastic installed over them as well as the back door.
Solution: Install more efficient windows to lower heating costs

Problem:
_**Crawlspace**_

Insulation is all hanging down underneath of the home making it more difficult to heat and there is no vapor barrier.
Solution: Tear out old insulation and re-install fiberglass batts. Install 6 mil+ vapor barrier underneath of the home.

Problem:
_**Flooring**_

There are several soft spots in the floor throughout the home most notably in the spare bedroom. The floor is so soft in at least one area that someone could fall through. Danny said that the hot water heater was moved out of it's original location and has been leaking for years. The floor rot is spreading due to this ongoing leak.
Solution: Address the hot water heater leak and install new subfloor in rotten areas of the home.

Problem:
_**HVAC**_

The electric furnace is not working and the home is heated entirely on a monitor heater. The monitor runs constantly because the home is so inefficiently built
Solution: Install a secondary heating source in the home or repair/replace the furnace.

Problem:
_**Ingress/Egress - Stairs**_

1) The front stairs are poorly constructed and with Danny's limited mobility he is having a difficult time getting into or exiting the home.

2) The back stairs are very steep and also poorly constructed.
Solution:
1) Tear off the porch and construct a ramp leading into the home

2) Tear off the rear stairs and build a new set with treads wide enough for a walker

Problem:
_**Roof**_

 __Roof is leaking in several spots and is most likely original to the trailer
Solution: Replace the roof with a metal roof

Problem:
_**Kitchen**_

1) Floor is very soft in several places

2) Stove is straight wired into the mobile home's electrical service without a plug. This is a real hazard. You cannot unplug the stove if there is a problem with it and you have to throw the breaker in the box before taking off the wire nuts.

3) The kitchen sink kept getting stopped up and was taken off the home's plumbing system. The kitchen sink is now straight piped over the hill behind the home.
Solution:
1) Repair/replace the kitchen floor to ensure no one falls through

2) Hire an electrician to properly wire the stove

3) Repair/replace the clogged plumbing lines and return the gray sink water back into the septic system.

Problem:
Driveway is in terrible condition and if there was a fire or medical emergency I do not think they would be able to reach the home. The photos do not do the driveway justice.

The slope behind the home is starting to slide and becoming more unstable. The earth has almost covered the electrical meter. This will be an ongoing problem.
Solution: Regrade the driveway, install ditches/culverts, guardrail cross ditches and 2 - 3 loads of road bond. Reshape the slope behind the home and remove the earth with a dump truck.

Problem: Wood Stove Pipe - single wall pipe is deteriorating badly at the ceiling due to a roof leak.
Solution:
Tear down single wall stove pipe from ceiling to Fisher wood stove. Clean remaining flue with 6" wire brush from inside, install proper flashing for stove pipe on the roof (silicon dektite boot?), access attic to assess any additional damage to ceiling adapter box, install new six inch single wall stove pipe/key dampener etc.. Also, wood stove is missing most of the fire bricks inside.

**Attic cannot currently be accessed due to the excessive amount of trash/debris in the room with the pull down stairs. I asked the client if she could find someone to help with that. She thinks this will be a very quick fix and if everything goes well it should be. However, the potential is there for this to turn into a large project so she can use her wood stove.

Problem: no water
Solution: have well company investigate and repair

Problem: Punch list type repairs - seals on the sashes of the double pane thermal windows is blown, ceiling fan needs hung, build a crawlspace door under the porch to prevent animals from gaining entry, insulate the tool/garden shed on the front of the house (becomes unbearably hot in the summer months - look at installing ventilation or new windows to assist). Her refrigerator is 31 years old and runs constantly - she would like a new one
Caport - The carport construction concerns me. The beams supporting the trusses are cantilevered out more than 4 feet and are supporting quite a load.
Solution: Keep an eye on it - may need to add in more posts to support the cantilevered portion of the roof system.

Problem: Bathroom - Shower door handle messed up and needs repairing. Toilet seat loose and needs fixed. Patsy has grab bars throughout her home to help her - someone did a nice job installing them.
Solution: Low priority repairs

Problem: Porch door - Door is out of square and does not close properly allowing air to flow through
Solution: Reframe door and bring it back into square.

Problem: Deck - Poorly constructed and missing joist hangers
Solution: Install joist hangers on all joists. Shore up/brace posts with better materials and cross braces. Railing is wobbling in some areas and needs to be repaired/replaced with higher quality work/materials.

Problem: Roof - Metal roof was installed approximately two years ago. The roof over the house has two layers of shingles and a layer of metal roofing on top. Pretty heavy load sitting on the roof, but the roof is not leaking currently. A portion of the carport roof has a very low pitch and I suspect that water is blowing back underneath of the sheathing since the water is not shed quickly enough. She pointed out water stains on areas of the underside of the roof. Low priority repair.
Solution: Install some more flashing and reassess after heavy rain storm

Problem: Laminate Flooring - Laminate flooring in living room where Patsy sleeps is starting to deteriorate. She mentioned that she spent several months in the Brian Center and there were some people living in the basement that were supposed to be taking care of her dogs. The people did not take care of the dogs and used the bathroom all over the floor. She suspects this is one of the main reasons that the flooring started deteriorating and that the flooring is of low quality/cheap.
Solution: All of Patsy's furniture and tons of other possessions would need to be moved out of the living room to replace the floor. Since Patsy is also living/sleeping in the living room this will be extremely challenging to address. Patsy may need to relocate to one of the other bedrooms upstairs while the flooring is addressed. Pretty large job given the amount of "stuff" in the living room.

Problem: Patsy would like to have someone come and haul away stuff. She said that she is getting rid of most everything that she can no longer use, but cannot find someone to come and haul it off.
Solution: Great volunteer project for someone that owns a truck to help her out. Her home and yard is very cluttered with her many possessions.

Problem: _**Windows**_ \- single pane mobile home trailer windows are creating an energy consumption issue and condensation issues inside the home. Peggy would like all of the windows replaced in her home (approx 15). There does not appear to be a threat to health or safety in this home.
Solution: Replace windows in the home. A volunteer group would be better suited to serve this client since there does not appear to be an imminent threat to health or safety.

Problem:
_**Mold / Moisture Issues**_

Substantial mold growth in Garry's closet. It's unclear where the moisture is coming from that's fueling the growth. It appears that it's wicking in from underneath of the siding. Back bedroom floor also feels spongy. The source of the moisture needs to be identified and addressed appropriately.

The middle bedroom has a moldy/musty smell as well.

The ceiling of where the hot water heater is located has some surface mold.
Solution: Determine where the moisture is coming from and address it appropriately. There is a repair in the siding above the closet that may be one of the culprits. The moisture looks as though it's being wicked up by the wood in the house. It's possible may need to tear out the closet or any other rotten areas and repair/replace as necessary.

Problem:
_**Crawlspace**_

Insulation is falling out from under the home and there is no vapor barrier.
Solution: Replace insulation under the home, install vapor barrier and address any plumbing issues while working under the home

Problem:
_**Exits / Entrances**_

The home has three good entrances/exits. The front porch/deck is not very well constructed and some of the joists appear to be broken. It is functional now just need to keep an eye on it for further deterioration. Stairs have a very basic railing, but would not pass code.

Front stairs to the left of the main entrance are not safe (no railings - falling apart).
Solution: Keep an eye on the front porch entrance and it may be necessary to stabilize it/repair it in the near future so it remains a viable entrance. The stairs to the left of the front porch should be replaced with a better/safer set.

Problem:
_**Bathroom / Kitchen / Plumbing**_

Bathroom - Garry repaired the floor with a thin sheet of plywood (temp fix). Bathroom is 102" x 80" and could use a remodel. Tub surround is allowing water into the framing/structure of the house and creating issues. Floor does feel pretty solid in the bathroom even around the toilet - unsure of how much plywood Garry put down in the bathroom.

Kitchen - When walking in the kitchen the rest of the house shakes, kitchen cabinets are coming apart and no hot water is reaching the kitchen for some reason. Floor does feel solid in the kitchen and not spongy. No leaks observed in the kitchen.
Solution:
Bathroom - given the number of people living in the home a full bathroom remodel in the near future may be warranted (after roof is repaired / foundation is shored up / electrical issues are addresses). The laundry is also located in the bathroom along with the hot water heat. Bathroom is OK and functioning for now.

Kitchen - more underpinning/blocking may be needed under the home to provide better structural support. Recommend having a licensed plumber assess why there is no hot water reaching the kitchen taps. Cabinets are falling apart given their age. Kitchen is functional for now except for the hot water issue.

Problem:
_**Electrical**_

Wiring in the home is very old and may be becoming more unsafe. Several outlets in the kitchen are popped out and not currently working. The fuse panel is located in Garry's bedroom and it's very old - old glass fuses. Outside light does not work
Solution: Recommend having a licensed electrician fully assess the safety of the electrical system in the home

Problem:
_**Roof**_

Roof is rusted and on top and looks like it was kool sealed in the recent past. The roof is rusted badly in some places and may have some pitting in some areas, which would allow water to reach the original roof that was most likely leaking. The power lines are relatively close to Garry's roof and it may make it challenging or a safety hazard to work on his roof.

Vent on the roof does not appear to be properly flashed
Solution: Kool seal is only a temporary fix - it appears that it's time to pull off the metal and replace it with new metal and gutters/downspouts. **See the note above regarding the power lines**

Problem: The home uses a gravity fed spring as a water source. When it rains the water becomes muddy/cloudy and the homeowner has to get water in jugs from another source.
Solution: Refer to USDA for a new well water system

Problem: GFI's in the bathroom shuts off every time it rains and vents in the bathrooms do not work
Solution: Consult with an electrician

Problem: Duct work has holes and may also be contributing to the energy inefficiency issue.
Solution: Replace with new insulated duct work

Problem: Belly liner under the home has a big swag in the middle. The homeowner suspects that it's holding wet insulation from the skylight roof leak in her bedroom. The homeowners sister has done some repairs under the home and pulled out several layers of wet insulation. The belly liner may be holding in moisture and creating ideal conditions for mold growth under the subfloor.
Solution: Tear out belly liner and wet insulation and re-insulate from underneath. Replace or sister in rotten floor joists if there's enough room.

Problem: Underpinning is very loose around the outside perimeter and allows air to freeze the water lines. This also creates an energy efficiency problem and makes the home very costly to heat/cool.
Solution: Tear out vinyl underpinning. Replace with 4x4 pressure treated posts or 2x4s, tyvek house wrap and metal roofing or some other air impermeable material.

Problem: Driveway is very rough and may make it difficult for fire and rescue to reach the home if necessary. Jamie mentioned having a medical emergency last year and they had to take her to the bottom of the driveway to reach EMS.
Solution: Regrade driveway and go back over with a layer of #3 stone and then a top layer of road bond. Driveway is 300 - 400 feet long to reach her house.

Problem: Exits - front stairs are very unsafe and present a trip/fall hazard. Jamie mentioned several times how unsafe they were. The back porch stairs are very unsafe and not well supported (back porch itself is solid).
Solution: Replace front and rear stairs with safer set that's up to code

Problem: Doors and Windows are leaking air/water - door frame to back exit is badly out of square and this may have been from settling (Morgan's bedroom door won't shut properly). Single pane windows are generating a ton of condensation that's dripping down onto unprotected sills and causing mold/rot. The floor in the kitchen is starting to get spongy from all of the moisture. Window by the bed in master bedroom is broken.
Solution: Replace windows/doors with more energy efficient products to help lower home heating/cooling costs. Home is very inefficient and the oil furnace runs constantly in the winter.

Problem: Roof is leaking badly around a skylight and creating mold/rot issues in the back half of the home. There are also a few water spots noted along the top of the walls throughout the home. Roof has been kool sealed by Jamie's sister at least once in recent years.
Solution: Metal roof replacement and roof over the skylight. Check on sealing off the skylight using tar paper or possibly a synthetic liner to keep warm interior air from creating a condensation issue. Also check on tear out the skylight and replacing with osb, insulation and drywall.

Problem:
Firewood

\- Sharon is too busy working to split firewood for her stove.
Solution: Deliver a load of seasoned firewood

Problem:
Attic

Insufficient attic insulation - only 3 to 4 inches of blown in cellulose.
Solution: Address after roof issue - blow in more insulation into the attic to help with heat retention.

Problem:
Bathroom Addition

Nice tub set with surround in the bathroom. The only problem noted was the absence of an exhaust fan and the window was sealed shut with plastic.
Solution: Install bathroom vent fan

Problem:
Interior

Kitchen - soft spot in kitchen floor in front of sink. Ran sink and did not see an active leak in the plumbing right now. Soft spot could have been caused by a previous leak. Original beadboard in ceiling is rotten from active leak - see roof notes.

The original beadboard ceiling throughout the interior of the home has been covered by a layer of clear plastic (help with heat retention?) and then 3/8 drywall has been added to the ceiling. Several areas of the drywall are missing.
Solution: Tear out kitchen floor in front of sink and repair/replace any rotten floor joists then glue/screw advantec or subflooring material to bring the floor back up to match height. Interior is not in that bad of shape. Some evidence of past roof leaks on the ceiling throughout the house, but that appears to have been addressed by Kool Seal.

Problem:
Roof

Old metal roof has been kool sealed at least once. Roof leaks around in an area above the kitchen where a chimney used to be located.
Solution: Tear off old metal roof and go back with new galvalume roofing. Also, replacing rotten purlins/rafters. Roof does not seem to be an emergency right now, but needs to be addressed prior to spending more money on the inside.

Problem:
Exterior/Siding/Windows/Porch

Siding - The exterior of the home appears to be covered in a layer of lead based paint. Please make sure that whoever works on the exterior home has been trained in the abatement of lead based paint. The siding is in rough shape and appears to be the original wooden lap siding. There are some areas where the siding is missing and rotten.  

Windows - Several of the sills have rotted out and have allowed water to get into the interior of the wall.

Front porch has completely decayed and only a portion remains of the original structure (concrete stairs and some posts). The entryway is not safe and needs to be addressed.

Back stairs - back stairs need to be repaired/replaced with a safer set

Home is only partially skirted and open to airflow underneath
Solution:
Siding - one possible solution would be to sheath over the lead based paint clap board with OSB or LP smart siding. If this is done then new window trim may be needed. Otherwise removing the lap siding may be necessary. West side of the house is covered in rigid foam that is deteriorating. The bathroom addition is clad in OSB sheathing and could use siding to prevent further decay.

Windows - recommend addressing water intrusion/rotted wood/sills prior to installing new windows. Sharon has already purchased several windows and flashing tape - see pictures.

Front Porch - recommend shoring up the roof over the front porch with 6 x 6 pressure treated SYP posts with concrete footers and erect a free standing deck for a safer entryway.

No vapor barrier under house, but crawlspace appeared dry. Also, home might benefit from some skirting to help with heat retention.

Sharon may be a great candidate for a skilled volunteer. She seems to have the means to purchase materials, but is extremely limited on time and I'm unsure of her skill level.

Problem: Front entrance unsafe. Door bad. Deck needs work. Gap between home and deck. Threshold floor damage. Exterior light getting wet.
Solution: The deck will need new rails and reinforcement at the very least. A lot of work is needed on the floor under the door, you will have to take out the old door which has fallen apart and repair the threshold area. You may be able to repair this with out removing the deck but it is hard to say. Remove bad subfloor, reinforce joists, install new plywood.' Work on deck then install a new door. The existing door is 34" x 76" - left hinge, opens out.

Problem: Ramp needed
Solution:
The best place for a ramp in my opinion is out the deck with the paddle boat on it, the one that you can see as you drive up to the house. This entry leads into the living room.

The threshold height here is about 35", that means a 35 foot long ramp. It must be a 1/12 pitch, follow ADA and code guidelines. It would have to have at least one turn in it.

Get an engineer from IL to look at it, both for the ramp and the bathroom

Ramp, deck , and landings will need rails

A pathway or driveway will need to be established on this side as well

Problem: Hallway floor damage.
Solution:
At this time there is a stack of 7/16 OSB in the already narrow hallway. This will need to be removed to do repairs. Remove weak sections, reinforce joists, install insulation if needed, and replace subfloor material. It is probably 5/8" thick.

Note walls are probably damaged as well - extent not clear

Problem: Bathroom is in bad shape. Commode is loose. Holes in floor. It is unusable by a handicapped person.
Solution:
Remodel. Room is 64 sq. feet. Widen doorway. Remove part or all of partition wall between commode and bathtub area. Remove commode, vanity, tub. Demo floor, being careful not to damage wires, plumbing, or heat ducts. Reinforce joists. install new insulation. Install new subfloor. Install walk in shower, handicap commode, vanity.

Joe says it is OK to remove the wall between the bathroom and an adjacent bedroom that is unused to make the new bathroom bigger

Problem: Back exit is blocked on the inside by a couple of big guitar amps and a table. . Exit is blocked on the outside by a paddle boat. Deck needs work.
Solution:
Remove stuff from the inside so that somebody could get out in an emergency. Remove paddle boat so that further assessment can be done on the deck, it needs reinforcement and handrails at the very least.

Note- this deck may need to be demo'd for a ramp ( it is 6" or so below the threshold ); see other repair

Problem: Strong Mold smell throughout home. Lots of dust and clutter in the house.
Solution:
There is a lot of moisture getting into the house, due to some small roof leaks, but also on the sides around the windows, etc. Client says the little trailer style gutters are clogged and as a result water gets in the walls.

Long term solution will include a roof with overhang. Short term solution can be to clean the gutters, replace screws in the gutters and on the aluminum siding, and caulk some places that are suspected of leaking. Clean the inside of the home , reduce clutter, and clean thoroughly with bleach water.

You will need to have a talk with Joe about getting rid of some stuff that is cluttering his house; it looks like the place has not had a good cleaning in a while.

Problem: Stains on ceiling indicate roof leaks. Water is also getting in the walls and damaging floors due to clogged mini- gutters and lack of overhang.
Solution:
A temporary fix may be Kool- seal, but ultimately a metal roof with overhang is needed. Client requests at least a 5 inch overhang and no gutters.

This is a 3/12 pitch trailer roof so 1x4 perlins can be installed over the existing roof.

Problem:
Heat issues. There is an unvented propane heater with a 20 lb. tank hooked up to it in the living room. The duct work for the electric furnace is not in good shape because Joe said he saw a possum crawl up through one of the vents.

Joe has a wood heater, which is outside in an adjacent building. He says it works good but I did not get a good look at the building , the heater, or the chimney on account of rain.
Solution: Inspect wood heater and chimney for safety. Have a conversation with Joe about the dangers of unvented propane heaters. Fix duct work, or better yet get them a mini-split.

Problem: Kitchen sink drains into bucket
Solution: According to Joe the only thing needed here are some drain parts (traps), he said that there was a clogged drainpipe which he fixed with some kind of high- strength cleaner. Install drain parts , some of which Joe may have.

Problem: Old sofa and other junk needs to be hauled off. Yard work needed.
Solution: Haul junk to landfill and clean up yard

Problem: Siding of trailer is dirty
Solution: pressure wash and clean

Problem: Back stairs are in bad shape and railing has completely rotted off.
Solution: Replace back stairs with a 4'x4' deck and new railings. Deck will need to be approximately 30" high.

Problem: Large sinkhole forming to the left of the front porch front what appears to be a drain pipe or water line failure. The toilets still flush right now and the homeowner said you can see water bubbling up from the sinkhole.
Solution: Hire a septic contractor to repair the line/tank or whatever is needed. A mini-excavator will be needed to dig up the tank and any lines.

Problem: Rear exterior door is blocked off in laundry area - threshold damaged by rats
Solution: Repair/replace back door for additional egress/ingress

Problem: Unfinished bedroom - Susan is trying to get custody/visitation of her two kids ( 8 & 10 yrs old) and this room is in bad shape. Multiple holes in the drywall, bad ceiling, moisture issues created from leaky plumbing on adjoining wall with bathroom. No heat source for this room was noted and windows need to be replaced.
Solution: Repair back bedroom and install heat source.

Problem: Rear Addition is below grade and water from the hill is draining right onto the exterior OSB plywood sheathing. Carlee's old room is filled with what appears to be extensive mold growth and it may be affecting the overall air quality in the rest of the home. The homeowner has suggested tearing off this addition and turning it into a porch. The homeowners main bedroom is also a part of this addition and has an adjoining wall. The homeowners bedroom does not appear to have the same issues. Also, the homeowners bedroom has 24" on center rafters with no insulation.
Solution: Tear off rotten portion of the addition

Problem: Electrical - broken receptacle/switch covers noted throughout the home. The microwave "sparks" when it's in use. Outlets do not work in the homeowners bedroom. Ceiling fan on porch - wiring issues - breaker trips and fan fell recently. The outlet to the left of the bedroom door in the TV appeared to have black soot possibly from a previous short. Nothing was plugged into this outlet.
Solution: Have a licensed electrician evaluate the wiring in the home and come up with a viable solution

Problem: Electrical
Rear Room Addition
Mold

Wood stove - Appears to be the primary heat source for the home. The hearth is damaged below the stove. The stove pipe from the stove exits the home through a masonry chimney and at the top of the chimney turns into single wall pipe and is in very close proximity to the wood siding.
Solution: Single wall pipe from stove up through ceiling into a thimble and then into triple wall stove pipe above roof line. Approximately 6' of single wall pipe, adapter box and 5 - 6' of triple wall pipe needed.

Problem: Roof - A portion of the mobile home roof was roofed over with a metal roof and some areas have shingles. A portion of the original mobile home roof is still use. There are a number of active and past leaks in the roof. The main concern is that the roof is too heavy to be supported by the mobile home's structure. There is an area in the living room where the wall has settled several inches and the middle of the roof appears to be supported by a single locust pole.
Solution: Because of the complexity of the roofing system created by the homeowner by adding so many different layers, it would be best to have a professional evaluate and come up with a viable solution.

Problem:
Hallway bathroom (bamboo) - Shower leaks and appears to be creating a mold issue in the adjoining bedroom. Toilet leaks and is rotting the floor and also adding to moisture issues. Floor is very soft around the toilet. Tub appears to be in good condition and usable in this bathroom. If the tub is going to be continued to use as a shower then a surround will be needed. The ceiling is starting to fall in due to a previous or active water leak around the vent fan.

Second bathroom (located in back bedroom) - This bathroom is in very bad shape and does not appear to be usable other than the toilet (old toilet - huge tank and constantly runs). The floor in front of the sink is not safe and the sink has been leaking for years (bucket under sink to catch water). The linoleum masks the floor issue and someone could potentially fall through. The shower pan has been leaking for years and same with the toilet. The drywall in the ceiling has fallen in leaving the roofing and wooden trusses partially exposed.

Water heater - access panel door is hanging open and will not close. Suggested to homeowner that the door be reinstalled and add insulation before cold weather arrives.
Solution:
***Roof issues should be addressed prior to spending more money on interior concerns

Hallway bathroom (bamboo) - total tear out and remodel  

Second bathroom (located in back bedroom) - floor is unsafe - tear out and remodel

Water heater - Reinstall access panel and insulate cavity

Problem: Harry has been having increased difficulty with mobility and has started using a walker. There is a 6 1/2" step down to his enclosed porch which leads to his bathroom. He has a hard time getting down there and uses a potty chair in the bedroom.
Solution:
Hee are a few ideas:

1) refer client to Independent Living. They could send out an engineer to plan a bathroom remodel. He needs a walk in shower.

2) Build up the floor to make it level with the kitchen. This would require removing 2 doors and changing the headers, and would also mean a complete bathroom remodel.

3) Build an entire new bathroom in one of the bedrooms, probably in the bedroom that is adjacent to the existing bathroom. . Plumbing would have to be redone.

Note- there is some 9" x 9" tile on the floor looks like it may contain asbestos. Test.

Problem: Harry has only one access/egress point into his home from the driveway. The front concrete stairs have settled and are no longer accessible for him. The top stair is approximately 17" below the porch.
Solution:
1) Look at the possibility of building a handicap accessible ramp from the side of the porch out to the drive-way. The well house may be in the way of providing this ramp.

2) Could possibly install another door off the kitchen on the back of the house and put in a walk-way to the drive-way.

Problem: Due to the age of the home (<1978) lead paint is suspected through-out the home and on the exterior siding. Several areas are flaking on the exterior and interior. Before any interior or exterior work commences on the house it may be necessary to test the home for lead to protect workers from exposure.
Solution:
1) Make sure any areas where renovations/repairs will occur inside or outside of the home have been tested for lead based paint

2) Due to the size of the home it may be too costly for lead paint abatement for the entire home.

Problem: No GFI's in bathroom
Solution: Add necessary GFI's in bathroom to prevent accidental shock hazards. Did not note or look for the presence of GFI's in the kitchen area.

Problem: Did not ask the client about septic system and where it was located. The bathroom was added much later (1950's) and it's unclear if the home has a septic system in place.
Solution:
1) Ask Mr. Payne about the presence of a septic system

2) Pull septic records from Madison County Environmental Health

Problem: Front and back doors jambs are rotting and doors will not seal properly.
Solution:
Remove and replace rotten wood where needed.

Adjust doors to seal properly and install new weather striping.

Problem: Dryer vent pipe has come apart under trailer.
Solution: New 4" flexible duct line with a 4" coupling attached with HVAC tape not duct tape.

Problem:
Front of trailer has no gutter.  

Back of trailer has damaged gutter.
Solution:
Add 80 feet of gutter to front of trailer and 2 down spouts with splash blocks  

Add 80 feet of gutter to back of trailer with 2 down spouts and dig in 20 feet of 4" drain line to day light.

Problem: Kitchen floor is stick down tile that is coming up.Thresholds are needed where new oak floors end, at kitchen and hall.
Solution:
In stall 140 sf of new laminate vinyl plank flooring over existing flooring.

Install new threshold Where oak floor end at kitchen and hall.

Problem: wall in guest bath has water damage may have a pluming leak.
Solution: Remove a section of drywall on the bed room side of wall to see if pluming is leaking. then repair if leaking.

Problem: Holes in walls
Solution: Apply joint compound sand and paint.

Problem: Back deck
Solution: Remove old deck and build a new 6'-6 x 6'-0"' deck see plan on file.

Problem: Front deck has uneven deck boards and rotten stairs and supports.
Solution: Tear down and remove old deck. Replace with new deck built to code. See Drawing.

Problem: electrical
doors
Underpinning is in bad shape on the back side of the house.
Solution: Replace underpinning on one side. Recycled metal roofing makes good underpinning. Install vinyl j channel.

Problem: Hose bib near main water line has had problems and breaks ocassionally. It was not leaking at the time, but Loy wants to improve this.
Solution: Work with Loy to install anew hose bib. Main water comes in beside meter base. There is a shut-off there but the valve may be rusty. Keep in mind that if you work on this and have to shut off power to the well, it may affect the other trailers.

Problem: Vinyl siding has green stains
Solution: pressure wash or hand wash

Problem: Drywall work needed on the inside
Solution: Patch, tape, mud, and paint. Consult James about how far along this project has gotten and work with him.

Problem: Back porch in rough condition. Threshold/sill damaged behind deck.
Solution:
Remove most or all of the deck. The deck is partly covered by a roof that will have to be supported somehow during demo. Repair area around door threshold that has rotted, I am not sure how extensive the damage is, but it has rotted part of the sill. After doing all repairs to the framing of the home and making everthing water tight, build back another deck. The old one is triangle shaped, but you may want to design a different size or shaped deck depending on the project budget. Steps and rails should be installed as well since you have an elderly client with mobility issues.

Consult homeowner before digging- there may be water or other underground pipes here

Problem: Loose step handrail-front porch
Solution:
Tear down the old hand rail and build new ones.

I did not look at this real closely but you may be able to talk to James and get him to help measure.

Problem:
Bathroom floor is weak under the tub and commode. Tub surround has a big hole in it. Black mold on drywall.

This is the bathroom that is adjacent to the bedroom that James has partially gutted.
Solution: Remodel needed. Shut off water and/or cap pipes. Remove tub and surround. Remove commode.Tear up bad subfloor. Watch for wires, HVAC ducts and pipes. Reinforce floor framing if needed. Install new insulation in floor if needed. Install new subfloor material, it is probably 5/8".Remove moldy drywall. Install new , mold- resistant drywall. Install new tub, trailer-size, 27" x 54". Install new surround. Re-install plumbing fixtures or get new ones. Install new vinyl plank flooring, 40 sft. Clean old commode and reinstall or get a new one. Reinstall trim.

Problem: Bedroom has suffered water damage. The homeowner has gutted a large part of it. Floor is weak in some places and framing is water-stained.
Solution:
The drainage and gutters should be fixed first in order to keep this problem from re-occuring.

Clean 2x4 framing with bleach water and let dry. Scab on some new framing and reinforce what has been damaged. The sub floor will need work, the best solution here may be to put a layer of 5/8" plywood over the entire floor.

Install new drywall- I would go with the purple, mold resistant stuff. Tape, mud, and paint. If you sand it use dust protection and seal off the room.

Talk to James about the amount of drywall and insulation he will need. Get him to measure and tell you.

After painting, install 108 square feet of laminate vinyl flooring.

Install threshold between rooms.

Install baseboards.

The room is 9' x 12'.

Problem: No insulation or drywall in kitchen or dinning room.
Solution:
Install R- 13 insulation in walls and R-30" in ceiling.

Install 1/2" drywall on ceiling and walls

Problem: Kitchen door and window are destroyed.
Solution:
Install new 35" x 83.5" metal door right hand hinge.in swing

Install new 42" high x 30.5" wide energy efficient window

Problem: Service cable is improperly mounted, old and frayed. wiring inside house is in bad repair.
Solution: Have an electrician install all new service and rewire circuits that are accessible because of no insulation are drywall on walls or ceilings.

Problem: The back deck is in rough shape and it seems like water is getting under it but not draining out. This contributed to excessive moisture on the back side of the home where James' dameged bedroom is. The deck is also pitched the wrong way, which may have contributed to the problem.
Solution:
James says that before the back deck was built, the family installed a drain. I believe the best solution will be to tear down the deck , clear everything out of the way and inspect the drainage system, if possible, and determine if it still working. If it is not, install a new French drain back here. Then build a deck over it that is correctly pitched and free standing. Check area where the deck was next to the house and make repairs as needed.

The existing deck is 13' x 13'. A smaller deck would be fine.

Problem: Hot water heater not properly wired.
Solution: Have an electrician install disconnect box and rewire water heater.

Problem: Drainage problem and water coming off the roof has caused damage to the house. James was up on the roof one time and fell, knocking part of the gutter loose.
Solution: The worst place is on the back side of the house where the big deck is, but the house really needs gutters all the way around. There are some places where existing gutters could be fixed, but new ones would be a good idea. You will need at least 80 linear feet of gutters to do the whole house. Get a quote from Joe Willis.

Problem: Kitchen counter badly burned.
Solution: Install new kitchen counter

Problem: Front deck is about to fall in.
Solution: Temporarily support roof then remove old deck and Rebuild deck.

Problem: Monitor heater needs to be serviced.
Solution: Have HVAC professional come service unit. Before cold whether.

Problem: Handrail on back porch is missing.
Solution: Build handrail back.

Problem: Damp crawl space.
Solution: Install 6 mill vapor barrier

Problem: Soot and smoke all inside house. Worst damage on ceiling tiles.
Solution: Clean and paint entire inside of house. Ceiling tile may need to be remove and replaced with drywall on ceiling.

Problem: Visited Eddie on 7/2/20, spoke w/his in home health worker, Betty, who showed me the damage to the floor and closet in the room nearest the kitchen, as well as the bathroom adjoining this room. He an no longer use this area of the house as it's not wheelchair accessible with sunk in floors covered with plywood. He does however have access to the rest of the home which includes a wheelchair accessible bathroom. There is also water damage beneath Eddie's kitchen sink. See last 4 photos added to assessment photos.
Solution: Investigate to see what needs to be done to repair this. Betty believes her son has fixed the water leak, from main water line, that is likely to have caused all this damage. But the rotted materials need to be removed and replaced.

Problem:
No water since Easter. Clients bucket- flush and use water jugs for cooking and hand washing.

The access to the well pump area is cluttered with debris and there is a fence and some rocks in the way; see photos.

According to the homeowners, something is wrong with the pump and they cannot afford to pay to have it fixed.
Solution: Although some recent grading has happened, the road is kind of rough and there is a tight curve, big trucks from the well company may hesitate on this site. The fence, rocks and trash should be moved, which the homeowners are capable of doing, so that a well guy can come up and look at it.

Problem: Hole in floor in front of the kitchen sink caused by old leak.
Solution:
The hole has been mostly covered by a scrap of plywood but is still dangerous.

Remove old flooring and subfloor material that is damaged. Cut a big square hole. watch out for wires and pipes, you could inspect from the basement. Install a new sheet of plywood. Thickness of subfloor unknown.

Reinforce the joists, repair framing damage if needed, Install flooring if time and finances permit.

Problem: There is a large amount of trash and recycling in the yard. A yard clean-up will be required to fix the water problem.
Solution: bag up trash, move rocks, move fence.

Problem: Rear exit, in basement, is blocked. Clutter does not allow easy movement to the door. The door is nailed shut with a board and is missing a knob. Basement has a strong mold smell.
Solution: A massive basement clean-up is needed here. Rent a dumpster. wear dust masks and remove trash and unusable items. Make sure there is a clear path to the door, then re-assess to determine how to repair or replace the door and entryway. Weed eat under porch, where the door opens, to establish a safe entry/exit.

Problem: Ramp usable but in rough shape. Covered front porch has some rotten decking.
Solution: Replace ramp .De clutter porch and assess further. Repair porch flooring.

Problem: Electrical box in bedroom is not accessible due to clutter.
Solution:
Remove stuff from room. Talk to family about donating and throwing stuff away.

The porches and other rooms also have a high clutter level.

Problem:
Bathroom needs work. Main problem here is no water, but other work is needed. Although the subfloor seems solid, some flooring will be needed. The windowsill is rotten, and the faucet is broken on the vanity sink.

Condition of tub faucets and plumbing unknown; tub needs cleaning
Solution:
Pull commode. It will need to be replaced or cleaned.

install vinyl laminate flooring 70 sft?

Replace or repair window

Replace sink faucet, clean sink, clean bath tub

Problem: The covered porch on the opposite side of the entrance is sagging.
Solution: The deck, although apparently seldom used, is 10' off the ground. The posts seem to be sinking into the ground and the deck is noticeably leaning. The area was pretty grown up with weeds so I could not look at it real closely, but the solution may involve jacking up and [pouring some concrete footers.

Problem: Flooring needed in home. The old linoleum has peeled up
Solution: Install high quality laminate flooring. 100 square feet would be a good start.

Problem: Rear exit blocked. High level of clutter throughout home.
Solution: Organize, throw away, donate. Most of the clutter is in the laundry room where the back door is unusable because of all the stuff in front of it.

Problem: Hole in floor bathroom #2. Hole in front of bedroom door area.
Solution:
One hole is next to the bath tub. The bathroom on this side of the house is not used much, neither is the bedroom, which is adjacent , but the holes should be fixed for safety.

  

Remove floor covering, Cut water and cap off plumbing. Remove tub. Cut out bad subfloor. Shore up joists. Install insulation if needed. install new plywood.

A full remodel is needed, but fixing the floor is the first step and can be done cheaper since she has another bathroom.

Problem: Back porch, in usable condition but step treads need replacement
Solution: replace step treads

Problem: The siding, which is fiber-cement- board, was not properly installed and water could get in the walls, especially around the windows. Window trim was never installed, boards were just installed to cover the trailer metal.
Solution:
The correct solution for this problem is to remove the siding and completely re- do it, but this may be unrealistic. There are some spots that could be repaired and patched. I have never done this but there are some online resources that involve a bucket of patch compound and some kind of fabric.

Caulk and paint , patch holes, etc.

Problem:
Although Daphne did not complain of roof leaks, evidence was seen that it was leaking. Ceiling stains were visible inside.

A metal roof was installed over the original trailer metal at some point. The pitch is 1 1/4 in 12 , which is too flat. The penetrations were not flashed properly or at all. The metal overhang is not right and consequently there are places where rain water shoots completely over the gutters.
Solution: The perlins are very far apart on this roof, I do not recommend standing on it. Other than re-structuring the roof , all I can recommend is to trim off the metal so that the water will go into the gutters (1 1/2" is the proper overhang). This will be painstaking if tin snips are used, nibblers recommended.

Problem: Monitor vents out under a window
Solution: I know this is not allowed but not sure where to move the monitor

Problem: Underpinning is in rough shape, ;lots of holes.
Solution:
Remove the worst sections first. Rake and clean out under trailer. Install 6 mil vapor barrier. Install new vinyl J channel with spikes. Cut pieces of recycled roof metal and put them under the top trim and into the channel on the bottom. Check plumb ocassionally.

Underpinning is not necessary under the porches, just under th emain part of the home where the plumbing is.

Problem: Heat issues.Client says heat does not reach her bedroom or bathroom.
Solution: Have HVAC man check the condition of both the heat pump and the monitor. It could be a ductwork issue; I did not assess the ductwork.

Problem: Bad water heater leak has caused floor damage. The water heater is still working, but it is 17 years old and leaning due to a hole in the floor. Looks like the main leak is out of the top, where the pressure relief valve is.
Solution:
The water heater is accessed from the outside by a panel in the side of the trailer. Cut off power. Cut off water. Drain water heater. Remove water heater. Remove rotten subfloor material. Reinforce joists. add insulation. Install new subfloor material (plywood). Install a new water heater. A smaller one would work because there is only one resident.

Replace access door. The existing one is 22 3/8" x 63".

Heater is plumbed with 3/4" pex.

Problem: Back porch is in rough shape. Boards rotten. Deck has noticeable lean. Steps not to code. 40" high.
Solution: Tear down deck and rebuild. You will need to somehow support the porch roof while removing the deck below. Build back a free standing deck that is about 6'x8'. Build steps with concrete landing and rails. Follow building code.

Problem: Trish has a couple of bedroom windows that should be replaced, one is broken. They are side- by-side. Wall is damaged due to moisture.
Solution: Remove old windows. Remove inside paneling. Repair /scab wall framing. Replace insulation if needed. Install some new paneling. Caution- there is an outlet below the windows. Inspect floor for damage. Replace with two double pane windows that will fit a rough opening of 28" wide x 24" high. Trim.

Problem: Kitchen drainpipe is clogged up. Kitchen sink faucet leaks.
Solution:
Trish' son replaced some drain pipes, but there is still a clog. A bucket catches the drain water. There is a clean-out under there but it is hard to reach. New drainpipes are white PVC, old drainpipes are black, 1 1/2" ABS.

  

The floor beneath the sink has been wet for a while, there may be some floor damage. Remove drain pipes. Clean out area under sink. Repair floor if needed. Snake the drain . Reinstall drain pipes. Run water and check for leaks and clogs.

Trish said that the drains work in other parts of the house.

Replace faucet. No spray nozzle.

Problem:
Kitchen floor tiles (12" x 12" linoleum sticky- tiles) peeled up or missing

Kitchen floor square footage is approx. 105
Solution: Remove all tiles and replace with a higher quality material. Shw or other brand of laminate vinyl snap- together flooring recommended.

Problem: Crawlspace access door (opposite of road) is damaged and should be replaced so it can be closed tightly for winter
Solution: Build a new crawlspace door. You can probably re-use the hinges.

Problem: Paint is flaking off the exterior siding (plywood) of the addition.
Solution: Tests indicate no lead paint. Scrape old paint and repaint exterior of addition.

Problem: Trish no longer uses her oil furnace and would like to remove it and use the space for storage.
Solution: remove old furnace and convert space into a closet.

Problem:
Trish's second bathroom needs some work. Faucet drips. Flooring needed.

There may be some other leaks or flooring damage.
Solution:
Repair or replace faucet.

Determine if there are any shower leaks or floor damage. when the adjacent water heater is removed and replaced. You can inspect the back side of the shower, where the plumbing goes in, from the outside access panel.

if the floor is in good enough shape install 40 sft of vinyl plank flooring.

Problem: Rosetta's porch floor, which is 3/4" plywood, is damaged and springy. This porch has been used for years to store firewood.
Solution:
Replace the plywood with ¾” oak or pressure treated plywood. If the material is thicker it could interfere with the opening of the kitchen door. This job should be done in preparation for a ramp.

The porch is not conventionally framed and has 3 big sills underneath. When you take the plywood off you should add some 2x6 pt framing underneath ,every 16".

Install new porch posts (pressure treated).

The porch is 20'long x 6' wide .

You may have to use temporary posts to take the weight off of the porch roof while replacing flooring.

Problem: Handicap ramp needed. A neighbor built one but it is starting to rot (osb).
Solution: Install handicap ramp. Ind. Living might do this. The ramp would be built off the back porch. It would be about 24' long to meet code. . Build hand rails and make sure the slope does not exceed 1 in 12. The ramp should be 48” wide.

Problem: Front deck is rotten and unsafe.
Solution:
Remove old rotten deck and trash. Add new 6' x 10' deck with steps built to code.

See plan in photos.

Problem: Side deck needs new hand rail. Steps are not built to code and lean.
Solution: Remove existing hand rail and 4x4s on deck and stairs. Install new properly installed 4x4 and hand rail to code.

Problem: Roof leaks reported around chimneys. Leak on side porch roof. There are some stains on the upstairs ceiling paneling
Solution: The roof has been re-shingled in the past 15 years or so according to Rosetta, Replace roofing material on side porch. The chimneys should be re -flashed or at least patched with tar. Tear off old shingles(2 layers)and re-roof the kitchen porch (which looks like it did not get shingled along with the rest of the roof last time). The square footage of the porch roof is 200 sf. The rest of the roof was not accurately measured.

Problem: There is some water damage to the siding on the back side of the house. This was found during the bedroom floor remodel.
Solution: This walls of this house has rough sawn framing , diagonal rough sawn 1" sheathing, tar paper, and asbestos shingles. On top of that is vinyl siding. Some of the rough sawn wood sheathing is rotten. In order to repair this, you would have to remove the vinyl siding, then remove the asbestos shingles. This would require special training and protective measures because of the asbestos safety hazards. Remove asbestos, install new 1" sheathing boards, and put the vinyl siding back on, and/or get new vinyl siding.

Problem: Gutter on side porch (where she keeps her wood ) leaks
Solution: Replace vinyl gutter with seamless. install downspout and splash block

Problem: Rotten floor at side door.
Solution: Remove metal trim and linoleum flooring replace a section of sub flooring where rotten reinforce joist where needed and add new 5/8"plywood replace linoleum and metal trim.

Problem:
Gutter requested on wood shed. This will make it easier for Rosetta to haul firewood and keep the wood drier.

The shed is leaning the wrong way which will make it hard for the gutter to shed water.
Solution:
Rosetta has spoken to her freind Charles about jacking up the shed . If this can happen it will be set up to have a gutter and downspout, spilling out on the downhill side.

Rosetta has an old piece of gutter that will suffice for this job. She may have some more gutter stuff, ask if she has some in her barn.

Problem: Rosetta's main source of heat is firewood. She has a wood shed full but needs help catrrying and stacking it
Solution: Help stack firewood once the porch gets fixed

Problem: Attach Stove ring for wood heater chimney.
Solution: Secure stove ring with screws at ceiling.

Problem: Roof repair.
Solution: Apply black roof cement on some places where roof is leaking.

Problem: Home needs exterior cleaning.
Solution: Pressure wash vinyl siding.

Problem: Repair barn behind house for use as a wood shed.
Solution: Needs some framing work and more metal added to roof.

Problem: Wobbly handrail -interior- leads to upstairs room.
Solution: Reinforce handrail The staircase leading to the second floor of the house has a wobbly handrail. Use timber-locks and 2x4’s

Problem:
Hole in floor in the room where the stove is (addition).

Possums get in.
Solution:
Warning- this may be a "can of worms" because there could be some wall damage due to the roof leak, and the floor was built close to the ground. The framing may not be pressure treated, and the whole floor is a bit "springy".

Remove furniture and stuff from room. Remove old carpet. Remove old subfloor in the damaged part of the room. I do not know if there are wires or pipes under there. Reinforce joists. Add plywood. Thickness needed is unknown.

Probably not a good idea to put insulation in the floor because it is close to the ground and will fall out.

Problem:
Hole in the floor. This is in the room that Nathan calls his "Junk Room". The hole in question is next to the water heater.

My theory is that the hole happened due to an old water heater leak, but it could be because of a roof leak as well.
Solution: Clear out room. This will require a conversation with Narthan as to what he wants to throw away and what he wants to keep. Remove old carpet. Remove subfloor around area that is damaged. Be careful because there are galvanized pipes (no longer used), electrical wires and drainpipes directly under the floor. Some are visible through the existing hole. Reinforce joists, add insulation if practical, and install plywood subfloor. Looks like the existing subfloor is 3/4". Install floor material if finances allow.

Problem: There is a roof leak somewhere in the transition of the trailer and addition roof. It has run down the walls and damaged the floor.
Solution:
The trailer really should have a new roof; it is a 1979 model and has a flat , 2- level roof. Because of its age and design, and the fact that there is some wall damage ( I saw some when I checked on a crew that was doing underpinning) the best plan will be to put 4x4's around the whole thing, then build a gable- style roof.

There is a masonry chimney on one side that could be removed to make room for a new roof, because it is no longer used. The old oil furnace chimney (jack) can be removed as well for the same reason.

Problem: Nathan's road needs some maintenance.
Solution:
Some water breaks would help here. Haul gravel and road- bond.

If Nathan had a 4wd vehicle it would not spin as much.

Problem:
Nathan burns wood as his main source of heat. He wants to install a Monitor heater as a backup, which he has. I am not sure what condition it is in. He also has an oil tank that needs to be hauled up the hill and hooked up.

The old oil furnace does not work at this time.
Solution: Drag oil tank up hill and position it correctly for oil flow. Install Monitor. hook up with copper lines.

Problem: A large portion of Nathan's floor is bare plywood. Lots of subfloor repair has been done here but it would be nice to have some flooring installed so that the place would be easier to clean( he has some dogs).
Solution:
Install some laminate vinyl plank flooring; Plan according to budget, the main rooms that need it are the kitchenb and hallway in my opinion.

150 square feet would be a good start.

The kitchen has a step up so you will have to get some kind of corner material.

Problem:
Yard has lots of Junk in it. The well company cannot get access to the well to do repairs because there is a camper trailer and a storage building in the way.

Michael's ex wife lives in this camper.
Solution:
Talk to Michael and his ex to make plans to move the camper. Inspect camper to make sure it does not fall apart when moved. Move camper. Michael says he can move it but his big truck does not run.

Clean out storage building. Move building. It it aluminum.

Weed eat area around well.

Problem: Electrical issues. Some outlets in the bathroom do not work. bad light fixture in kitchen. Several other outlets do not work. Denise says that the problem is due to water getting in the walls. The circuit box is inaccessible at this time because there is a bunch of stuff piled up in front of it. Breakers sometimes trip.
Solution: Un-clutter room where the circuit box is. Have an electrician look at the box and make some repairs to make the place safer

Problem: Roof is leaking in several places. Water is getting into the walls. Edges of drywall on the ceiling have dark mold stains.
Solution:
Plan A) Clean roof. It has a lot of gunk on it from leaves, etc. You might try wire brushes or a pressure washer. Apply a 1/4" layer of "Thru- The -Roof" around all penetrations. Apply 2 coats of Kool seal.
