Plan B) New metal roof. This one has a 3/12 pitch. Dimensions of roof approx 154" wide x 70' long. Create overhang to get water away from walls.

Price for plan A only is listed below.

Problem: Water gets in the walls ; this has created a mold problem and possibly some electrical problems. The whole house has a musty smell.
Solution:
A good cleanup will alleviate some problems but they will come back if the roof does not get fixed.

After roof repair, De- clutter house, clean all mold stains and repaint.

Cleanup should be done properly to avoid mold exposure, wear dust mask, put up plastic sheeting, etc. "The Family Handyman" has some good info online about how to clean up mold.

Problem: Deck needs reinforcement. Porch roof fell one time because it is not structuraly sound ;current posts are aluminum and are not attached very well.
Solution:
Install new posts with diagonal braces and concrete. Build new steps. Build rails ( deck height is 35".

Tear down old metal porch roof. Install new posts. Make the new porch roof have at least a 2 in 12 pitch. (this will have to be a "shed- style" roof with the high end coming up above the trailer roof.) You may be able to re-use the all-metal porch roof.

Problem:
Two bathrooms in home. Bath #1 is in good working condition but does not have a fan.

Bath 2 has no fan either, and the tub is not hooked up. Commode and sink work.
Solution: Install fans in both bathrooms. Talk to client about her needs as far as shower and tub

Problem: Second exit is a small deck that has been enclosed as part of a dog lot. the dogs were out there at assessment time so I did not get to look at the back exit to determine if there were any problems with it. Client says that you can get out that way.
Solution: Have Marla put the dogs somewhere else and further assess the back exit.

Problem: Underpinning needs work, much of it has fallen down, insulation under house has fallen out.
Solution:
Remove old underpinning and let the area dry out. Rake and clean out underneath. Install vapor barrier. Install vinyl underpinning channel with spikes. Use recycled roofing metal as underpinning. Measure and cut pieces to fit in the channel at the bottom and under the aluminum trim at the top. Check plumb ocassionally with a short level.

Replace missing insulation- not sure how much

Problem: Yard work needed. There is some erosion above the trailer.
Solution: Weed eat, mulch, mow, etc. Talk to Marla and Denise, they have a rough plan

Problem: Home has lots of clutter.
Solution: Marla needs help cleaning up, donating some items, and throwing some stuff away.

Problem: Water problems. Extremely low pressure. Commode fills and flushes, sinks are usable but the water just trickles. Client cannot bathe or wash clothes.
Solution:
A well company may be able to fix this but the area must be cleared; see above repair.

The info that I gleaned indicated that the well, pump., and pipe going into it need work. There is a lot of iron and rust in the system. The pressure tank, switch, etc (in crawlspace), are OK.

Mark A has more info

Problem: Clutter
Electrical issues. Box looks bad. Some upgrades will probably be needed.
Solution: get an electrician to further assess and make some recommendations.

Problem:
There is a roof leak around the chimney. Drywall visibly damaged around chimney.

Asphalt shingles are 15 years old. Flashing around chimney is not right. An old TV antenna has wore a hole in the shingles. Rocks have wore off most of the shingles and some are missing
Solution:
New roof if finances permit, otherwise patch

low budget solution would be to remove the antenna, clean moss around the chimney, and "Thru the Roof" it.

Problem: Kitchen sink drain needs work
Solution: Replace drain parts and maybe baskets

Problem: A trailer on the property has two people living in it and is on the same well as Michael's house.
Solution:
This home was not assessed but it will have water problems too; the well solution will affect this home.

I am not sure what the situation is , but it sounds like Michael is letting some folks live there

Problem: Bedroom floor is weak . It was damaged at the same time the big leak in the bathroom happened. Damage has extended under the wall between the bedroom and bathroom.
Solution: Remove furniture and carpet. This would be a good time to get all the carpet out of here and replace with vinyl plank flooring. Cut out a big square around the area of damaged plywood and remove. Reinforce joists and add insulation if needed. install solid plywood. Install floor covering.

Problem: Porch roof leaks where it attaches to the trailer .
Solution:
The reason it leaks is because the porch roof , which was built by volunteers years ago, has little or no pitch. Water can get back behind the top layer of metal, which is only about 2 feet long.

The existing deck and ramp are in decent shape, you may need to replace a few boards.

Re-design a porch roof where the posts nearest the house come up above the roof line and gutters. You may be able to leave the posts on the other side. There should be at least a 2/12 slope on the new roof. The gutter should catch rain water and keep the area around the door fairly dry.

Install diagonal bracing where needed to stiffen the structure.

Remove old metal carefully, it can be re-used.

Problem:
Bathroom floor very weak around the commode. Weak place under vanity. Residents say the tub has a weak place under it. This happened due to a water leak when they were away.

Roof leak in this room where the ceiling fan is.
Solution: Bathroom remodel. Remove commode, vanity, tub/shower unit. Cut out all damaged subfloor. Reinforce joists. install insulation. Replace subfloor. Install new tub/shower and plumbing. The existing unit is 54" x 27" with a center drain. Install vinyl plank flooring. 60 square feet. Reinstall commode with new wax ring

Problem: Weak floors- hallway-laundry area
Solution: Remove laundry machines and damaged floor material. Reinforce joists and install some new plywood and floor material if needed. (This can probably just be a sheet of linoleum.)

Problem: Roof leaks around the ceiling fan in the bathroom.
Solution:
Cody has attempted to caulk the problem area but it still leaks. There are several places where it could leak. I told him to get a gallon of "Thru- the Roof" and give that a try. Caulk all penetrations, slathering on a 1/4" layer of the stuff.

This trailer has a 3/12 pitch, so may be a good candidate for a new metal roof eventually, but the above solution should be tried first.

The home has full-size seamless gutters, which has really helped. These could be re-used if a metal roof is installed.

Problem: Underpinning needs work. The existing stuff is painted OSB that has rotted.
Solution: Remove old OSB. Clean out under trailer. Rake. Install 6 mil vapor barrier on the ground. Install vinyl underpinning channel with spikes. Measure and cut recycled metal. It should fit in the channel and under the aluminum trim at the bottom of the trailer. Use a level to check plumb occasionally.

Problem: Back deck needs work.Some deck boards need replacement. Rails are loose or missing.
Solution:
Talk to the homeowners about their sattelite dish, it is mounted to the deck and must be removed.

The deck is 36" high and consists of steps and two 36" x 36" platforms at different heights.

Replace decking below door.

Build rails all the way around.

Problem: Ditch work needed behind house. Lots of erosion. See photos.
Solution: Here are a few ideas- Dig a big ditch behind the house. Build a retaining wall, Put down some mulch or do something to stop erosion.

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Client requests a porch roof for shade and to keep off snow and rain. Carol is in a wheel chair.
Solution: Once the new ramp is built, build a "shed-style" roof with plenty of pitch, kind of like the one at Eddie and Gail Bowens.

Problem: Bad roof leaks . Clients catch water in buckets whenever it rains.
Solution:
The roof leaks for several reasons. First, the metal is old (circa 1970?) and repeated applications of aluminum- tar and other products have not solved the leak problem. The other reason is that the pitch is too flat, a 1/12 pitch on either side. The steep part of the roof is an 8/12 pitch.

Roof square footage is approx. 700 square feet. There are two 16" x 16" masonry chimneys and one 1 1/2/" plumbing vent. There is an electrical weatherhead on the side.

The solution to this problem would involve re-framing the existing roof on top of what is already there. Installing new rafters from the peak to the outside walls would create a 4/12 pitch. Then add perlins and metal. There are a lot of details to work out, and the rafters would have to be 22 feet long (I- joists?) and/or possibly supported by a knee wall above the interior, load bearing wall.

It looked like the framing of the existing roof and walls is good enough to support the extra weight of the build- over, but you should probably get a second opinion.

This would cost a lot but might be worth is because the house is otherwise in fairly decent condition, and re-doing the roof would make it last a lot longer.

I have made a crude drawing of the idea which I will put in the file.

Get an experienced roofer with lots of framing experience to quote it.

Problem: Deck in rough shape. Plywood floor in deteriorating condition.
Solution: The existing deck is 10'x12'. Tear down and rebuild a smaller deck, maybe 6'x8 or so.Bring the deck height up to the threshold. Slope deck away from house, build steps or discuss ramp with clients, due to their limited mobility. Deck height is between 12 - 18". There are no rails currently, and they are not required by code, but you have elderly residents so you might consider building rails.

Problem: Hole on the side where you go down to the basement
Solution: Get margaret to show you the secret passageway to the basement. Looks like a rat may have chewed this, fix with pt wood of varying thickness

Problem: Once the roof is fixed, insulation, drywall , and paint will be needed in the living room and other parts of the house.
Solution:
Move furniture. Lay down a drop cloth. Install dust protection. Demo old drywall, take to landfill. Install new drywall, tape, mud, sand, paint.

I did not accurately measure the square footage but it is at least 400

Problem: Margaret has removed the insulation in the bedrooms because it was soaked from leaks. Bare 2x4's exposed.
Solution:
Once the roof is fixed, install some insulation, drywall, etc.

Move furniture. Lay down a drop cloth. Install dust protection. Demo old drywall, take to landfill. Install new drywall, tape, mud, sand, paint.

I did not accurately measure the square footage but it is at least 400

Problem: Old linoleum flooring is worn out throughout the home. Thresholds are odd heights.
Solution:
If it does not interfere with any door openings, install new flooring over the old. Vinyl plank flooring will probably work best because the floor is a bit uneven.

Note- i do not know what the old linoleum is made of, sometimes the really old stuff can contain asbestos.There are at least two layers/.

Some custom thresholds may be needed

Problem: CO and Smoke Detectors needed
Solution: Install a battery powered unit

Problem: Electrical problems. Meter box rusted out on the bottom. Short in bathroom. Outlets pulled out of wall. Some outlets do not work. Bad light in kitchen. Rusty hot water heater.
Solution: Have an electrician come out and make it safer

Problem: Wall and floor damage in living room due to roof leak. The chimney has been removed, but the hole in the side of the roof where it was was not fixed. Mold on drywall.
Solution:
The first step is to repair the roof with a sheet of 5v metal. Loosen screws on the metal around the damaged area. You may have to remove a sheet. Repair framing and perlins or plywood. Cut a sheet of metal and slide it under. Replace screws.

  

After the roof leak is fixed then start fixing the wall. Remove drywall. Use mold protection. Remove wet or damaged insulation. Repair and/or scab any damaged framing. Add insulation where missing. Some floor repair will need to be done.

Put down a drop cloth. Tape and mud drywall. Sand using dust protection. Paint.

Problem:
No heat. Judy's woodstove chimney has been removed. The woodstove has been scooted over to one side.

Judy has a propane fireplace, and there is a copper propane line going through the wall, but nothing was hooked up. There was a 100 lb propane tank at her house that was not hooked up, and I don't know if there was any propane in it.
Solution:
The best idea is probably to install a mini- split or other low maintenance heating system. Judy is not in good enough physical shape to mess with firewood, and the propane tank would be hard for her to handle. The propane truck may not be able to make it up to Judy's.

Note that this is a big house, and some rooms are not lived in. Some attempt could be made to close off some rooms and make the home more efficient before a heater is installed

Problem: No hot water. The existing hot water heater has no power to it, and I do not think it has been wired properly. The heater is rusty around the elements.
Solution:
Remove old water heater and Install a smaller one . The wire that is hooked up to the existing water heater may be good enough to re- use on a new, smaller, one-element water heater. It would be best to consult an electrician on this, have him take a look when he comes out to look at the other electrical problems.

A small, one- element water heater would work fine here. Lowe's sells a 19- gallon one for about $350.

Problem:
Water system needs a lot of improvement. It is a gravity fed system. She has water but the pressure is very low at her kitchen sink. Pressure is ok, however, in other parts of the house. There could be clogs in some lines or an air lock.

Reservoir is in poor condition, and gets water from the overflow of another reservoir.

Judy's water line is not buried very deeply. In some places, including her driveway, it is on top of the ground.
Solution:
The existing gravity fed system uses a spring to fill 2 reservoirs- one is Judy's and the other feeds two houses below (Judy says these homes are unoccupied). We opened Judy's reservoir lid (concrete), and looked inside- It was full of water, but there was a lot of plant growth and the water appeared stagnant. It did not appear to be flowing in or out. There was also a 1 1/2" gap on one side of the larger concrete lid. Roots had grown into it.

The ideal situation for Judy would be a well because her health may not allow her to do maintenance on the system- clean spring, reservoir, unclog lines, etc.

The existing system could be made to work- it would involve weed eating and brush cutting around the spring and reservoirs, inspecting and possibly digging up the spring to make sure the water supply is safe and flowing out.

Judy's reservoir should then be cleaned out ; it may leak and may need repairs. Use some bleach when cleaning, then get the water going to it . This may involve bypassing the other reservoir- Judy says nobody uses it- It might be easier to get a new plastic reservoir-

A new water line will be needed, and probably a booster pump.

There is a shut-off valve under the house on the end of the house where the meter box is.

Problem: No steps out back. 24" off ground
Solution:
Build a 4'x4' deck with steps. Handrails are not required by code but may be needed because of Judy's health

Check for underground lines before digging, Slope deck away from house.

Make a concrete landing for steps.

Problem: Floor damage under refrigerator. not sure how bad, Judy says there is a hole.
Solution: Remove fridge. remove bad plywood. Cut bigger hole. waytech for pi[pes and wires, there may be some directly below the floor. Scab joists, add insulation, install new plywood.

Problem: Bathroom #1- commode ok. Tub- not used (no hot water). Pressure is adequate in the bathroom sink.
Solution: Get the hot water heater fixed . Clean out stuff from tub and then see if the tub and associated plumbing works- Judy says pressure is low.

Problem: Bathroom #2- commode is usable. Float may be messed up. Adequate pressure in sink. Weak floors. Tub has been removed. No light- existing light looks like it shorted out at some point. Outlet /switch box pulled out of wall here.
Solution:
Remodel needed. Note that there is another bathroom is slightly better shape- it should probably be fixed first so she will have one decent bathroom.

Work here would involve subfloor repair, new flooring, new tub, and plumbing.

Problem: Mystery leak. wet floor. could be plumbing leak in wall. Judy knows where it is.
Solution: remove drywall on one side of the wall and diagnose further

Problem: Lots of trash and clutter inside and outside the home
Solution: Big clean-up. Bag up trash and recycling and take to the dump. Use dump # and go to the landfill with construction trash.

Problem: Home is not energy efficient. It is hard to heat because of its size.
Solution:
Judy closes off some rooms in winter to make the place easier to heat, but it is a big house for just one person. The belly liner of the trailer section seems intact so there is some floor insulation. Not sure how much , if any, insulation was installed during the roof overbuild. There is a gable vent on one side, you could remove that and look in there to see how much insulation is in the ceiling. If possible, add insulation to the ceiling to increase efficiency.  

There is a window in the bathroom that may be damaged, I did not look closely.

Judy suggested a French door in one opening so she can close off part of the house. It would have to be a special size because the opening is shorter than normal.

Problem: No smoke or CO detectors
Roof leaks
Solution:
The long term solution is a new metal roof. Roof is flat so a gable truss system or shed roof will be needed.

A short- term solution will be to apply "thru- the Roof" caulk around all penetrations and replace the damaged gutters (trailer style). Remove the 1/4" screws holding the gutters. You will need a utility knife to remove gunk from the screws heads.Wear safety glasses. Remove screws and old "gutters". clean area with wire brush. apply a bead of caulk and install new "gutters."

The short term solution price and materials are listed below.

Problem: Monitor heater needs work. Donna says "O " rings are needed.
Solution: Bullman heating and air?

Problem: There are a lot of flower beds surrounding the house choked out by weeds.
Solution: Weed, mulch, plant flowers. Get Donna involved.

Problem: Front steps too high (10" rise). The storm door is hard to open because there is no deck, just steps, and the storm door opens out.
Solution:
Tear down steps. Build back a 4'x4'deck with rails. Use CHC and code guidelines. Make a stringer landing pad. Build steps on the side, leading towards the driveway/ parking area. You will have to tear out part of the flower bed. Make a path to the parking area.

Please talk to the landlord before you start digging post holes to determine the location of underground water lines, pipes, etc

Problem: Back deck in rough condition. It is functional but has some problems. It slopes towards the house, and is bolted to the house. Framing is not sufficient.
Solution: Tear down and rebuild. The existing deck is 16'3" x 7'.A smaller deck would be fine. Build using CHC and code guidelines. Suggested size 6' x 8'. Make a stringer landing pad. Build steps. The deck is 30" high so code says build rails. Talk to landlord before you dig, she will probably know where the underground water lines, drain pipes, electric lines, etc. are.

Problem: Existing ramp is too steep and has a little ramp that is in front of the door that is also too steep. Ramp is made of plywood and is starting to deteriorate.
Solution: Build new ramp. It would have to be pretty long (over 30 feet) and there are a lot of options on how to design it. I would recommend an engineer from Independent living come out and work with John, because he has some specific requests regarding its design (he built the original one).

Problem:
There is lots of trash under the trailer. Insulation has fallen out. Water pools under house. Lots of trash under deck.

Landlord cut a hole in the underpinning to repair a leaking pipe and the pipes could freeze in colder weather. The underpinning (plastic, Fake- rock style), is mostly in good shape but there are a few holes here and there.
Solution:
Clean out junk from underneath the deck . Open crawlspace door and start cleaning out the space under the trailer.

Call landlord since you will be working around the water line. The water line is near the access door and is covered by pink insulation, so be careful not to break it as you work under there ( it is PVC). There is a hose bib stub-out.

  

Haul junk to landfill. Rake out underneath. If you find any problems like leaks report them to the landlord and to CHC. Install vapor barrier. Fix holes in underpinning.

Problem: Cabinets in rough shape
Solution: replace cabinets

Problem: Kitchen sink drain leak. Donna has got it propped up with a stick to keep it from leaking.
Solution: replace some drain parts

Problem: Commodes in both bathrooms, though functional, have some issues.
Solution:
There are two bathrooms.

The first one is 20 square feet. In this bathroom, the toilet leaks when flushed. There is a leak between the flush box and bowl. You could try tightening the bolts, but you may have to replace the bolts and gaskets.

In the second bathroom, the commode will not shut off. Try adjusting the float, you may have to replace some stuff.

Problem: New flooring requested in living room.
Solution: install 154 square feet of laminate flooring

Problem: Cold air can come in under the front door. Door in rough shape.
Solution: Remove old door, repair area around threshold , install new door. Re-use knobs, they are good. Door opens out , left hinge. I did not measure the door height and width.

Problem: Several windows are broken and taped up. No storm windows on house. Wall damage around windows (single-pane).
Solution: The long term solution will be a new roof with overhang and window replacement. Jerry at Mars Hill hardware can order double pane replacement windows. Call him and he will tell you exactly how to measure them.

Problem: CO/ smoke detector not working. She has taken the batteries out.
Solution: install new batteries.

Problem:
Foundation problems. Sherlena's front porch seems to be pulling away and sinking down. There are some big cracks.

According to Sherlena, this problem has been happening for 15 years. Some cracks have been patched but she says the problem has gotten worse in the last 3 years, and new cracks have formed.
Solution:
Metal porch supports may have lead paint on them. Existing porch measures 6'2" x 9'2". Support porch roof. Tear off concrete/block/brick porch. This will be a big demo job.

Some foundation work may be needed on the corner of the house where the porch is.

Rebuild a pressure treated deck in the place of the old porch. It will need steps and rails (deck height is approx. 42"

Problem: No gutters on part of the back side of the house. Water is pooling up back there and getting around the house and in the crawlspace.
Solution:
Install gutters, downspout, drainpipe. 20' is needed. The roof overhangs the fascia by quite a bit, so some carpentry will be needed to build out the correct overhang for gutters.

Eli (son in law) installed a French Drain back here that seems to work, but another section of drainpipe is needed .The gutter drainpipe should be seperate from the french drain pipe.

Problem: Gutters have not been cleaned in a long time and are falling apart. Water sits on the back side of the house and could cause damage.
Solution: Remove front gutters. Just leave these off because client cannot clean gutters easily. Replace back gutters and make sure the drain system works. Joe Willis at Mars Hill Hardware is a good gutter man. Talk to Janice about the importance of keeping the gutters clean, maybe get her a good ladder (hers is sketchy) so she can get a young relative to keep the gutters clean.

Problem: The crawlspace door is falling apart . Cold air and varmints could come in the basement.
Solution: Rebuild crawlspace door. This will require removing the door which is 30 1/2" x 52". CAUTION: door has some lead paint on it.Wet the area with a hose, wear a dust mask and other protective gear, and haul the old door to the landfill. You will have to remove the frame, too, and re attach pressure treated material to block.

Problem: Aluminum siding damaged by rock
Solution: There is a small hole in the siding and the corner is dented up, water could get in and damage the wood beneath. Make a piece of flashing to protect the area.

Problem: Roof leaking in multiple places. Around the dormer may need attention while replacing roof.
Solution: Janice showed me where the ceiling tiles were stained and water drips. Replace with new metal.

Problem: Trim and paint is needed on the front porch and around the back door.
Solution:
Warning: Tests indicated the presence of lead paint on the front porch. the back door area was not tested.

Painting the front porch will require scraping which will release dangerous lead dust. Do not do without proper training and safety equipmant.

The back door area might could be caulked and painted without scraping

Problem: Ceiling light does not work. Wiring suspected.
Solution: Check bulbs. Check switch. Check fixture. Check wiring in attic.

Problem: Home could probably use more insulation. I did not inspect the attic but there is an access hole.
Solution:
Get a 6 foot step ladder and get Janice to show you where to go up into the attic. If reasonable, install some insulation to increase energy efficiency.

The cheapest way to get good insulation is to rent a blower and use the green-guard blown insulation. It is a lot cheaper than the fiberglass bats.

Problem:
Rocks have fallen on the back side of the house. One damaged the siding but has been moved,

Lots of rocks are still back there that she wants gone.
Solution: The easiest thing to do is chuck 'em in the creek, but you better check with the Town of Marshall about this.

Problem: Basement/crawlspace has got a lot of junk in it
Solution: Cleanup job. There is a lot of old paint. Contact landfill regarding disposal. Janice does not have a truck so she has a tough time getting rid of stuff.

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install battery unit

Problem: Siding dirty
Solution: Pressure wash. Hand clean area where the hole in the siding is to avoid trapping water behind siding.

Problem: Area around trailer is grown up. There are some vehicles that are covered with weeds.
Solution: Weed eat. Consult Jack to see what he wants weed-eated.

Problem:
Water system questionable. Main water supply line to house is the old style black plastic pipe with metal hose clamps. The system, according to Jack, is a gravity water system that fills up a reservoir with a pump. Location and condition of the reservoir is unknown. Pipes are laying on the ground under the trailer and are not insulated. No underpinning.

The condition of the plumbing in the home is unknown. More than likely, the pipes are the old style polybutyl, which could freeze and bust.
Solution: Determine location of reservoir and spring. Clear around the sites and inspect for safety.

Problem: No water pressure
Solution: Need new pump and tank, according to plumber hired by Friendly Ave week of July 29, 2019

Problem: Front deck and steps in bad condition.Client cannot climb steps. Ramp needed.
Solution: Tear down old deck. Dig 4 holes. Install and plumb posts with concrete. Diagonal brace. Frame 4x4 deck. Frame approx 12' long ramp. Make concrete landings for steps and ramp. build steps and rails. make walkway to parking area.

Problem: Back deck leans towards house. Loose rails.
Solution: Replace back deck.

Problem: Larger bathroom needs lots of work. Hole in floor. Commode does not work right, no water to it. Old carpet covers floor. Roof leaks thru loose ceiling light fixture. Client cannot get in tub. No water to sink.
Solution:
A full bathroom remodel is needed. Clients have another bathroom, but it is not usable at this time. Priority should be placed on making one bathroom (this one)safe and usable.

This bathroom is 7' x 4'7". (33 square feet)

At the very least, remove the commode and remove the old carpet. Cut out damaged subfloor and reinforce joists. Install new plywood and flooring. Replace commode. Check water supply to commode and replace supply line if needed.

A full remodel would consist of the above plus a new, walk- in shower, new sink, new faucets, new light fixture, fan, and drywall work. etc. Price below given for the minimum repair in the paragraph above.

Leak in roof should be fixed before a remodel is attempted to prevent further ceiling and floor damage.

Problem: Hole in floor around rear exit
Solution: Remove some floor covering (linoleum and carpet)and cut a hole around the damaged area. shore up joists and install some new plywood.

Problem: Roof leak. Stains are visible mainly in the larger bathroom, clients say that it is leaking around the light fixture. Another place is by the kitchen sink, down the walls.
Solution: The first thing to try is patching- get a bucket of "thru the roof" or other caulk and apply around penetrations. Clean gutters.

Problem:
Second bathroom needs work. it is 32" x 7'1".

Commode not flushed. Jack says drains are not working for commode or shower. No water in commode tank. Hot and cold work for walk- in shower unit.
Solution:
Diagnose drain problem. Jack mentioned a relative that may do this. Repair drain clog, if that is what it is, and try to get water to the commode to flush it.

Sink in adjacent room is in unknown condition

Clients have another bathroom, but Joann cannot get in the tub.

The other bathroom is larger and probably should be fixed first so that clients will have one working bathroom

Problem: Front door has no window, hole covered by plastic. No lock.
Solution: Replace door. It is a trailer style door with an aluminum flange. Call discount Mobile Home Supply and see if they have a 32" x 76" door. Right hinge, opens out.

Problem: Heating problems. They have a heat / AC pump but it has a bad bearing, according to Jack. It was pretty hot in there when I visited. Homeowners' only current source of heat are unvented 30 lb propane cylinders with a construction- type unit that screws to the top. There is another small, unvented propane heater but it is not hooked up.
Solution: Mini split or other safe heater

Problem: No underpinning. Some insulation missing under trailer, plumbing could freeze
Solution:
Install recycled metal underpinning with vinyl channel. It would be best to fix plumbing problems first but a good start could be made. Install vapor barrier.

Client has several sheets of roof metal stored underneath the trailer, it may be usable for this project.

Problem: Weed eating and mowing needed as of assessment time .Old door and other trash needs to be hauled off
Solution: Josh has a good pickup truck. Some stuff may need to go to the landfill, use dump card #. Ask family about mower, weededater, etc.

Problem:
There are two major plumbing leaks, one in bathroom, one in kitchen.

The kitchen leak is under the sink area. Leaks are coming from a cluster of 1/2" polybutylene water lines. A steady mist is leaking out through several pin holes in the water lines. The mist feels hot. The homeowners were unaware of the leak, so it has been leaking for an unknown period of time.
Solution:
I suspect that the polybutylene water lines, circa 1978, froze at some point,causing the pipes to split and develop leaks. The trailer does not have very good insulation underneath, so more than likely the pipes will freeze again.

Replace all polybutylene water lines with PEX.

Problem:
Weak floor in front of bathtub.

An inspection underneath revealed a hot water mist spraying the floor from below. This has been happening for an unknown period of time.

This is a similar problem to the one in the kitchen- the 1/2" polybutylene water lines underneath the floor have several pin-holes that have sprayed water, causing a big white- mold spot and damage to the subfloor.
Solution:
Replace all polybutylene water lines with 1/2" PEX.

Floor will need to be replaced under the tub.Bathroom will have to be remodeled again, it was remodeled in Nov. 2015. You should be able to re-use the tub, surround, commode,flooring, etc.

Problem: Septic Issues. The drain pipe going to the septic tank, which is located to the left of the trailer, has been cut off. The drainage has been re-routed to a black corrugated drainpipe that leads out to the field below the trailer. I do not know if the drainpipe leads to a drain field or not. Josh said he did this because nothing was draining and he did not have the money to pump out the septic tank. Condition of existing drain field is unknown.
Solution:
Get a pro septic outfit to assess the situation and recommend a solution. They may need a new drain field.

Josh mentioned that there are a couple different septic systems on the property.

Problem: Weak floor in hallway near laundry machines.
Solution: Move washer and dryer. Remove floor covering and repair the subfloor. Cut out bad subfloor. Watch out for wires, water lines, and ductwork, they can be directly under the subfloor. reinforce joists, add insulation if needed, Install new sub floor, install flooring

Problem: weak floor in Tara's bedroom
Solution: Remove floor covering, cut out subfloor, watching for wires, pipes, and duct work. Reinforce joists and install new plywood. Homeowners can handle flooring.

Problem: weak floor in second bedroom
Solution: remove furniture, floor covering, cut out old plywood, being careful of ductwork, wires, and pipes. reinforce joists and install new plywood. Homeowners can replace flooring

Problem: Back doorway in poor condition. Back steps are unstable.
Solution: Remove old steps and build a new, free standing 4'x4' deck with rails, steps and a concrete landing. make sure it slopes away from the house, and install diagonal bracing. Remove back door. Make any needed repairs to the subfloor. Make new jams for the door ( the door has been cut at the top but is reusable). Install new strike plate and lockset. Install new door. caulk, paint and trim.

Problem: Broken windows- living room
Solution:
The two most urgently needed replacements are between the living room and front porch . There are two that are 54" high and 31 1/2" wide.

Remove old windows , make sure openings are in reasonable condition, install new ones.

Note- windows are under a covered porch.

Check with Jerry at Mars Hill hardware about ordering windows

Problem:
Josh has low water pressure. There is enough to shower with, and he is getting by, but we suspect a major leak. There is a lot of water flowing around the corner of the house, on the outside. Mark A. and I dug around but could not find the pipe. The area is extremely overgrown and needs to be mowed or weed eated before more digging and investigating can be done.

Josh's theory of the apple trees growing roots around the line may of may not be relevant, someone has dug around the trees but I saw no pipes, leaking or otherwise. Area was dry.

Josh shares a reservoir with some neighbors. It is located on a neighbor's property above him. Josh can put you in touch with the landowner. Mark. A. and I got permission and looked at the reservoir. It is in poor condition and had no visible overflow. Weeds and multiflora rose were grown up around it.
Solution:
Mow and weed eat yard. Grass is high so a bushog could work here. Do some more digging and try to find the leak. It may take some digging equipment .

Mow/ weedeat around reservoir and spring. Look at the spring situation and make sure it is safely covered.

Replace broken line if you can find the leak.

Problem: Leak between porch roof and trailer roof due to no flashing
Solution: Remove mini- trailer gutters directly above porch roof. Do this by removing the sheet metal screws and cutting off the gutters above the porch. Install 1/2" x10" "L" shaped metal flashing by sliding one end under the sheet metal that folds over the top of the trailer roof. Re- install new, 1" roof screws and caulk. Fasten the other end of the flashing down with some roof screws as well, going thru the flashing and into the ribs of the porch roof.

Problem:
The exterior walls of the house are damaged in several places. It is mostly due to water splashing up on the house due to no gutters, a roof leak, and termite damage.

The home is sided with a fake- brick siding which has been stuccoed on. Underneath is wire lath and a skim coat of cement. There is no vapor barrier, so the brick stuff may have to come off. This can be done gradually, and Caroline seems willing to do the work.
Solution: This will be something that can be worked on gradually, once it is decided, by removing some brick, how badly damaged the walls are and what kind of siding will be used to replace it. Concentrate on the French Door areas first.

Problem:
Roof on back side is in bad shape. Leaks around chimney. Soft place on roof. Rafter tails rotten. Soffit bad.

Roof framing looks solid here according to an attic inspection.
Solution:
Have custom-made flashing, tarps, plywood, metal, and other materials on site. Tear off shingles and throw in dumpster or trailer, or at least on an old tarp on the ground. Remove bad plywood. Repair and replace rafter tails. Install sub fascia and fascia, Replace bad plywood. Install drip edge. Install vapor barrier. Install metal. Flash chimney. Carl Haas has offered to make custom flashing for CHC purposes, but you need to give him a lot of notice.

Have the tarp set up so that you can cover the roof at the end of the day.

The roof is 850 square feet.There is a big chimney.

Problem: Gutters are needed on the home to minimize future siding damage.
Solution: The rafter tails on the front side have been cut off (plumb cuts). The new metal does not overhang the rafter tails evenly, so a creative solution will be needed to install some kind of sub fascia and/or finished fascia. Then install gutters on this side. The opposite side needs lots of work on the rafter tails, roof repair, etc. before gutters can be hung there.

Problem: Old French doors damaged (2 sets). Wall and header damaged due to termites and water.
Solution:
The first thing to do is talk to Caroline, and, if possible, her dad. They have thought about it and have a plan for this . Here is how I understand it:

The main entrance to the home at this time is on the right as you face the front of the house. The exterior French doors leading into the room are damaged and lead into a room with a lot of mold on the ceiling due to a leaking roof. Caroline wants to remove this door and build a wall here with a window (she does not yet have the window).

Caroline wants to establish the main entrance to the house in the center, where an old French Door is. This door should be removed and replaced with a new French door which Caroline has purchased and is on site.

Problem is, the new door is wider than the old door, so the rough opening will have to be wider. Also, there is water and termite damage to the header and framing around the existing door. You will have to remove some brick siding material, remove the old door, repair and replace wall framing, and build a new header and reframe the door opening.

Check for lead paint on the inside of the house before demo begins. Plywood and tar paper the walls around the door. Install window wrap.

Problem: The electrical weather head , which goes through the roof, is leaning pretty hard (see photos)
Solution: From the inside you can see that

Problem: Commode is wobbly , may leak around base
Solution: Since the house is on a concrete slab, you will need to pull the commode and make some repairs to the concrete around the flange. Caroline thinks that the flange bolts will not hold because the concrete is busted around there. Use some kind of high strength concrete patch. You may have to get a flange repair kit. Install a new wax ring and re-install commode

Problem:
Something is leaking, either the drain lines or water lines, in front of the house. When I was there, Caroline and her dad were trying to figure it out. The phone company had just installed a ground rod and it looked like they had driven it through a drainpipe or water line. Caroline had dug it up partway. The pipes are under the ground on the outside of the house.

At assessment time she had the water cut off to the kitchen, but still had water to the bathroom.
Solution: Caroline'e dad, Michael, agreed to fix this problem over the weekend, so check up to make sure it got done.

Problem: The floors in every room in the house are damaged. There are big holes in the bathroom and bedrooms. Other places have fallen a foot or less to the ground.
Solution: Rebuild entire floor

Problem: Chimney is not safe. Amy said there was a chimney fire two winters ago in which the fire dept had to come and tear out the wall to extinguish the fire. The wall is still torn out and the chimney has been stuccoed back together, there are some bad cracks visible from outside. Stove pipe is rusty and does not fit into the chimney very well.
Solution: new stainless steel chimney

Problem: Roof leaks especially around chimney. The roof metal looks like it has not been replaced since the home was built. A big oak fell on the porch years ago and the roof is visibly dented.
Solution: New roof

Problem: The house has a lot of clutter inside and out
Solution: Big clean-up. Rent dumpster (if Griffin can deal with the road) and haul stuff off. Amy says she can get a truck.

Problem: Hot water heater, although functional and standing, has a big hole under it. The tub has the same problem. Commode does not work properly if it rains a lot.
Solution: Completely remodel bathroom

Problem: Kitchen is in bad shape. Refrigerator does not work and has floor damage beneath. Freezer works but has fallen through the floor. Cabinet has fallen through floor.
Solution: rebuild kitchen

Problem: Exterior door in kitchen will not open all the way and is damaged due to a break in

On the downhill side of the house you can see a sizable stream of water that is running underneath the porch and one corner of the home.I thought a pipe may be broken but since Amy has water with adequate pressure at this time, we agreed that the source may be an underground spring that surfaces underneath the house.
Solution:
Not sure exactly how to solve this- there is an abandoned well house right above the home, water may be coming from there.

Drainage is poor around the home and water sits for a long time . Amy says that the home has actually flooded when culverts above got stopped up.

Problem: Septic questionable. Amy said that there was a septic tank, but that there may not be a drain field. She says that when it rains a lot the commode will not flush properly.
Solution: install drain field, new tank?

Problem: Plumbing leak around toilet reported by Shadyside 7/12/19
Solution: Wanda called 7/30/19 to state this issue has worsened. Hired Autry plumbing to take a look tomorrow 7/31/19

Problem: Gutters needed on lower side of home
Solution:
Install gutters. Make the middle high with a downspout on either end of the trailer. Make sure the gutters drop 1/2" every 10 feet. Make one gutter fit into another by trimming the top of one. Caulk and rivet. Install two downspout outlet tubes. Install downspouts. install downspout to drainpipe couplings. Install black corrugated pipe to direct water to a downhill location.

All materials for this job are on site either in Jim's back yard or in his shed. The only thing you may need is an oversized downspout outlet tube and a tube of Lexel caulk.

Talk to Jim about finding some Vols. for this job, there are some guys at his church that seem willing. Carl H & Carl B. would also be good on this.

Problem: Soffit needed to keep out bees and varmints.
Solution:
Soffitt job has been started, so there is a pattern to follow. Vinyl soffit material, J Channel and F channel is on site, stored in Jim's yard under plastic in two big cardboard boxes. There is also a coffee can with roof nails that will be needed.

Ted Roberts, Jim's neighbor, has volunteered to help install soffitt. He recently had hand surgery, however, so it may be a few weeks before he can get out there. (he has a ladder). I also talked to a young fellow from Laurel Branch church who was weed eating that said the church could help. If you talk to Jim he could coordinate some vols. to come out.

If needed I can come out and get the crew started, once they get going they should be able to do it themselves.

Problem: Need smoke detectors and CO detector
Solution: install battery operated smoke detectors and CO detector

Problem: Roof leak and lack of overhangs are causing walls and floor to rot out in the master bedroom.
Solution: Install a new metal roof with 8-10" over hang.

Problem: Electrical problem. Outlets are dead in a bedroom. Lights still work. Breaker is not tripped. Latasha has some electrical knowledge and has done some wiring but cannot figure it out
Solution: Get an electrician to look at it

Problem: Wall covering needed where remodeling has taken place. Corner of living room.
Water comes in the back side of the house. Problem discovered by volunteers summer 2019.
Solution: Damaged flooring has been repaired, but water still can come through into the basement. Best long term solution will involve some kind of drainage improvement on the back side of the house. Heavy equipment may be needed to move dirt away from the house, which is piled up against the back side.

Problem: A few spongy deckboards remain
Solution: At site visits the week of 7/8/19, discovered there are still a few weak deckboards that could be replaced.

Problem: Need kool seal on roof again. Shadyside did but it rained too soon so it has to be repainted.
Solution: Kool Seal

Problem: Flooring peeling in kitchen
Solution: Demo and replace with new, high quality, moisture resistant, laminate

Problem: Roof leak
Solution: Nathan called today to report a roof leak he says he was unaware of. It caused damage to floor and now there's a hole. Jake should reassess.

Problem: Bathroom needed painting
The yard needed some maintenance and he bay window needed some TLC. Outside of the window looked rough and on the inside, there was mold on the bay window.
Land slopes toward home, water is penetrating beneath and causing moisture problems
Solution: Refer to ASP manual for digging drainage ditch full length + of home, near bottom of slope, sort of adjacent to deck and divert water around sides of home.

Problem: Beneath the home is moist and lacking insulation. There's also subfloor damage.
Solution: Lay vapor barrier then investigate extent of subfloor damage and whether repairs are needed. Add insulation.

Problem: HVAC unit has quit
Solution: Amanda was told the compressor could be replaced for $2,500 but only a one year warranty, if the whole unit was replaced it'd be $5,000 and have 10 year warranty. She can't afford either of these repairs. This is an electric unit that serves as both AC in summer and (their only) heat source in winter time.

Problem: When Bennie gets out of the hospital he will need a ramp to get in and out of the house, at least temporarily
Solution: Sonia's co- workers have agreed to build him a ramp soon

Problem: Second exit to home ( sliding glass door) is blocked by boxes, shelves, etc. After you go out that door, it goes into a room that is totally cluttered. It would be almost impossible to get out of in an emergency. Exterior door in poor condition. Deck here needs work.
Solution:
Remove trash, organize, donate, etc.. talk to Bennie, he has some collectibles in here

Focus on establishing an emergency exit. Once entry/exit is established, replace the door and fix or replace the deck. Deck is 4'x4', 30" high.

Problem: Roof leaks.
Solution:
This is a 3/12 pitch with asphalt 3-tab shingles. Some of the plywood is exposed, and there is a hole in the roof that is visible from the top, on the edge of the addition.

The addition, although a 1/12 pitch roof, has shingles. Shingles on the trailer section of the roof are 25 years old. The addition appears to have shingles of a similar age.

Recommended metal roof on the trailer part, membrane on the flat part.

Rent a dumpster and remove the old shingles. Repair any damaged roof sheathing.

Remove skylights and roof over, they are leaking.

Problem: There are some holes in the floor and weak places, especially in the kitchen. At one point Bennie fell through the floor. Most places have been covered by scraps of plywood, but this still creates a tripping hazard.
Solution: Remove plywood scraps. Determine plywood thickness, my guess is 5/8". Cut away square sections of subfloor , being careful of HVAC, wires, and pipes (set saw depth). Check the condition of the framing beneath. Shore up framing by sistering on 2 by material to existing joists. Replace insulation if needed. Replace plywood. If time and finances permit replace floor covering.

Problem: Threshold of main doorway is damaged. Door is in rough shape but usable, door knob is is good shape but strike plate is messed up
Solution: Remove old door, fix threshold, install a new door, reinstall knob. door slab measures 33" x 79", with no screen or storm.The existing door opens out with hinges on the right, but the new one should be the opposite- opens out, hinges on left.

Problem: Homeowner says Outlets do not work in one room (unused).
Solution: Have an electrician look at it

Problem: Siding is water damaged because water has been running down the side of the trailer for quite some time.
Solution:
The siding is Medium Density Fiberboard. The bottom edges are in bad shape. The worst place is around the main entrance and door threshold, , where the new ramp will be built. The existing siding resembles T- 111, which is probably what you should replace it with. Remove bad siding, repair any framing damage, replace some insulation if needed, install new siding, caulk, and paint.

Warning this could be a "can of worms" depending on how much rot has occurred behind the damaged siding.

Problem: Underpinning needs work.
Solution:
Weed-eat area, a lot of poison ivy is growing up around the home. Replace almost all the underpinning, some may be reusable but a lot of it has holes and most of it has fallen over.

Consider using recycled roofing metal for underpinning.

Problem: Bath tub needs a new faucet, old one uses vice- grips to turn knobs. Skylight leaks.
Solution: install new tub faucet, see photos

Problem: Second bathroom needs a new tub faucet.Big tub- see photo. Cleanup needed.
Solution: install new faucet ,clean up tub

Problem: Home is clutttered. The addition (the one that is closest to the road, with a flat roof), is the most cluttered and blocks a second access to the home. A bedroom is full of stuff and Sonia wants to clean it out.
Solution:
Clean up , donate, throw stuff away. Consider renting a dumpster.(Griffin Waste Service).

Make sure to consult with homeowners about what stays and what goes, Bennie has a number of collectibles

Problem: There is an addition whose floor was framed and walls were built, but that was as far as they got. The floor is sagging at this point and the whole thing needs to come down because it creates a safety hazard. There is also a big pile of boards in the yard, some of which are nailed together and have nails sticking out. Again, a safety hazard.
Solution: Demolish addition. De- nail boards that are reusable. Make neat stacks of de-nailed lumber. Haul the rest to the landfill. Work safely and wear good footwear , gloves, and glasses. Consider getting a dumpster.

Problem: Weed eating and other yard work is needed.
Solution: The underpinning and other repairs cannot be done till the place gets cleaned up. There is lots of poison ivy, so stay away if you are allergic and use protective gear.Weed eat around perimeter.

Problem: There is a large amount of trash around the house, especially on the porch. Work cannot begin till the place is cleaned up. Client has no car so cannot haul off. Old sofas, garbage bags, etc. Storage shed on property full of junk.
Solution: Haul stuff to Hot Springs Collection center or landfill, or rent a dumpster if Griffin is willing to bring one up there (4wd road).

Problem: Floors throughout house are weak or missing. Scraps of plywood are on top of the damaged floor. Bad hole in bedroom, only covered by carpet.
Solution: Remove old subfloor. Replace or repair damaged floor framing. Install new subfloor. I would guess 3/4 of the entire floor in the house is bad.

Problem: Electrical safety issues. Home runs on temporary power pole outside. Wires are jury- rigged into the house.
Solution: Complete electrical upgrade

Problem: Bathroom floor in bad shape. Daylight visible through floor behind commode. Soft place in front of tub.
Solution: Complete bathroom remodel

Problem: Porch is full of old couches and other trash. Holes in porch floor.
Solution: Clean off porch. Jack up porch roof and replace porch floor

Problem: Back door is not a safe exit
Siding is painted MDF (press- board). Some of it is busted out and has suffered water damage.
Solution: The worst side is the one where the main entrance is. Replace siding on this part of the house (160 sft. needed). Repair framing if needed (bad place near commode wall). Replace with T111 plywood. Caulk and paint.

Problem: Edge of roof leaks . Roof boot missing for plumbing vent
Solution: Remove a piece of metal. Install a piece of plywood. Install boot. Caulk. 3"-4" plumbing vent.

Problem: Low water pressure
Solution: Amy says that there are some broken pipes up around the reservoir, which is in a holler above the house. Several other homes are served by the same reservoir, and it sounded like folks in the community were going to take care of this problem themselves.

Problem: Wilma's main entrance, the one to the left of the house as you face the home from the parking area, has a deck that is wobbly. The deck is also sloping towards the house, which directs rain water toward the door threshold. Wilma says that she sometimes has to call the ambulance due to breathing difficulties, and the last time that they came out, EMS had a hard time getting her out to the ambulance because of the slick, unstable deck and the muddy terrain. Although Wilma and Howard can both walk, Wilma is requesting a ramp to make access to the home easier for her and others.
Solution:
Build a walkway out to the parking area.

Use a 4 foot level and a straight, 10 foot 2x4 to determine how much slope the ramp will need to have. The parking area is actually higher than the door threshold, so the walkway will have a very gradual slope. Code requires no more slope than 1 inch every foot. This should not be a problem here. Build the ramp to code. Install rails.

Steps and step rails here are in good shape and may be able to be removed and re-installled.

Consult Howard before digging here, he probably knows where the power lines, water lines, etc are

Problem: There is an unused bedroom that need a lot of work. There is a hole in the floor in the corner, and the carpet is old and should be replaced.
Solution:
Care will have to be taken on this project to avoid dust because of Wilma's COPD. Fortunately the door can be shut and a towel put over the door. You could also take stuff in and out of an open window in this room.

Remove furniture and matresses. Remove trim. Remove old carpet. remove tacks, staples etc. Look at floor and find any weak spots. remove damaged subfloor and reinforce joists if needed, replace insulation if needed. Install new subfloor material (probably 5/8" plywood).

Install high quality laminate flooring and trim.

Problem: Rats have chewed holes in the walls
Solution:
According to the homeowners, the rats are mostly gone, they have trapped them and their dogs kill them. The holes need to be patched up though. Remove some sections of drywall, repair framing damage, install new insulation if needed, replace drywall, mud, tape, paint.

drywall here is thin- (3/8").

Fill in rat holes around the outside of the house, see underpinning project.

Howard will tell you where all the holes are.

Problem: Underpinning needs work
Solution:
The underpinning here was installed by Community Action Opportunities. There are two layers of foam board insulation. The bottoms of the underpinning pieces have started to deteriorate and there are some holes. At this point it looks like the pipes will not freeze but the underpinning should be patched up and protected from further damage.

One could install used roofing metal over the existing underpinning to provide protection from dogs, varmints, and weed eaters. Install vinyl underpinning channel with ground spikes. (Gentry's does not have spikes or channel). The metal will fit in the channel. Check plumb of metal with a torpedo or 2 foot level.

Fill in the holes that are visible dug by rats and other varmints.

Problem: Plumbing- Low water pressure in the kitchen sink. Washing machine hose leaks.
Solution:
The hot side in the sink has plenty of pressure but for some reason the cold does not. The problem could be in the faucet or the line may be clogged; you will probasbly have to go under the house because there are no shut off valves accessible under the sink.

The washing machine hose should be replaced, including a new gasket. I talked to Howard about this and it sounds like he can handle it.

Problem: Bathroom needs some work
Solution:
1) Repair hole in wall next to shower. It is currently covered by some boards. Cut a big enough hole in the drywall to see how bad the damage is and repair framing if needed. Drywall here is probably 3/8". Replace drywall, tape, mud, paint

2) Bath tub is not used. clients say that the faucet leaks. You will have to turn the water on to the tub to diagnose leaks, there could be some other ones in the water lines. Replace faucet of tub. See photos for correct faucet.

3)Clients request new commode, the old one does not flush right

Problem: Flooring is needed in Wilma's bedroom. Subfloor has been recently installed and is solid.
Solution: install 90 square feet of high quality laminate flooring.

Problem: Reported by CC Raleigh: need a better living situation for the small dog under the porch, and a new home for the rabbit that was left with Shirley (she does not want it).
Solution: A follow up group could discuss these suggested projects with Shirley.

Problem: Ronald is in desperate need of a ramp and deck repair. When I was there, I watched him go out the front door with his walker, throw it down the steps, and grab the wobbly handrail and make his way down the (busted) steps. Then he picked up his walker and got in his van , with some difficulty.
Solution: Establish a safe rear exit for Ronald while the work is being done. Tear down the old deck and steps. Build a new deck that is 4' x 6'. Build to code. Build a ramp. It will have to be 35-40 feet long.
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Eectrical work needed.
Solution:
Install light fixture in living room. Talk to Ronald and find the outlet that got covered up during drywall installation. Expose the box and add a cover. Fix boxes in corners of wall and ceiling. Kitchen light does not work (fluorescent, see photos). There is a lot of "tidying up" of loose wires, etc.

Ronald did not report any shorts but it looks pretty obvious that this stuff should be fixed.

A few years ago someone working on the roof put a screw through a wire in the ceiling and caused some electrical issues. As far as I know this problem has been fixed but whoever goes out to look at it should be aware that this happened.

Problem: Ronald's back door is taped shut and there is stuff blocking his exit.
Solution:
Ronald does not use this door, but he may need it as an emergency exit especially if work is done on his front deck and ramp. You will have to convince him to un- tape the door and move the stuff.

The back steps are in good condition, hand rail is sturdy here. Build another rail on the other side.

Problem: Well house is not accesssible. Ronald has not changed his water filter in a long time as a result and has dirty water.
Solution:
The existing well cover is dry- stacked cinder blocks, but there is no door. It is covered by old roof metal with blocks on top. Remove metal and blocks and inspect the well system for leaks, etc. You could build a pump house with the existing cinder blocks and add a roof, or get a " Fake Rock ". He just needs a way that he (or someone) could change the filter or work on the pump, etc.

Area was grown up at assessment time; weed-eat

Some insulation may be needed.

Problem: Gutters do not have down spouts or drainpipes hooked up to them.
Solution: Gutters seem like they are in good condition. To prevent erosion in the corners of the house, add downspouts and drain pipe. drainpipes should direct water to the downhill side.

Problem: Shelves needed in kitchen. Talk to Ronald about specific locations.
Solution:
Build Shelves. Use 1x12 material, screw brackets into studs.

Big Pine Log and Lumber should have 1x12's.

Problem: Unfinished drywall ceiling. Trim and paint needed, kitchen and living room.
Solution:
Install Baseboard (Ronald has 12- 8' pieces). Add some drywall screws where needed (there are some loose places). Tape and mud. Finish drywall and paint ceiling and walls. . Note- an electrical outlet got covered up. Ronald knows where it is. Find it and cut the drywall around it. Make sure splices are good, with wire nuts, and put a cover on the box. Install 1x4 trim on ceiling.

Ronald says he has 2 gal. of paint.

Problem: Ronald does not have much ventilation in his house. He would like to replace a fixed window with a bigger window that opens with a screen.
Solution: The window in question is to the left of the front entry. It is approx. 20" high x 45" wide. Order a new window and get it to the site. Remove old window. Remove some sheet metal. Create a bigger opening and install the new window. Watch for wires, there is an outlet below. Trim out with weatherproof materials.

Problem: Underpinning needs work, pipes could freeze.
Solution: Currently, Ronald has stone underpinning. A lot of it has been done already, and this might be a good low- skill project. There is a pile of stones on site. Consult with Ronald before starting work.

Problem: porch roof leaks
Solution:
An attempt could be made to patch the roof by applying roof caulk and replacing the nails with screws. However, the best solution will be new metal. The existing stuff is corrugated metal and it is pretty thin.

The roof is 2 / 12 pitch or less, so I recommend placing the screws on the ridges.

Problem: Side steps are in need of improvement. They could be repaired but it might be just as easy to tear out and rebuild completely. There are no handrails. 30" from threshold of door to ground.
Solution: Build new steps with 5 steps with a rise of about 6". Set posts in ground, install hand rails on both sides. Make a concrete landing, either poured or patio blocks.

Problem: Back steps need some improvement for easier access.
Solution:
Rip down 2x6 pt material to 2 1/2" and add to treads. This will also reinforce the woobly handrail post. treads are 48" wide.

Deck height is approx. 36"

Problem: The front porch steps are not built to code. Treads are not wide enough and the handrails are missing. Virginia needs improvements for safe entry and exit.
Solution:
Steps on the front (facing the road) are wobbly and have no rails. Tear down and rebuild. Install handrails on both sides. There are some patio stones for a landing already in place. Make steps 48" wide.

If a ramp is built, this would be the side of the house to do it on; the deck height is 22 1/2" here. It is also closest to the parking area.

Follow building codes.

Problem:
Roof shingles are worn out. 21 year old asphalt 3-tabs.

Metal porch roof has some leaks.
Solution:
The main section of the roof does not leak at this time, but Virginia is being proactive and wants to avoid ceiling damage.

The roof is approximately 1800 square feet. Typical- 3 or 4 /12 pitch on a doublewide

Tear-off of old shingles recommended.

Penetrations: 1 fireplace chimney ( metal)

1 dryer vent

1 sattelite dish

3- 1 1/2" plumbing vents

3- square metal vents

Problem: Back deck in rough shape. Boards are splintery. Frame sags. Handrails broken. No post bracing. Beth does not let her kids go out here. Deck height 53".
Solution:
Although an attempt could be made to patch it up, the best solution here would be a complete tear- down and rebuild. You could re-use some of the material that is in good shape and does not get destroyed during demolition.

The existing deck is 12' x 16'. To save money a smaller deck should be built back. (8'x 10 or smaller).

Use the CHC deck guidelines and follow the code.

Consult Beth's father and the property owner for locations of water lines, drainpipes , etc before digging.

Reinforce the front deck so that clients can use it for entry and exit during construction.

Build steps and rails. Terminate stringers on a concrete landing pad.

Problem: Front deck in rough condition. This is the deck on the left side of the house as you view it from the parking area. Several holes in deck. The joists underneath are not attached to a framing band on one end. Foundation of deck is not built to code. Deck slopes towards house.
Solution:
Although an attempt could be made to patch it up, the best solution here would be a complete tear- down and rebuild. You could re-use some of the material that was in good shape and does not get destroyed during demolition.

Use the CHC deck guidelines and follow the code.

Consult Beth's father and the property owner for locations of water lines, drainpipes , etc before digging.

Reinforce the back deck so that clients can use it for entry and exit during construction.

Build back a similar- size or smaller deck (existing deck is 8' x 12'). Deck height is approx. 24".

Build guard rails and step hand rails. Stringers should have a concrete landing.

Problem:
Roof leaks. Several stains are visible on the inside, mainly around the skylight in the bathroom. Numerous coats of Kool Seal have been applied but they are peeling up (see photos).

Several windowsills in the home are moldy. This is probably resulting from water running down the side of the trailer and infiltrating the walls and sills. Beth tries to clean this up with bleach water, but the problem will not go away until a long term solution is reached.
Solution:
Beth's trailer has a 3/12 pitch roof. The trailer measures about 14' wide x 63' long. The best long term solution is a new metal roof.

The terrain around the trailer is well-graded, so you could probably skip gutters on this one.

If finances do not permit, an attempt could be made to patch it up. The mini-gutters could be cleaned out, they are growing weeds now, Apply Lexel -type roofing caulk around the plumbing penetrations and skylight.

Warning- be careful walking on the roof, only step on the roof trusses.

Problem: Plumbing leak- shower water supply valve.
Solution:
This repair can be accessed through the kids' room closets. There is a thin panel that comes off. The part that is leaking is a shut-off valve that supplies cold water to the shower.

It may be possible to just tighten this valve up, but be prepared if something breaks. If it does this is what you will need to do:

Cut power to pump. Open bathtub faucet . Cut water lines on either side of the valve. Replace valve. Use a PEX ball valve.

Existing plumbing here is 1/2" polybutylene. Note- pex stuff does not work on polybutylene. Get the right couplings.

Problem: Floor under the washing machine could need work. Beth says at one time there was a leak that caused damage. I did not get to assess fully because the washing machine was going at the time.
Solution: Remove washer and dryer and check floor for soundness. Remove damaged floor material and replace subfloor , reinforce joists, etc. if needed. Replace floor material.

Problem: No vapor barrier under house. The insulation that protects the main water supply line that comes up out of the ground is soaked and ineffective. Needs new, dry insulation before winter.
Solution:
Remove old, wet insulation. Rake area and put some 6 mil plastic down. The insulation may have gotten wet because of a hose bib leak, maybe the hose connection wasn't tightened enough. . Check for other leaks and make any repairs needed. Then Install new, unfaced fiberglass or other, mold resistant insulation (Reflectix might work well)around the water line. While you are under there, install vapor barrier under the home. This will involve cleaning out and raking the dirt underneath, and cutting pieces of 6 mil plastic to fit around foundation blocks. It is helpful to remove some vinyl underpinning before you lay down the plastic. This also lets more light in.

There is an access panel to the left of the deck (uphill side).

Problem: Beth does not use the commode in the second bathroom. She was told not to by someone- perhaps her grandpa- that worked on it in the last few years. The flooring in here is carpet.
Solution:
Some further diagnosis is needed as to why the commode should not be used. The subfloor seems solid, the tank is full, and the water supply, although shut off at this time, does not appear to leak when turned on.

Have someone take off a piece of underpinning near the meter base and look at the drainpipes under the house while someone flushes. Look for leaks in the drain system.

The carpet has been peeled back around the commode, but the floor does not seem level. Some attempt could be made to level the floor and vinyl plank flooring could be installed in part or all of the room here. The proper way to do this is to pull the commode, fix the subfloor, install flooring,then reinstall the commode.

Clients have another bathroom in the home.

Problem:
Monitor heater is not working properly- it throws a code- Beth says it will not heat the entire house.

Client has an electric furnace , she says it only heats half the house

She also has an unvented propane heater powered by a 20 lb. propane tank- this heater is not supposed to be used in the home, it is for construction sites.
Solution: Have a heating pro look at the system and come up with a practical solution, it would be nice just to have one good heating system in the home,

Problem: Drawer falling out in kitchen
Solution: remove drawer and install drawer slides or other repair

Problem: Ceilings of both bathrooms have mold stains. Roof leaks may be contributing to this problem, but also, there are no vent fans in either room.
Solution: Install bath fans in conjunction with new roof. Note- electrical work needed; you will have to run a wire and switch

Problem: Circuit panel is blocked by TVs . Panel is located in kids' bedroom.
Solution: Talk to Beth about moving some stuff around in the room.

Problem: The small, trailer-size gutters are cloggged with debris and weeds are growing in them
Solution: Clean gutters. This is a job that can be done by the homeowners, but they may need some coaching on ladder set-up, and I am not sure they have a ladder.

Problem: A/C will not work properly. Does not cool or shut off. They had a local HVAC friend try to fix but was unable. Need a professional diagnosis and repair.
Weak place in floor near back door (laundry area)
Solution: The floor has some water damage due to a roof leak. The roof should be fixed, then remove weak subfloor, reinforce joists, and replace plywood. Approx. 2' x 2'area. Watch for wires, plumbing, and HVAC when cutting a hole in the floor.

Problem: Clean- up needed.
Solution: Earl and Jacksie, despite their health problems, like to get out and putter in the yard. The back of the house, where the new deck is, is in need of a good clean-up and landscaping. There are also lots of places that have piles of stuff that need to be cleaned up. Work with the homeowners and get them involved-. Make a scrap metal pile so the family can haul it to the scrap yard- Mikey has a big flat bed truck.

Problem: Ceiling has been damaged as a result of a roof leak. Bay window area has been damaged as well. Cabinet above laundry machines is starting to fall down.
Solution:
Once the roof is on, remove light fixture,damaged ceiling material and repair.

Shore up cabinet. You may have to remove it.

Remove paneling from bay window and make repairs there as well.

Problem: Home needs paint, but consider where moist siding will need replacement. Don't paint these areas.
Solution: Per conversation with Ann 5/6/19, she has 5 gallons of paint, no rollers, brushes, or trays.

Problem: Edna called to let us know she broke her hip about 4 weeks ago, needed surgery and rehab. She's coming home May 11th. Needs grab bars at tub/shower, a handheld shower head installed
Solution: Checking in with CCRaleigh to see if this is something they can do.

Problem: Kin has requested porch roof to help keep deck from getting slick
Solution: I explained this is not a high priority but I would add it to assessment. If anything came up to get a group out there for another urgent need, maybe they could address porch roof

Problem: soft spot in floor where you enter bedroom
Solution: this was reported by Kin's ex-wife, Sandra. It's a concern for them.

Problem:
Insulation missing around pipes in corner bathroom. This is the bathroom on the opposite side of the parking area. Pipes could freeze if left uninsulated. The insulation was removed to fix the leaking tub drain.

No vapor barrier under house.
Solution: Install approx. 100 sq. feet of R19 unfaced insulation. Get some 15" wide and some 23" wide. Install 6 mil plastic under as much of the house possible as a vapor barrier (1680 sft) . There is some plastic on site.

Problem: Ramp had to be removed to do underpinning work.
Solution: Reinstall ramp, all materials on site.

Problem: Spoke w/Maggie 4/2/19, their youngest daughter was recently diagnosed with EDS - Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, causing her to have difficulty walking.
Solution: Grab bar at shower and handrails needed down hallway. An idea down the hallway so that it doesn't come out into the space much, is to attach a small piece of wood, like a perlin or 1x, then attach a 2x4 to that so there is a place to grip. CHC has a grab bar in storage.

Problem: Leak at top of bay window
Solution: Spoke w/George 4/2/19 and he reported leak at top of bay window. He has a suggestion for repair. Use the same rubber membrane that is on the roof to cover this area to prevent it from leaking.

Problem: Back steps and railings are unsafe.
Solution: Replace steps and railings at sliding glass door. Replace railings at back door.

Problem: East side windows are failing due to sun exposure.
Solution: Replace 9 windows, reflash.

Problem:
Roof issues- back porch

1)Porch roof has some leaks. Screws were not installed properly.

2)Eaves of back porch were not done right. Water leaks behind gutter.  

3)Flaking paint on one area of porch roof.
Solution:
1) Caulk holes with Lexel. Install screws where needed.

2)Remove gutters. Remove screws from bottom side of roof metal. Remove aluminum flashing. Remove and replace all damaged wood on edge of building. Some wood may have to be cut back to get the right roof overhang (roof metal should overhang drip edge 1 - 1 1/2" into the gutters). Install drip edge on edge of plywood perlins. Reinstall roof screws. Reinstall the old gutters and re caulk seams , if salvagable, otherwise install new gutters. Please install 5" aluminum gutters, not the flimsy vinyl ones. Make sure gutters are sloping the right way.Edge of roof is approx. 27' long.  

3) Ideally, Charles would like this section of roof to be repainted. This would involve scraping the old paint off. Since the trailer is a 1973 model, I needed to test for lead. However, some of the paint is red, so tests were inconclusive. The only sure way to test would be to send a sample to the lab.

Problem: Corner of the porch is starting to have some problems. Some boards and at least one post should be replaced. Steps are also starting to decay; if time and materials permit, replace steps. Handrail requested.
Solution:
At this point I don't think a new porch is necessary; the corner that is damaged and touching the ground could be repaired. You will have to temporarily support one post while you fix the material under it- cut out the rotten stuff with a sawsall and replace with ground contact pressure treated material.

Steps are not very high off the ground (21" rise). A duplicate could be made using the old stringers as a pattern. Make a concrete landing or use solid cap blocks.  

Build a handrail on one side. Follow code.

Problem:
There is a steep hill and some springs behind Charles' house. Water makes its way under the trailer.

Charles has spent lots of time, and has come up with some rather ingenious ways of diverting water around the back side of his house. Some of these systems are starting to fail and more work is needed.
Solution:
Dig a French Drain on the back side of Charles' house. Make sure you talk to him before the job starts, get his input and **have him show you the location of the oil line and water line. You will be digging right around th** em.  

Do some research before the job begins- The online WikiHow instructions are the best I have found. Use solid white drainpipe and install a cleanout for snaking.

Work with Charles to clean out ditches, improve drainage , etc. around back.  

The ground is super rocky around here.

Call Pangles or ask Charles about gravel, they may know of a local source.

Problem: Pauline has some health problems, and she gets out of breath really easily. Steps are hard for her. She would like to install a ramp/walkway to get in and out of her house more easily.
Solution:
Build a walkway from the back door to Meadow Fork road, near her mailbox.  

It would be fairly level, see photos.  

Make it 48" wide and approx. 16 feet long.  

It is important that the slope of the ramp/walkway does not exceed a 1 in 12 pitch.  

It is also important that the framing slopes away from the house so that water does not flow towards the house, causing rotten threshold, etc.  

The ramp may have to slope slightly down, then up for this to happen. In that case you will have to install some 4x4 supports underneath.

Problem:
Kitchen sink drain is not working right. Pauline has jury- rigged it, and the drain pipe, which is too small, runs out through the side of the house and into the yard.  

Drain line is clogged up underneath the house somewhere.
Solution: Pauline says she still has the original drainpipe p- traps and other parts. Try snaking the lines first, if that doesn't work you may have to cut the drain line underneath the house and replace some sections of drainpipe.

Problem: Plastic lattice on porch is flimsy and not nailed on well.
