Solution: Remove vinyl lattice. Use a 4 foot level to lay out pickets (ballusters) so that there will be spaces between them that do not exceed 4 inches. Drill pilot holes to reduce splitting, which will happen especially near the ends. Install 42" pickets. This is a big deck so you will need quite a few.

Problem: New ramp in the back needs to have some shingles nailed onto it for better wheelchair traction
Solution: Shingles are on site. Nails needed.

Problem: Low pressure at times. Client hears "clicks" from pressure tank.
Solution: Replace pressure switch.

Problem: Make a better cover for the well pump area in the yard.
Solution: Apply insulation and metal (both on site) for well pump roof.

Problem: Back exit cluttered, Kile can't access ramp. Parking area/shed also cluttered.
Solution: Clean up, de-clutter back exit.

Problem: Underpinning needs some work.
Solution:
Purchase some vinyl underpinning to match the existing and install.

Call Gentry's hardware- he may have a few pieces of this stuff.

Problem: Crawlspace door in rough shape
Solution: Build a new crawlspace access door that will close off cold air to keep pipes from freezing.

Problem: Kitchen sink faucet leaks.
Solution: New faucet. Existing has sprayer. see photos for type.

Problem: Back door flimsy. Bottom support missing.
Solution: The door is operational but Charles would like to have it replaced because it is weak. This is one of three exterior doors. It is a mobile home size door, 32" x 72", right hinge, opens out, no storm door.

Problem: There is an interior door that will not close.
Solution: move strike plate

Problem: There is a room, part of the enclosed porch, that needs work. At first it was thought that the roof was leaking but an inspection of the attic revealed that the problem may be due to moisture from other sources, namely the basement stairwell, where moist air comes up from below, and lack of ventilation.
Solution:
Put 6 mil plastic down under the stairs where the dirt floor is. Clean the room thoroughly and open the windows in dry weather. Install a box fan to circulate air. Install better quality ceiling material.

I told the clients about this solution and it seemed to me that they had the resources to do this themselves. If they cannot, it may be a good project for a volunteer crew.

I gave the family a project list and took a photo of it. It can be seen in the Progress Photos.

Problem: Dog feces in house. One dog bites.
Solution:
Mary needs to be convinced to make the dogs go outside. There is a good chain link fence that encloses a big dog yard. I'm not sure if there is a doghouse, if not you could build one.

This is more of a dog training issue than anything else, but the dogs will need to be kept outside while work is going on in the house, they are very noisy and one bites.

Problem: Siding is starting to rot in one place on the front porch.
Solution:
Replace 1 4x8 sheet- t-111 plywood. Existing T111 has a 10 1/2" profile, see photos.

There may be damage to framing underneath.

There may be some other places that need work, I happened to notice this one.

Problem: Toilet pouring water, leak has become worse
Solution: Investigate and repair

Problem: The pipe at the well head is blistering and in immediate danger of bursting
Solution: Replace pipe with new 3/4" pex line.

Problem: Kitchen sink not connected to septic. New bathroom needs to be plumbed to septic
Solution: Run new drain lines from kitchen sink and bathroom to septic.

Problem: Huge trash clean up needed down the hill from Eugene's
Solution: Remove old tires, trash, metal, etc

Problem: 16 year old ramps are too steep. No hand rails.
Solution:
The property is such that a ramp could work on either side, however, I think it would be easier to build a ramp on the left side (as you face the home from the parking area). A set of easy - to - climb steps could be built on the right side.

The ramp needs to have a 1 and 12 pitch, therefore it needs to be 32 feet long because the deck height is 32". Follow building code.

Steps should be built with about a 7" rise (deck height on the right side is 34". Make a concrete landing pad at the bottom.

Consult ASP Construction manual for detailed ramp and step - building instructions.

Problem: Steps on side of front porch have split treads. Tread nosing hangs over too much. Insufficient stringers. . Hand rails and guards need work. Porch rails and pickets are OK but could use some TLC.
Solution: Tear down steps. Deck height here is at least 40". Build new steps with hand rails. Make a concrete pad landing. Follow building code.

Problem: Heating duct has a hole in it.
Solution: I did not inspect the entire heating system, but if you remove the metal crawlspace access door, you can see a hole in the ductwork. This could be fixed with tape, and whoever does it can inspect the rest of the duct work. Tape hole(s) with approved HVAC tape, inspect system for other defects. Call HVAC pro if needed.

Problem: Heat pump dims lights when kicked on
Solution:
Family says the breaker does not trip, but an electrician should probably look at this- maybe the wire is too small or something-

There is an electrical contractor on Meadow Fork who has been in business a long time- Southern Lights- 622-3405.

Problem: Lucille has requested help cleaning the vinyl siding on her house
Solution: Clean siding by hand or rent a pressure washer. Get her grandkids (age 14 &12) involved.

Problem: New bathroom is in place but needs plumbing roughed in and hooked to septic so volunteers can complete the bathroom.
Solution: Rough in drain lines for bathroom sink, shower, lavatory, washing machine. Install new drain line from kitchen sink. Hook all drain lines into existing septic.

Problem: Hole in floor- in front of kitchen sink. Small kids in home.
Solution:
Hole seems to be limited to the area just in front of sink- under sink is not damaged, but the cabinet bottom needs to be removed, and work done on the sink.

Remove floor material, cut out square hole, reinforce joists if needed, replace insulation if needed, install new plywood. Flooring can be done later.

Problem: Broken window (living room). Both panes broken, plastic torn
Solution:
Replace this window with a double pane , single or double hung window.

From the inside, the window measures 31 1/2"wide x 55" high, including the aluminum flange.

Keith at Gentry Hardware may be able to order a window, if not, try Jerry at Mars Hill Hardware.

Problem:
Bathroom #1 needs work. Hole in subfloor near bathtub. Tub cracked.  

Supply lines to sink are shut off because water lines leak.
Solution:
This tub has been patched a couple of times; I don't know if the patch is holding.There are a couple of holes that seem to extend under the tub, so the tub must be removed.

This is a tub/ shower unit, trailer- size (54)". There is an interior wall that could be moved to install a regular- size (60") tub/ shower, but then you would have to move the wall and the plumbing.

Remove tub, plumbing. remove all bad subfloor materials. reinforce joists if needed, install new insulation if needed, install new plywood subfloor.

install new tub and surround, new fixtures, valves, drains, etc.

Problem: Bathroom #2 needs work. Big hole in front of sink. Existing floor material is carpet. Hole extends under sink. Tub has a crack about 6" up from drain. There is a seperate shower.
Solution:
Remove sink and associated plumbing fixtures. Remove cabinet and countertop. Remove all carpet in room.

Purchase flooring for the room and put it in the house.

It looked like to me that the only real bad place was around the sink, but once the carpet comes off you can thoroughly inspect the floor for more weak places. Remove all damaged subfloor material.Watch out for wires, plumbing and HVAC when you cut holes in the floor Set saw depth.

Shore up joists if needed. Add insulation if needed. Install new CDX plywood. The thickness will be either 5/8" or 3/4". This can be determined before major demo is started by drilling a 1" hole in the floor in an inconspicuous place where the floor is solid.

The whole room needs new flooring, but the subfloor seems OK around the commode, tub, and shower.

The bathtub has a crack, but it will still hold about 6" of water. There may be a way to patch this tub (it is a cheaper fiberglass model) but I am unfamiliar with how to do this.

The priority here should be to remove the old carpet and get a solid subfloor. Installing new floor material can come later, besides, the tub may need replacement anyway if it cannot be patched.

After the subfloor is solid, put the cabinet and countertop back if they are in reasonable condition.

Problem: Decks need work. The front deck is serviceable but needs some TLC. Back steps are kind of sketchy.
Solution:
Front deck- replace split boards, reinforce handrail, clean deck so it will be less slippery, etc.

Back steps- These are wobbly and do not meet code. Best to tear out and replace with new 4x4 deck.  

Install code- compliant rails and steps. Install 3 1/2" thick concrete pad at bottom of steps.

Problem: Underpinning needs work.
Solution:
Remove old underpinning. Clean out junk from underneath the home. Install vapor barrier ( 6 mil plastic) you will need 1600 square feet.

Replace old, flimsy vinyl with recycled metal underpinning. Amanda has 3 sheets of roof metal left over. Sheets are around 14' long. The next door neighbors have several piles of old roof metal. Talk to them and see if they could spare some metal to do the job.

Build a pressure- treated frame and install metal. See enclosed instructions.

Make a couple of access panels near the bathrooms

Problem: Heaps of old shingles in yard. Lots of trash around including broken glass shards.
Solution: Amanda just got a new roof so the shingles may be hauled off soon. Amanda has access to a trailer and a pickup, but both need work at this time. Bag up trash, haul construction debris to landfill, work with family to organize yard, save scrap metal. etc Dump card # 19660.

Problem: Kitchen sink needs some work. Faucet is loose, leaks on hot supply side (copper line). Cabinet bottom shot.
Solution:
Close hot and cold shut off valves under the sink. Unhook water lines. Unhook drain pipes. Replace faucet with a new one. Re- install drain pipes. Check foe leaks.  

Remove bottom of kitchen cabinet. Replace water damaged material with new plywood .

Problem: Parking area flat, muddy with pot holes. Driveway could use some too.
Solution:
Apply about 16 tons gravel or shale. Ask Amanda or a family member who has a dump truck that can deliver.

Spread with rake.

Problem: There is a thick layer of ice on the heating unit.
Solution: Call HVAC pro- Ben Houser (local contractor) knows a guy

Problem: Bedroom wall has some peeled- off wall paper
Solution: Replace wall paper or paint

Problem: Fire pit in back yard needs improvement
Solution: Talk to Amanda about this, it would be nice to gather some rocks from the woods and make some improvements. Burn scrap (untreated) wood if the weather is not too dry

Problem: There are several large holes in the duct work. As a result the heater runs more than it should and warm air blasts into the crawlspace, which is poorly underpinned. . Client has a huge electric bill.
Solution: According to Arriel the heater works good, but it is being overworked, All ductwork should be replaced , although in the short term, someone could crawl under there and apply tape to the ductwork, that would help some. Then call an HVAC pro to get a quote to replace the duct work (some special tools and know- how are needed ). Heater should also be cleaned while the HVAC guy is there.

Problem: Roof leaks. Arriel says water leaks through both bathroom fans and through a light fixture. Porch roof leak near front door.
Solution:
The roof is a typical 3/12 pitch shingle roof. A home-made metal porch roof addition is leaking at the metal / shingle transition. There are several nail holes that could be caulked, and roof cement can be added to the suspected places. Another idea is to install a ridge vent, that way you could eliminate the square metal vents, which I suspect are leaking as well.

New flashing may help at the transition as well.

There is a 5 gal bucket on the roof that looks like it contains a fair amount of roof cement.

Electrical weatherhead boot looks like it could be leaking. Install new split boot and caulk.

Problem: Bathtub is leaking. Tub drain suspected. Water collects in the belly liner below, causing the floor to stay wet. Mold in bathroom is growing as a result.
Solution:
First step is to drain the belly band. It is holding a large amount of water, one idea is to have a "bucket brigade" and poke a small hole in the belly liner and drain it bucket by bucket.

Remove belly liner and wet insulation. Dry out area and inspect for water damage. My suspicion is that the tub drain has been leaking, but there could be another source.

Best case scenario- floor is not damaged, replace tub drain and insulation.

BUT- It is likely that the floor has been soaked long enough to cause a lot of damage. In that case you are going to have to remove the tub to repair the subfloor.

This could turn into a big job but the first step is to dry the floor out and go from there.

This will be a dirty job- wear coveralls, gloves, glasses, etc.

Problem: Decks are in need of repair. Handrails and steps do not meet code and are damaged. .
Solution:
Replace some deck boards (2x6 decking). Install diagonal bracing. Improve handrails and guard rails.

The steps are serviceable but do not meet code. Replace if time and finances permit.

Existing deck is 12 feet wide (deck boards are 2x6x12.) Length notmeasured, estimated 20 feet.

Reinforce framing . Build new guard rails and step handrails if time and finances permit

Problem: Gutters along back of house do not work. Water comes off the roof and the existing gutters dump water next to the heater (there are no downspouts or drainpipes art this time.
Solution: Re- do the gutters on the back side of the house. Install downspouts and drainpipes. Keep this system seperate from the French drain.

Problem: Drainage problems. A strong spring and a steep mountain is behind her house.
Solution:
Dig around the black drainpipe in the back and try to divert some water into it . (There is some water going into it now so we know it is working).

There is a big rut in the back full of water. This would be a good place for a French drain. Dig ditch, add silt cloth,put 2" of gravel, 4" sewer pipe with holes FACING DOWN , cover with cloth, add gravel to top. The ditch will need to be at least 70 feet, more if you put a solid drainpipe in to get the water completely away from the house. pipe must daylight (come out of the ground) at the low point. Drop should be 1" per 10 feet.

You might want to rent a "Bobcat" or something to help dig; consult family about electrical and plumbing lines before digging.

Use 4" pvc sewer pipe with holes. Install pipe with holes facing DOWN.

"Wiki- How" is the best online instruction source for this project that I have found.

Install cleanouts so that the drain can be "snaked" if clogged.

Problem: Underpinning needs work. Possums and cats get under the house. Holes in ductwork due to varmints.
Solution: Improve underpinning. Most of the underpinning is in decent shape but there are some missing and broken panels.

Problem: There is a lot of junk on the property. Trash in yard, scrap metal, etc.
Solution: Haul stuff to landfill. When I was there Arriel had a trailer in the yard that she planned to use to haul stuff. Tires had air and she had a trailer hitch and ball on her vehicle.

Problem: No water at assessment time. Clients had shut it off due to a water line leak to the bathtub.
Solution:
Latasha and Tom are currently trying to fix this themselves. They are going to have to move a heavy fish tank that is in the way of the wall between the bathroom and bedroom, where the tub plumbing is. Then they can access the problem , which they think is a broken water supply line. She seems confident that they can do this, and I told her to keep us posted.

  

  

Clients are able to use the house next door to take showers, etc.

Problem: Roof leak- bedroom. Drywall falling above bed. A couple other places on the ceiling are stained.
Solution: New metal roof. This is a 3/12 pitch trailer roof. Install perlins, metal. Install gutters, soffitt, fascia, drainpipes. Penetrations include wood stove pipe, plumbing vents, and roof vents.

Problem:
Wood stovepipe , although double- wall, is pretty beat up. Roof leaks around stovepipe. Stove is also too close to the wall.

Stove seems to be in decent shape but i did not inspect thoroughly.
Solution:
Remove stovepipe. Move stove. make sure floor framing is good. Install a wood stove pad? Install some 2x2's horizontally on the wall. Install Hardi- board or other fireproof barrier. Follow clearance requirements to make sure the stove is the proper distance from the wall.

Install new black pipe, ceiling box, hood, and double wall pipe, etc.

The roof of the trailer is rather flimsy and the roof frame may need some reinforcement to hold the weight of the stovepipe.

Problem:
There are a couple places that Latasha mentioned where the floors need work.

Old, unused heat registers create a trip hazard
Solution:
Remove clutter from the place where the old washing machine was. Remove any damaged plywood. Reinforce joists if needed. Install new plywood.

Remove refrigerator. water is leaking back here somewhere and Latasha wants to replace the fridge. Inspect subfloor, remove bad plywood, reinforce joists if needed, replace plywood.

Remove old floor heat registers- there are several that are broken and create a trip hazard. Install material to nail to and put back plywood that is flush with the existing subfloor.

Install some insulation in the floor where possible.

Problem: The back door has no steps or deck and is about 26" off the ground.
Solution: Build a small deck (4' x 4')and set of steps here for access.

Problem: Second bathroom has a tub that is broken.
Solution:
Replace bathtub. It is 54" x 36".

Install new tub surround and shower plumbing.

Install new faucets. Install new tub drain.

Commode works but needs cleaning.

Subfloor in here seems OK.

Problem: Primary bathroom needs some work. Sketchy- looking electrical, tub drain questionable. Holes in drywall.
Solution:
There was no water at assessment time, so i could not know for sure, but I strongly suspect that the tub drain needs to be replaced. An inspection underneath revealed that the drainpipes from the tub need to be replaced as well. New tub surround needed, but tub seems OK.

Clients have found a leak in the water supply to the bathtub. The plumbing is in the wall between the bathroom and an adjacent bedroom.

There are some lights in this room that have been installed with sketchy wiring. Remove lights.

Latasha says that there is a leak in the water line that goes to the commode.

Commode has some issues and Latasha would like to replace it.

Patch holes in drywall. Finish drywall and paint.

Floor is ok in here as far as I could tell.

Problem:
Drainpipe issues. There are at least two drainpipes that drain out onto the ground out onto the bank between the trailer and the road. It looks like one is for the bathtub and sink in one bathroom, the other is for the kitchen sink.

Drainpipes from the bathtub in one bathroom need repair.

Septic system is questionable- Latasha was not sure where the tank was and thought that they might share Locke's system. Latasha also mentioned a bad smell coming from Locke's yard .
Solution: Have an experienced plumber take a look and see what he recommends. The drainpipes need to be tied into the existing septic system. They either need their own tank and drainfield or if they are using Locke's, someone needs to determine if the system can handle it.

Problem: Living room window broken
Solution:
This is a trailer window which includes a storm. The window opening is currently covered by insulation and plastic.

Replace window. If finances permit, get a double insulated single hung. If not, Latasha has a storm window down at the old trailer that looks like it would work here.

Several windows are single pane without storms.

Window is 30 1/4" wide x 53 1/4" high excluding the flange.

Problem: Two teenagers share a bedroom- Christopher, 15 , and Brli, 13. Latasha said that DSS reccomends a new bedroom be built so that they can have seperate bedrooms.
Solution:
Latasha wants to build an addition adjacent to the teens' existing bedroom.

The site is not ideal for this, but it may be possible. Draw up a plan and put together an estimate for a small (6' x 10?) addition.

Design considerations must include the trailer roof, and the room may need to "step- down" to a lower level to make the roof pitch work.

Consider drainage back here, it will be on the back side next to a pretty steep bank.

Problem: The front deck, which is in decent condition, has no step handrails. Deck height is approx. 45"
Solution: Build handrails on both sides of steps

Problem: Underpinning in rough condition
Solution:
Replace about half of the underpinning. Some existing underpinning can be re-used. There is also some underpinning down at the old trailer that can be reused. You could also tear off the metal on the porch roof down there and use that as underpinning.

The site has very poor drainage and a vapor barrier should not be installed until something is done about that

Problem: Junk on property
Solution: Haul to landfill

Problem: Hallway floor has a weak place. High traffic area.
Solution: Tear up a section of floor. Remove damaged subfloor material and reinforce framing. install new plywood and floor material.

Problem: Driveway is very rutted. Gravel washed out. Denise and Jayden walk. Driveway is about 160 feet long.
Solution: I talked to Desiree (landlord ) about this. She claims to have fixed the road several times. It is fairly steep but seems like some grading and gravel might help. Have someone who works on roads look at it.

Problem:
Several electrical issues were reported.

1)Breakers trip

2)exterior lights get wet

3)Light "blew out " in hallway

4)one outlet does not work

5) circuit box circa 1987
Solution: Have a qualified electrician fix the major issues

Problem: Deck slopes towards house. Water gets in doorway. Roof leaks between porch roof and trailer roof because of improperly designed roof (too flat)and flashing. Door is sticking because it is swelled due to water damage.
Solution:
The short- term, cheapest solution here is going to be to re- flash the porch roof. Remove old flashing, thoroughly clean off old tar. Install new flashing . Do not do it the way it was done before. Instead, remove part of the trailer- style "gutters" and slide the new flashing under it. Caulk with Lexel or Thru the Roof and install new screws. The bottom of the flashing should overlap the roof metal by as much as possible.

If you need some new trailer- style "gutters" they are available at Discount Mobile Home Supply.

Long term solution is to tear down entire deck and porch roof. Rebuild using the salvageable materials. Most materials, including roofing, are re-usable.

Deck should slope away from house at least 1/4". Roof pitch should be 2/12 or greater.

Problem: Commode leaks at bottom
Solution: replace wax ring

Problem: Flooring needed in kitchen. Subfloor is solid but existing floor material (laminate) is worn, some has screws sticking up that she trips over
Solution: New flooring. High quality vinyl plank laminate recommended. Rough guess for square footage is 80. "Shaw" brand is good

Problem: Lots of junk that needs to be hauled away (this has been completed) BUT Some debris was left behind, at the top of her driveway, from a previous group. During phone conversation 8/1/19, Denise asked if next week's group could haul this away.
Solution: Haul off to landfill. Dump #21479

Problem: Denise has requested a motion sensor light for when she walks down the hill in the dark
Solution: Install motion sensor light

Problem: Siding dirty
Solution: clean

Problem: The porch roof is missing some metal and has a big hole in it. One of the outside rafters , a scabbed 2x4, is collapsing and may fall.
Solution:
This roof is failing for several reasons: First, It does not have enough slope. There is only a 4 inch drop between the high side and the low side. It was also built with scabbed- together rafters which are coming apart. Also, there is no flashing between the porch roof and the trailer.

Remove metal roof material. Remove all plywood decking. Remove 2x4 rafters. Haul damaged, unusable materials to the landfill.

Cut off material from the remaining posts on the downhill side. One extremely warped post should be replaced .

Install a new horizontal support that spans the 4x4 posts.

Install new rafters. Roof slope should be as close to 2/12 pitch as possible,this means the low side of the roof will have to be around 6 feet (the top side is 7'4". )

Install 1x4 perlins perpendicular to and on top of the rafters, 2 feet on center. Install metal roofing.

Install flashing that goes on top of the new metal and under the "gutters". screw and caulk with roofing caulk.

Existing dimensions of the deck are 10' wide by approximately18' wide.
Volunteer or Groups:
Christ Church (Raleigh);
Grace Church Cathedral/ St. Pauls

Problem: Handrails and guards on front and back decks need work
Solution: Install some new pickets. Replace two step treads. Replace some 2x4 material. Add screws in some places. Install some diagonal bracing.

Problem: Front storm door has a broken latch
Solution: Replace latch

Problem: Missing window pane. storm window.
Solution: The easiest thing to do here is probably to order a replacement storm window. The measurement of the window, which includes an aluminum flange, is 41 1/4" high x 31 1/2" wide. The window can be replaced by removing the screws from the inside.

Problem: Underpinning is in rough shape. It should be improved so that the trailer will be better insulated and the pipes will not freeze as easily.
Solution:
The existing underpinning is vinyl, and can be replaced, but the stuff is pretty flimsy and also expensive. In this case, if you use vinyl, the cost will be over $500 because the trailer is about 4' off the ground.

Metal roofing, recycled if possible, makes better underpinning; Make a pressure- treated frame and put up metal with roof screws.

Problem: Drywall has some holes here and there
Solution: Patch drywall. 3/8" thickness.

Problem: Lots of junk in yard. Old pallets, sofas, trash, etc.
Solution: Haul off to landfill. Get Dump number.
Volunteer or Groups:
Christ Church (Raleigh);
Grace Church Cathedral/ St. Pauls

Problem: Dog lot in disrepair. Dog needs a place to run.
Solution: Shirley's idea is to make some kind of dog run. There is an existing chain link fence dog lot, but it needs repair.

Problem: Underside of trailer stays wet
Solution: Remove a couple of pieces of underpinning and install 6 mil plastic sheeting. You will need approx. 750 square feet. Cut around block pillars. (based on findings week of 7/8/19, solution could be that this area needs to dry out as best as possible, then apply vapor barrier, replace wet insulation).
Volunteer or Groups:
Forsyth United Methodist Church;
Grace Church Cathedral/ St. Pauls

Problem: Siding dirty
Solution: pressure wash

Problem: Decks slippery, handrails and guards insufficient
Solution:
There are two small decks, one serving each exterior entrance. They are on the same side of the building.

Vicky has nailed down some asphalt shingles to the deck surface which helps. Scrub deck surfaces with warm water and a wire brush. Build solid, code- compliant hand rails. Take a look at the steps; There are only two but they seemed high; I did not measure. A better set of steps could be built. Build guard rails.

Problem: Roof has been leaking for years. The proper flashing was never installed. Damage has occured to the area around the chimneys, ceiling drywall and perlins, and is starting to damage the inside ceiling joists. Roof screws are rusty.
Solution:
Hire a pro roofer to flash the chimneys. Cricket needed on big chimney. Replace roof screws.  

One chimney is 28 1/2" x 54 1/2". The other is 17" x 17".  

Vicky talked to a roofer 6 weeks ago in Hendersonville who was highly recommended to her. He is backed up with work. I told her to try him again, see if he has insurance, and get an estimate.

Replacing roof screws could be done by volunteers as long as they were trained on proper screw installation. Vicky has several unopened bags of roof screws.

Problem:
5 windows have broken panes. The two most important windows to replace are in her bedroom.  

Currently Vicky has got a stick propping up one window in her bedroom. The mechanisms that keep it open are broken. If it rains or gets cold, Vicky has to remove the stick and slide the window pane down. It is very heavy and she can barely lift it, plus if it slips then it could crash down and cause injury.
Solution:
Replace windows.

These are special windows, double- paned, that are designed to fit metal- sided buildings. There are at least two that have both panes broken.  

The two priority windows in her bedroom have no inside trim so I measured the rough openings.

Order single -hung or casement style double pane replacement windows that are easy to open.

1)3'8 1/2"x 6' RO

2)3' 6" x 6' RO

Note- exterior siding is metal and may require special trim.

Problem: Water collects on this side of the house. A solution is needed to dry out this area to keep the doors and decks dry and to have a place to store dry firewood.
Solution:
The ideal solution to dry out the area would be a 10' wide x 40' (approx) porch roof that extends along the side of the house. Said roof would cover both decks, the place where the water line goes in the house, and her firewood stash. Roof would need to be metal and have at least a 2/12 pitch. If the fascia board is removed you could attach rafters to the sub fascia and install new rafters. The roof would have to be pretty low on the low side, say 6'2" to achieve that 2/12 pitch.

A roof like this would also block a lot of light. A solution may be to install transparent roof material in some places along with the metal.

This solution requires gutter work. Joe Willis recommended.

Problem: Vicky needs a grab bar next to her commode
Solution: Install a grab bar. Follow instructions.

Problem: Water damage to threshold, trim, and jams of exterior door.
Solution:
There is a metal drain grate next to an exterior door. Figure out how to remove it and unclog the pipe (2" pvc) that is blocked. You may have to dig up the pipe and clean it out or replace it. I suspect it T's in to the nearby gutter drainpipe.  

The door can be fixed, damage does not extend very far in

Problem: The building is cluttered.
Solution: Talk to Vicky about throwing away, donating, or organizing some of her stuff.

Problem: Basement wall is stained from old water damage (repaired).
Solution: Clean basement wall ( painted block) and re- paint. Vicky has Kilz paint.

Problem: Front porch steps, Mark's only means of entering home, have come loose from deck.
Solution: Mark reported this over the phone on 2/7/19. He has to be extremely careful when entering the home. He thinks it would be a simple fix, but he is not able to physically reattach the steps to the porch. He has it "rigged" for now by putting a rock beneath the bottom step, but steps should be reattached to deck.

Problem: Living room floor has sunk down.
Solution: Jack up floor from beneath in order to make level. This was reported by Mark over the phone on 2/7/19 and not on Jake's original assessment.

Problem: Sara has a small bathroom off her bedroom and the floor is weak.
Solution: Investigate best method to repair/replace floor. Unsure of extent of damage. This was reported by client over the phone on 2/7/19 and not on Jake's original assessment.

Problem:
Front porch steps (concrete) do not meet code. They vary in height, (8-9") and there are no handrails. A second set of steps from the parking area to the front porch steps does not have rails either.

Patricia is very concerned about this problem because of her balance issues and ankle injury.
Solution:
The steps are OK as far as their width and depth, but need to be worked on so that they will be 7" or less in rise each. You could do this by adding pavers or thin bricks to the existing steps. You will have to add a step at the bottom. Then add metal handrails on both sides. . These may have to be custom made because of the shape of the side of the steps.

The other set of steps, from the parking area to the front steps, could have pressure-treated wood rails. You would Tap- Con the 2x4's into the sides of the concrete steps and add ballusters. However, if you are going to have rails made for the front steps, you might as well make rails for this set of steps as well.

Recommended welders- Keith Rice, Nate Penland. Have them paint it black.

Problem: The covered porch slopes towards the house which has led to some problems with water leaking through into the basement below.
Solution:
Patricia has a carpet covering the porch at this time. The carpet is covered by a sheet of plastic. An inspection underneath from the basement revealed some small leaks. Existing porch floor is untreated, painted tongue and groove yellow pine .

This is not an easy problem to solve, it is hard to justify tearing off the porch floor and rebuilding it with the proper slope.Here are some ideas-

1) paint porch with anti-skid porch and floor paint, a couple of coats should seal up the gaps , you would still have standing water that would have to be swept off

2) build 3 foot high knee walls around the perimeter, this would keep most water out except for in a driving rain.Cut overhanging boards off flush.

Problem: The attic could use some more insulation to save energy costs in the home.
Solution: Measure square footage on both sides. Go upstairs, there are two access doors, one on either side. Clean out junk from attic space, seal penetrations and blow more insulation into the space. There is a great online article from "Family Handyman" with instructions on how to do this job.

Problem: Cold air comes in the front door.
Solution: Re-do weather stripping. Pry off old door stop trim. Replace with a thicker but narrower piece of trim. Install heavy duty weather stripping.

Problem: Windows are hard to open and close for Patricia.
Solution:
Windows are pretty old, with sliding metal tracks and springs. There are also storm windows. She says she has lubricated them, but they are still hard for her to open. They are not impossible to open, however, and part of the problem is that Patricia is only about 5 feet tall and cannot get the right leverage to open them.

You might try further lubrication, or better , double pane windows. Community action?

Problem: Cracked linoleum floor in kitchen. Patricia sometimes trips on it.
Solution:
New linoleum. A thicker material may interfere with the door. I suggested a threshold strip but she thought she would trip on it too.

Square footage not measured

Problem: There are some holes in the front porch floor.
Solution:
The covered front porch is decked with 5/8" plywood. It has been water damaged. Remove porch furniture. Remove handrails. Remove all old , damaged plywood. Reinforce joists if needed; a brief glance underneath did not reveal any serious damage to the framing . Replace with 5/8 pressure treated plywood. Do not use a thicker material because that would interfere with the door. Reinstall hand rails.

The porch is approx. 75 square feet.

Problem: Front step handrails are weak. The steps are concrete, and the rails are held in by a brick fascia on the sides. The bricks are crumbling.
Solution: You may be able to remove the rails and bust off the loose brick , then re-attach the rails to the concrete part of the steps. Make sure you have 36" clear width on your steps.

Problem: Roof leak. There is a wet spot that can be felt on the ceiling of the back porch.
Solution:
This side of the roof has a lot of moss. It would help to remove the moss and check for leaks. Tar or replace shingles if you find the leak. Tar around chimney and other penetrations.

Shingles (3 tab) are estimated to be 20 yrs old.

Problem: Heather says there is an outlet that sparks when you plug something in. Circuits are easy to overload.
Solution: An upgrade would be good, or install some new circuits. Existing electrical box has breakers, looks like it is from the 1980's.

Problem: Back door does not open /close right
Solution: Remove door and shave off a bit. Install new strike plate and door knob. Note- the back porch is unheated, so the door does not have to be weather- tight.

Problem: Heat may be an issue. Her main source of heat is an unvented propane wall heater. Right now she is out of propane.
Solution: Heather says Amerigas is coming soon to install a big propane tank. Right now she has 4 -100 lb tanks. At that point she says they will get her gas log fireplace going.

Problem: There are several windows in the home that should be replaced. They are old- school single panes with metal frames. The frames are rusting, the paint is peeling, and they are hard to open. The bathroom window will not close and is cracked. There are storm windows on the outside. A living room window and a bathroom window tested positive for lead paint. The others have not been tested but one can assume they will test positive as well.
Solution:
Hire a lead paint contractor to replace the windows. Priorities listed below. Inside trim measurements have been given.

Window 1- (bathroom)- 35 1/2" w x 36 3/4" high.

window 2- living room - 51 1/54" w x 48" high

window 3- (living room ) 52" w 48" high

window 4- (kitchen)- 51" w x 36" high

window 5- (bedroom)- 51" w x 36" high

To save money, slightly smaller windows could be installed, you would have to pack out some framing and re-do the trim.

Problem: Kitchen needs work. Countertop chipped, cabinets are beat up, some fronts are missing. Heather says mice come through some holes in the wall.
Solution: The ideal solution would involve new countertops and cabinets.

Problem: Carpet in living room and in a couple of bedrooms is in pretty rough shape.
Solution:
Protect room from dust and tear up old carpet. Install new flooring material. The living room has a concrete floor, so make sure to use a high quality floor material that is suitable for concrete subfloors. Underlayment may be required.

The living room is the first priority, other rooms in the house could be floored if finances permit.

Living room - 170 sq. ft.

Bedroom- 115 sq. ft.

Bedroom 2- (storage)- approx. 115 sft

Problem: Back porch needs work
Solution: Remove old, unwanted appliances and dispose of at landfill. Clear out room and remove the old vinyl tiles that are peeling off. Clean the floor, maybe paint the floor, organize and clean room. Talk to Heather about what to throw away, give away, etc.

Problem: Concrete walkway from the back exit to the front of the house is busted up and not safe to walk on.
Solution:
Bust up the walkway the rest of the way and pour new concrete or install some pavers.

A drainpipe needs to go in first, see previous repair.

Problem: There is a gutter that extends past one corner of the house and empties onto a pressure treated wood bridge over the creek. This has caused the bridge to grow algae and be very slick. The bridge is also under- framed and is bouncy in the middle.
Solution: Install a downspout on the gutter. Install a drainpipe. You will have to bust up a concrete walkway to bury the pipe, but this is ok since the walkway needs to be redone anyway, it is crumbling. Direct the drainpipe into the creek. Reinforce the framing of the bridge. It has two metal girders under it, but none in the middle. Add metal girders or figure out a way to reinforce with wood framing. Clean the slick deck boards with a wire brush. Install asphalt tread tape or similar product.

Problem: Gutters need cleaning.
Solution: Clean gutters

Problem: Roof leaks. there is an obvious black ceiling stain in her closet.
Solution:
The shingles are at least 16 yr. old, so full replacement would be ideal, but the shingles look pretty good and none are missing. So, repair would be the most cost effective at this time.

Complete structural repairs to roof frame.

An inspection of the attic revealed that the main leak comes from around the masonry chimney. Chimney is unused . Remove chimney and roof over.

An unused electrical weatherhead has no boot. Remove weatherhead and roof over.

There are no plumbing vent boots. Install plumbing vent boots . Caulk.

Problem: HVAC unit is making weird noises and has been worked on by a heating man, Steve. The unit works but may need service or replacement in the future. Unit uses old- school Freon which can no longer be purchased.
An inspection of the attic revealed two broken rafters. The roof is stick-framed and only braced in one section of the roof.
Solution:
Structural repairs needed to roof framing system.

Sister on two 2x6 rafters to reinforce broken ones.

Install 2x6 collar ties onto existing rafters.

The attic is kind of a tight space but there is an access in the ceiling.

Problem: Bathroom tile cracked. This probably happened because there was an old leak that weakened the plywood. The floor seems structurally sound but will eventually need new tile.
Solution: This is not a high priority for Jill but will need doilng eventually. The broken tile could cut somebody.

Problem: Deck needs work. Most of it is in good shape, but there is a broken 2x6 joist under the deck in front of the door. On the end where the tongue is, there is a ramp that is too steep (2 1/2/12) and some rotten or missing deck boards.
Solution: Sister on a 2x6 to the existing, cracked 2x6. Screw the decking into it. Tear off end of deck that is rotten. Tear off ramp. Dispose of materials at landfill. Install a guard rail where the ramp was.

Problem: Roof leaks. Water stains visible on the inside, mainly on the edges.
Solution:
I see two possible solutions to this problem, one is a metal roof. The trailer has a fairly flat roof, it is one of those with a "hump" in the middle. You would have to first build a knee wall on either side to make an even surface for the rafters to rest on. Then roof trusses could be installed.

Soffit, fascia, siding for knee walls, gutters and drainage are not included in this rough estimate.

The other solution could be a membrane roof with gutters. Screw a 2x4 into the sides at the top to provide a little bit of overhang and a place to install the gutters. Again this may be tricky because of the odd- shaped roof.

Roof is 14' wide x approx. 60' long

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install a battery powered unit

Problem: gutter knocked loose by Griffin waste
Solution: install new gutter. Joe Willis has agreed to install gutter, downspout, drainpipe.

Problem: Storm window broken by Griffin Waste Svc.
Solution: install new Storm window

Problem: Roof leaks in several places.
Solution:
This roof has a very shallow pitch (1/2 in 12). The steeper part of the roof is 2 1/2 in 12. A pitch of at least 2 in 12 is needed for metal roof, steeper for shingles to be effective.

Linda's daughter Melinda has a friend, Kelly Hudson, of Wright Way Restoration, who is a roofing contractor. He has applied some elastomeric acrylic coating with fiber mesh. This has been partly sucessful but is only covering about 1/4 of the roof. The job has not been completed because the family cannot afford the cost; Kelly has so far done the work for free.

Although I am unfamiliar with this roofing system, the work done so far looked good and Kelly seems to prefer this system over EDPM or TPO, the only materials I am familiar with for low- slope roof applications. Kelly is insured, and has agreed to submit a quote to CHC.

Gutters will not be included in the estimate.

The name of the system is Everest Roof Systems.

Problem: There is a weak place in the corner of the floor near the back door.
Solution: remove a section of linoleum . Cut out damaged subfloor. Reinforce joists. Install new plywood.

Problem: An exterior light does not work. Two fixtures in the house are broken.
Solution: Check wiring. Replace three fixtures.

Problem: Kitchen faucet is loose and leaks sometimes.
Solution: There may be a part missing. Remove faucet, take to hardware store and see if you can find the parts to fix it. Otherwise replace the whole faucet. It has a spray nozzle.

Problem: Some underpinning has holes in it
Solution: replace some underpinning. channel, spikes and trim is probably still good.

Problem: Linda has two bathrooms. Commodes in both rooms have issues.
Solution: Replace seats, replace guts of both commodes. Note- commodes are 20 yrs old, could be replaced if finances permit

Problem: Bathroom door will not close. Bedroom closet door will not close.
Solution: Install strike plate on bathroom door. Move strike plate down on closet door. You may need to drill a new hole.

Problem: Yard work needed
Solution: clean gutters, mow, weed eat, clean up, etc

Problem: Kitchen cabinet doors are water damaged.
Solution: Replace doors

Problem: No bedroom window.
Solution:
There is a window in the room, but it has been covered up. Linda wants to remove it and put it on the other (exterior) wall.

Removing the window may be tricky because it may have been installed from the outside with a flange. It has been paneled over on the opposite side. You may have to cut the nails.

Problem: Smoke detectors do not work, no CO detectors.
Solution: Install at least one co/ smoke detector.

Problem: Yard cleanup needed
Solution: There is a place wher an old trailer got torn down, looks like someone is trying to salvage the scrap metal. Talk to the family about hauling unwanted junk to the county landfill. Use dump card number and get there 1/2 hour before the landfill closes.

Problem: Bathroom paint is peeling, possibly due to oil based and acrylic paint being applied to the same surface. . Ceiling drywall sagging, needs work.
Solution:
Add screws to ceiling drywall. Re-tape and mud ceiling. Paint ceiling.

The walls where the paint is peeling may not take paint because i suspect that layers of oil based and acrylic paints have been applied to the same surface and did not stick , The walls may be beat served with wall paper.

Tests for lead paint came up negative, after the room was tested I found out that the bathroom was added on in 1980. However, scraping the loose paint off will create dust so measures should be taken to reduce drywall and other dust for the residents' and workers' health.

Problem: Numerous roof leaks. The home was roofed in the 1970's and some of the metal was salvaged. Black stains on ceiling drywall inside the house. Both blocks and flue on the woodstove chimney nearest the porch are cracked, but the stove is still in use.
Solution: There are three pitches on this roof- 3/12, 2 1/2/12, and 1/ 12. Roof will need approx. 1440 square feet of metal on the steeper sections of the roof. For the lower slope part, remove old nails and replace with 1 1 /2 " roof screws. Apply 2 coats of aluminum roof seal. There are some other chimneys and boots that will be needed for various penetrations, see the drawing of the roof provided in client file.

Problem: Front deck is sagging. Porch posts that support the roof are leaning.
Solution:
Remove firewood and other stuff from under the porch roof. Temporarily support the roof with posts. Remove and de- nail deck boards, which are in good shape. Inspect the house framing and siding for damage and repair before rebuilding the deck. This may take time ; I could not inspect the side of the house easily. You may need some flashing and siding materials.

Rebuild or reinforce porch frame, a free stranding structure would be best. Reinstall deck boards. Reinstall and reinforce posts, or install new ones.  

This deck is close to the ground, make sure that the deck slopes away from the house slightly.

Install some gravel in front of the porch as needed, it is too low for steps.

To the right of the front porch is an exterior door. I am not sure if this door is used, but the steps are all busted up. If the door is in use, build a new set of steps here. if not, tear out the nail - ridden remains of the old steps (there are only a couple of steps).

Problem: The rear exit needs work.Door does not close properly. Deck does not have proper handrails. Deck steps crooked.
Solution:
Door slab is OK. Install a new knob and strike plate. Tear down old deck and rebuild a free standing one in its place. Do not attach deck to house, slope deck away from house.

Existing deck is approximately 4'x 6'.

Build steps and rails.

Make a concrete pad at the bottom of the steps.  

A rough drawing of the proposed new deck can be found in the client files.

Problem: Drywall on the ceiling is sagging. Tape is peeling.
Solution:
This job should be done after the roof is repaired. The first thing to do is look in the attic and make sure that the ceiling joists are in ok shape, reinforce if needed. Some drywall will need to be replaced. It will be a dusty job, so protect residents and workers from dust. The old, moldy drywall should be removed using hazmat suits, gloves, and glasses. Install plastic sheeting and drop cloths. Install new drywall, install some new screws, tape, mud, etc. Finish drywall. The existing drywall has a textured finish. Paint.

Note- ceiling has not been tested for lead paint ( house was built in 1977).

Problem: I suspect that there is not much insulation in the attic. Also, check the ceiling joists, it may be possible to reinforce them, which might help the problem of the sagging drywall.
Solution:
Reinforce joists then add attic insulation.

There is access to the attic through a closet, talk to Dave.

Ideally, this job could be done during roof replacement because it will be easy to reinforce joists and install insulation from the top, while the roof metal is off, that is if there are spaces between the roof boards, it felt pretty solid up there in most places.

approx. 1200 square feet insulation needed.

Blown insulation estimate at R19 insulation value, more could be added

Fiberglass bats could be used but that is more expensive.

Problem: There was some questionable looking wiring in the home.
Solution: No electrical problems or shorts were mentioned but an electrician should probably look at it.

Problem: Around the back of the house, on the creek side, the crawlspace access needs work. A piece of plywood is just barely covering the entrance, and is not well attached. If the plywood falls off, the pipes could possibly freeze.
Solution:
Clean out the area and make a better access. This may involve installing a removable plywood panel.

Check the crawlspace for uninsulated or leaking pipes while you are there.

Problem: There is quite a bit of clutter inside the home.
Solution: Work with the homeowners to get rid of or donate some stuff so that it will be easier to move about the home.

Problem: Yard is cluttered.
Solution: Work with the family to dispose of old matresses, old rotten lumber, and trash around the home. Dave more than likely knows someone with a truck to haul materials to the county landfill.

Problem: No CO or smoke detectors
Solution: Install battery powered unit

Problem: Hole in bedroom floor.
Solution: Client had leak that caused damage to bedroom floor and has since discovered a hole. When I spoke to her 11/29/18, I told her I'd add it to assessment. There's the potential a summer group may be able to assist with this repair. SM

Problem: No heat. Building is poorly insulated.
Solution:
The old propane heater is circa 1962. According to Austin Heating, it is shot and should be replaced. Wall mounted unit recommended since ductwork is questionable.

Client has a large propane tank outside that is partly full.

Heat registers are broken and pose a danger on the floor. Cover them up if a new heating system is installed.

Although the trailer is only 300 square feet, it is still hard to heat because of the under-insulated 2x2 walls.

An effort could be made to replace some insulation with solid polyiso board. Take off an exterior aluminum panel and check on the insulation.

Problem: Roof is old, flat, and leaks.Ceiling material has many stains and is starting to fall down.
Solution: There may be a way to put a metal roof on this thing. The walls are 2x2 so I hesitate to put more weight up there, but the trailer is only 10' x 30'. You could frame up some 2x2 rafters , use 1x2 perlins, and put metal on it. More study is needed.

Problem: Kitchen sink drain is missing some parts. Water drains out into a bucket that Mary dumps out when full.
Solution: Install S trap and other drain parts. Existing S trap is metal.

Problem: Deck needs repair or replacement. Posts lean, rotten decking.
Solution:
This deck was built 20 yrs. ago by Mars Hill Baptist. The ramp is the right slope and the deck is sloped away from the house, but the rails are not built to code. You may be able to reinforce and replace rather than completely rebuild; tough call. At any rate, diagonal bracing should be installed and rails should be built to code. Replace rotten deck boards.  

This is a pretty big deck, a smaller one could work here. Both exterior doors open to the deck.

Problem: Bathroom needs some work. Sink not usable because the faucet is broken.
Solution:
The subfloor here seems OK.  

Replace sink and cabinet.  

Replace tub surround; old tub may be OK. Faucets needed.  

Commode works but is old.

Problem: Some gravel is needed at the bottom of the driveway
Solution: Call Danny Collins and have him spread some gravel

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install

Problem:
There are several weak spots and holes in the floor. Some places are hard to see because they are hidden by thin linoleum and someone could fall thru if they did not know where the weak spots are.

The holes are in well traveled areas. They were caused by wear and tear and possibly from moisture coming up from the ground.

3 holes in kitchen

1 in living room

2 in bedroom
Solution:
Remove floor covering. Remove bad plywood. Reinforce joists. replace insulation if needed. Install new plwood , matching the thickness of the old. Install high quality laminate flooring over top. Do not use flimsy linoleum or cheap stick on tiles.

a rough estimate of the flooring needed is 300 square feet.

Problem:
Roof needs work. It is leaking on the corner of the porch and house, rafter tails are rotting. Water damage around chimney.

Existing porch roof pitch is not steep enough for shingles to be effective ( it is 2/12.).
Solution:
The permanent solution here is a new metal roof. However, the roof could be patched, boots replaced, etc. Neither the homeowner nor the landlord can recall the last time the roof had new shingles.

If the roof material is replaced, old shingles should be torn off to reduce weight on the framing. Tearing off old shingles would allow for repair to any damaged roof sheathing anyway.  

Estimate given for 970 square foot metal roof.

Problem: Gutters on the back side of the home are in bad shape and leak. They are the cheap vinyl kind. Water can easily get under the trailer because the gutters are ineffective.
Solution:
Install new, 5" aluminum gutters on the back side of the home. Install new downspouts . Buried drainpipe is not needed in this situation as long as the water can be diverted to a downhill location.

A downspout should be installed on each end of the trailer, the high point of the gutters should be in the middle.

If groups are experienced in gutter installation, order 20' lengths of gutter from Summit and have the supplies delivered.

Another option would be to have Joe from Mars Hill Hardware come out and help the crew. He can bring his truck and make any length gutter, and help install.

Problem: Insulation fallen out of some parts of the floor, especially around commode drain. Crawlspace access door is hard to open. Rusty metal panels that need to be removed for crawlspace access are dangerous to grab. No plastic down on ground under trailer.
Solution:
Make a couple of access doors or panels. Replace the rusty sheets of underpinning metal. Install some new insulation under trailer. Put down plastic under trailer to reduce moisture. Install some sheet metal screws to hold the pieces of metal underpinning together.

This job should go along with new gutters to dry the place out.

Problem: Loose outlet- AC outlet
Solution: Turn off power. Repair drywall around outlet. You may need a scrap of 3/8 drywall. You may need to replace the box as well.

Problem: Bathroom door in poor condition
Solution: Replace bathroom door and knob

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem:
Electrical problems

Some outlets do not work

Loose outlet in bathroom

Breakers trip sometimes
Solution:
Notify landlord of issues

Hire electrician to replace outlets, etc

Problem: Back deck in poor condition. Handrails wobbly. Posts are leaning. Temporary ramp in bad shape and too steep.
Solution:
Tear off old deck and ramp. Replace existing vinyl underpinning with recycled roof metal. Rebuild deck. Ramp not necessary at this time but could be built if finances permit. Deck height is 31".

Existing deck is 16' x 8'. The new deck will have to be a similar size to allow egress thru the sliding glass door and the other exterior door.  

Build at least one set of steps with a concrete landing. Code requires handrails since the deck is over 30".

Problem: cold air gets in around door
Solution: weatherstrip

Problem: Back door does not lock (sliding glass door)
Solution:
Get new lock

consult landlord- he should take care of this

Problem: Exterior light is getting wet due to hole in gutter. Streaks of rust are visible below the light fixture. .
Solution:
Install a mini- roof over the sliding glass door that also covers the light fixture. Replace light fixture.

This should be done after deck repair is complete.

The roof does not have to cover the entire deck. It should have at least a 2/12 pitch.

Problem: Old, funky carpet in hallway- to right of front door as you walk in. Carpet throughout house could stand to be replaced.
Solution: Tear out old carpet and install new flooring. Client has COPD so try to minimize dust

Problem: Front door blocked from fully opening because of trash. Back door hard to get out because of trash and dog feces. Trash and clutter throughout home makes it difficult to move safely through the house. Space heater partly blocked by clothes, etc.
Solution:
Big clean- up needed. Using contractor trash bags, gloves and other safety equipment, fill bags and load them into a trailer or truck. Take trash to the local dump which is next to Big Laurel Baptist, about 5.5 miles away.  

The collection center is open Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 7:30 am to 6 m. and Saturday from 8 to 5.

Collection ctr. on the Marshall Bypass (25/70) is open M-F 7-6 and Sat. 8-5.

Mary and I picked up a few bags of trash and cleared out some space from around the heater, but much more work is needed.

Dump card # 12030.

Problem: Refrigerator is broken. Rotten food inside.
Solution:
Refrigerator works but is full of spoiled food due to power outages. Clean out old fridge or dispose of it and get a new one.

If a new fridge is delivered, from Lowe's for example, the guys may dispose of the old one and install the new one.

Problem: Outside work. Trash in yard, cluttered shed
Solution:
Clean out shed, Haul off some yard debris, stack firewood in a dry place

Mimi does not want bushes to be pruned

Problem: Gutters clogged, leaking
Solution: Clean gutters and make some repairs. At this point it may be easier to replace gutters, or just remove them if she is not able to keep them clean.

Problem: Heating issues. Client has wood stove but no firewood. Monitor heater needs work (client has two).Heating oil supply low.
Solution:
Client has a hard time physically and does not want to deal with firewood, so the priority should be to get her monitor working.

I was not able to look, but she claims she can take the thermostat off the heater in the basement and put it on the one in her living room. She says she knows how to do this and has printed instructions, but needs help physically because you have to take the heaters loose from the wall in order to remove and install the thermostats.

Mimi has internet and knows of a You Tube video on how to do this.

Problem: Underpinning in poor condition. Animals (possums and dogs) get under the house. Insulation has fallen out. Lots of moisture under trailer. No plastic on ground under trailer. Pipes exposed to weather and could freeze.
Solution:
Remove all underpinning, which will increase visibility and allow area to dry out. Remove all old insulation. Lay new, 6 mil plastic down. Install new insulation. Install a pressure- treated underpinning frame with metal underpinning- used roof metal is ideal. Create crawlspace access doors.

Landlord Warren Ray said on the phone that he had plans to insulate the pipes and install some fiberglass insulation under the trailer before winter, however, if the underpinning is not adressed the animals will just get back under there and tear the insulation out again.

Gutters would be helpful here to dry out the area, but it is unlikely that the gutters will be cleaned by the homeowner or the landlord.

French drain or drainage ditch with gravel may be an alternative to gutters here.

UPDATE- several crews have worked here see below

Problem: A couple of plumbing boots on the roof are damaged and could leak.
Solution: Replace boots , these may be available at Discount mobile home Supply

Problem: Broken storm window
Solution:
Replace storm window. The broken one has a flange, and is removable from the inside. Measurements, including the flange, are 32 3/8" wide x 54 7/8" high.

Call Discount Mobile Home to order window.

Problem: Back bedroom, used as a storage room, is moldy according to Martha.
Solution: Clean room. Throw out junk. Open windows and ventilate with a fan.

Problem: Floor damaged under fridge
Solution: A piece of plywood has been placed under the fridge, so I am guessing that it is covering a hole. Remove fridge, remove piece of plywood, and inspect the damage. Remove bad plywood, reinforce joists, add insulation, and install new plywood with a thickness matching that of the existing floor.

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install

Problem: Commode is wobbly due to a weak floor. Floor is water damaged; water on floor. There are a couple of small leaks in the copper water lines under the sink.
Solution:
Supply line is not leaking. Looks like the leak is around the flush box. It could also be a bad wax ring, there is water around the bottom of the commode.

Pull commode. Remove damaged subfloor material. Inspect commode flange for damage. Reinforce joists. install new insulation. install new plywood. Set flange at correct height ( Bottom of flange should rest on top of the finished floor. )Install 30 square feet of new flooring material (laminate vinyl flooring suitable for wet locations or tile is recommended). Install new wax ring. Install new, ADA approved commode .

Shut off water. Repair leaks in copper line with shark-bite couplings. Replace old shut- off valve with a new ball valve.

Update- problem has gotten worse as of 1-9-19

Problem: Hallway in front of washer/dryer has a weak floor.
Solution: Remove washer/dryer and inspect floor for other weak spots. Remove bad subfloor material, reinforce joists, replace insulation if needed, and install new plywood. Install approx. 25 square feet of new floor covering ( vinyl laminate flooring suitable for wet locations recommended). Install metal transition strips to meet up with the old floor material.

Problem: Bad floors in bedroom. Worst section is next to the wall between the bathroom and bedroom.
Solution:
Tear up carpet in part or all of room. Remove damaged plywood. reinforce floor joists. Install new insulation if needed. Install new plywood (CDX recommended.)

This room is unused at this time so new floor covering is not urgent.

Problem: Some cleanup and yard work needed. Gutters clogged. Siding dirty.
Solution: Clean gutters. Clean up flower beds. Wash siding. haul off some stuff. Yard work.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install a battery operated unit

Problem: There is some yard work that Laney may need help with
Solution: Weed flower beds, plant flowers, split wood for fie pit. There are some splittable logs next to the fire pit.

Problem: Randy's driveway is in bad condition. It is very steep. 4wd is required, and in good weather, the driveway is passable, but when it is muddy or snowy residents must park at the bottom and walk up. The driveway is less than 1/4 mile, but is straight up all the way. Big ruts. Randy says he has wrecked a few times.
Solution:
Randy says that when he had the money, he would hire Danny Collins to dump loads of gravel, which worked, but required lots of money and continuous maintenance. I asked Randy about the possibility of rebuilding a less steep road. He explained that his property, about 2.75 acres, was "hourglass shaped " and may be hard to re- route a new road through it.

A highly experienced grader may be able to plan a less steep route through the property, but they would have to be aware of property lines, or get permission from neighbors. A new road would also be extremely expensive.

The best route for now may be to just put more gravel on the road. Randy estimates it would take 7 8- ton loads.

Danny may have some ideas about how to improve the road with waterbreaks, culverts, etc.

Problem: Decks and siding in need of pressure washing
Solution: Rent a pressure washer and clean the decks and vinyl siding.

Problem: Although the deck frame is in OK condition, several deck boards are rotten, split, or missing. Ramp handrail missing. Handrail post wobbly. There are a couple "Mini ramps" out back that need improvement.
Solution:
Priority 1) The deck is 8' x 70'. Replace , at minimum, 1/3 of the boards. . There is a"mini-ramp," covered by carpet, that is spongy. This is the entrance/ exit Kile uses most. This "mini ramp" should be torn out and replaced with one that is wider. The deck boards under it are bad anyway.  

Repair handrail top. Replace post and put it in concrete.  

Priority 2) The ramps around back, although not used as much, should be worked on. There is a big concrete slab out back. One ramp is too steep. It would be nice to improve the ramps so that Kile, an outdoor enthusiast, could spend some time outside on the decks.

Problem:
The third bathroom, which is the one most used by the family, is big and has two sinks. There is a shower, but you have to step up to get in it. The commode is located in a place which is hard for Kile to get in and out of .  

Wilma wants to re design this bathroom so that Kile can use it easier.
Solution:
One of the sinks could be removed, which would free up some space. A closet wall could probably be removed. Reposition commode, install walk-in shower.

The subfloor is sound here.

Problem: The second bathroom, which is 30" x 71", is unusable by the client. Commode wobbles.
Solution:
This could be a good backup bathroom if "spruced up'. The commode flange is probably too high, that's why it is wobbling. It does not appear to be leaking and the subfloor seems sound.  

  

Remove commode, fix flange, replace flooring. Add new wax ring, commode, etc.

Problem:
4 1/2' x 8' bathroom is in poor shape. Dangerous holes in floor, hidden by carpet. Hole under commode.

Clients do not use this bathroom.
Solution:
Bathroom remodel. New subfloor. Reinforce joists.

Since there are two other bathrooms in the home, one approach would be to remove the tub, commode, and sink, cap off the water lines and drain lines, reinforce joists and add insulation, and put down a new subfloor. That would make it safe. This room could potentially become a closet for storage.

Problem: Excess moisture in crawlspace
Solution: install 6 mil plastic on ground under trailer

Problem: Moldy smell in bedroom
Solution:
Help Wilma clean out the room. Clean walls with bleach.  

There are holes in the adjacent bathroom floors so there may be soft places in the floor of this room. Moisture coming up from the ground may be causing the smell.

Problem: The chimney that services their wood stove needs cleaning.
Solution: Get a chimney brush and clean the chimney

Problem: Electric furnace is in need of service. Wilma says it " clicks off and on".
Solution: Get a good HVAC man to look at it.

Problem: Kitchen floor linoleum peeling up
Solution: Install good quality vinyl plank flooring. Approx. 100 sq. feet.

Problem: No CO detectors. Smoke alarms missing or disabled
Solution: install CO/Smoke Detector- battery powered

Problem:
The Chandlers have a wood stove in the kitchen. The chimney is not safe.

They have a Monitor heater but it needs work.
Solution:
Chimney is supported by a concrete slab up in the attic. An inspection revealed a pretty wide crack in the brick work. The stovepipe does not go up into the chimney very far.

Some improvements could be made to the existing system, but the long term, safest solution is a stainless steel double wall chimney.

I told the Chandlers that they shouldn't use the stove till it can be made safer.

Shane F (son-in law) says he will provide them with some space heaters til they can make some improvements in their heat situation.

Problem: Front door is broken. Glass pane busted. Strike plate needed.
Solution:
New door. Since this door is kept in the dry, you could use a wood door slab. You may have to cut the door down slightly. The existing door slab is 32" x 78 3/4". Install new strike plate. You may need to make some repairs to the jam where the strike plate is. Door opens in with hinges on the left.

Existing doorknob is serviceable.

Problem: Front gutter leaks. This is especially problematic during the winter when the leaking water then freezes on his front step.Gutters on the back of the home are undersized and in poor condition.
Solution: Install a new gutters across the front and back of the house. Make sure gutter seams are not above steps in case of leaks in the long term. Tie downspouts to existing drains.

Problem: bushes growing close to house
Solution: prune

Problem: Bathtub tile surround has some loose tiles. water could be getting in the walls. Tile installed in 1970's.
Solution:
Re-do tile surround

Plumbing is ok here

Problem: Basement cluttered. Lori wants to clean it out.
Solution: Clean basement

Problem: Deck boards are slick and staying wet. Grass is growing up between them . Rails are not built correctly and are not sturdy enough.
Solution:
Some work has been done here by volunteers a couple of years ago. The concrete deck has been busted up and removed. Wood framing and pressure treated 5/4 deck boards were installed in its place. The Deck now has a slope away from the house, which is good, but plastic sheeting was placed on top of the framing before the deck boards were installed, causing water to pool up between the deck boards and deteriorate the wood (it cannot dry out.)

I suspect the reason that the plastic was installed was to try to keep water out of the space under the deck. The deck is underpinned with cinder blocks. There is an airspace between the joists, so water won't be totally trapped under there. The plastic needs to come off. Replace the deck boards if they have started to rot on the bottom. Reuse if still in good shape.

Some kind of drainage system may be needed to get rid of water under the deck but I do not know exactly how to do this right now.

Rails need improvement. New 4x4 posts should be added in between the existing ones, and notched into the framing. Then put the deck boards on, notching around the posts. . Install pickets.

This deck is 24 feet long by 92" wide.

Problem: The back deck is not a safe entry/exit. The door is in ok shape, but the deck that you walk out onto is wobbly. A section of the deck is sinking and needs to be removed. There are no safe steps.
Solution:
Remove parts of deck. Rebuild parts of deck. You may have to temporarily support the porch roof while doing this. Build 2 sets of good steps. Build rails since you have a disabled client. Deck height is 26".

Plans for this deck can be found in Wanda's file, copied and given to workers.

Problem: In the living room, there is a place where a wall was removed. You can see the outline of the framing on the ceiling and walls. There are some exposed wires, not in boxes, that are in the ceiling where the wall used to be. Drywall sags here.
Solution: I don't think that the wall was load-bearing, but the drywall is sagging. A finished, "post &beam" type assembly should be put in place here to hold up the drywall where it sags. The wires should be put in boxes to the side of the post &beam, so they won't be covered by the wood.

Problem: Bathroom sink countertop has a big crack through it. Drain leaks.
Solution:
Idea 1)Wanda has a newer pedestal sink on her porch. This sink needs a bracket to attach to the wall. Wanda says she will try to get the needed bracket. If she finds it, remove sink, drainpipes, and cabinet. Install pedestal sink. Wanda has a faucet for it.You will need drain parts for it.

Idea 2). Replace the existing countertop/sink unit. The cabinet looks like it is in ok shape, but one of the doors is askew. If you can fix the door, you can just get a new sink/countertop and use the existing faucet. You will still need to replace some drain parts because the drain is now leaking.

Problem: Kitchen floor has a place where the plywood has some "give" to it.
Solution: I suspect this problem is due to the plywood not breaking correctly over the joists. You will have to remove some linoleum and cut out some plywood to figure out how to reinforce the framing. Then screw plywood down and install a threshold strip or narrow band of some kind of flooring to hide the repair.

Problem: The kitchen sink cabinet is damaged and sunken in. This happened due to an old leak (repaired).
Solution: Remove bottom of cabinet. Inspect subfloor for damage and make any needed repairs. Replace cabinet bottom with plywood. 5/8" will probably work. You may need to install a couple of sticks of wood to hold up the plywood. Approx. 6'long x 24" wide piece of plywood.

Problem: Front door hangs up on floor. It is pretty worn out.
Solution: The front door needs to be repositioned in the opening. The floor here seems solid but due to some past repairs, has a hump in it that causes the door to hang on the bottom. Since you have to remove the door, it would be a good time to replace it because it is starting to wear out. You will also probably have to modify the rough opening and re- do some trim , inside and out.

Problem: underpinning repairs and installation needed to minimize pipe freezing
Solution:
Wanda used to install underpinning on trailers for a living. She has collected enough vinyl under pinning to do the job, just needs help installing. You will need to purchase some materials. Involve Wanda in the planning process for this job.

It would be a good time to put down some plastic and clean out the underside of the trailer. Patch up insulation that has fallen down.

Problem: Washing machine does not work. Drainpipe for it freezes.
Solution: Remove washing machine and haul off. I am not sure why the drainpipe freezes and did not assess thoroughly, Crawl under house to see if the pipe could be insulated or protected in some way.

Problem: Hallway drywall in rough shape, some missing. Good size hole in wall.
Solution: Repair, hang, and finish drywall. Mud, tape, sand, paint. install some trim.

Problem:
There is no soffit on the back side of the house. Siding missing up high.

No gutters on house.
Solution:
Install soffit material. You could use plywood for the soffit and siding like they did in the front. Some vents should be put in place. Caulk and paint.

Wanda has a long piece of gutter in good shape. Hang gutter on back side. Install downspout, drainpipes. Bury drainpies if possible, taking care to avoid underground water,drain, or power lines.

Problem: Wanda is in the midst of a bedroom remodel. There is a weak place in the subfloor.
Solution:
Wanda has got the room stripped down to bare, plywood subfloor. Remove a section of plywood (it is screwed down). Reinforce joists and make the subfloor solid.

Paint the walls. Wanda is an experienced painter and should lead the project.

Install about 100 sft. of high quality laminate flooring. Install a removable plywood panel in front of the water heater closet. There is a full sheet of 5/8" plywood on site. Install trim.

Problem: The higher part of the exterior of home is unpainted. Bare plywood.
Solution: Nail down any loose plywood. Caulk. Paint.

Problem: Wanda's metal roof is starting to rust.
Solution: Apply sealant to roof. Wanda has a 5 gal. bucket of Kool-Seal. You will have to purchase more to apply two coats (recommended).

Problem: Pileated woodpeckers have damaged the well house.
Solution: Wanda's dad has the wood to fix this. Contact him and get him involved in the project.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Deck in bad shape
Solution:
Tear down and rebuild.

existing deck is 6' x 11'. Deck height 35"

Rebuild steps with concrete pad landing. Install rails.

Problem:
Water is getting into the side of the building. Damage has happened to some window sills.

No leaks were seen or reported on the inside ceiling of the home, only on the sides.
Solution:
Because of the age of the trailer, a new roof with fascia, gutters and drainage is the permanent solution. Metal is rusty and the edges are cracking.

Mary has stopped some leaks by installing some new screws, caulk, etc. Trailer has had a thin layer of Kool Seal.

Cleaning the mini- gutters, installing new screws, Kool Seal and caulk will help if finances do not allow a new roof. If you go this route, go ahead and caulk the roof penetrations.

Problem: Heat pump not working.
Solution:
Repair pump.

Mary has a working Monitor heater that does the job.

Problem: Several tree limbs are touching roof. Yard work needed. haul off some trash, clean gutters
Solution: Haul off some trash, clean gutters, prune , etc.

Problem: Dangerous electrical issues. Several outlets are pulled out of the wall. There is some exposed, hot wiring. Breakers are tripping.
Solution: Have a good electrician address safety issues

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution:
New metal roof. Gutters and drainage.

This is a 20+ year old shingle roof. Shingles are worn. It looks like someone tried to build a porch roof onto the existing roof and tore it off, causing some leaks. There is one leak that drips when it rains in this location, visible from the living room.

Install 1x4 perlins over the shingles every 2'.

PENETRATIONS: 1)two 1 1/2" plumbing vents 2) one roof vent 3)one bath fan

The roof is a 3/12 pitch. It is 7'8" on either side of the ridge. Length not measured, check with Beth, looks like standard 60' length

Install new ridge vent material.

Install gutters. Fascia board with drip edge and flashing already exists here.
