hook up downspouts to drainpies which carry the water to a downhill location. Determine location of all buried lines and dig ditches for drainpipes if possible.

Problem: Kids' bathroom tub is cracked and leaking. It is causing the floor to rot. Drips visible under trailer.
Solution:
I told the family to stop using this tub to keep floor damage from getting worse. They have another bathroom in good shape.

Remove old tub. It is a trailer-size tub with a center drain, order from Discount Mobile Home.

Repair subfloor with new plywood, sister joists. Add insulation.

You may have to replace the surround as well.

Problem:
Deck steps need replacement. Rotten tread, no landing pad, broken stringer. Not built to code.  

Height of deck is around 42"
Solution:
Replace steps, build handrails. If you make the treads end close to the outside wall you will only have to build one handrail.  

Make a concrete pad landing at the bottom.

Problem: Beth's main source of heat are two space heaters and a portable Kerosene heater
Solution: Mini split or other efficient heater

Problem: No finished flooring under kitchen sink. Small hole in subfloor.
Solution: Clean out area and make sure the subfloor is good, repair if needed, then install a few pieces of laminate flooring under the kitchen sink.

Problem: Junk clutters yard
Solution: haul off with truck

Problem: No CO detector. Clients have kerosene heater
Solution: Install

Problem:
There is a big deck in front of the trailer. It has pulled away from the house leaving a 10" gap between the door and deck. A kid fell through one time.

Deck 20 yrs old and in rough shape, posts are leaning.
Solution:
Tear down the deck.Homeowners will have access to a tractor- that may be an easy way to tear this down. Haul unusable materials to the landfill using Mikey's truck.

Rebuild a smaller deck. Talk to the owners, a 6x8 deck would probably be fine. Make it freestanding and sloping away from the house. Build steps and rails. Make a concrete landing at the bottom.

Problem: Back deck is in bad shape.20+ years old. it slopes towards the house. Bad rails. Steps are unsafe.
Solution: Tear down and rebuild a free standing deck. Existing deck is 6'x8'. Deck is around 3' off the ground. Build rails, steps. Slope deck away from house.

Problem: Roof is rusted and leaks. 3/12 pitch.
Solution:
Install a metal roof with soffit, fascia, gutters and drainage.

Talk to Edward Roberts, he has liability, is local, and knows the family.

Problem: Outlet in Bathroom does not work.
Solution: Replace outlet (nonGFI) with GFI outlet.

Problem: There is some heavy trash that should go to the landfill. An old, broken freezer needs to be cleaned out.
Solution: Clean out old freezer. Haul stuff to landfill. Clean up yard. Mikey has a flat bed truck.

Problem: The Roberts' can use some help with cutting bushes and other yard work
Solution: Cut brush, weedeat, clean up yard

Problem: No Co detector
Solution: install

Problem: ceiling drywall and some trim has come loose in some places inside the house.
Solution: The roof should be fixed first. Then you can come in and do some drywall repair. This could involve removing existing drywall and fixing some ceiling framing.

Problem: A sewer drain pipe has come loose under the trailer
Solution:
Remove some underpinning to access the area. Clean and glue the pipe together.

I gave Sarah Rooter King's number. and another number in Erwin, TN. She is going to try and take care of this problem herself ASAP. I told her to keep us posted.

Problem: Some 10 years ago, according to homeowner, a tree fell on the roof, The roof was damaged and is misshapen as a result. The previous owners covered the entire roof with asphalt roll roofing. This, remarkably, has kept the roof from leaking for many years, but it is starting to wear out. A couple small leaks, staining the ceiling, are visible inside the home, as well as a porch roof leak. Sarah is rightfully concerned that the damaged roof may not support a big snow load.
Solution:
The existing roof here is a 3/12 pitch. In order to address the structural issues, 2x4 rafters should be installed over the existing roof every 2 feet. Plumb cut rafter tails and allow rafters to overhang the building by at least 8". Install perlins, 2x4 sub fascia and 1x6 pressure treated fascia board. Then metal can go over that.

Install gutters, downpouts and drainpipes.

install vinyl "F"channel on the building and sub fascia. Install vented vinyl soffit material to keep out bugs.

Problem: There are some continuously wet areas around the trailer. Sarah says there is a spring on one corner, under the old shed that needs to be removed. Ground stays wet under trailer.
Solution:
Dig a French Drain . start where the old shed was, then go around the side. Another French Drain could be dug around the back. DETERMINE LOCATIONS OF ALL POWER LINES, WATER LINES AND DRAIN PIPES BEFORE DIGGING.

A French drain can be put in by low skill workers, but In order for it to work it must be done right, Use solid sewer pipe (the white, solid stuff, not corrugated black pipe). with holes. Cover that with silt cloth. Use 3/4 gravel. Follow CHC guidelines.

Gravel can be ordered and delivered from Danny Collins at 828-777-6352

Problem: Underpinning needs work.
Solution:
Sarah wants to clean out debris from under there, add plastic, and replace some underpinning. I told her to be on the lookout for some used roof metal to use as underpinning. Cut custom pieces of metal to fit the space. When installing the metal, check plumb with a level every once in a while.

Build a pressure treated 2x4x frame to support the underpinning and make a couple access doors , especially around back where the water line is.

Problem: Old shed needs to be remove so drainage ditches can be dug.
Solution: Dismantle shed and haul off / reuse materials.

Problem: Old electric furnace is no longer used. Sarah says it still works but she wants it removed . The chimney will need to be removed for roof repairs anyway. Her wood stove provides sufficient heat.
Solution: Remove furnace and chimney and convert the space into a closet.

Problem:
Back porch is in bad shape. There is a roof leak that soaks the area in front of the main entry/ exit of the home, making it slippery. Porch floorboards have rotted and fallen through making it unsafe.

Area is extremely cluttered. there is an old fridge that does not work. The freezer, which works, is leaning because it has fallen thru the floorboards. Freezer is rusty.
Solution:
Short term solution-

Remove debris from area and put in dumpster. The fridge may need to be disposed of in a certain way- ask Griffin about this. Make a safe way for clients to get in and out of their home. This may involve building back part of a porch or a ramp,or even a gravel pathway, and patching up the leak above to dry out the area.

If safe, get up on the roof and patch the hole with a piece of tin. Replace rotten roof boards.

Get the clients an new freezer. Make a temporary place to put it while the porch area is being worked on.

Long term solution is a new porch, or extensive repairs. Note- lead paint is present. Asbestos shingles. Special procedures must be followed during demo.

Problem:
Front porch has a bad roof leak that has caused major structural damage. A post has fallen down. Lots of rotten material on that corner of the roof. Porch framing damaged. Holes in deck.

This is not a safe exit. Although the steps (concrete and block), are in ok condition, porch is too damaged to safely walk on.

The porch foundation is block. Some are broken. The blockwork serves as underpinning.
Solution:
The solution here is probably going to be a complete tear-off and rebuild. You may be able to save the roof by supporting it with temporary posts and repairing framing.

The siding here is asbestos shingles.Lead paint may be present., so special procedures must be followed during demo.

Problem: There are some electrical issues that appear urgent. Missing covers, loose wires, etc.
Solution: Look at wiring under the kitchen countertop that serves the water heater and pump. these wires should be tested and put in boxes. unused wiring should be removed.

Problem: Home is cluttered, especially on the outside. There are old refrigerators, bags of trash, and debris piles that are preventing accurate assessment of some parts of the house.
Solution:
Order a dumpster and a Port a Jon from Griffin Waste services. Get a crew out there to remove trash.

Griffin- 828-281-4549

Dumpster rental for 3 days- $285

Port-a -jon rental- $100 for 4 weeks.

Maybe get some plastic, sealable tote boxes for Nora to put stuff in she wants to keep

Problem: Bathroom in rough condition. Toilet leaning. Tub faucet plumbing exposed. Wall covering missing. Floors uneven and water-damaged.
Solution: Complete bathroom remodel. uo may be able to re-use the old cast iron tub if you can clean it.

Problem: Drain leaks. This problem was reported by a volunteer plumber from Foster Creek Church. Kitchen sink drains onto ground. Bathtub drains onto ground.
Solution: ~~At assessment time, my flashlight batteries were dying and there was some kind of varmint under the house that I could not see well. Assess drainpipes and go from there ?~~ ?Re-do drain system under house- the commode drain seems ok, but kitchen and bath drains are not hooked up. PVC drain pipes. Rooter- King Job? __~~__~~

Problem: New countertop and kitchen cabinets needed. The old countertop is rotten and the cabinet is moldy from water damage
Solution: Install new countertop and cabinets.

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install

Problem: A wire has been cut that goes from the pump to an exterior electrical box. the wire has been spliced together, but since it is outside, it could short out if it gets wet. Then she would be out of water. Wire is covered by a milk jug, and currently goes underground for a ways.
Solution:
Cut power to pump. Remove wire from box and pump. Use conduit and run it along the side of the house. Drill a hole through the side of the pump house and rewire the pump. A 30' section of wire should do it.

Ann has an aquaintance that has agreed to do this job, but he has not showed up yet.

Problem: There is a soft place on the roof around the masonry chimney. The shingles are coming up around the electrical boot. Shingles are 20 yrs old. Drip edge was never installed. Fascia board and soffit are damaged. Gutters are falling off.
Solution:
Strip off shingles. Repair roof deck with new plywood in places that need it. Install drip edge. Re-shingle roof. Flash chimney. You may need to cut a ridge vent. Metal roof also an option but there are a couple of valleys. Install split boot around electrical weatherhead, new vents around plumbing boots.

Repair soffit and fascia. Repair or replace gutters.

Roof is approximately 1640 square feet. Roof pitch is approximately 5/12.

Problem: Ann's only source of heat is a wood stove. Although it is a good heat source, and her family helps her get wood, she is not as physically able to deal with firewood as she once was.
Solution: Client requests small, efficient propane heater. She does not want oil.

Problem: Some siding is damaged due to moisture.
Solution: The existing siding is a fiber-board type stuff that deteriorates easily when the paint wears off, and is falling apart in places. Replace part of the siding with T-111 or other similar material. Install flashing and caulk where the two sidings meet to keep water out.This siding is probably 5/8" thick but you better double check. Paint. Whole house could use paint, client has a 5 gal. bucket that is probably still good.

Problem: Drier vents out into the living room, pushing moist air into living room.
Solution: Get a vent kit and hood. look behind the dryer, unplug. You may have to cut a hole in the floor. Run vent to the outside of the house , through a hood attached to the exterior siding.

Problem: Well pump shed (attached to house) needs work. Door is damaged and hard to open/close. Bad wiring to pump (see other repair).
Solution:
Replace door. Get an exterior door, 32" x 80. The existing door is left hinge and swings out.

Roof needs work and leaks. , there are no shingles up under the soffit, probably because they were impossible to install (no room to swing a hammer). A metal roof could work here.

Some other improvements could be made to the well house - insulation , etc.

Problem:
Deck has a set of steps that are not built to code. One step is super high.

Deck boards are slick and dirty
Solution: Rebuild deck steps with rails. Clean deck with wire brush or pressure washer, or replace boards if finances permit. 8' x 8' deck.

Problem: Home is cluttered
Solution: Assist Ann with removing and storing various items. Donate, throw away, etc.

Problem: Insulation in crawlspace is falling out. Faced fiberglass r13. Paper facing on insulation is moldy.
Solution: Remove insulation. Faced insulation should not be installed in a crawlspace. There is good underpinning here so more may not be needed.

Problem: No smoke or CO Detector
Solution: install battery powered combo unit

Problem:
There is an addition, built only 8 yrs. ago, that has mold. It is on the ceiling. An inspection of the roof revealed that the pitch is way too shallow ( less than 1 /12) for shingles, therefore it leaked, causing the mold problem. A couple places on the roof were soft.

The floor is also weak along the back wall.It was built way too close to the ground, with the band and some joists touching the ground, and moisture has caused rot.

The family has closed off this room and the adjacent (unused) bedroom to minimize mold exposure.
Solution: This room would be hard to fix without great expense. Unfortunately the best solution to this problem may be to tear the entire (12' x 12') addition off entirely. Then you could fix the roof back with the original (3/12) pitch, reinstall plywood and shingles, and close off the door, or make another exit.

Problem: Back deck slick, broken boards. This is their second exit.
Solution:
Remove old washing machines and junk. Tear off deck. Improve gravel pathway and put a concrete step in front of the door. Use scrap wood to make a concrete form.

The doorway is close to the ground so a deck is not really needed here anyway.

Problem: Primary Bathroom needs a new shower stall . Client says it leaks. No floor damage yet.
Solution: Install new 36" x 36" corner shower stall. Other upgrades may be needed. Clean and paint. Install bathroom fan.

Problem: There is a bedroom , part of the original trailer, That needs work in order to be used.
Solution:
Clean out stuff. Repair drywall (probably 3/8"). Clean walls, paint. I did not see any roof leaks or mold in this room.

This should be done after the more urgent removal of the moldy addition.

Job may involve removing the exterior door or making an exit to the outside here.

Problem: There is a second bathroom (8' x 8') in the home that the clients would like to have remodeled. The batrhroom has not been used in years. Tub is cracked, lots of clutter in the room.
Solution:
Remove clutter. Replace tub. Other repairs may be needed- state of plumbing unknown.

First priority should be to fix the primary bathroom, then if funds allow work on this one.

Problem: Gutters are clogged. Overgrown limbs touch roof.
Solution: Trim back branches and clean gutters

Problem: Vinyl siding dirty
Solution: Wash with a pressure washer

Problem: No Co or smoke detectors in the house
Solution: install battery powered combo unit

Problem: Crystal has a well in front of her house, by the road. It is covered by a wooden box made of scrap lumber. The concern is that the well pump, pressure tank, switch, etc. will get wet and freeze because there is no roof on the structure, just some un - nailed boards covering the top. Water pipe is severely blistering and in imminent danger of bursting.
Solution:
Remove top of box. Remove old insulation. Replace existing damaged water line. Check pressure tank and switch for correct pressure and leaks. After fixing all problems, put some new, dry insulation in there (Imogene has some).

Make a roof for the box out of treated lumber and roof metal .

Problem: Home hard to heat. Not muck insulation in attic
Solution: Remove gable vent cover. Rent an insulation blower and blow cellulose insulation in attic.

Problem: Crystal needs a better heater
Solution:
Right now she has gas logs run by a portable propane tank, and space heaters.

Mini split or better propane heater and bigger tank recommended.

Problem: Window and house trim is rotten and has been infested by wood bees. Paint has tested positive for lead.
Solution: Wrap window and fascia trim with aluminum. Paint soffits.

Problem: Roof leaks. Bad plumbing boot.
Solution:
Landlord has applied Kool seal and tar about 3 yrs ago according to Jerry.

Lower cost repair- more Kool seal, new trailer gutters, and more caulk and roof cement. Replace 1 1/2" plumbing boot.

A metal roof could be installed over the home but that would require trusses because of the flat roof.

Trailer is approximately 30 feet long. It is 12 feet wide.

Problem: Wobbly handrail
Solution: Re- do the guard rails on the long side. The existing deck is 6' wide x 20' long. When you build back the rails, install a post through the deck framing and into the ground for more stability ( the existing 4x4 is just screwed into the deck boards, that is why the rail is unstable). Some other work could be done on this deck, it is showing signs of age but is stable other than the rail. Steps are good.

Problem: A lot of air comes in through the windows making the home hard to heat. Window putty is cracked and panes are loose.
Solution:
Install some new, energy- efficient windows. You can order them from Discount Mobile Home Supply in Weaverville.

The three windows that need replacement the most are 41 1/4" high x 31 1/2" wide (including flange)

Problem: Door is floppy. Lots of air gets in around it. Older style trailer door with diamond window.
Solution: Install a new exterior door with a storm door. The existing door is 73 1/2" high x 32" wide (slab size). left hinge, opens in.

Problem: Bathroom needs some work. Tub has come loose from the wall, and although stable, water can get behind the tub and damage the wall and cause mold.
Solution: The floor seems stable, but the condition of the wall behind the tub , where water can find its way in, is unknown. Install new tub and surround, maybe some fixtures, possibly new vanity faucet.

Problem: No smoke detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Gutters needed. Water from hill runs under house.
Solution:
A 30 foot section of gutter has been installed on the back of the house, over the main entrance. A downspout goes into a drainpipe, which runs along the side of the house and downhill. A similar system could be set up on the opposite side with the water being directed downhill. If drainpipes are installed underground you will need permission from the landlord, Larry Wyatt. You will also need to determine locations of any underground pipes or lines before digging. Sheila seems to think that digging ditches for drainpipes would be just fine with the landlord.

90 feet of gutter is still needed. Purchase 5" gutters and aceessories from Summit (they will deliver 20 foot sections) so they will fit with the existing gutters. Follow the pattern of what has been done before.

Problem: Where one of the worst windows is rotted around frame, appears there's wall damage here as well. Jake assessed further when he went to measure windows and made Eddie aware of the situation.
Solution: Speak with Jake. May involve removing siding, any rotten materials, and replacing.

Problem: The Morrow's only use woodburning stove to heat.
Solution: Work out with homeowner the most preferred and efficient way to heat the home. As they age, woodburning will become more difficult.

Problem: Plumbing freezes.
Solution: Repair broken pipes. Insulate.

Problem: No insulation.
Solution: Install insulation.

Problem: Porous asphalt siding on main home exterior.
Solution: Install new, durable siding.

Problem: Roof leaks. 5 V tin roof - the tin is old and rusty. The nails have been pounded down too much, destroying the sealing function.
Solution: New metal roof is needed.

Problem: Bathroom attachment is a platform type construction versus a standard stud frame construction. Exterior walls are covered with rolled asphalt roofing atop Celotex black fiber board. Fiber board is exposed on three sides causing water damage to the walls and windows.
Solution:
Re-frame bathroom walls. Install new siding. Drywall and paint interior.

Size of bathroom attachment is 8' x 23'9".

Problem: Weak floor in front of cook stove.
Solution: Repair joists if needed, lay new sub-floor, and install new floor covering.

Problem: The bathroom floor is very soft, specifically around the toilet. Joists are lacking, especially framing near the toilet. Floor slopes away from main house construction. There is no water in the toilet. Shower has been unusable for over 10 years. Floor, ceiling and walls have severe water damage. The bathroom is an addition to the original home and was done very poorly. There is no insulation.
Solution: Tear off existing bathroom and replace with a new room. Most cost effective solution is to bring in an prefab 8x10 building and built out the bathroom in it. Family will need a porta-jon during the renovation.

Problem: Kitchen sink drain not hooked up properly
Solution: Investigate best solution

Problem: Gutters requested.
Solution: Per phone convo w/Rena 7/25, she feels like trailer would last longer with gutters. She believes water runs down and into her walls and that is quite possible.

Problem: Floor beneath bathtub is getting weaker. Previously water damaged.
Solution: Per phone convo w/Rena 7/25, now that the tub has been repaired, it's getting used more, they are noticing how weak floor is. It is not at the point of falling through, but soft. She'll call if it gets worse.

Problem: Bathroom faucet leaks around faucet.
Solution: Per phone convo w/Rena 7/25, faucet is very old and prob just needs replacing.

Problem: Kitchen sink leak underneath
Solution: Relayed by Rena via phone convo 7/25. Need to investigate why leaking.

Problem: Front porch handrail post on lower right is deteriorated.
Solution: Remove and replace post.

Problem: Kitchen sink cabinet base is falling apart due to water damage.
Solution: Replace fiber board in cabinet.

Problem: Interior passage/entry door latches missing. Master bedroom and closet doors inoperative.
Solution: Remove and replace door latches.

Problem: Dangerous electrical issues. Hot wires exposed.
Solution: Replace broken and missing cover plates. Rework electrical box in laundry room. Address hot wires in kitchen.

Problem: Broken vinyl tile flooring.
Solution: Remove tiles and replace floor covering.

Problem: Deteriorating carpet.
Solution: Pull up carpet and replace floor covering.

Problem:
Window frames and sashs broken and cracked glass.

Update-There are 5 broken or cracked windows. One of the kids cut themselves on a broken pane.
Solution:
Consider replacement with vinyl DBL hung.

Glass 29 1/2" W x 26 1/4" H.

Est. cost for each window is $279.00.

4 of the windows measure 55 1/2" tall x 31 3/4" wide , including the flange.

One smaller window, broken, is 15 3/4" wide x 41 3/4" high.

There are five windows in the CHC storage bldg. (Marshall location) that would fit the 55 1/2" x 31 3/4" size; they are a bit smaller.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem: Both bathrooms need toilet and lid replacement.
Solution: Replace toilets, seats, and lids in both bathrooms.

Problem: No bath or shower in either bathroom.
Solution:
Master bathroom - shower surround is missing

Hallway bathroom - needs new shower surround over existing bath tub.

.

Update- my view is to remodel the smaller (hallway)bathroom so the clients will have one good bathroom. This would involve commode replacement or repair, new sink and cabinet, and a new, sturdier fibergass tub and new surround.

Problem: Water heater is leaking and is 30yrs old.
Solution: Replace water heater. Ensure elements are sized to fit electrical breaker.

Problem: Bathroom drain system needs to be redone. Old tub cracked. Walk- in shower needed.
Solution:
This will be a complex bathroom remodel because the bathroom was built on a concrete slab. A channel will have to be cut in the concrete for new drainpipes.

Remove old tub. Remove bathroom sink. Remove chest of drawers. Remove washer.

Old drainpipes are ABS.

Problem:
Paint, trim, siding and caulk are needed on some unfinished parts of the home. There is a place out back and also on the porch.

CAUTION: This home was built before 1978 and may contain lead- based paint. Lead paint is suspected. Use Lead paint safety measures if disturbing more than 10 square feet.

There is a place around back that is not painted at all and needs siding- this would be a good place to start.
Solution: Install hardi board siding, trim, paint, caulk.

Problem: There is a piece of trim that is pulling off the house. The phone line and sattelite cable are attached to it.
Solution: Call phone company and sattelite company. If no response then go up on a ladder and use a bar clamp to pull the board into place, then use screws to re-attach. Use caution around the nearby power line.

Problem: There are gutters on the home . This may be on purpose, some people don't want them, but water can drain into the basement.
Solution: Talk to the family, maybe some gutters could be installed in some places as long as they can be cleaned regularly

Problem: A tree fell on the roof in December. The gable end was damaged and the roof leaks as a result.
Solution:
The roof is not leaking bad, and some temporary patching has been done, but it could get worse. There is also another small leak on the far end of the house, but on the same side of the roof. There are a lot of exposed nail heads, and some missing and damaged shingles over the whole roof, especially on the side with the tree damage.Shingles are reported to be about 12 years old. For these reasons, the best idea would be to re- shingle the whole roof, or at least the side that has the damage. The other side has no leaks reported. There are no chimneys and the only obstruction is the sattelite dish.

The solution for repairing the structural damage would be to remove shingles, remove a plywood section, replace the fly rafter,replace the plywood, tarpaper and re-shingle. The existing sheathing is 3/4" OSB on truss framing, 24" centers.

CDX would be a stronger replacement plywood.

The homeowners have collected a good-sized stack of shingles that appear to be in good shape. They are a mix of architectural and 3-tab shingles. Another option would be metal roof..

The side that is damaged is 644 square feet. Other side is 490 square feet. I have given an estimate for the damaged side.

Roof pitch is approximately 3 / 12.

Problem: Exit facing road is not safe. Deck is leaning significantly towards the house. Step handrails are wobbly.
Solution:
There is a third rear exit, but it is currently blocked- covered with plastic and stuff is in front of it. A safe alternative exit should be made.Tear down deck and rebuild completely.

The existing deck is 5'x8'. Steps , handrails, and guard rails will be required.

Build deck to code. Slope deck away from house. Make it free standing. Rails to be 36" from deck surface.

Storm door and exterior door here is in bad shape.Replace both. Repair any threshold damage found.

Door is 73 1/2" x 32" slab size, opens in, left hinge.

Storm is 35 1/2" x 77" including flange. Opens out, left hinge.

Problem: There is some sketchy looking electrical work in the home. Some outlets do not work (trailer side. )
Solution: Run wires in a better way, especially to the microwave. Repair outlets.

Problem: Monitor oil heater needs repair. Laney says it needs a new "Brain". She has consulted with a heating man, Nathan Jefferson. Her son also is a heating technician.
Solution: Work with the family to get the right parts installed

Problem: No fascia, soffit, or gutters on house. Bees build nests in exposed insulation between rafters.
Solution:
Install fascia board. Install soffit framing. Build "bird boxes". Install vented soffit material (vinyl). This would be a good thing to do at the same time as roof repair.

If time and finances permit, install gutters and drainpipes. Consult homeowner for location of underground pipes and wires before digging drainpipe ditches.

Problem: Soft spot in floor of kitchen. Weak spot in living room floor. Happened due to old water leak (fixed).
Solution:
Remove finished flooring. Replace plywood.Shore up joists if needed. Install some new flooring (existing floor material is laminate). Plywood and flooring unknown thickness. Replace damaged insulation if needed.

Homeowner's relatives have put a piece of sheet metal over the worst place in the kitchen so it is temporarily safe there. There is nothing over the weak place in the living room.

Problem: Rear exit not safe. Cinder blocks once used as temporary steps are now unstable.
Solution:
Build a deck and steps out back. Door swings out, left hinge.

Make deck 8'x8' with steps going towards the heat pump.

Build free standing deck sloping away from the house. Steps must be 36" clear width. Deck height 34", handrails required , must be 36" high.

Steps must have solid landing in the form of a concrete slab or cap-blocks. You might find a creative use for the old cinder blocks.

4" minimum spacing between pickets.

Steps must be the same height except the bottom one.

Problem: Front deck needs repair. Rotten deck boards, hand rail tops. Otherwise structurally ok.
Solution:
Remove all 5/4" deck boards. Use square drive bit. Replace deck boards. Replace handrail tops.

Deck is 7'4" x 7'4".

If you purchase kiln-dried material from Mars Hill Hardware, you can immediately apply stain or paint.

Problem: Storm door has come off two of its hinges. Closer is bent. Trim around door is damaged.
Solution:
Remove old storm door. Remove old trim and old caulk. It may be possible to repair the old storm door, but you will have to remove it anyway so it would be a good time to replace it. Replace "Brick-mold" trim with 1 1/2" material ( #1 2x4's), caulk and paint. Install new storm door, latch, and closer.

The existing storm door opens out, right hinge. Width and height were not measured.

Main door in good shape.

Problem: Exterior light is dangling by wires
Solution: Shut off breaker and replace exterior light

Problem: Propane heater needs repair. Client does not have funds to get someone to look at it. Empire brand, could not find mfg. date
Solution: Get Heating man to look at it

Problem: Tub in Master bathroom is cracked. Weak spot in floor, damage could extend under tub. Area water damaged. Client has trouble getting in and out. No leaks right now.
Solution:
Remove old tub. Repair subfloor. Install walk- in shower. Plumbing, drains , faucet need to be redone.

The existing tub is 43" wide x 60"long.

The rest of the bathroom is in decent shape.

Note- there is a second, smaller bathroom in the home that could be used while construction is happening in the master bath. This bathroom also contains a bathtub that is hard for the client to get in and out of.
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Siding repair and painting is needed
Solution:
The siding here is 1/2" mdf with faux- wood grain. Replace some siding boards. This type of siding requires immediate caulk and paint.

The whole house could use paint and caulk once the siding is fixed.

Problem: Snow piles up in front of Ruby's front door and is hard for her to clear in the winter.
Solution: Complete porch repairs. Build a porch roof. This can be accomplished by extending the gable end.

Problem: Gutters clogged
Solution: clean gutters

Problem: Weeds and bushes grown up on one side.
Solution: Weed eat and cut brush. This job is needed for access to siding for repairs and painting.

Problem: Deck has fallen. A relative of Crystal jacked it up, but it needs further reinforcement.
Solution: Install 4x4 pressure treated beam and three new piers. Utilize existing cinderblock.

Problem: No CO/Smoke detector
Solution: install

Problem: Clients may need a walk in shower soon
Solution: They need to keep their tub now because that's the only way they can bathe with hot water. When they get a well then they can get a walk in shower.

Problem: Back doorway/ Ramp/deck needs work
Siding is in rough shape
Solution: Siding made of unknown material- I am researching this

Problem: Guttters need replacement
Solution: Repair/replace gutters and drainpipes. Working on details

Problem: Junk needs to be hauled off . An old shed needs to be torn down
Solution: Tear down old shed and take loads to the landfill

Problem: Water problems, no hot water
Solution:
Hugh and Nita have not had any hot water for a long time. They do not have a water heater, and heat up water for baths on the stove. Their home is on a gravity-fed system, which works but requires maintenance. There is a good reservoir, but the spring is a lot further up. Nita's solution is to just get the water out of the small creek. The problem here, although the watershed is clean, is that the pipes get clogged up frequently even with a screen. Nita, at 81, is still able to walk up the holler and maintain the pipes, but it is getting harder, and she has to do it often, sometimes once a day in rainy weather.

The family is afraid, with good reason, that a water heater will get clogged up with silt.

Their daughter, Nina, wants to get them a well, and is looking into a USDA Loan for that.

Monitor the situation, and if they are able to get a well, get a small, one element water heater for them. (house does not have 240 power).

Problem: Melissa purchased a "shed" that is up to code to be used as a home.
Solution: This is essentially new construction. No kitchen or bath. Clients need assistance getting bathroom fixtures installed (most urgent) and also kitchen set up.

Problem: Bad floors. Lots of plywood patches. Several dangerous places.
Solution:
Remove patches, remove old subfloor, reinforce and scab joists, put back plywood

Care should be taken to reduce dust because of client's copd

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: install metal roof. the existing roof is fairly flat, see photos, rafters needed.

Problem: Steps are slanted and slippery. Rails starting to rot.
Solution: Build a better set of steps. Add handrails. The existing deck is in decent shape and is 44" high

Problem: Joe has a difficult time getting in and out of the shower.
Solution: install a handicap shower in the larger bathroom. the other bathroom does not have a tub/shower.

Problem: gutters need work
Solution: Re- attach the gutter on the front side using hidden hangers. it is falling off. Install drainpipes on each corner

Problem: Kitchen sink needs work. Drain leaks.
Solution:
The old counter top is damaged, Remove sink and faucet, install new countertop. The old faucet and sink can be re used. Reinstall sink and faucet. Replace drain trap parts. Replace basket strainer.

Note- home on gravity water. there is a shutoff under the trailer, condition unknown.

Problem: Clients may need help hauling off junk
Solution: Haul stuff to landfill, get card #

Problem: co detector neede
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Addition with the wood stove has two leaks- one in the doorway and one where the addition roof joins the trailer. Water pudddles in the room during rains
Solution:
The reason why the doorway leaks is mainly because the deck height is higher than the interior floor height. Water runs into the room through the doorway. The roof connection leaks because of bad flashing. an attempt should be made to caulk, flash and tar the corner of the addition roof.  

Caulk around the threshold to try to stop water getting in. Door needs to be trimmed anyway- that would stop some water

Problem: Bathroom is in rough shape. Commode wobbly. Tub drain leak. Faucet leak. Hot water heater leak. Floors weak. Hot water heater supported by boards. hole in floor next to water heater.
Solution:
Remodel. New shower, sink, plumbing, hot water heater, commode.

Handicap commode and walk in shower recommended- elderly/disabled residents

The water heater is only 6 yrs old with new elements according to Michael, so could be reused  

Note- home on gravity water  

room is approximately 8'x8'.

Problem: Kitchen sink faucet does not produce hardly any water when you turn on the tap.
Solution:
There are a couple possible reasons why I think this may be happening. 1) the supply lines are spliced together and are 3/8 or smaller, and may be clogged. they also have small leaks. Also, there is a busted shut-off valve that is visible from the crawlspace access. I thought maybe it had busted off in the "almost shut" position.  

Replace water lines to the kitchen faucet and add shut-offs under the sink.

There is a newer, ball valve shut off under the house that may work.

Home is on a gravity fed system. .

Problem: Porch roof leak
Solution: The roof leaks because of missing flashing. This will be tricky, but try to install some aluminum flashing under the little trailer gutters, caulk with roof caulk, and install new 1" roof screws to hold the flashing onto the gutters.

Problem: Back deck is not in good shape. Joists have come loose.
Solution:
Tear down and rebuild. Be prepared for threshold /floor damage. Repair any floor damage and install new flashing under the trailer metal to keep water out.

Existing deck is 8' x 10. Build a new, free- standing deck that size or smaller. It should slope gently away from the house. Install deck blocks and 4x4 posts. Use 4" Timber lock screws to attach framing to posts. Build new steps on the side. Go ahead and install handrails since you have elderly/disabled residents. Improve the pathway from the new steps around the building with gravel, etc.

Problem: Wood in yard needs to be split. They will need more for winter,.
Solution: rent a wood splitter, get more wood

Problem: Junk around back needs to be hauled off. Also, the oil barrel needs to be better supported, it is leaning into the trailer too much.
Solution: Talk to the family about what goes. Get some concrete blocks to further support the oil barrel after rolling it away from the house. Check connections on barrel for oil leaks

Problem: Wood stove could use some work.Ava says the grates are worn out. The stove mat is worn .
Solution:
get new grates for wood stove. "King " Brand.  

Get new mat.

Problem: CO Detector needed
Solution: install battery unit

Problem: Front deck has some rotten boards.
Solution: The framing of this deck seems solid enough to warrant repairs rather than a complete teardown. Remove all deck boards. Sister on new 2x8 joists to existing ones that are the most damaged. Install new deck boards. Remove steps (she does not use them.) Install handrails where the steps were. This will require a new 4x4 post.

Problem: Back ramp has wobbly handrails. Other than that the back deck and ramp seem to be in good shape
Solution: Improve handrails by installing 4x4 pressure treated posts set in concrete, attached to the side of the ramp.

Problem: A set of steps in the front is blocked by overgrown bushes. Rear ramp blocked by bushes. Carport surrounded by overgrown bushes
Solution: prune or remove bushes

Problem: Crawlspace access door is rotten and off its hinges
Solution: Build a new one

Problem: The carport is cluttered. Access to rear handicap ramp is blocked
Solution: Talk to Jerlene, she has a plan to donate some stuff to My Sisters Place in Marshall and haul other stuff to the dump. There are several pickup loads.

Problem: Jerlene has requested a porch roof.. She says that snow piles around both front and back doors making access difficult in winter. She has to get a neighbor to dig her out
Solution: She has talked to someone at French Broad Baptist about this project. It would be quite involved because of the width of the deck and the way the roof is. You would have to start the rafters up near the peak of the existing trailer roof. The rafters would need to be at least 16 feet long, and slope down to a 6 foot high supporting band on the outside of the deck. The highest point of the roof would require removing some shingles and installing transition flashing. flashing would also be needed on the sides of the walls of the newly constructed gables. Metal roof recommended because of the low slope application. Metal roof requires a 2/12 pitch or steeper.

Problem: Poor drainage around trailer. No gutters. Water collects near house and under it.
Solution: Where water falls from roof edge, dig drainage ditch and divert water away from home.

Problem: No working CO or smoke detector
Solution: install battery powered combo unit

Problem: Driveway is deteriorating quickly with recent rains.
Solution: Rob received quote from Marty Evans to repair driveway. Large equipment will be needed for this job and Marty is well known and respected for his good work.

Problem: Wanda is in need of a handicap ramp due to mobility issues.
Solution: Build a 24' long handicap ramp over the front steps on the left side of the porch. The ramp should slope no more than 1" per 12" of run. The ramp will come off there house perpendicular to the porch for 12', then turn slightly to avoid running into the bushes. The ramp shall be 4' wide with railings at a height of 36". There shall be a 4'x3' concrete landing pad at the end of the ramp. See attached diagram for details.

Problem: No good air flow, no AC. Trailer gets HOT.
Solution: A porch roof on street side of trailer would help with sun exposure and overheating of the home.

Problem: Danny removed his wood stove. The chimney was removed during re-roofing. The chimney has been donated to CHC. His only heat source now is the trailer furnace(electric). (circa 1987)
Carpet in bedroom aggravates clients breathing issues
Solution: Remove carpet and install similar laminate that was recently installed in living room and hallway

Problem: Clifford's son had one of his legs removed and is wheelchair bound. Needs a ramp.
Solution: Install ramp

Problem: Back/side small concrete covered patio needs new overbuild, carpenter bees and woodpeckers have torn up
Solution: Disassemble by removing tin for re-use, replace all wood with pressure treated, re-apply tin.
Volunteer or Groups:
Holy Comforter;
St. Andrews Episcopal Church

Problem: Plumbing issues: Bernice has called asking if someone can unstop her faucets, neither bathroom or kitchen are functioning properly.
Solution: According to Bernice, could be sediment/small rocks clogging faucet. Will need investigation and repair to secure water source.

Problem: Betty Jean has issues from water running under the trailer and washing out the foundation. Noted by Christ Church Raleigh.
Toilet in second bathroom needs repair.

Hole in daughter's bedroom floor. It is along the wall about 1 1/2" wide and unsure how it got there, doesn't appear to be water damaged. They've covered with carpet and moved daughter's bed to their bedroom as she fears snakes coming through.
Solution: Investigate cause of hole. If not from a bigger issue like water damage or wall separation, patch hole.

Problem: unsafe back deck
Solution: Remove old deck and put up a new one . Make it 6' x 8', free standing, with steps and hand rails (the deck height is 36").

Problem: The only heat source is two space heaters
Solution: Mini split or other safe heat/ ac source

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: membrane

Problem:
A couple of windows are broken

Water gets in windows
Solution:
replace window on front deck- 28 1/2" tall x 31 3/4" wide including flange

replace bedroom window 15 3/4" wide x 41" high including flange

Try to keep water from running down the side of the trailer by installing some flashing above the windows. Seal with roof caulk. This has been done in a couple places.

Problem: Bathroom faucet leaks
Solution: install a new one- Dave has one

Problem: interior doors need work
Solution:
Replace bathroom door-24" x 80".

Girls'bedroom door -replace jams; install door knob

adults' bedroom- no strike plate

Problem: Several sections of drywall have come loose. The worst place is in the bedroom. Drywall is sagging. In other places the ceilng material is badly stained. This happened due to a roof leak (fixed).
Solution: Replace some sections of drywall. Repair and repaint others.

Problem: Driveway is not usable. Someone put in a new culvert and did not cover it up.
Solution: Cover the culvert

Problem: Junk under trailer blocks crawlspace access. Homeowner also reports musty smell coming from crawlspace.
Solution:
Haul stuff to landfill.

Remove more stuff from beneath home and lay vapor barrier.

Problem: no smoke or CO detectors
Solution: install battery powered combo unit.

Problem: There are some broken widows. Most all windows are single pane. Some windows in the addition are old and may have lead paint on them.
Solution:
One window has been purchased and is sitting at Discount Mobile Home Supply. It is the living room window that is broken and taped up. It is a double pane replacement window. Remove old window and install new one.

Other windows can be ordered from DMHS.

Problem: The gable end of the trailer has some OSB siding that has been water damaged.This problem is easy to see when you first pull up.
Solution:
Tear off osb and install some sheet metal siding. Some framing improvements may be needed. There are some sheets of metal on site to be used for this purpose; ask Mary where it is.

Install metal rake trim (green) over the old roof metal and new gable end siding.

Completing this project will make a big difference in the looks of the home.

Problem: Rosetta needs some plumbing upgrades. There are some small leaks in her copper pipes and in her drain pipes
Solution: Replace old copper water lines with PEX. Re- do the sewer drain pipes, the glue joints are coming loose.

Problem: There is some water damage to the siding on the back side of the house. This was found during the bedroom floor remodel.
Solution: This walls of this house has rough sawn framing , diagonal rough sawn 1" sheathing, tar paper, and asbestos shingles. On top of that is vinyl siding. Some of the rough sawn wood sheathing is rotten. In order to repair this, you would have to remove the vinyl siding, then remove the asbestos shingles. This would require special training and protective measures because of the asbestos safety hazards. Remove asbestos, install new 1" sheathing boards, and put the vinyl siding back on, and/or get new vinyl siding.

Problem: Drainage issues. When CC Raleigh served on 5/12/18 they noticed flooding beneath trailer causing a foundational pillar to be nearly washed out.
Solution: CCRaleigh worked on diverting water but more needs to be done. Need to have Jake reassess.

Problem: Beulah called with concerns about mold in bedroom closet.
Solution: Investigate. If mold is present, determine what kind and perform mold remediation according to professional recommendations.

Problem: Crack in kitchen wall.
Solution: Beulah has called with concerns about this. Investigate.

Problem: Because of her health issues, Cynthia is not very mobile. Currently there is only one exit- She must climb a long flight of stairs to get to her vehicle. There is an elevator but it is currently out of order.
Solution: James says that at assessment time that Independent Living was going to repair or replace the elevator. Call James for info on the progress of this project.

Problem: Driveway is muddy
Solution: Get Danny Collins to dump 8 tons of 3/4 gravel on the driveway

Problem: Septic problems. Commodes not flushing properly, system drains slowly
Solution: Get Carter Septic or Rooter King to come look at it, snake drains, replace drainpipes, etc.

Problem: Client has no heat at this time
Solution:
There is a propane wall heater with a 100 lb tank but client does not have any propane.

She also has a portable propane heater (not reccomended. )

She says that the wall heater works.

Social Svc. might be able to help with heating assistance

Problem: Electrical concerns.
Solution:
Faith says there is a breaker that keeps tripping in the house. Kitchen breaker. She says it trips 3 or 4 times a month.

Landlord recently repaired a switch.

Send an electrician out to diagnose and hopefully repair.

Problem: Floor in living room has some weak places. Floor in bedroom has a hole.
Solution:
Remove sections of old, rotten press board subfloor and replace with CDX plywood. Reinforce and scab joists if needed.

Landlord has put a piece of plywood over top of one bad place in the living room and covered it with a rug. This is not a proper repair as it is a tripping hazard.

Floor covering, laminate or other, can be installed after subfloor is stabilized.

Problem: 2 Windows are broken.
Solution:
Priority 1- The window in the kids bedroom is 15 1/2" wide and 55" high. Trailer- style window. measurements include flange.

The second window is in the kitchen area and is part of a bay window. it is a fixed window; pane could just be replaced. 20 1/4' wide, 16 1/4" high.

Call Discount Mobile Home for info on double pane replacement windows.

Problem: Bathroom work needed
Solution:
Bathroom 1- approx. 40 sq. feet

The main problem here is the commode- it won't flush. It is either clogged up or the drainpipes are clogged. Other drains seem to drain very slowly, so I suspect a systemic problem.

There is no shower head here. Bathroom door broken.

Flooring needed.

Bathroom 2- Commode flushes very slowly.

Hole in floor- missing heat register

Weak place in floor next to tub

Snake drain- Rooter King recommended

Problem: Water line leak suspected. Main water line could freeze. Hard to access water line for repairs.
Solution:
Looking under the house (there is a crawlspace access door round the back), I noticed a pool of water and heard a hissing sound. I suspect it is coming from the main water line, but access was blocked by a piece of plywood wedged underneath the trailer. Water line is 3/4" black pipe. There is a shut- off valve but it looks old.

Find leak, shut off water, and repair water line

Problem: Kitchen sink drain leak
Solution: Replace drainpipes, trap and basket

Problem: Front door busted
Solution: Install a new exterior door. The existing one is 31 1/2" wide x 73 3/4" tall. Knob and deadbolt can be reused.

Problem: Bad carpet in hallway, bathroom needs floor covering.
Solution: install 100 square feet of vinyl plank laminate flooring

Problem: No CO Detector
Solution: Install battery powered unit

Problem: Heat pump is not working. As of assessment date, the unit is only 16 months old and may be covered under a parts warranty but will still cost labor to repair. Rutherford H&C installed it through CAO in 2017. Electric strips work but not the heat pump, so heating is very expensive and there is no AC. AC is critical in warm weather because of Velma's heart conditions.
Solution: Have Rutherford (828-287-2240) diagnose and repair the unit.

Problem:
Porch post busting thru porch floor. Floorboards bad in some places.

Paint peeling on porch.
Solution:
Support porch roof with double 2x4 jack. Remove old post. Remove damaged floorboards. Inspect framing and repair if needed. install new floor boards. Put post back.

Note this porch could have lead paint- not tested yet.

Problem: Gutters are not working properly. Water gets in basement.
Solution: Remove old gutters. Inspect fascia boards and repair if needed. Clean and repaint fascia board. Install new gutters, wider (6") if possible. make sure they slope towards the downspout.

Problem: Fascia and soffit damage
Solution: Remove rotten material and repair fascia and soffit

Problem: Windows in home are old, single pan with storms. James puts plastic or tarps over them in the winter to conserve heat.
Solution:
Replace windows with double pane insulated windows for energy efficiency. Caution- removing old windows may release lead dust. Test for lead paint before starting and take proper prcautions if lead is present

estimated materials cost $250 per window

Problem: Work needed in basements. In the first basement, the rock basement walls are showing signs of wear and the mortar or clay is falling out. There is a joist that is cracked.
Solution: Remove canned goods from shelves. Remove shelves. Remove loose material with wire brush. Clean walls. Stucco the walls with high strength mortar mix. Sister on a 2x6 joist to the cracked one. Put some shims under the bearing points of the joists in a few places. Put shelves and canned goods back.

Problem: Two basement doors do not close and open easily and are roytting on the bottom.
Solution: Improve or build new basement doors.

Problem: Old stove in creek. Old appliances on back porch. Clutter in basement
Solution: Remove old appliances and take to dump

Problem: Cluttered upstairs rooms
Solution: Help the family organize, donate, and get rid of stuff. Consult james and Sandy for guidance.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery unit

Problem: Electrical issues. Several outlets and switches do not work. Ceiling fan does not work. Circuit box is circa 1974. Breakers old and brittle.
Solution: Electrical upgrade needed. New circuit panel and breakers. Client estimates $2500 based on talking to his nephew who has electrical experience

Problem: No hand rail on front steps
Solution: Install handrail. Concrete Steps. 33" high. Metal handrails recommended.

Problem: No water coming from well.
Solution: Well company checked it out and the well is dry. Need to redrill well deeper, install bigger pump.
Contractor: Clyde Sawyers and Son Well Drilling

Problem: Unsafe wheelchair ramp. Wobbly rails, posts giving way, deck boards rotten.
Solution: Tear down old ramp. Rebuild ramp. Follow Code. 1/12 pitch. This ramp will need to be 50' long. Make it 48" wide with wide landings. The old ramp is a little too steep, but the new one can be built in a similar way. Install sturdy handrails.

Problem: Back door is broken. Deck post broken. Hand rails loose. Not a safe exit.
Solution:
Replace back door. 32" wide, 74" high. Door opens in, left hand hinge.  

De-construct the old deck so that materials can be reused. Repair the vinyl siding under the doorway. Then build back a 6' x 6' deck with steps.

Problem: Electrical- outlets broken, loose. Covers needed.
Solution: install at least 3 new outlets with covers. Boxes will need to be stabilized, drywall work may be needed.

Problem: Interior doors need replacement
Solution: Replace 3 28" wide x 78" high interior doors. Replace one 32 3/4" wide x 74 7/8" high interior door.

Problem: The roof could use some TLC. The shingles are over 20 yrs. old but no leaks have been reported. However, some shingles have blown off, the skylight is cracked, and some boots need caulk
Solution: Caulk and tar, caulk skylight crack.

Problem: Interior of enclosed porch needs some work. Exposed insulation. Tommy will tell you what needs doing.
Solution:
Install 7 sheets T-111 style plywood (see existing material).  

Install window and door trim  

This might be a good job for various skill level volunteers if the family provides direction

Problem: Master bathroom could use some work. Big bathtub is cracked, Drain does not work right, one of the two vanities needs new drain trap
Solution:
Replace drain and patch hole in tub.  

install trap and drain for second vanity  

There is a working shower (regular size) in this room.  

This bathroom has plenty of room for a walk in shower if that is ever needed.

Problem: Client requests new flooring in living room
Solution: Install 400 sq. feet high quality laminate flooring

Problem: Drywall patching needed
Bathroom in bad shape. Doorway too narrow for wheelchair. Floor weak. Surround damaged. No handicap commode. Loose tiles.
Solution: Complete bathroom remodel. Mary says that Independent Living is going to remodel the bathroom and widen the doorway. The contractor has already visited.
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Back deck fallen in. Door in rough shape. Not a safe entry/exit.
Solution:
Tear down old deck. Build a new, 4' x 8' deck with guard rails. Make it almost flush with the door threshold for wheelchair access. Build a 48" wide ramp with handrails. Put a concrete pad at the end. Ramp should be a pitch of 1 in 12.  

The deck height is 36" so the ramp will need to be approximately 36' long. You will have to disconnect the oil tank and move it , it will be in the way of the new ramp.  

Install new exterior door and doorknob.  

Make a new place for the oil tank. You will probably need some copper pipe supplies.

Problem: Bedroom , although unused except for storage, has floor damage and there is a moldy smell
Solution:
Remove furniture. Remove old press-board subfloor and shore up joists if needed. Install 3/4" plywood subfloor. Floor covering can be installed later.

Use dust protection

Problem: Ramp is serviceable but steep and needs to be extended. The deck to which the ramp is attached has some rotten places.
Solution:
Independent living plans on improving the parking area.However, they do not plan on making any deck or ramp improvements.

The ramp and deck should be torn down. Some materials can be salvaged. Take a look at the siding that was covered up by the old deck and make repairs to any damaged siding and framing. Build back a similar-sized deck. Make the deck free standing, with a small gap between the deck frame and the house.If you build back a deck that is wider, the ramp can be shorter because of the sloping terrain. The new ramp should have a pitch of 1 in 12 or less. Ramp will need to be around 16 20 feet long. Build handrails at 36" high. Make the ramp 48" wide. Make sure to have a slight slope on the deck, away from the house frame. Extend the width of the concrete walkway for a landing at the bottom.
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Electrical problems- some outlets are broken.
Solution:
Install new boxes  

install covers

Problem: Roof leaks around wood stove pipe
Solution: I did not look at this closely but a boot could be added

Problem: Dishwasher leak. Clients have a bucket under the sink. Leak is not active because supply line is shut off now, so there is no hot water in the kitchen
Solution: Old plumbing here is 1/2" copper. A "T" is needed. Replace what you can get to with PEX, some has been replaced already. Mary's son is supposed to fix this soon.

Problem: Water system could use some work
Solution:
The family gets their water from a spring. A plastic tank gets filled up then a submerged pump pumps the water to the house. The system looks like it has not been maintained recently. The lid to the reservoir is not sealed and the wind could blow it off.

Check the spring to make sure it is covered and safe.

drill a hole in the top of the reservoir to make a way to put the intake hose in there and close the lid.

Check overflow system

Problem: There is lots of junk in the yard.
Solution:
Clean up trash, haul metal to scrap yard.

Remove old tires.

Haul junk to landfill

Problem: Yard work is needed once the trash has been cleaned out.
Solution: Weed eat, mow, cut bushes. Work with Mary.

Problem: Gravel needed in parking area. Wheelchair can't get good traction when it is muddy
Solution: Install gravel. This is one of the jobs that Mary says Independent Living will do.
Contractor: Independent Living through NC Vocational Rehab

Problem: Drain pipes need work.
Solution:
At the time of my visit, Crystal was working with a friend to fix this problem. Apparently the drainpipes broke due to freezing. Pipes were exposed and septic was draining on ground. According to Crystal the helper was due to show up that day to dig up some more lines and glue up some drainpipe. Septic tank and drainfield are located in a flat spot below the house. It would be a fairly easy fix- dig up pipes with a shovel, make some cuts, and glue pipe together, or use a fern-co connector . There are some pipes in the crawlspace under the bathroom that need to be repaired as well.  

Install a clean-out somewhere in the system while you are at it.  

Check in with Crystal - hopefully this job will be done soon by her and her friend.  

UPDATE- The Septic drainpipe is fixed, however, the entire system needs to be improved. Almost all of the drainpipes are on top of the ground or barely buried. Some can come apart. I called Roger Ezell, a local plumber and Crystal's neighbor, to look at the system and make recommendations for improvement.

Problem:
There is only one entry/exit at this time.  

One door is blocked by a shelf and some other stuff.

This door has been hung upside down and is in rough shape. Door is 28" wide.
Solution:
Remove stuff from in front of door. Remove door and trim materials. Frame up the rough opening with pressure treated material and concrete screws.  

install siding below window opening, make waterproof.

I talked to Crystal about this during NHN follow up. She likes the idea of a window that can be opened and the screen removed for emergency exit purposes.

Remove trim. Install a double hung, single hung, or casement window that provides at least a 24" high, 20" wide opening for an emergency exit. A 30" wide x 54" high window would work here.

Window must be installed no more than 44" from floor to bottom of window. .

Problem: Roof leaks around chimney.
Solution:
The old section of the home has very old metal on it. The newer addition is ok .

Note- work on the rafter tails and fascia board and install drip edge before roofing.

Remove old metal. Get rid of flying squirrel nests and make any repairs needed on roof deck. Install approx. 900 sq. feet of new metal.  

Chimney is no longer used and can be removed.

Problem: no gutters on house
Solution:
Install approx. 80' gutters, downspouts, etc. hook up to drain pipes. Direct water away from home .  

Note- work is needed on rafter tails and fascia board before gutters can be hung

Problem: There is a ramp on the property that is way too steep and dangerous.
Solution: Remove ramp, salvage and de-nail materials, and build set of steps in place of the ramp. Make it approx. 4' wide with 4 2x12 stringers. Build handrails and put a concrete pad at the bottom.

Problem: Flying squirrels have infested the roof of the home because there is no soffit.
Solution:
A new roof has been installed on the old part of the house (grey metal.) The newer part of the house has good metal(green, but squirrels can get in. Soffit and fascia should be installed on this part of the house to keep out varmints. Crystal has quite a bit of vented vinyl soffitt on her property.

Job will require working up high on a ladder. Gutters are not recommended because of the difficulty cleaning them.

Install soffit and fascia boards. Install vinyl channel and soffit material.

Problem: Drainage issues. The basement gets wet.
Solution: Determine locations of all underground electric, water, and sewer lines. Dig a French drain behind the house. It will need to be about 25' across the back and then sloping down the side maybe 20'. Dig trench, install silt cloth, add 2" gravel, install 4"solid drainpipe with holes, addd more gravel, fold silt cloth over, and add soil.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem: There are some windows in the home that are broken and / or need replacement.
Solution:
Window 1- approx. 27" wide x 27" high. This is a double pane window with one pane broken. It is a double hung window so you might be able to just replace the pane, or replace the entire sash. Or you could replace the whole window.

Window 2- There are two old, single pane window installed in an opening in the block. Remove old windows and plywood. Frame the opening using pressure treated 2x8's and concrete screws and install a double-hung, double- pane window in that space. The opening in the block is 5' wide and 38" high.  

Test for lead paint around these windows, it is an old house.

Problem: Wiring in the basement needs tidying up. There is a ceiling box with dangling wires.
Solution: Cut power. Put wire nuts on and tape.Install cover. Or install a pull chain light fixture in the box.

Problem: Crack on the side of bathtub
Solution: caulk

Problem: Smoke detectors have been disabled.
Solution: Crystal says that she took them down because they were going off randomly. Install new battery powered CO/ Smoke detector

Problem: The back door is not usable at this time. Steps are rotten.
Solution: Right now the homeowners don't use the door and it has plastic on it. The door will need to be made usable. A construction project requiring use of the door may happen, or the door can be used as an emergency exit. ( There is already a second exterior door in the home). Remove plastic and make sure the door works properly. Tear out old steps, build a landing and rebuild steps with a concrete pad or dsolid cement blocks at the bottom of the steps. They are approximately 32" high. Hand rails needed on steps if height is 30" or more.

Problem: Plumbing drain leak
Solution: repair with 1 1/2" Fernco coupling

Problem: Carolyn has difficulty navigating the steps in and out of her home.
Solution:
The family has requested a handicap ramp. The best location for a ramp is out the back porch. Ramp would need to be about 24 feet long. (Deck height is 24")It would need to turn once. 1/12 drop max. Build hand rails.

As a less expensive alternate, you could replace the existing back steps with easier- to climb stairs. Build them to code with 2x12 stringers with 11" treads and a 6" or so rise. Build hand rails.

In the front, a second set of steps should be built in place of the existing ones. Deck height here is 30". Follow code. Install a pressure treated post in the corner to support hand rails.

Problem: There is a problem with the septic drain system
Solution:
The family is currently trying to fix this themselves- A relative has got the septic tank and drain lines dug up. A cleanout has been installed but it looks like there is still a clog between the tank and the drainpipe. A drain snake should be used to unclog the drain lines.

Not sure if the family will be able to do this- monitor the situation and maybe hire Rooter King or another outfit to clean the drain.

Problem:
Roof needs maintenance.

It does not leak at this time.
Solution: Apply 2 coats of Kool-seal or other coating.

Problem: The floor around the front door and behind the sofa is very weak. Joists have been water damaged.
Solution:
Remove a section (approx. 12'x8' of floor material- (laminate and carpet). Remove rotten subfloor, replace and scab floor joists. Install new subfloor.

Clients have requested removal of old floor material (carpet and laminate). They want to install new vinyl laminate flooring. Room is 216 square feet. If finances do not permit, clients are OK with just putting plywood back and getting the flooring at a later time.

Thickness of existing subfloor is unknown- it may be rough sawn 1" boards.

Baseboards and other painted material should be tested for lead paint before starting this job.

Problem: The front corner of the house has structural water damage. It has been caused by bad drainage on that side of the house.
Solution:
Allow inside corner of gutters to dry and caulk with high quality roof caulk.

Determine location of all water lines, electric lines, etc by talking to the family.

Dig a drainage ditch around the front porch approx. 40 feet from the front corner to a downhill location.

Hook up 3 downspouts to the drainpipe. bury drainpipe.

Supplies for this job should all be available at Gentry's in Hot Springs.

Problem: Rita suspects that the drain field has been clogged by tree roots. The family has to snake the drains every 6 months or so.
Solution: Monitor and re- do drain field if the situation gets worse

Problem:
Exhaust chimney for oil furnace has come loose

water in basement

new water filter needed
Solution: Rita and David will look into fixing these problems in the basement. The exhaust for the furnace is hard to get to but will be easy to put back together. There is a sump pump in the basement that pumps water out; Rita says there has always been water here. David will make sure the pump is working and address the other problems here as well.

Problem:
The bathroom needs some work. Client's disabilities make it hard for him to get in and out of the tub.

Vanity cabinet is in bad shape. Bottom of cabinet is damaged and white mold is present.

Floor covering is worn.

Wall covering is worn.
Solution:
Client should ideally have a walk-in shower. However, the current tub/shower is adequate, and Paul has a shower chair. A lot of plumbing work, including a new, handicap commode, has been done here by Paul's son in law. Nothing seems to be leaking.

Replace vanity cabinet. The existing one is 36" wide, 20" deep, and 30' high. The sink is old but re-usable. A new faucet might be a good idea at this point, but not necessary.

Replace floor covering. 55 sq. ft. To do a pro job on this you should take up the commode. Replace wax ring when done flooring.

Replace wall covering or paint. Approx.120 sq.ft.

Test all surfaces for lead paint before beginning work.

Problem: Linoleum floor is worn out in the kitchen and the bathroom.
Solution:
Install a durable, water resistant floor covering such as vinyl plank laminate.

The bathroom is 52 sq. ft.

The kitchen is 130 sq. ft.

Problem: Carbon monoxide detector needed
Solution: Install a battery powered CO detector- the fire dept. may be able to help out on this one

Problem: Roof leaks. Client has put buckets in living room to catch water.
Solution:
The shingles here are 25 years old so it is time for a new roof. The suspected leak is around the chimney. Dorothy says that a chimney cleaner recently got up there to look at it and said that it was leaking around the chimney and that there was some rotten plywood. I could not get a good look at it because of the steep pitch of the roof. A stout, long rope will be needed to assess the leak better.  

Tear off shingles and repair plywood. Re-roof with shingles or metal. Flash around chimneys.

This is a steep, 9/12 or 10/12 roof and will require safety equipment.

Square footage of roof is roughly 3000 sq. feet

Problem: Decks have some rotten places
Solution:
On one of the decks you will have to remove the tiles and replace rotten material beneath. Put back pressure treated wood.

On another deck, the outside edge is rotten and will require some reconstruction.

Problem:
Bathroom work needed. Dorothy has a walk- in shower.The shower drain leaks. The commode water supply line leaks. She bucket- flushes.

Client has a seperate bathtub but it is hard to get in and out of, so she does not use it. .
Solution:
Repair the drain for the shower.

Replace commode with a new, handicap model.

Replace wax ring and water supply line for commode.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Mary's (Kinston);
St. Andrews Episcopal Church

Problem: No hot water.
Solution:
Install a new hot water heater.  

The old water heater is a gas-powered model. Dorothy told me that it no longer works. A repairman came out and could not fix it.The heater is 12 years old.  

A smaller, electric,one-element model could work here because there is only one person living here.  

A new circuit breaker and wiring will need to be added for power to the new water heater.

Problem:
Heating issues.

Dorothy has a wood stove in the kitchen and a wood furnace in the basement. She also has plenty of firewood. However at this time her health prevents her from being able to operate the wood stoves.  

Dorothy also has a working propane furnace and a large fuel tank, but her financial situation is such that she has no propane.
Solution:
This problem may solve itself because as Dorothy's health improves she plans on being able to operate the wood heaters. The weather is also getting warmer.  

Social Services or other assistance programs that could help with propane could be contacted.

At this time client has two space heaters.

Problem:
Bathroom needs work.  

Dorothy has a bathtub but she does not use it because it is too hard to get in and out of. She did use the seperate, walk-in shower, but the drain has come apart and she does not use it either. So, she bathes using the two bathroom sinks.  

The commode, an older model, has a leak, probably in the supply line. She currently has the water shut off and bucket- flushes.
Solution:
Repair or replace the shower drain.  

Repair or replace commode supply line.  

Replace older model commode with a new, handicap model.  

According to Dorothy, except for those problems mentioned, the plumbing works good.  

The floor has not been damaged as a result of any leaks.

Problem: Soffit and fascia material have suffered damage due to rot and woodpecker damage. Some trim boards are in similar condition. It looks like there maybe some termite damage in one corner of the house as well.
Solution: Replace soffit/ fascia material , preferably as part of the roof project. Remove rotten trim material, install new, painted material in its place.

Problem: There are 2 other sliding glass doors in the house that will not open, or are very hard to open for Dorothy.
Solution: Talk to Dorothy about a solution. She could be ok with the SGD's being held in position and used as a fixed window,, because she has 3 other exterior doors in the house.

Problem: Dorothy will probably need some help with yard work this summer.
Solution: mow, weedeat, etc

Problem: Broken sliding glass door in sunroom. Currently covered by plywood.
Solution: Remove SGD, Frame up wall, and install an exterior door and window.

Problem: Client needs help cleaning floor and other household tasks till her health improves
Solution: Send low skill volunteer to help clean bloodstained floors etc.

Problem:
The floor in the kitchen and leading to the bathroom has several holes. They are in the section of the house that was originally a single wide trailer, and the floors have worn out or have been water damaged.

Some holes have pieces of plywood over them but Eddie's wheelchair cannot roll smoothly over them. The worst hole is in front of the kitchen sink. It is invisible because the linoleum floor is intact.
Solution:
Eddie put a chair near the area to remind him not to drive his wheelchair over there. His brother helped him put a few scraps of plywood over some holes.  

Remove old particle board flooring. Repair joists if needed. Replace entire subfloor with new CDX plywood. It is most likely 5/8".

Care should be taken to avoid dust , put up plastic sheeting.

Install flooring material over the subfloor. It should be thin yet strong.

Subfloor must be flush with the floors in the rest of the house for smooth riding for Eddie's motorized wheelchair.

installing rigid foam insulation in some areas may be a good idea at this time

Problem: The covered deck in the front is falling down and unsafe to walk on.
Solution: Tear down the deck and make it to where the sliding glass door will not open. Haul old materials to the landfill.

Problem:
Eddie's brother made a ramp for him but it needs some work. Rails are loose and there are no ballusters. It is a bit narrow. The end of the ramp nearest the door slopes down towards the doorway. The concern is that water could get in the doorway and cause damage.

A second ramp may be a good idea here because Eddie only has one way in and out currently. The second ramp could be built using materials on site, a salvaged ramp obtained by the family.

Make sure ramps are built using a slope of no more than 1 inch vertical for every 12 inches horizontal.
Solution: Adjust the ramp so that it will be uphill all the way to the doorway. Make better handrails. Install ballusters.

Problem:
Some plumbing work may be needed.

Also, some insulation has been removed, or has fallen out of the floor.
Solution:
There was a recent problem with the septic drain. It looks like a pipe came loose. I talked to Eddie and he said that his brother temporarily stuck the pipes together, but that it needs to be glued.

Put back insulation or install some new stuff.

Problem: Sliding glass door is not usable by the client. It leads to a deck that is in bad shape **this deck has since been removed
Solution: Cut a piece of wood to hold the sliding glass door in position, turning it into a window.

Problem: Storm door in rough shape. Hard for Eddie to open.
Solution: Install a new storm door. The existing door opens out with a left hand hinge. it is 36" wide x 79"high. Install closer at the top of the door for ease of access.

Problem:
Eddie's bathroom situation needs improvement.

Eddie has two bathrooms. One of these he cannot use because the doorways are too narrow. The bathroom that he uses has been remodeled by an aquaintance to include a handicap shower. The doorway is still a bit narrow. Eddie gets in the shower by means of an improvised, movable ramp that probably needs improvement. There is exposed wiring above the doorway.
Solution:
Improve ramp or raise floor. Finish work needed. Commode may be needed but I am not sure how much he uses it due to his disabilities.

The doorway could be widened a couple inches. Close up walls and finish. Cover up or somehow waterproof cracked tile next to shower surround.

Problem: There are some windows that need replacement. Some are broken, some have rotten sashes and sills due to water infiltration and improper siding installation. There is one double window in the kitchen where the wall is rotten around and underneath the window. Vinyl siding on the outside of the wall is loose and the wall is movable.
Solution:
Install windows. Measurements for these three windows were given to Tony Thompson.  

1.Rough opening- 57 3/4" high x 38" wide. Framing looks ok under this one. This window is in a bedroom, facing the road.  

2.Double window- in kitchen- Rough opening is 56 1/2" high x 67" wide. The wall is rotten here. Wall rebuild needed.  

3\. On gable end- this is an old trailer window with a missing storm pane. It is 32" wide x 55 1/2" high ,this measurement includes the aluminum flang  

install flashing, window wrap, and other materials to keep water out.

Problem: Underpinning needs work in several places. Water could freeze.
Solution: Install underpinning. Use recycled roofing metal and pressure treated 2x4's.

Problem: Broken mirror/closet door
Solution: Remove mirror/ closet door and dispose of

Problem: There is a shed on the property that Eddie would like to be able to use to repair small engines, etc. Right now it is leaning due to being transported from another location.
Solution:
In order to make the shed handicap accessible you will have to jack it up , put cinder blocks under it, etc. Eddie and his brother may be able to provide a jack and help do this.

Make an easy way for Eddie to roll into the shed. Gravel path, etc.

Problem: Eddie would like to have some gravel installed so that a path could be made to his work shed
Solution: Install gravel. Eddie will tell you what he wants.Danny Collins can deliver gravel in his dump truck. 828-777- 6353
