Problem: There is a downspout that is not hooked up to a drainpipe. Water can get under the corner of the house
Solution: Cut off downspout and install a solid 4' corrugated drain pipe that goes under the ramp and to a downhill location

Problem:
Insulation work may be needed. insulation has fallen out of floor due to plumbing work.

Condition of attic insulation, if there is any, is unknown.
Solution:
Remove old insulation and add new. Use rigid foam or unfaced fibergless.

Determine attic access and assess insulation in attic. Install blown insulation if appropriate.

Problem: Carbon monoxide detector needed.
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Black stains on baseboard behind commode in bathroom. Due to water getting in the back side of house (overflowing rain barrel).
Solution:
Dig a French drain behind the house. WATCH FOR POWER LINES AND GAS LINES. Contact Town of Hot Springs for info. Currently there is a thin layer of concrete on the ground, most of which is busted up. The area would be better served by a graveled trench with a drainpipe in it.

Dig trench, install landscape cloth, install 2" gravel, install drainpipe with holes, cover with landscape cloth, cover with gravel, fill in with a layer of dirt on top.

Wanda Sue's family will clean up the mold.

Problem: In the back of the house there is a section of the roof that funnels a lot of water down to a rain barrel close to the side of the house. The rain barrel overflows and over the years has caused damage to the floor and possibly to the foundation.
Solution: There is no way to install a gutter here (see photos), but a large downspout of some kind (maybe a drainpipe) could be fabricated to channel water into a large drainpipe which would then direct the water away from the house.

Problem: Living Room window will not close.
Solution: Repair framing if possible or replace window with new Energy Star qualified window.

Problem: Gutters on front porch shed water onto porch
Solution: Add some flashing or replace cheap vinyl gutters with aluminum ones.

Problem: electrical- one loose outlet, breaker trips when furnace runs. Clients do not want to use their electric furnace because of this.
Solution: Tighten up loose outlet- may involve a little drywall work. Check breaker box and add a seperate circuit if needed

Problem: Door knobs needed. One in son's room, one front door
Solution: Install 2 locking door knobs and strike plates.

Problem: Hole in drywall- son's room
Solution: patch,sand, paint. Drywall is 3/8" thick

Problem: Drainpipes needed in all 4 corners of house.
Solution: the site is graded properly but drainpipes are needed to divert water away from house.

Problem: Deck and siding needs some TLC
Solution: pressure wash deck and siding of trailer

Problem: There is a shed on the property that if fixed up would be a good play house for Anthony
Solution: Clean out shed and paint, etc

Problem: Broken play set in yard
Solution: This looks like it could be repaired but I didn't look closely

Problem: Trash in yard
Solution: Haul to dump and/or landfill.

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: addition on old trailer (not occupied) pulling away from structure. Hazel fears it will come completely apart and fall down into the road.
Solution: Discussed demolition of the addition but Hazel said there are things in there that are worth keeping and she'd rather try and support the building to keep it from shifting further. Unsure how to go about this.

Problem: Front Porch roof leaks.
Solution: On the front porch, you might could peel up the shingles and install wider flexible tape - type flashing such as Ice&water sheild, but because of the low pitch of the roof (<1/12), the same problem could re-occur. Only other option would be to rebuild the porch roof with a steeper pitch.

Problem: Vanity faucet broken in one bathroom.
Solution: replace faucet

Problem: Old carpet aggervates client's breathing problems.
Solution: Tear up old carpet and install laminate flooring. 150 square feet needed. Care should be taken not to stir up too much dust during carpet tear-out. Plastic sheeting may be needed to keep the area dust-free.

Problem: weak floor - laundry room
Solution: This is not urgent but may get worse over time.Remonve some floor covering, cut out a section of floor, reinforce joists if needed, install a piece of plywood. Watch for wires and ductwork when cutting a hole in the floor. Install some new flooring when done.

Problem: A ramp may be needed at some point
Solution:
At this time, Donna is not in a wheelchair, however, she is considered disabled. Because of her COPD, she says she gets really out of breath when going up the stairs. I

This would have to be a long ramp because the door height is 38" (back door). This would necessitate a ramp at least 38' long to meet code. It may have to have a landing with a switchback.

Problem: Back porch roof leak
Solution: install aluminum or flexible flashing-

Problem: CJ is having trouble heating his home. The original furnace is not used, ductwork questionable. His Monitor oil heater does not work. He has a wall mounted propane heater but cannot afford propane at this time. He uses a stand alone kerosene heater.
Solution:
CJ wants to get a 100 lb propane tank. Talk to landlord.

CJ has contacted Von Hamby to repair the monitor.

Problem: In the kitchen, you can see where a cabinet caught fire one time because it is right over the stove.
Solution: Remove cabinet. Clean and paint area where the cabinet was and maybe install a high shelf .

Problem: Area around bay window is rotten.
Solution: Purchase two single hung windows with flanges- 36"wide x 60" high. Remove bay window and rotten wood. Re-frame opening, approx. 5' high and 10' wide. Allow for required rough openings of the two windows. Install T-111 siding. Install windows and trim materials. Caulk and paint. After drying in, install drywall on inside, sand and paint. Use a vacuum for dust when sanding.Install interior trim.

Problem: Outlet on exterior of home can get wet. No GFI.
Solution: Cut power and Replace existing outlet with a GFI outlet rated for exterior application

Problem: Roof leaks. Ceiling has mold stains.
Solution:
There are 4 plumbing vents that are pretty obviously leaking- they don't have proper boots. CJ thinks that the roof is under-vented and he is probably right. There are a couple places where patches could be leaking as well.

A membrane roof may be be the best solution here because of the shape of the roof.

Install 3 new plumbing vent boots and a new vent.

Problem: No ballusters on front deck. Handrails warped and not well attached.
Solution: Install ballusters and replace some handrail and guardrail material

Problem: No steps- back exit- 16" drop
Solution: build one step next to door

Problem: Tub rusted. New surround needed.
Solution:
Remove old tub and surround. Check subfloor for damage and repair if needed. Floor seemed good in rest of room. Replace tub and surround. Old plumbing could be re used.

Tub is trailer-size, 54" x 27.

CJ has plumbing skills and can help on this one.

Problem: Underpinning in bad shape.
Solution: Replace half of the underpinning. Use pressure treated frame and used roof metal.

Problem: All windows in the home are single pane. only two windows in the house can open. All windows are currently covered in plastic.
Solution: Replace some windows. You could call CJ and have him measure the old windows. Get single or double hung windows that open. Estimate for 5 windows given below.

Problem: No insulation in floor. It has fallen out.
Solution: Fiberglass insulation will probably just fall out again. Install rigid foam polyiso or blue- board. Cut to fit between floor joists.

Problem: CO/Smoke detector needed.
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Electrical upgrade needed. The breaker box is from the 1960's. Some breakers are loose and damaged. Loose wires around house, splices with no boxes, etc.
Solution: Some improvements have been made. Some loose wires have been put in boxes, boxes switched out, covers installed, etc. but more work in the breaker box is needed. Get an electrician to upgrade the system.

Problem: There is a hole in the floor under the kitchen sink. This is due to a leak that got fixed. Kitchen sink drainpipe is duck taped and has no trap. Sewer gases can come up from the drain system.
Solution:
Replace subfloor and reinforce joists. Replace sink drain components, add trap.

This may be possible to do without removing the cabinet, countertop and sink, but the countertop is showing signs of wear, so if finances permit it would be a good time to replace the countertop.

Problem: There is a corner of the house that is rotten.
Solution: This is a log house so this is not easy to fix. Cut out rotten material with sawsall or chainsaw, checking for wires first. Then pour a footer and install cinder blocks to fill in. This won't look real good but it will serve the purpose.

Problem: Rodents and bees are finding their way into the house. There are 2 holes in the drywall in the bedroom.
Solution:
Louise has duck-taped some holes in the drywall. A bees nest has been sprayed, Louise complains of rats and mice.

The drywall is attached to the log wall with furring strips.

Remove a section of drywall and get rid of the bees nest. Patch drywall.

Rats and mice get in another hole according to Louise.

patch drywall, sand&paint.

Problem: Roof leak. The corner of the porch is leaking badly and the soffit and fascia material are rotten.
Solution:
The shingles, according to the homeowners, are at least 20 yrs. old. The pitch of the roof is 2/12 or less in some places. Other places are A metal roof would be better here because of the roof pitch.

The roof is framed with pine poles as rafters, some poles are less than 3" in diameter. On top of that are 1" rough sawn boards (solid sheathing). Because of this the shingles should be removed first to minimize weight on the roof frame. Shingles should also be removed to facilitate repairs on rotten sheathing beneath the roof material.

Frank knows the place needs roof work, but it is unknown how much he is willing to contibute, financially or otherwise.

Problem: There is no insulation in the attic.
Solution: Install 8" of blown insulation to attic. approx. 1000 square feet. 25 bags would give you r19 insulation value. Install more if finances permit. Blower rental is usually free with purchase of insulation. (Lowe's)

Problem: All windows in the home are single pane and covered in plastic.
Solution: Replace as many windows as possible in the home. Frank has measured them at one time and may have plans to replace.

Problem: Gutters are needed on back side of house. Roof valley channels water to back side, causing structural damage to logs on corner of house.
Solution: install gutters with downspouts and drain pipe.

Problem: There is a lot of moisture getting to the back of the house. Dark stains can be seen on the inside of the house. No French drain. Valley of roof channels water to the back.
Solution: Dig French Drain. Check with Frank and homeowners about underground lines. System should drain out the side closest to the paved road (septic is on other side). Add gutters (see seperate repair)

Problem: Because of Bill's disabilities, he may need a ramp in the near future.
Solution:
It would not be hard to build a ramp here, it would need to be 16-20 feet long.

Build a ramp with a 1- in -12 pitch with hand rails.

Make a concrete pad at the end of the ramp.  

Gravel or concrete pathway.

Problem:
Bathtub- Tile surround is damaged. Water could get in and cause more damage.  

Bill may need a walk in shower soon due to his disabilities.
Solution:
This happened due to an old leak. The plumbing was repaired but the surround was not fixed at that time.  

A new tile job or surround will be needed soon.

The other option is a walk- in shower.

need to re-assess for photos and estimate.

Problem: Bathtub drains really slowly.
Solution: Other drains in the house seem to work ok, so the problem is probably in the tub drain trap. This cou;ld be snaked or try to clear with a coathanger. If that does not work then the trap will have to be cut loose under the house, which has a tight crawlspace.

Problem: Threshold is damaged. Made of particle board.
Solution: Replace with solid wood or aluminum threshold.

Problem: Gravel needed on road and on pathway to porch
Solution: Order 1 or 2 loads from Danny Collins 777-6352. Have him spread most of it on the road and a pile to gravel the path

Problem: CO detector needed.
Solution: install battery unit

Problem: Toilet leak, no shut off valve
Solution: Sending Chris Lord out to investigate

Problem: There are 2 windows in a kids bedroom that should be replaced. Both are broken.
Solution:
1) 24" wide x 35" high.

2)24" wide x 54" high.

Both of these windows should be double-hung so that you can open the top or the bottom.

Note- one of these windows may have lead paint- it is old

Problem: Interior door to spare bedroom missing.Causes heat loss.
Solution: install interior door 24" x 80"

Problem:
There is an interior wall that is unstable. You can see a 1" gap between the top plate of the wall and the ceiling. Part of this wall is not well fastened to the ceiling joists, and "gives" when pushed on.  

Not sure how this happened- Could be a combination of settling and bad framing. James and I thought at first that the floor was sagging, but an inspection in the basement revealed that there was only a 1/4" sag. Floor joists are engineered trusses, but I could not inspect them because drywall was on the ceiling.  

This wall is not load bearing.
Solution:
Go down in the basement and screw in a 2x8 to the joists under the wall, parallell to the joists. Install two jack posts and fasten them to the 2x8.  

Go upstairs, remove furniture from back side of wall,and remove a couple of sheets of paneling. Make long tapered shims to go above the top plate. screw 4" timber locks or other long screws through the top plate and shim, and into the ceiling joists above.  

Doing these things will stabilize the wall so it cannot move up or down.

Problem:
Access issues. Cynthia used to be in a wheelchair, but can walk now with assistance. James has a bad knee and they have to go down a long flight of exterior steps when they need to go out. Since these stairs are uncovered, they can be slick in rain and snow.

The other exit from the home is by way of a covered deck. Client must then ride an elevator down. Elevator does not work.
Solution: Independent Living has approved installation of a new elevator system.

Problem: Driveway is muddy, gravel needed.
Solution: Get Danny Collins to dump 8 tons of gravel on the driveway.

Problem: Roof screws backing out. No leaks reported but could leak.
Solution: Access roof by extension ladder from side deck. Tighten screws with 1/4 driver in a cordless drill. Replace screws that have bad rubber washers. This roof is about a 6/12 pitch.

Problem: No floor insulation, minimal attic insulation.
Solution: Install R-30 in floors, R-38 in attic

Problem: Septic system is not functional. Client does not have a usable bathroom.
Solution: The septic tank and drain field were recently installed. Drain pipe is visible under trailer but not connected. It is 3 or 4 inch. Glue up drainpipe and then she should be able to bucket-flush. Once she has water she can flush toilet.

Problem: No water. Client gets water in jugs from neighbors
Solution:
There is a well, tank,and switch installed by Tommy Allison of Blue Ridge Well- 775-4480. Pamela is satisfied with the job.

The water line is "stubbed up" right outside the trailer. It is sch40 pvc. it looks like you could connect it with glue and pipe to a hookup on the side. Then after the power was turned on it would work. The wiring for the pump is in place.

An electrician will have to wire the main power from the meter base to the circuit box for this to work.

Problem: Pamela has no steps. She uses a box to get in her door.
Solution: Build a set of free standing steps with handrails on both sides. Height of doorway is about 32".

Problem:
Home on temporary power. Main wires not hooked up to home. Well won't work without power

Client has two outdoor GFI outlet boxes below the meter base She runs extension cords off of these to her house.
Solution: get an electrician to hook up main power.

Problem: Home has no permanent foundation. Water pipes are not protected from freezing. Home wobbles.
Solution:
A permanent foundation is needed. Pamela does not plan to move.

Right now the home is supported by a metal frame and trailer wheels. Pamela hired a man named Ron (778-1910) to do foundation work. He has not come back. He dug some holes for concrete footers .

Pour concrete in the footers and support the metal trailer frame with blocks. Remove trailer wheels. install underpinning to keep pipes from freezing. Make a pressure-treated frame and install used roof metal as underpinning. Make an access panel.

Problem: Drainage system is in place but gutters are not hooked up
Solution:
Cut downspouts, hook up to gutters, hook up to corrugated pipe.

client has downspout bands for attaching to side of house.

Problem: Muddy house site
Solution: plant grass seed. Add gravel to turn-around spot. Make gravel path.

Problem:
Electricasl issues. According to Barbara, one outlet "shoots fire".

Not enough outlets in rooms. Upgrade needed.
Solution: At the very least, replace one outlet. There is a modern circuit box in the basement, but more upgrades are needed.

Problem: Big pile of trash bags block rear exit. Clients have no vehicle.
Solution: Get someone with a pickup truck and/or a trailer to come out and make trash run(s). Ask clients to help load.

Problem:
The kitchen floor has some damaged plywood, under the area where the water heater is, due to an old leak in the washing machine. ( no longer here).

The floor is a bit spongy here.
Solution:
remove water heater and replace plywood.

Put water heater back.

Problem:
According to Barbara, there is a water issue. Showers only last 5-10 minutes then the water runs out.

Plumbing appears to be in decent shape. Some recent work was done when the water line froze in the basement.

Clients paid several hundred dollars for this repair.
Solution: There could be an issue withe the reservior ( thge home is on a gravity-fed system.) The reservior is located across the creek on property owned by the landlord. I attempted to talk to the landlord to gain permission to look at the reservior but was turned away.

Problem: Floor around commode is weak. The commode is an older model that uses a lot of water.
Solution: Remove commode, reinforce/repair plywood floor, reinstall a better commode with new wax ring and bolts

Problem: wobbly rail-porch
Solution: Remove one rail , reinforce framing, reinstall rail

Problem: Cliuents claim roaches are in home.
Solution: Call pest control

Problem: Leaky faucet. Bottom of cabinet water stained.
Solution: Replace faucet. Clean up black stain on cabinet.

Problem: Electric stove (older model) only has one working eye
Solution: replace stove

Problem: No CO or smoke detector in home
Solution: Install battery powered smoke/co detector

Problem: Gutters have no downspouts. There is a place where gutters will need work if a small roof is built over the back door.
Solution:
Add downspouts and black drainpipe to direct water away from the corners of the house.

There are 2 good downspouts in the falling-down shed.

Problem: hole in water heater/furnace closet
Solution: patch hole

Problem: Back door is an interior grade door and no longer closes securely.
Solution: Replace with exterior grade door with window and lock.

Problem: Pipe burst under the home during extreme cold in January 2018.
Solution: Repair broken pipe.

Problem:
Access issues. Although functional, the front door is hard to open and the area around the edge where the latch is is busted.

Access out the back door is restricted. There are two back (exterior) doors. they are both stapled up with plastic to keep out the cold air. One door has a 1" gap at the bottom . The other door does not fit the opening very well.

There is another exterior door in the bedroom. The access is blocked by a bed.
Solution:
At least two doors needs to be made functional so the clients have two safe exits.

Replace front exterior door, it is 35 1/2" wide and 76" high.

Repair or replace one or both back doors. Repair area around doors so that they open and close correctly and keep cold air out.

The bedroom exterior door can be removed and "walled over".

Problem:
Plumbing/drain issues.

Kitchen sink drains onto ground ( pipe missing). This is 1 1/2" or 2" pvc.

Clients are not sure where the septic tank is. looks like it is beside the house but I couldn't tell for sure.
Solution:
Locate septic tank. Call landlord for location.

Find pipe end and glue in a drainpipe.

Problem:
Chimney and fireplace work needed.

Cracked or missing bricks.

Stove handle broken.

There is a piece of OSB (flammable) behind the wood stove in the living room. Looks like it was put there to block holes in the chimney. This was originally a fireplace but now there is a metal (single wall ) stovepipe going into the wall above.

Bedroom chimney has some damage as well. This is a woodstove with a fireplace insert.
Solution: Remove OSB and fix the area behind it. Patch up chimneys. Inspect chimneys for soundness. Clean chimneys if needed. Roof is steep.

Problem: Weak floor on deck in front of front door. porch flooring is 5/4" treated deck boards.
Solution: Add framing beneath porch floor. Check for other framing issues while you are underneath.

Problem:
Electrical upgrade needed. There are not many outlets in the rooms. Lots of wiring on the outside of the walls.

Some wiring is spliced together with wire nuts but no boxes.
Solution: Have an electrician install boxes, check wiring for safety throughout home. Upgrade wiring if finances permit.

Problem: Work needed in bathroom. The commode wobbles. Flooring needed. Shower surround leaks.
Solution:
At some point the clients may need a remodel including a walk in shower. At minimum, the bathroom needs a new tub/shower surround. Remove commode , check flange and subfloor for damage and install vinyl plank flooring. Install new wax ring,bolts, and commode ( get a new, handicap one if finances permit).

The bathroom is 72 square feet.

Problem: Window next to front door is broken. Clients put a piece of vinyl over it.
Solution:
Replace window pane. it is 13 1/2" wide x 42 3/4" high.

Gentry's Hardware cuts glass.

Problem: At least two interior doors are in bad shape and need replacement. .
Solution:
The bathroom door slab is 32" wide by 79 1/2". Hinges and a knob will be needed.

Bedroom door was not measured, but it is a metal door and has come apart at the bottom.

Problem: Clients say water is not good to drink and has lots of sediment.
Solution: I did not see a water filter under the house. There may be one next to the well/pressure tank system, down in the barn. The well system is in a stall down there, but you could not see it because there was cardboard and other material stapled to keep out the cold. A water filter could be installed, and the water tested. Clients drink bottled water.

Problem:
Handrail work is needed. Inside the house, the stair rails are wobbly leading up to the second floor. There is a landing that needs work also.

Outside, the rails on the back steps are wobbly as well.
Solution: Repair or replace hand rails. You will need to come up with a better way of anchoring the posts or other vertical supports.

Problem: Broken latch on wood stove
Solution: I did not investigate this problem thoroughly, Ronnie mentioned it later. Replace latch.

Problem: Underpinning needs work. Pipes freeze.
Solution: Ronnie has worked on this and has patched together some underpinning, but a better system is needed. Make a pressure treated 2x4 frame and install old roof metal.

Problem: Clients have a hard time accessing the barn, where their firewood is stored, because of muddy conditions.
Solution:
Add gravel. The road to the house is not too bad, but the area from house to the barn is muddy.

If son's truck is not an option call Danny Collins 777-6352

Problem: Rotten soffit and fascia
Solution:
Remove damaged boards and replace with new material. Paint.

Some of the damaged areas have been covered with aluminum flashing, which will have to be removed to assess the damage.

Some of the paint on the house is lead-based.

Problem: Pipes burst at water filter during extreme cold weather.
Solution: Repair water line, install new water filter, install insulation to prevent future issues.

Problem: Paint peeling on exterior of house.
Solution: Paint house. A test near the meter base revealed lead WAS present on the bottom coat.

Problem: There is no smoke or CO detector.
Solution: install combo unit (battery powered)

Problem: Underpinning is in disrepair.
Solution:
Replace underpinning. The inexpensive way is to make a ground- contact pressure treated 2x4 frame and install old roof metal as underpinning. It lasts longer than the vinyl stuff.

Make a couple of plumbing access panels.

Problem:
Broken outlet cover in bedroom

light cover needed in hall
Solution: Install covers. Talk to homeowners- there may be some other electrical issues

Problem: Hole in floor near water heater in storage room.
Solution: Remove some carpet and replace plywood. Shore up framing if needed.

Problem: water heater does not work
Solution: replace elements

Problem: No water
Solution: Have well pump inspected
Contractor: Clyde Sawyers and Son Well Drilling

Problem: Electrical problems. Outlets in living room don't work. An outlet in the bedroom is in a water damaged wall.
Solution: This problem cannot be solved properly unless the walls dry out; see new roof Repair. Replace or repair outlets with new boxes. drywall work may be needed.

Problem:
Kitchen sink sprayer hose has a bad leak. Clients turn off water to it when they use water in the kitchen.  

New faucet may be needed.
Solution: Replace sprayer hose or disable side spray and plug.

Problem: Toilet shutoff leaks, does not work properly. Leak is causing floor damage.
Solution: Replace shutoff valve.

Problem: No water. When I visited Judy, she did not have a system set up to get water to her house.
Solution:
There are two reservoirs visible across the road from her house. One reservoir, the one she uses, has a good supply of water coming into it at this time.Judy and her neighbor, Helen, both say that the spring supplies good water. It is located slightly above the reservoir, and is contained in a spring box underground. You can tell where it is because there is a fairly large pipe sticking out where the spring supposedly is.

The reservoir is only elevated slightly above the house. A pump will be needed to supply enough pressure for showers, etc.  

Judy says she had a pump and pressure tank behind the house but that they were not enclosed or insulated.

It was hard to tell what happened from talking to Judy , but the tank and / or pump may have frozen. Someone removed the pump and pressure tank.

Install new pump and pressure tank system. This system could be located inside the roughed- in addition, and insulated to protect from freezing.

I could not find the original water line to the reservoir, and it was not hooked up on either end. It look like someone had tried to put in a water line but they did not bury it. So- it looks like a new water line will be needed from the reservoir to the new pump system. 3/4" PEX recommended. The water line will cross the gravel road. Bury lines 2' deep.  

Install new water lines throughout the house.

Problem: Stovepipe is not set up safely. Daylight visible through wall penetration, single wall pipe through house wall and on the outside.
Solution:
Client has a good, big wood heater. She could use another heater because of the large size of the home, which has no other heat source at this time. She has an electric space heater and propane gas logs, but no propane,. There is an empty 100 lb. propane tank outside.  

Client was running low on wood at assessment time so I gave her Glen Tucker's number.

Problem: Rear exit is blocked by clutter. There are no steps out the back. Door is approx. 20" off the ground.
Solution: Remove clutter around door. Build a 4' x 4' landing and steps. Build rails.

Problem: Weak floor. Worst places are under the fridge, in hall, and in one bathroom
Solution: Judy had some help installing some OSB to patch the floor but more work is needed. The fridge will need to be moved and reinforcement done to the floor beneath. Framing may need work . Use plywood.

Problem: Handrails needed on deck
Solution: Build about 20' of handrails. This is a covered porch, add 2x4's and ballusters to existing posts.

Problem:
Both bathrooms are in need of work. In one bathroom, the tub has been removed, and the room is full of clutter. The other bathroom's tub was filled with stuff, and the toilet was not flushed.  

The condition of the water lines, plumbing, and drain system is unknown because client has no water at this time  

There were some old polybutyl pipes visible under the house.
Solution:
Concentrate on getting water to the bathroom that is semi- functional, the one with the intact tub. The plumbing can be shut off to the other bathroom.

Re-doing the water lines is recommended because of the old polybutyl pipes. Bring the water lines up thru the floor and run all water lines inside the house to improve access and keep from freezing.  

Some additional remodeling may be needed.

Problem: A couple of light fixtures are loose or missing
Solution:
Install a couple light fixtures. Bulbs needed.  

Do a general electrical safety inspection.,

Problem:
Siding missing. The highest priority is around back, where the stovepipe comes through.  

A lower priority project would be to install housewrap and siding on the larger addition to protect it from the weather.
Solution:
For the back, Install vinyl siding. approx. 40 square feet. Job will be affected by stovepipe solution.  

If time and money permits, additional housewrap and siding can be installed on the addition. It is a good sized addition, I did not measure it accurately. 200 square feet would be a goo0d start.

Price given for siding around the back only

Problem: Rooms in house are very cluttered
Solution: Organize, get rid of trash, donate unwanted items.

Problem: Piles of trash outside. There is an unfinished addition with no floor that has lots of trash .
Solution: Take materials to landfill, recycling center.

Problem: Drywall in living room is smoke-stained and has no mud or tape.
Solution: Clean drywall. Tape and mud. Sand and finish drywall. Paint.

Problem: Home is energy- inefficient and hard to heat mostly because of its size.
Solution:
Judy closes off some rooms in winter to make the place easier to heat, but it is a big house for just one person. The belly liner of the trailer section seems intact so there is some floor insulation. Not sure how much , if any, insulation was installed during the roof overbuild. There is a gable vent on one side, you could remove that and look in there to seee how much insulation is in the ceiling. If possible, add insulation to the ceiling to increase efficiency.  

There is a window in the bathroom that may be damaged, I did not look closely.

Problem: Holes in bathroom floor caused by water damage. There are no visible plumbing leaks now. Hole under tub.The floor is soft around the commode, which is loose. The water heater, located in a bathroom closet, is leaning and there is a hole under it. Client has put some fiberglass insulation around to keep out cold air. The bathroom sink is unused. The drain is not hooked up to it. There are some galvanized drain pipes visible under the sink.
Solution:
Complete remodel needed. This bathroom is 8'x7'. Tub measures 30" x 60".

Remove tub, commode, sink, and water heater. Repair framing and subfloor. Install new plumbing for shower, tub, sink.

install new flooring, tub/shower, commode. Sink could possibly be reused, plumbing needed.

The water heater is 15 years old but seems to be in working condition.

Problem: Deck needs work. Handrails are wobbly. Posts missing or poorly installed.
Solution:
The deck is not very high off the ground (26") but the existing handrails should be repaired. Install some posts that go from the ground to the handrail height, 36" from the deck. Notch them in to the existing deck. Use timber lock screws or lags to fasten.

Replace some deck boards that are cracked or damaged.

Problem:
There is an issue with the septic system. Teresa has noticed that in the last year or two, the water in the home has taken on a funny smell. This is probably not due to sulfur because it has only happened recently.

Teresa says she has to have the system pumped out every year. Ocassionally, the drain lines seem clogged and nothing drains right in the house.
Solution:
By talking to a neighbor and looking around the outside of the house , I suspect that rainwater coming off the hill and from a culvert under a road above the house is getting into the septic tank, filling it up and causing drainpipe issues.

Have a septic pro come out and inspect with these findings in mind. Tell him about the water smell.

The area around the house has poor drainage, it looks like at one time there were some effective ditches dug back behind the house , but those have filled up.

Dig out the ditches behind the house to direct rainwater to a downhill location.

Working gutters with drainage away from the home would also help this problem.

Teresa is planning on calling the county Health Dept. and giving them a sample of her water to be tested.

Problem: Gutters failing. Water gets in crawlspace.
Solution:
The old vinyl gutters could be salvaged, but are lower quality. If the gutters are completely replaced, use metal ones.

Install downspouts and drainpipe. run the drainpipe away from the house to a downhill location.

I have priced materials to replace the whole thing- both sides, with metal gutters.

Make sure to use high quality caulk.

Problem: The house is difficult to heat.
Solution:
ENERGY EFFICIENCY PROJECT

Right now, Teresa has a monitor oil heater and an electric space heater She complains of high heating bills. I asked her if the attic was insulated and she thought so, but didn't know how well. The access panel in a bedroom closet ceiling was blocked with household items.

Get the family to de- clutter the area and assess the attic for proper insulation. More insulation in the attic space would reduce heating costs.

An inspection of the crawlspace revealed that the floor joists were inulated with fiberglass, but that some was falling out. If finances permit, the fallen insulation can be put back up, then install insulation board over the joists, to reduce thermal bridging and keep the fiberglass from falling out.

The crawlspace is approximately 1000 square feet.

I told Teresa that she should block up her vents for the winter to keep cold air out.

Problem: broken window in bedroom
Solution: This is a double pane window- approx. 36" x 36" One of the panes is broken. Call Asheville Glass to see about getting it fixed.

Problem: Crawlspace access door needed.
Solution:
Right now there is a scrap of plywood against the access hole, but it does not fit right.

Cut a properly sized piece of plywood and prop it shut with something.

Problem: Vinyl siding needs cleaning
Solution: Wash siding using buckets and soapy water. Pressure washing not recommended because the home has poor drainage and water might flood the crawlspace.

Problem: Trash and old furniture on porch and around home
Solution: Haul off stuff with truck. Teresa has a neighbor with a pickup.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery powered CO detector

Problem: Client has mobility issues. Ramp needed.
Solution:
Build a ramp with handrails. Independent Living or French Broad Baptist would be good resources.

There is a set of concrete steps, 40" high. then the yard slopes down to the parking area, where there are 2 steps (concrete).

The ramp will have to be long and have some zig-zags to it.

Make a concrete pad at the bottom.

James, the landlord, has given permission to cut down the bush in the front yard.

Problem: Porch plywood is in rough shape.
Solution: replace 2 sheets- 3/4 ply.

Problem:
In the basement, there are some copper pipes that look like they could freeze.

The basement doors do not shut properly, letting in cold air.
Solution:
Insulate pipes.

Rebuild doors. They are plywood.

Problem:
Bathroom needs work. There is some mold in here. Some parts of the floor are damaged, but overall it feels solid.

Plumbing does not appear to leak at this time.
Solution:
Barbara needs a walk in shower because of her disabilities. There is an existing tub, it is 59" x 29". There is a wall next to the tub that contains the tub/shower plumbing, but it could be moved. If the old tub is removed subfloor repairs could be made.

A large portion of the floor has been replaced, 4-5 years ago.

Problem: Barbara has a hard time cleaning her house and organizing due to her physical disabilities. Some places need paint.
Solution: Help clean organize, paint

Problem: Old flooring is peeling up in some places (linoleum)
Solution: Install new floor material. Use vinyl plank or higher quality laminate that will last.

Problem:
Old furniture on porch, in home, and in yard needs to be disposed of.

Trash in yard.
Solution: Haul stufff to landfill or dump. Use dump card #.

Problem: Yard work needed.
Solution: Trim bushes, etc.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem:
Porch and house have lots of clutter. Hard to move around. Hazel does not have a truck to get rid of trash, etc.

There is an old trailer and an old house that have lots of trash or items that could be donated.
Solution: Send a crew with a pickup truck to help her get rid of trash, recycling, donations ,etc.

Problem:
Linoleum flooring is worn out in kitchen.  

Owner requests old carpet to be removed in the living room.  

  

**Owner called about other issue 11/29/18 and while on the phone stated that she "lucked out" on 1200sf of carpet, enough for entire trailer. She doesn't have additional tools/materials (underpadding, tie strips, carpet stretcher) or the ability to do this herself. I told her I'd add notes to the assessment and offer to capable summer group(s).
Solution: Install high quality laminate flooring in both rooms. The kitchen is more worn. It is about 160 square feet. The living room is about 275 square feet. Materials cost given is for both rooms.

Problem:
Loose handrail on porch. Broken steps on back deck. No handrails on either set of back deck steps (40" deck height).  

The back entrance has a 9 " step down to the deck. This is a little too much for Velma since she has knee problems.
Solution:
The porch step handrail can be fixed with a 2x4 scabbed on to the existing 4x4 that is loose. Screw into the rafter above.

On the deck, remove broken set of steps and rebuild with new stringers. Make the steps 36" wide to meet code. Use 3 stringers, follow code. Install new step handrails.

The opposite side steps are OK, but have no handrails. Install handrails.

Build a small step ( 4 1/2" high x 36" wide x 11" deep) to make it easier for Velma to get on her deck.  

The deck is showing signs of wear but seems structurally sound. More work could be done if time and finances permit.

Donald and his brother Jake may be able to do some of this work, make sure to try and involve them if a volunteer project happens.

Problem: Front porch roof has some holes in the metal roofing that need to be caulked.
Solution: Apply high quality roof caulk to the holes in the metal

Problem: Roof leaks. Ceiling stained.
Solution:
Several stains are visible from inside the house. They are on the edges of the closet, bedroom, and hallway.

An inspection of the roof revealed no obvious leaks. The shingles are not worn or missing, and the penetrations seem adequately caulked. There are several vents on the roof, but no ridge vent. There was some snow on one side of the roof so a complete inspection did not happen.

Look again in better weather , maybe apply some roof cement to try and stop leaks

Problem: Rough road. Big ruts. Goes straight up.
Solution:
Scrape road. Since this is not Velma's property, the landowner should be called upon to remedy this problem.  

Order gravel from Danny Collins- 828-777-6352

Problem:
There are some bathroom issues.

In the first bathroom, the tub is cracked on the top side. Water cannot get in easily but the crack may get worse. (it is a plastic, trailer size tub). Commode and sink work good.  

In the second bathroom, the tub surround is cracked in a few places. Velma has caulked it but the surround is loose at the bottom.

In the second bathroom, the commode is cracked but does not leak. Monitor and replace if it starts leaking.
Solution:
The tub in the first bathroom is probably ok for now. Some kind of tape or adhesive could be applied to stop water getting in. Client has requested a walk- in shower here but this is not urgent at this time.  

In the second bathroom, replace tub surround. The tub is 27" x 54". Use high quality caulk and follow manufacturer's instructions.

Problem: Some underpinning is damaged
Solution:
replace 72 square feet of underpinning. Available at Discount Mobile Home Supply.  

Make sure to install bottom channel and use a level.

Problem: The right side of the kitchen sink leaks
Solution: Replace basket strainer

Problem: Some low skill outside work is needed around the place.
Solution: Talk to Velma and Donald about what work is needed. The goat shed and chicken house need work. There may be some stuff that needs to be hauled to the landfill.

Problem: Road is washboarded and hard for her to get up (she drives a 2 wheel drive vehicle).
Solution: Improve road. talk to professional grader.

Problem: No Smoke or CO detectors in home
Solution: install battery powered combo unit.

Problem: Roof shingles are missing. Area around chimney could leak. Roof shingles are 20+ years old and the gravel has worn off of most of them.
Solution:
New Roof. Metal recommended because of the high wind location on a ridge above Marshall.

Isaac Kanaar is Alma's son- in law and is a building contractor. I talked to Debbie, Alma's daughter, she is going to get an estimate and proof of insurance.

The family has another quote from Terry Chandler for $5400. They don't think he has insurance.

The roof is 2614 square feet including the attached carport.

Problem: Bathroom remodel needed. Floor is very weak, especially around commode. Walk- in shower needed.
Solution:
Remodel bathroom.

The room is about 70 square feet. The old tub/shower is 60" x 30". The vanity can probably stay, as the floor under it seems ok. Remove tub/shower, remove commode, remove old subfloor. Reinforce framing by sistering on or adding new joists. Install new plywood. Install walk-in shower. Install vinyl plank laminate flooring ( about 60 square feet needed). Install new handicap commode with new wax ring. Install new plumbing and drains. .

Problem: Floor is weak in one corner of the house near the sliding glass door.
Solution:
Peel up carpet and replace damaged plywood. Joist reinforcement may be needed.

This may have happened due to water infiltration from a small deck, accessed through the sliding glass door. Mark says this deck is never used, so the door acts more as a window. The deck looked like it was sloping away from the house, which would be good for drainage, but I did not check it with a level. If water is flowing towards the house from the deck it may be a good idea to remove this deck soon.

Problem: Hallway floor is giving way. The worst place is on the original, trailer side between the kitchen and bathroom.
Solution:
Remove linoleum. Remove bad flooring. Reinforce joists to support more weight. Replace subfloor with new CDX plywood. The plywood thickness is probably 5/8".

install new flooring (high quality laminate recommended). 40 square feet.

Problem:
Front and back deck need work.

Front deck- closest to the parking area. Some parts of the deck are over 30 inches high and, by code, need guard rails. This deck also has some rotten boards. There are some "humps" in the deck, due to settling?

Back deck. This deck is very slippery when wet. No guard rails. Broken stair tread. No step hand rails.
Solution:
Front Deck- Install at least 16' of guard rails, starting at the highest place off the ground.

Replace at least 10 deck boards.

Install step hand rails.

Some posts may need adjustment to take out "humps".

Install missing ballusters (20)

BACK DECK- 5'x8'- Clean deck with pressure washer or wire brush, Let dry and install tread tape or asphalt shingles.

Build guard rails and hand rails on both sides of steps.

Fix step tread.

Problem: Electrical shorts reported. Mark says a couple of outlets spark when you plug something in
Solution: Get an electrician to install new outlets and fix safety issues

Problem: Heat registers are broken. Sharp metal edges.Old furnace in questionable condition.
Solution:
Install new heat registers. Attach to duct work with high quality silver tape.

Note- furnace is very seldom used. The ductwork is not visible from underneath trailer, so the condition is unknown.

Problem: Window broken in Sara's room. The family has plastic taped over it for now.
Solution:
Remove old trailer windows and install new double pane windows that open.

A replacement window that is 28" high x 64" wide will work here. See photos.

Problem: Ceiling fan is wobbly. Lights work only partially.
Solution: Mark suggested removing the fan and installing a simple light fixture rather that trying to repair the fan

Problem:
Mark would like to have his laundry room changed around. Currently there is a washing machine in the laundry room, but the family keeps the dryer in a shed, so they must make trips out there.

Mark mentioned that the dryer was not in very good working condition.
Solution:
There is room here to move the dryer in, but you would have to install a 240 outlet. There is a wire there (nutted off) but no outlet.

The dryer vent is also not hooked up. There is a hole drilled in the floor for it, and a vent hose is visible underneath the home. You will have to crawl under there to hook it up.

Install outlet, hook up vent, install new dryer.

Problem:
The family could use a new stove and some new cabinets.

Their oven does not work properly. It may be hard to find parts for due to its age.

They have a range top but they cannot put an oven there because plumbing is in the way
Solution: Creativity will be needed here to find a solution to the stove problem. You will have to remove some cabinets and maybe move some drainpipes and water lines.

Problem: Siding looks like it has some damage. This is on the left side of the house if you are facing the house from the front deck, carport side.
Solution: Could not assess due to rain. Set up an extension ladder and take a close look, there may be a roof or flashing issue.

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: New Flooring requested in the living room. Carpet is getting worn and Mark has to vacuum a lot due to son's asthma
Solution: Remove carpet and install 250 square feet of flooring material. Use high quality laminate flooring that will not fall apart in a year.

Problem: Betty is concerned about her roof and requests that Kool Seal be applied. Although not currently leaking, the trailer roof is 20 years old.
Solution: apply Kool Seal or other brand of roof sealant,

Problem:
Bathroom vanity has a leak ( hot water side).

Faucet handle broken.  

Bottom of vanity is loose and black with water damage.

Water is shut off to the hot side and does not appear to leak unless you turn the water on.
Solution:
To fix this you will probably have to shut off the water to the whole house. Cut off polybutyl pipes. Remove vanity bottom, check subfloor for damage and repair, fix vanity bottom with a piece of plywood, and install couplings and new supply lines for both hot and cold with cutoffs.

If finances permit it may be easier to install a whole new set-up (vanity, sink, plumbing, etc. ).

Problem: Patsy has been having increased difficulty getting around. Walking is painful for her, especially on steps. She makes an effort to excercise and still tries to garden, but may need a ramp with handrails soon.
Solution:
Build ramp. It would be fairly easy to build because it would go straight out.  

Follow building code for ramps. They can only drop 1" horizontally for every vertical foot. The ramp will have to be about 14' long because it is 14" off the ground (approx).  

Ramp must be at least 36' wide.  

There must be handrails on both sides. The only problem with the rails is is that they would block some access to her porch. Maybe you could make handrails with hinges that can swing open?  

You will also have to move some raised beds (railroad ties) to make a wide path for the ramp entry.

Problem:
Vine has grown up between fascia board and roof metal.  

The vine has been cut and is dead but needs to be removed.
Solution: Remove vine. install new fascia board.

Problem:
Deck has boards that were improperly installed by a volunteer aquaintance of Patsy. There are big spaces between the boards (1 1/2"). Safety hazard.  

The boards were also not cut off flush with the deck band so the ballusters are not attached securely.  

The ballusters have spaces between them up to 6 1/2". (code calls for 4" maximum).
Solution:
Remove ballusters. Remove new deck boards.

Reinstall deck boards with 1/4" spacing.

Cut off deck boards flush to the band.

Reinstall ballusters with a 4" maximum space between them. Drill pilot holes to avoid splitting.  

Patsy has deck boards. Recycle sound material.

Problem: Patsy needs help with her garden beds, weeding, etc.
Solution:
Move railroad ties, get rid of rotten ones.

Some Railroad ties may need to be moved if a ramp is built.  

She likes Black Eyed Susans. Might be a nice thing to plant some.

Problem:
Loose steps. Handrails wobbly.  

This stairway is 16 feet long and it is seldom used, but needs to be made safe.
Solution: Screw down loose treads with deck screws. Stiffen up handrails with 2x4's, posts, or rebuild.

Problem: Commode seat loose. Bol;ts are broken
Solution: install new seat

Problem: Cleaning and organizing needed.
Solution: Help Patsy get rid of / donate / organize some stuff. house is cluttered.

Problem:
No heat. Exterior heat pump/ AC unit is not working properly.  

Pam has a small space heater on loan.
Solution:
According to Pam, there is a major electrical problem with this unit. It is 17 years old and when in use, it trips the breaker. Verlan Davis, an HVAC man that Pam knows, installed the unit. (Verlan's # is 828-243-1250). He has done maintenance on it through the years, and has recommended a new heater. Also, Pam and Megan think that the ductwork is coming apart because they have seen rodents coming through their heat registers.  

It may be worth it to get a second opinion, but a mini- split unit through French Broad EMC might be a good option.

Problem: Roof leak. Water is getting in between the trailer and enclosed porch bedroom addition.
Solution: Add flashing to the porch roof/ trailer transition. Use hi- quality roof caulk such as Lexel. The existing flashing is not attached, and a 4x4 holds it down up there. Apply caulk to stick the flashing in place, and add some sheet metal screws in a few places, thru the flashing and into the ribs of the metal roof panels. Remove 4x4.

Problem: Handrails of back porch steps are loose
Solution: Reinforce step handrails

Problem: Water is getting in the back door and adjacent window.
Solution: First, try cleaning the little trailer gutters above the doorway. you might try caulking the joint where the gutter has a seam. Some improvements could be made to the gutter above the door, or a small roof could be built above the doorway. If you build said roof, make sure it has at least a 2/12 pitch and make sure it is properly flashed to avoid leaks at the roof transition. The roof would not have to cover the entire deck, just shelter the doorway.

Problem: Second bathroom has a bathtub that is cracked. Clients do not use it. The sink and commode are in good shape and in use here.
Solution: Remove old tub. It is a trailer-size, center drain model. Repair subfloor beneath the old tub. Install new tub, drain, faucets. This would be a good time to replace the floor material; it is currently carpet. If you replace the flooring, you will have to take up the commode to install flooring under it. After installing flooring, replace the commode with a new wax ring and flange spacer if needed.

Problem: Underpinning is rotting
Solution: Install new underpinning. Remove old, damaged plywood underpinning. Pressure- treated landscape timbers are in place , and look to be in OK shape to nail to. You may have to replace some. You may want to install some vertical 2x4's in places. Use old roofing metal (call CHC for availability) as underpinning- it will outlast the expensive vinyl stuff.

Problem: Drywall patching needed
Solution:
Repair, paint, and finish drywall.

Use a vacuum with a sander attached for dust collection to protect heath of the residents.

Use drop cloths to protect finished floor

Problem:
A bedroom addition needs work. It is used as a living space but has no insulation and no siding.

Dimensions of the room are 9 1/2' x 13'.
Solution: This addition is actually an enclosed porch. Plywood was installed on the inside of the walls. A crew could install more framing, on layout for insulation, install insulation, and install exterior siding (T-111 plywood siding would work well here). There is some siding already up. Caulk and paint siding. The inside will need work, too, but I do not know what it looks like because the inside was covered by a shiny, tarp-like material when I visited.

Problem: There may be an issue with the septic tank. Megan says she can smell a bad odor sometimes. According to the family, the lid for the tank, about 1 foot underground, may have rotted away. In the past some work was done in the yard and the original concrete lid broke. It was replaced by a wooden lid, then re- buried. This was 10 years ago.
Solution:
Not sure where to find a septic tank lid. Try Parker Farm Supply. Know what type of lid you need before digging. Some are plastic, some are concrete.

Talk to Pam and Gary, her neighbor, about this before starting work.

Dig about a foot down in the front yard and find the tank. Try not to knock too much dirt down in it, Get a new, rot- proof lid , put it on, and re- bury.

Problem: Soft place around toilet in one of the bathrooms
Solution:
This problem happened due to a shower valve leak (since fixed.)  

Remove commode, wax ring. Remove a section of linoleum. Remove damaged subfloor material. Reinforce framing, adding joists if needed. Replace plywood, it will be either 5/8" or 3/4". Install approx. 5' x 10' piece of linoleum. Install 10' long threshold strip. Reinstall commode with a new wax ring.

Problem: Porch roof leak
Solution:
The roof is leaking at the transition of the main roof and the added porch roof. The side that is leaking is the side nearest the road. This a a tricky problem. an improperly pitched gutter may be making the problem worse. Here is a suggested remedy:  

Remove 2 sheets of metal on the porch.Remove the damaged OSB roof sheathing. Repace OSB with 1/2" plywood. Replace roof metal and re- flash and re-caulk.  

Remove the gutter on that side. Re- install the gutter, pitching it at a steeper slope away from the source of the leak. Get a new end cap. Clean the gutter and re- caulk with Lexel.

Problem: Second bathroom has a tub faucet that has a broken handle that is stripped out.
Solution: replace faucet

Problem: Electric heat pump/ AC unit is not working properly. Clients complain of extreme heat in the summer. The family has heat but the large double wide may be hard to heat if it gets really cold.
Solution:
For heat,The family has a Laser oil heater which is in use at the time, and a backup propane unit.

The electric heat/AC pump unit has been disabled. Donia, who has some experience with HVAC machinery, pulled the fuse and took the fan out. Donia mentioned that she talked to Austin Heating, which is less than a mile away, and they said they would charge $100 just to come look at it. I suggested they get some other quotes from Bullman or Gentry. It seems that some parts could be replaced, mainly the fan motor, or as Donia suggested, the capacitor.

The family had some guys cutting down trees in the yard. I suggested they leave some shade trees, and run fans with open windows in the summer. This did not appear to them to be an adequate solution.

Problem: 4 interior doors needed in order to allow privacy in bathrooms and bedrooms now that the family have youth living in the home of both sexes.
Solution: Install 4 new 32" x 78" interior doors. Slab, knob, and hinges needed. Jam and stop materials on site. Interior door trim needed. Master bathroom door does not shut right. Needs work, or a new door. Discount Mobile Home Supply has everything you need.

Problem: Painting is needed in rooms where the drywall has been patched
Solution: paint 3 rooms

Problem: There is a lot of clutter in the home.
Solution: A couple of rooms need to be cleaned out and organized. Talk to Phyllis.

Problem: Front covered porch in need of repair. Posts and some framing are starting to decay.
Solution: Some jacking up of the structure will be necessary to get the porch roof weight off. Because of the way the joists are framed, repairs are possible here rather than total tear- down and rebuild. Some new deck boards mat be needed

Problem: Larry and Phyllis both have some trouble getting up and down stairs. They will soon need an easier way to get in and out of their home.
Solution:
A ramp would not be very practical here because of the terrain and the way the house is built. Larry has a plan to install a wheelchair elevator in his basement.

The plan is to remove the basement steps and install a platform that will lift up to the top floor by means of a winch. He has a winch.

Talk to Larry about helping him with this job.

Problem: ceiling fan is loose
Solution: Cut power to fan. Take apart and make sure the ceiling box is metal and installed correctly. Remove some drywall and reinforce framing if needed.

Problem: There are some drainage issues around the back side of the house. The gutters here are falling apart and not effective. There is a downspout that is not hooked up right and drains water into the middle of the block foundation.
Solution:
In order to fix this problem, a French drain should be installed. This job must be done correctly to be effective. Use solid drainpipe with holes in the top, not corrugated black pipe. Install a cleanout so that the drain can be snaked if clogged. Use silt cloth and gravel. Do not hook up the french drain to the gutter drainage system. Make sure the pipe "daylights" or is exposed so that the water can get out of the system.

Remove old gutters and downspouts. Install new gutters and downspouts. Slope the gutters towards the outside of the house so that the problem of the wrongly- sloped gutter will not be repeated. Install drainpipe to get rid of gutter water.

Use wide gutters that hold a lot of water so that you can use one downspout rather than two.

Larry requests that snow guards be installed because of the large amount of snow that they receive in this mountainous area. His old gutters busted because of snow.

Recommended Gutter installers- A1 Seamless gutters- 828- 645- 7707, Dotson gutters 828-691-7268

Problem: paint needed in basement
Solution: This is a block basement. Clean the blocks first then apply mold resistant paint (Kilz).

Problem: flooring requested in a bedroom. Old floor covering has been removed. The bedroom is 10' x 8.5'.
Solution: Install floor covering. Larry requests carpet but may be talked into laminate- ask him

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery unit

Problem: Vinyl siding dirty
Solution: Wash siding . Larry has a pressure washer but it needs repair as of Nov. 2017

Problem:
Above the kitchen sink, there is a window where water has leaked in. The water was running down the outside wall of the trailer and seeping in around the window. There also may be some roof leaks, although none are obvious. Condensation may also be happening.  

The long term solution will be a metal roof, but temporarily, flashing has been installed to keep water out of the window opening.
Solution:
This job may be best accomplished from the outside by removing the sheet metal.

Remove the single pane trailer window. Repair water damaged wood framing. Replace insulation. Install new window. Trim inside and out.

Problem: Roof leak in living room at wood stove.
Solution: Investigate and repair.

Problem: Severe propane gas leak in the yard.
Solution: Replace line from tank to house.

Problem:
Nancy's driveway is steep,rutted and requires 4wd or all wheel drive. It is not graded properly. The driveway is about 1/4 mile long. There are no water breaks. Client had the road worked on last fall and it washed out. At this point Nancy and her disabled grandson have to walk up at times.

This issue started when the road (hwy. 19) was widened a few years ago. The state bought Nancy's old place across the road and bought her a trailer. There was a better driveway to the site but the state changed it. Nancy has tried to get the state to fix her driveway but they have not been willing.
Solution: Get a professional grader to take a look at the site to see if a less steep driveway could be built in another location. Nancy told me that she has 10 acres, but I was confused about where the property lines were. Also, the driveway would be next to hwy. 19 so the state might have to get involved somehow.

Problem:
Weak place in the floor - front entrance/laundry room.

This problem happened due to an old water heater leak. According to Nancy, Aaron Pike replaced the water heater through CHC, but the weak place is still there.
Solution: Take up some flooring and replace water damaged plywood.

Problem:
Roof leaks. There are 3 leaks in an unused bedroom that is used for storage. You can see dark stains on the ceiling.

The porch roof may be leaking where the transition to the trailer roof is.

There could be a condensation problem because the roof is under-vented. The stains are on the edges of the roof.
Solution:
The 3-tab shingles are 15 years old. Before you put a new roof on, try adding some vents because the roof seems under- vented.

Install flashing between metal roof and shingle roof. Attaching metal flashing to the aluminum trim -under the shingles with sheet metal screws and roof caulk. This may help water from getting under there.
Volunteer or Groups:
Lower Providence Presbyterian Church;
Christ Church (New Bern)

Problem: Leaks in larger bathroom. One leak is coming from the shower plumbing or drain and goes under the wall into the bedroom.
Solution: There is a panel that can be removed to look at the plumbing behind the shower. Sometimes something just needs tightening. Stuff will have to be moved out of the way so you can remove the panel.

Problem: Toilet in small bathroom is not flushing. Nancy thinks there is some kind of obstruction. Other drains in house work.
Solution: Remove toilet and remove obstruction. Put toilet back with new wax ring.

Problem: Floor in living room is bare OSB.
Solution:
Install approx. 250 square feet of laminate flooring.  

Do not use cheap linoleum or cheap sticky- tiles.

Problem: The place has not been mowed or weed-eated in 2 years
Solution: Cut down small trees/ bushes. Mow and weedeat. Talk to Nancy for direction.

Problem: Lots of clutter in bedroom and on porch
Solution: Talk to the family about donating items. Get trash bags and make a run to the dump.

Problem: vinyl siding dirty
Solution: wash siding

Problem: air leaks around front door
Solution: install some new weatherstripping

Problem: Porch floor has a weak place. there is a big knothole. Close to front entrance.
Solution: Adam has plans to repair this section of the porch. He says it may involve jacking it up, but seemed confident to be able to do this himself.
Volunteer or Groups: CC New Bern/St. Mary's Lakewood, WA

Problem: Clients have two heaters- a monitor oil heater and a wood stove. Joyce says that the monitor is not working properly. Clients also have a good wood stove, but had no firewood at assessment time. Joyce mentioned that it was difficult for them to get firewood.
Solution:
Clients have requested a high efficiency electric heater and know about the program that can help finance a heater through French Broad EMC.

Monitor should be serviced in the meantime until better heating can be provided.

Problem:
House is poorly insulated. The roof overbuild does not include added insulation, The roof has little or no insulation, just the old trailer ceiling stuff (thin).

The floors appear to have some insulation, underneath the belly liner seems mostly intact. There is plastic on the ground.

Walls are 2x4 at best, windows are mostly single pane
Solution:
On the gable ends, plywood panels could be removed in order to install insulation on the roof.

Spray- foam insulation is more expensive, but may be more impervious to critters.

Blown insulation would require some kind of baffles to be installed to hold the insulation in and keep varmints out.

Estimated cost not including baffles

Problem: Porch roof leaks
Solution: It looks like you may be able to patch it using roof cement, screws , and flashing.

Problem: Old single pane windows are not efficient
Solution:
Replace several windows in home. Double pane, single hung OK.

1) 45 1/2" wide by 38 1/2" high

2) three windows 30" wide x 39" high

3) two windows 27" w x 52" high

4)two windows 14" wide x 51" high

5) two bay trailer windows- single pane, you may be able to get replacements at a trailer supply place

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: front window( on porch) brokennote- lead paint
Solution:
replace window

32" wide x 67" high

Problem: Electrical issues. Several outlets in the home are loose and pulled out. One socket has no outlet, and there are some loose wires. Light on porch has the wires cut to it. Holes in the drywall will necessitate installing drywall at the same time electrical repairs are done so that the boxes will fit.
Solution: Get someone with electrical skills to reinstall new electric boxes . The drywall is 3/8 thickness.

Problem:
Main heat/ AC unit does not work. This is an electric heat pump/ ac unit, installed outside. Connie says it has been damaged. Inside there is a furnace , "Intertherm" brand, in a closet in the laundry room. It was making a buzzing sound. Two built- in breakers were turned off at the unit and the buzzing stopped.  

Note- the family has a small portable propane heater but Connie says it will not heat the whole house.
Solution: Contact HVAC pro to diagnose heating problems

Problem: Laundry room floor has a weak place, in front of the furnace closet. This probably happened due to an old leak which has been repaired, but the OSB floor is damaged.
Solution:
Cut out a section of subfloor and replace OSB with CDX plywood. Reinforce joists if needed.  

Note- this room has no finished floor, it is just OSB, so it would be a good time to install flooring ( 42 square feet)

Problem: Broken window in bedroom
Solution:
Replace broken unit with a double or single hung double pane window.  

Get a replacement window that will fit a 35" x 39" rough opening.

Problem: back steps need to be rebuilt
Solution: The deck height is 57". Framing is ok on the deck, but it needs diagonal bracing. Handrails and balusters are needed.

Problem: The porch roof needs repair. It is roofed with transparent material and some pieces are broken or missing.
Solution: remove damaged panels and replace.

Problem: Bathroom sink drain missing. Supply lines are shut off.
Solution: install "S" trap. There is a 1" ID outlet from the sink to a 1 1/4" drain (ABS).

Problem: There are several big holes in the drywall in various locations
Solution:
The drywall throughout the house seems to be 3/8 thickness. Wood will have to be added to have something to nail to. Finish and paint drywall.This job should go along with electrical work since the drywall holds in the boxes.

There is some thin trim that is missing or broken. It is 1/8' thick by 1 1/2" wide with an oak look. You will need short trim nails to install it.

Problem: New finished floor material is needed in several rooms of the house.
Solution:
Dylan's room- Here there is some flooring that has been installed, but it might be easier to re floor the whole thing. The room is 9x12- need 120 sft. laminate flooring $240  

Hallway- 30 sft.$60

Laundry room- 50 sft $100 Bare subfloor here, needs repair.  

Bedroom - 15x12 - 180 sft $360 Carpet must be removed. Connie has offered to help rip out the carpet.  

Unoccupied bedroom-120 sft- $240

Problem: Vinyl siding around the back has some holes in it.
Solution:
Replace some vinyl siding. A corner piece has big holes.

There are no windows on this side of the house. If finances permit and the homeowners want it, it would be a good time to add a window in either bedroom. You will have to do some re-framing and watch for wires when cutting the holes.  

The best approach here may be to get some siding that matches the color, tear off siding on this side , and re-use the old stuff with the new. Use roof nails to install siding. Make sure there is a vapor barrier.

Problem: Back door will not close right
Solution: Repair door . The area where the strike plate was is busted up. Repair Jamb with a piece of 5/8 thick by 2" x 10" .

Problem: Roach Problem due to furniture given them that was infested with roaches
Solution: The family has been in touch with an exterminator about this problem. Communicate with them before hiring anybody.

Problem: Connie would like a fire pit to be constructed out back to have campfires and burn paper and wood.
Solution: Talk to Connie about location. Get some rocks. maybe Gentry Hardware knows where you could get some.

Problem: Cleaning and organizing needs to happen in the home
Solution: Talk to Debra or Connie about this job.

Problem: There is a lot of trash about the yard.
Solution: Haul trash to the dump or landfill. construction trash must go to the land fill.

Problem: No working CO/ smoke detector
Solution: There are some units that need a cover and a battery, otherwise just get a new smoke / co detector

Problem: At the entrance to the bedroom there is a very soft spot in the floor, hidden by carpet. You could fall thru if unaware
Solution: Remove a section of carpet and replace the plywood, reinforcing the framing if needed. Replace about a 2' x 5' section. Get some flooring and put over it. Install a threshold at the transition.

Problem: Front deck needs rebuild. The deck slopes 2 inches towards the house, causing water to flow towards the doorway. This could cause water damage
Solution:
Tear off old deck and rebuild. The existing deck is 42" wide and 8' long. deck height is 26". Since you have an elderly resident, put up rails. Steps need rebuild.

Build the deck so that it is free standing and slopes away from the house.

Add diagonal braces to the posts.

Problem:
The second bathroom in the home needs work. The floor, although stable, is warped and the toilet leans.

The tub, a big center drain model, is cracked on the outside. It is an old, plastic tub.
Solution:
Since she has another bathroom, this is not urgent, this bathroom is usable. If a remodel was done, new plywood could be put over the old and shimmed up level, the toilet re-fitted, and the tub replaced. Estimate for materials is rough

A walk in shower may be a good idea here in the near future

Problem: Back deck needs work. The deck is 10' x 8'2". It is probably 20 years old but could be fixed.
Solution:
For some reason the builder of the deck used a 2x4 ledger to hang 2x8 joists?. The inside deck board has pulled loose. It might be tricky, but take off a couple of deck boards first so you can get to it, then try to replace that 2x4 with a 2x8. You could also try adding a 2x8 underneath the joists, attached to the 6x6 posts.

Install another hand rail on the side of the steps. It will be about 8'3" long.

Add diagonal bracing to the 6x6 posts underneath for reinforcement.

Problem: Back door in bad shape. Storm door rusty, exterior door knob does not close right
Solution: Replace door. Exterior door, 32"x 77 1/4". As you stand on the deck, the hinges for both doors are on the left. The storm opens out. Order from Discount Mobile Home Supply.

Problem: The tiles in the kitchen have peeled up; some are missing.
Solution: These are vinyl stick down tiles. If you can find matching ones then you mat be able to peel up some and re-stick them ,and add new ones. Otherwise , you could redo the whole thing , possibly by putting new tiles down over the old ones. The most durable type of flooring for this job is vinyl plank, which require no glue and will last a long time. Kitchen is about 144 square feet.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: The front porch is not built correctly. The deck slopes towards the house, causing water to get into the door threshold. As a result, the floor is weak beneath the threshold and the wall moves when you push on it. The deck has a lot of bounce to it because the framing beneath is inadequate.
Solution:
Remove old deck. Build back a smaller size deck, making sure it is sloped AWAY from the home this time. You may have to make a little bridge going across due to the location. Add handrails and brace posts.

Some materials may be reusable if demo'd carefully

Once the deck is built then see if you can fix the loose wall, you may be able to screw it down and stabilize the threshold, or you may have to remove the threshold and repair weak floor beneath

The landlord does not want a roof to be built back.

Problem: The porch roof has very little slope. As a result it is leaking, and is also under-framed. The 2x4 that holds all the weight of the roof is cracked and may give way soon.
Solution:
Remove porch roof. Demo and take materials to landfill. Rebuild another one at a later time.

Note- Robert says he will talk to his landlord who has a tractor about removing the porch roof.

Problem: There is no rear exit to the home. The back door is not used and opens to a 40" drop.
Solution: Build a small deck and steps with rails out the back. The deck should be free standing with 45 degree bracing to the posts. It should also slope gently away from the house to get rid of water. Make the deck 3 1/2' x 4', with a set of steps 3 1/2' wide.

Problem: Water heater is not producing much hot water
Solution: New thermostat or new water heater. Heater is 16 yrs. old. It is a one-element Whirlpool model, wired for 110 electricity.

Problem: New flooring requested in two bedrooms. One bedroom is 165 square feet, the other is 72 square feet.
Solution: install laminate flooring

Problem: kitchen cabinets are coming apart on one side of the kitchen
Solution: you may have to remove the cabinets, then fix them and re-hang them. Or buy new cabinets.

Problem: In the bathroom, the tub and shower valve are leaking. Floor wet.
Solution: Replace the tub and shower valves. Access is fairly easy, there is an adjacent closet whose shelves have been removed. Floor is wet but not damaged.

Problem: 2 interior doors needed
Solution: Replace old, busted doors. they are 24" wide, 79 1/4" tall. wood doors. try Discount Mobile Home Supply.

Problem: Robert has a couple windows that are leaky, single pane storms.
Solution: Replace 2 windows. They are 39" high and 45 1/2" wide.

Problem: kitchen sink drains slow
Solution: take apart sink drain and clean it out

Problem: Underpinning work is needed
Solution:
install some new underpinning (vinyl,) where some is broken

Install underpinning under porch

Problem: The roof, although not leaking at this time, has been well maintained by Kool-Seal.
Solution: Apply 2 coats of Kool Seal.

Problem: smoke/CO detector needed
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: 2x4 rafters do not provide enough space for insulation that would meet code and not cause condensation
Solution: add more framing to the ceiling. Should be 11 " of space.

Problem: there is only one entrance/ exit
Solution: you would have to re-frame an opening somewhere, planning needed.

Problem: no heat
Solution: install a heater if needed by winter.

Problem: wiring needed in home
Solution: some has already been done

Problem: No septic
Solution: Tie in to town septic-Permitted?

Problem: no plumbing in home. A toilet and shower pan have been purchased but they are not hooked up
No water
Solution: Presumably you could get town water here but not sure how to do that.

Problem: no power
Solution:
There is a 220- 3 prong cord on the side of the house that is meant to be plugged in as a power source.

Not sure how this works with building permits

Problem: Front deck has weak spots- getting dangerous to walk on
Solution:
Tear down old deck and rebuild. The existing deck is 12 1/2' x 3'4".

Build steps and hand rails.

Problem: Roof leaks. There are some visible stains in the hallway, bay window area and laundry area.
Solution: New roof needed. This is a flat trailer roof and will need rafters. Shed- style or trusses. Install metal roof

Problem:
Sliding glass door to front entrance has a broken pane. One pane has fogged up. Door lock freezes in winter as a result of condensation on the single pane window. Client cannot open it sometimes.

Water infiltration has caused a weak spot in the floor on the inside.
Solution: Replace sliding glass door . Repair floor with new plywood. Put some new flooring on top.

Problem: trailer siding dirty
Solution: pressure wash or hand scrub.

Problem: Propane heater blocks the doorway
Solution: Jim says he moves it out of the way when he needs to get out the door but a permanent home should be found. Talk to Jim.

Problem: Deck wobbly. Steps too steep.
Solution:
Reinforce deck with diagonal braces. Rebuild steps to code, add handrails and guard rails.This is the deck on the side away from the road with the regular exterior door.

This deck is 5'x10'.

Problem: Part of an outbuilding (block wall) is falling towards the house
Solution: remove block wall

Problem: The air conditioner is supported by a platform , it needs reinforcement.
Solution: Rebuild platform with 2x4 supports.

Problem: The front patio ,(a concrete slab) closest to the road, needs work. Peeling-up old carpet causes a tripping hazard on steps and patio.
Solution: Remove propane tanks and furniture. Scrape up old material and clean the concrete. Let dry. Concrete patch may be needed. Paint. This may be possible to do in a day if the weather is good.

Problem: Yard work needed.
Solution: Prune, weed, etc. Jim wants some bushes pruned, talk to him for directions.
