Problem: Some drywall patching and painting is needed here and there. There is some old damage and a stain in the closet from an old roof leak, and a place in the kitchen that needs patching.
Solution: Patch drywall, finish and paint.

Problem: Sketchy wiring, shorts reported. some switches and outlets do not work.
Solution: Have an electrician check it out and fix the stuff that is dangerous

Problem: Deck boards are worn out. One is broken
Solution: Replace deck boards. up to 20 could be replaced if finances permit.

Problem:
Bathroom remodel needed.

Bad leak in the tub drain water pours out underneath trailer).

New toilet needed.

Vanity cabinet bottom damaged, moldy (due to leak).
Solution:
This bathroom is 5' x 10'6".

Remove old tub. It is a center drain, trailer-style tub. This may be a hard tub to replace but you could try Discount Mobile Home Supply. A new, regular tub will require moving the drain. Repair subfloor with new plywood. Install a new drain. Install new tub. It will need a surround as well.

Remove toilet. Remove vanity cabinet. repair any subfloor damage. Install floor material. Install new toilet. The vanity cabinet and sink are in ok shape but the bottom is moldy, you should have materials on hand to repair or replace the water lines to the vanity. It may be possible to tighten up the connections, but be prepared. Replacing the vanity may be the simplest thing.

The subfloor here appears to be sound but should be checked for damage. you may be able to reuse the floor material.

Problem: Exterior door in rough shape,plastic where glass used to be
Solution: Install a new door. This is a trailer size 32" x 76" with no storm. It opens to the outside with the knob on the right.

Problem: No CO or Smoke detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: On the back side of the house, there is a place where there is not enough roof overhang. Could cause soffit/fasdcia damage.
Solution: Add 2 pieces of metal roofing, slide them up under the existing. Overlap 1 foot

Problem: Hole in hallway floor. As you come in the door closest to the parking area, it is right in the middle of the hall before you get into the kitchen.
Solution: remove some floor covering and remove damaged plywood. install new plywood (probably 5/8") and new flooring. You will have to find flooring to match the existing, ask homeowners where they got their flooring. Some trim may have to be removed as well.

Problem:
Septic drain leak under house.

This is not a big leak, more like a seep, but you can see where it has leaked thru the access door in the front of the house.
Solution:
There is a flexible coupling that connects two 3" drain lines. The coupling could just use tightening, or possible replacement. You will have to do some digging under the house to access the drain line.You can reach it through the crawlspace access.

There is also a drain from the washing machine to another 3" line that is not connected properly. some couplings or short pieces of pipe needed.

wear protective gear

Problem:
2nd Bathroom is in need of repair.

Bad floor near toilet.

Tub is cracked and not used.

Hole near shower entrance.
Solution:
Note- there is another, working bathroom in the home.

Don't worry about the tub- they never use it.

This is a 7'x 8 1/2' bathroom.

Remove carpet. (protect area from dust).

Remove toilet.

repair subfloor around toilet and shower with new plywood.

install new floor material. 60 sft

install new toilet with wax ring.

install threshold

replace vanity cabinet and faucet

Problem: Clients have silt in the well water which causes plumbing problems.
Solution: install a couple of water filters

Problem: Area behind kitchen sink is damaged due to water damage. Cabinet doors are in bad shape.
Solution: Unhook sink plumbing and remove faucet. Remove old sink and countertop. Inspect floor for water damage and repair if needed. Install new sink and countertop. The existing one is 24" wide x 9'9" long. install new cabinets.

Problem: There is a roof leak on the porch.
Solution: Attempted to fix this by caulking a hole at assessment time, but keep an eye on it. it may need some flashing if caulk dosen't work

Problem: Gutters needed on back side of house. approx. 60' needed.
Solution: Install gutters . Downspouts and drainage is already there.

Problem: No CO Detector
Solution: install battery unit

Problem: painting requested in the kitchen.
Solution: paint. use drop cloth and plastic to protect surfaces and paint neatly

Problem:
On the back side of the house, there are several siding boards that are rotting.  

siding is rough sawn 1x10 with 2 1/2" battens.  

The boards should be 8' 2" long.
Solution:
Replace siding boards and battens. The main places that need repair are behind the oil tank. This tank is not moveable according to the homeowners.  

Paint siding (grey color)

Problem: A minor roof leak has been reported.
Solution: Ed Roberts put a new roof on this house two years ago. The family says they are going to contact him to try and have this fixed.

Problem: Client requests new windows. The old ones are single panes with storms. There are 8 that she would like to have replaced, one is missing a storm window and is leaky. None are broken.
Solution:
Although costly, This would be a good energy efficiency project. The one leaky window could be replaced at a lower cost. She has had some windows replaced already, maybe by Community Action.

Most windows are approximately 28"w x 54 1/2" high.

Problem: CO detector needed.
Solution: install one

Problem:
Roof needs some work. There are some nails sticking up, visible from the top side of the roof. The roof has less than a 2/12 slope, so some issues can be expected.

This is a fairly new roof with architectural shingles. The shingles don't seem to be leaking but there are some places where water can get in.

Chimney cap needs replacement, chimney needs cleaning.

Note- only one chimney is used, but there is a leak in the other one.
Solution:
Replace 2" plumbing boot

Add roof cement to 2 masonry chimneys

Replace one chimney cap (rusted)

Clean chimneys

Caulk nail holes
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem: There are 2 windows whose sills have rotted.
Solution:
Replace two windows. Once the old windows are removed the rough opening will be around 36" wide x 40" high.

Re-trim on outside, re-caulk.

siding seems in ok condition, inspect when you take out the old windows.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem:
Front door needs some work. The door will not shut properly and is not plumb with the jambs, causing an air leak.

The threshold and frame are not nailed down properly.
Solution: This door could probably be repaired, but the homeowners are requesting a new one with a half- glass front.

Problem: basement door needs replacement
Solution:
Install an exterior door. You will have to do some framing.

The family seldom uses this basement, but cold air can come thru and a safe exit should be established for anyone who is down there.

Problem: Linda has requested new flooring material to be installed in the living room. The carpet has some age to it, but is not totall shredded. Linda would like to have new flooring similar to what has been recently installed in her kitchen. That stuff is laminate vinyl flooring.
Solution:
Install new flooring . 250 square feet will be needed.

Make sure to protect the homeowners from dust during carpet removal.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install a battery powered unit
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem: gutters need to be replaced to alleviate water/moisture issues rotting out the home.
Solution:
install all new seamless gutters and run to existing drain lines.  

Before the gutters go up, someone should go out there and fill in the hole left by the missing chimney. - Completed by Carl Haas (volunteer)

Problem: The steps off the front porch need work. No handrail on one side. The other handrail is wobbly.
Solution:
This is the third entry/exit to the home and needs to be improved for safety. The steps should probably be rebuilt.

You will need 12 ' stringers. Build new steps back that are like the old ones. Build two good handrails.  

The landing at the bottom and the rest of the steps are in decent condition.

You may have to re-do the gate so that the handrails will work out.

Problem: Gutters need work.
Solution: Replace some sections of gutter, some just needs to be re-hung. Some downspouts and drainpipe are needed.

Problem:
Rear exit is not safe. Deck floor is soft and needs replacement.

Storm door has a broken hinge.
Solution:
Remove old deck. The deck is not very high off the ground.

The old deck, which extends around the corner and has a set of steps, can be removed and a simple 4'x10' deck can be built back in its place. Client does not need a large deck, just a safe exit.

Make a free standing deck with a gentle slope away from the house to drain water. Build a handrail on one side.  

The storm door hinge could be replaced as the cheapest door solution. The area behind the door is another enclosed porch, so an insulated exterior door is not necessary.

Problem: Ceiling drywall will need to be patched once the roof leak is stopped.
Solution: Protect bedroom with plastic. Patch drywall. Textured finish. Paint.

Problem: The enclosed porch could use some new flooring.
Solution: install laminate flooring- 50 square feet

Problem:
There is a roof leak. Water damage can be seen in the bedroom.

The roof metal appears to be in good shape, but wysteria vines are covering a large part of the roof.
Solution:
The vines will have to be cut off the roof to further assess the leak. Water may be collecting somewhere and rusting the tin , or getting in somehow due to water being not able to drain off the roof.

Once the vines are cleared away, clean the area and find the leak , then roof cement, flashing or metal can be applied.

Problem: A rat has been getting in the house. In the bathroom, some work has been done recently by a man hired by the family. The floor was giving way under the commode. A new washer and toilet have been installed and the floor reinforced, but there is still a place where plywood was not installed, and a rat can get through from below.
Solution:
The family has a big rat trap that they have been setting behind the commode. Julia says they got the rat.

Plywood should be installed to keep any more varmints out.

The washer will need to be moved.

Problem: Storm door needed. The old, single pane storm door provides an entrance to an unheated enclosed porch. existing door does not have a handle and is coming apart at the bottom.
Solution:
Install a new storm door.

The old one is 31" x 79".

It opens to the outside. Hinges are on the left if you are standing on the outside.

You could put an exterior door here, but it is not necessary because the enclosed porch is unheated.

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install a battery powered unit

Problem: Steps leading up to the deck are starting to rot. handrails loose.
Solution: Replace 1st set of steps up to the first landing. Build it back the way it was (same width, same stringer design.) Build back good handrails.

Problem: Back door , although functional, will not open because of cluttter. It opens to the inside, and the washer and dryer are in the way of easy access to the main part of the house (kitchen).
Solution:
Remove clutter (boxes, etc) and find another place for the washer and dryer, or get a stackable unit.

There is also a storage space for mops, etc. that interferes with getting out the door.

You could also get a door that opens to the outside.

Better access is needed both for an emergency exit and in the event that a ramp needs to be built back here.

Talked to Betty and it sounds like she and her family will work on getting the clutter removed.

Problem: Ramp may be needed in the near future. Client has bad knees. She can get in and out of the home but must climb a flight of stairs.
Solution:
Betty says that she has applied to Independent Living for a ramp, but was turned down. This may have been because the front deck is about 5 feet off the ground, and a ramp would be impractical there. However, a ramp could be built that goes in the back door. The yard would have to be re- landscaped and a concrete pathway built, that gradually slopes up to the back yard, where an approximately 12 foot long ramp could be built to the back door. Build the ramp with a slope of 1" in 12" with handrails on both sides.

Talk to Ind. Living about this, maybe they could help.

Problem: Walk-in shower needed. Client has trouble getting in and out of existing bathtub.
Solution:
This bathroom is small, (5'x7'), but in fairly good shape. The vanity sink and a shelf may have to be moved to make a walk- in shower practical. The existing tub is metal and in decent condition. Floor solid.

skilled plumber needed

This is something it seems Independent Living could help with.

Problem: There is a big hole in the smaller bathroom. It extends under the "floating toilet". Clients have put a piece of plywood over it but part of the hole is visible. the plywood id not well supported and someone could go through if they stepped in the wrong place. I told Cindy to stay out of this bathroom and use the other one.
Solution: Remove commode and install in master bath. Cap toilet drain. Install plywood over the holes to make the floor safe until the bathroom can be remodeled.

Problem: There is a hole in the corner of the bedroom floor. It is partially covered by a piece of furniture. Water is getting into the walls and soaking the floor after a rain.
Solution:
Remove furniture. Cut out all bad subfloor material. Reinforce joists. Add 3/4" or 5/8" plywood.  

This would be a good time to re- floor the whole bedroom. Square footage not measured.

Please note that this problem was caused by a roof leak and will continue to get wet until the roof is repaired.

Problem: The master bathroom, although functional, is in need of some repairs. The shower faucet leaks when running. The bathtub faucet handles are not secured onto the knobs. Clients use pliers to turn the water on and off. Toilet leaks around bottom. One bolt is broken. Flush box is cracked. The floor underneath the shower is soft and the surround leaks.
Solution: Replace shower faucet. Replace bathtub faucets. Replace shower stall. Repair floor under shower stall. Replace commode with new bolts and wax ring.

Problem:
Heating issues. Client claims to have " no heat", but when asked she said that her propane heater did work. There are 2 -100 gal propane tanks out back, maybe they just couldn't afford to fill them last winter.

The main furnace, an electric unit that came with the trailer, is in disrepair. It looks like someone has tried to work on it.

There is also an outside unit, which Cindy says is hooked up to the other furnace.
Solution: Have an HVAC man look at the system .

Problem: Kitchen sink drain leak
Solution: Looks like the basket on one side is leaking. Just replacing the one basket should do it, but if finances permit it would be a good time to replace the entire sink and drain assembly with a new faucet. It kind of stinks under there so the drain probably needs cleaning anyway.

Problem: water is getting into two windows in the bathroom.
Solution: This problem is probably due to the lack of overhang, but it might help to re-caulk around the windows.

Problem:
The roof leaks bad a couple of places, where the trailer roof meets the porch roofs. Water has damaged the walls and rotted the floor. The porch roof is higher than the main roof in this place.

No other leaks were obvious, although a problem was reported with water getting through the windows due to lack of overhang on the gable end of the roof.
Solution: Install new 29ga metal roof on purlins. Metal shall overhang eaves by 8".

Problem: Smoke and CO detector needed
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: New roof needs some follow-up work
Solution: See repair # 972

Problem: Back door does not close.
Front door needs to be re-painted.
Gail requests ceilings and bathroom be painted.
Solution: Paint

Problem: Storm door doesn't close properly, let's in a lot of air.
Solution: Replace storm door.

Problem: Vinyl siding could use washing, especially porch ceiling.
Solution: wash

Problem: hand rail needed on steps out back
Solution: install hand rail using pressure treated lumber

Problem:
Old plumbing circa 1978 (polybutyl)

no leaks at present but sytsem should be eventually re-done with PEX

Albert Autry did temporary fix and guestimated $4-5,000 to replumb entire home
Solution: replace old pipes with PEX

Problem: one of the outlets dosen't work in the living room
Solution:
turn off power and replace outlet

note- thin walls

existing unit has multiple outlets in one box

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: There is a place in Stephanie's bedroom where the flooring covers a heating outlet.
Solution:
this may not be dangerous, but should be checked out by an HVAC person.

A hole will have to be cut in the floor and a heat register installed.

vaccuum dust out after cutting

Problem:
Under Stephanie's house, the ductwork that comes from her furnace has filled up with water in one place. This seems to be a result of water getting on the floor and leaking down into the ductwork.

This happened due to a plumbing leak.
Solution:
This could be as simple as cutting the zip-tie that holds the ductwork onto the furnace outlet, cutting loose a strap that holds the ductwork up, and letting it drain out. Dry the area and the duct with a fan.

Note that there is another heating issue in her house so an HVAC pro may be needed to fix everything and inspect the system.

Problem:
There is a lot of erosion back behind Marie's house. Deep ruts and little plant growth.  

The roadside also has the same problem.
Solution:
The ruts will have to be smoothed out and then grass seed with straw be immediately planted. Hydro seeding may also be an option.  

Marie has talked to some contractors who have experience doing this stuff, see repair details.  

There may be some other ground covers that you could plant besides grass.  

The area around the trailer is graded properely and she has gutters with downspouts hooked up to drainpies, which go underground away from the house.  

Some or all of this work could be done by volunteers.

Problem:
New replacement windows have been requested by homeowners. The old ones are single pane.  

Good energy- efficiency project
Solution:
Windows in kitchen- rough opening is 30 1/4" wide x 53" high.

There are two of these windows, side- by- side.

in the living room, there is a big fixed window, with 2 windows that open on either side. t  

Total measurements are - 101" wide x 54" high (approx.)  

The windows that open are 54" high x 25" wide (Approx)

Problem: In the bathroom, the floor is damaged beneath the tub/ shower unit.
Solution:
Floor feels stable for now, but eventually the unit will need to come out and the floor repaired.

The unit is a one- piece, so it should be reusable.

Access to plumbing in water heater closet.

Problem:
There is an active water leak in the closet of the laundry room. The old galvanized pipes are leaking.

Clients deal with this by shutting off the water at night.

It is hard to tell where the water lines go , some are buried under the house, which, in most places, has very little clearance under it.
Solution:
Turn off water at the valve provided by the town.

Replace most or all of the old galvanized pipes with 3/4" PEX.  

install shut off valves.  

System will have more pressure than usual because clients are on town water  

highly skilled plumbing job

Problem: Bathroom floor is weak. Toilet wobbly. Leak in sink. No faucets in shower stall. Clients bathe with garden hose hooked up to bathroom sink.
Solution:
Remodel bathroom,Need new toilet, sink, shower unit, faucets, etc.  

The bathroom is 40 square feet.

shut off water, Remove toilet, shower stall, sink.  

Rebuild floor . Replace / repair joists, install new 3/4" plywood  

install new toilet, sink, shower, and associated plumbing.  

The shower stall is 59" x 31".

There is a basement below this room where access can be gained to sewer pipes and water pipes. You can stand up in it.  

tests showed lead paint on the windowsill, but nowhere else

Problem:
Hole in kitchen floor. Water heater on ground. Heater still works but leaks ; bottom rusted.  

Hole under kitchen sink. Soft in front of sink. Rotten joists.
Solution:
Shut off water, remove water heater. remove kitchen sink and cabinet, repair joists and subfloor. There are several layers of floor material- tiles, hardwood, etc. Old tiles look like they are from the 1960's , made of unknown material.  

Basically remodel the kitchen from the ground up.  

Install new water heater. The old one is 22" wide and 30" high

This part of the house is built very close to the ground.

tests showed lead paint present

Problem:
There are some weak places on the roof. Old leaks have been well patched with tar, but caused some damage to the sheathing.  

Roof is leaking and needs replacement.  

There are some gable vents. 2 roof vents have been tarred over
Solution:
Tear off old shingles and repair sheathing damage. Install new drip edge, flashing, 30 year class A shingles and flash around chimneys ( 2 of the chimneys can be removed per Sage).

Roof is approx. 6/12 pitch

1350 square feet

Problem: Underpinning work was done here in summer, but was not completed.
Solution: install 200 sft of vinyl underpinning

Problem:
There is a weak place in the hallway floor. Tara says you can see daylight through it.

There is also a hole in Josh and Tara's bedroom. It has been temporarily covered with plywood
Solution: Get some 5/8 or 3/4 plywood , reinforce joists, and replace plywood.

Problem: Broken refrigerator
Spring no longer reliable. Family no longer able to upkeep due to age and disabilities. Family has had to go without running water for long periods of time.
Solution: install a well

Problem: Heat/ AC Unit is not working properly. There is a leak visible in the basement. Stopped working 7/24/17.
Solution: Hire heating contractor to inspect and repair. The family mentioned Blue Ridge Heating , who installed the heater in winter of 2016, but also said that they have gone out of business.

Problem:
On June 16, 2017, the back wall of the basement collapsed. This is a cement block wall. There was no concrete or rebar in the wall. Although the owners claim to have installed a French drain, this had to be caused by water damage (there is a big hill behind their house). I did not notice a stream of water anywhere, but the weather was dry.  

The family hired Precision Restoration Services (828-348-1371) to shore up the floor. They used pole-jacks on cement cap blocks and 6x6 posts. The floor looks to be well supported now but the outside, load bearing wall does not have much under it. An exterior door will not open due to the sag in the wall.  

When the wall fell the drain line to the septic broke. This has been repaired by the homeowner so the septic system works.

According to Tom, the drain lines run out the back side, where the wall fell, and around to the front yard where the septic tank is. He says there is room to dig behind there to install a French drain.

Clients' insurance will not cover this repair.
Solution: Dig dirt from around back side of house. Install a French drain designed to handle heavy volumes of water. Rebuild back wall using big blocks, concrete, and rebar. The outside, load bearing wall will need to be jacked up level.

Problem: Front porch (concrete) appears to sag in the middle.
Solution: Remove tiles and level up with concrete and cement.

Problem: white mold on joists in basement
Solution:
This looks like it has been a problem for a while. Joists seem pretty solid.

Once the basement foundation is fixed then install a dehumidifier.

Problem: Gutters needed on back side
Solution: Clients have purchased gutter material (vinyl), will need help hanging it when the time comes. This will help the drainage issue

Problem: HVAC unit leaking water
Solution: Have an HVAC guy look at it. Probably a clogged drain line.

Problem: Leaking plumbing in kitchen
Solution: Fixed plumbing issues in kitchen

Problem: Unstable front steps to front deck
Solution: Fixed steps to front deck

Problem: Leaking toilet and fixtures
Solution: Replaced toilet and leaking fixtures

Problem: Soft living room floor with hole in the middle, rotten bathroom floor
Solution: Replaced living room and bathroom floor

Problem: Underpinning is needed. Crawlspace on the north side of the home is exposed.

A septic drain leak was found by Holy Trinity as they were working on siding. The leak was plugged but further work is needed on the drain system. Shower is not plumbed to the septic, water drains onto ground.
Solution:
Plumb shower drain, tie it into the septic. there is an existing "Y" that is plugged but not glued. There are some odd angles so you will have to get 45's, 22's, or flexible couplings. There is a stack of 1/2" osb on site that can be used to protect workers from the ground. You may have to rip down some osb to fit in the crawlspace access.

Also, the 3" drainpipe from the junction where the shower drain would come in to the place where it goes down into the septic tank is actually sloping uphill. Cut out a small section and add a coupling so that the pipe slopes down. Use a level to determine slope.

Kenneth's son, Jason, has [plumbing experience and has offered to help do this repair.

Wear Haz- mat suit and rubber gloves. .

Problem:
In one corner of Dorista's bedroom, there is a weak corner. it is covered by a chest.

The corner does not see a lot of traffic but should be fixed soon.
Solution:
The floor joists here are wet and have white mold.

Since this is Dorista's bedroom it might be best to try and do this job from the outside or underneath, to minimize dust.

An attempt could be made to reinforce the floor by removing some siding and underpinning on the outside . If you were to do some digging you may be able to access the floor joists and do some scabbing, etc.

If it is found that the joists are too weak then some flooring would have to be removed from the top. Use dust protection.

A previous group tried to jack up the corner of the building and could not get the jack out.  

Be on the lookout for termite damage and rot, this corner is close to the ground.

Problem: There is a hole in the hallway between Kanda's bedroom and the storage room.
Solution: Remove old floor material and plywood (this section is a trailer). Patch the hole with 5/8 or thicker plywood. add 2x4 material to reinforce floor. Add linoleum or other floor cover.

Problem: Though roof has been replaced, volunteer Carl is of the belief that some of the water damage to the walls may be coming from rain water on top of windows.
Solution: Caulk above windows.

Problem: There is a soft spot in the kitchen floor. (Reported by St. George's Fredericksburg, VA/ St. Francis Greensboro, NC).
Solution: Remove a section of subfloor. Reinforce joists and install new plywood . It will be 5/8" or 3/4".

Problem: Slow flushing, frequent clogging.
Solution: Nina believes her septic tank needs to be pumped. I asked if she treated it monthly and she does not. A properly cared for septic shouldn't need to be pumped. Contact local septic service company. We have used Able Septic in the past (828-254-1920), if no digging is required, they charge $235.

Problem:
Kitchen sink plumbing has some leaks. Right now there is a water hose hooked up to it

Roger has no sink cabinet, the sink is attached to the wall

Sink is grimy

there is a big hole in the drywall behind the sink.
Solution:
Subfloor must be well repaired before this job happens.

Unhook plumbing and remove sink.

patch drywall, clean wall

Note- wall under drywall is block with 1x4's attached.

fix leaks/re- plumb/ repair / replace water lines

re- do sink drain with no leaks

Clean and re- install old sink or replace with a new one with a cabinet

Problem: The kitchen walls are moldy and stained black. The kitchen sink is grimy. The wall behind the sink is stained, too.
Solution: Clean walls, sink

Problem:
Roof leaks. The only place where leaks are visible inside is in one bedroom closet.  

The shingles are 21 years old.  

There are some missing shingles on the back side.  

skylight flange is cracked.  

there is no ridge vent
Solution:
This could be patched but due to the age of the shingles a roof replacement is probably in order.  

Replace shingles.  

install ridge vent  

roof is approx. 1200 square feet

Problem: The attic fans are not working. This may cause excess moisture in the roof.
Solution:
Repair or replace attic fans.

Owner will call Discount Mobile Homes about the fans.

Problem: Bathroom fan makes a funny noise.Owners suspect wasp nest.
Solution: get a step ladder and take off the trim . inspect . repair or replace.

Problem: vinyl siding dirty
Solution: pressure wash /wash by hand

Problem: Deck needs washing
Solution: pressure wash

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Front door will not open and shut properly.
Solution: Betty claims that at one time, there was a lot of water flowing underneath the trailer (erosion. ) As a result the trailer settled, and is not quite level as a result. An inspection beneath revealed the trailer to be stable, but you could see a ditch where the erosion happened. The settling may have affected the way the doors close and open. Before anyone goes to jack up the trailer, an attempt should be made to reinstall this and the back door to see if you could modify the rough opening and just make the doors work.

Problem: Back door is hard to open and close. Same problem as front door
Solution: Remove door, work on opening, and reinstall.

Problem: Grab bar needed in bathroom.
Solution: Talk to Betty about what kind she wants and where.

Problem: Bathtub cracked
Solution:
Replace tub. The existing tub is a center-drain, mobile home style tub and may be hard to find a replacement. (try Discount Mobile Home supply.)  

A different unit could be installed but that would require changing the drain, plumbing, etc.

New plumbing fixtures recommended  

note- the home has another bathroom

Problem:
Front deck needs some work.

rails damaged  

steps need to be reinforced
Solution: Replace 3 boards.

Problem:
Back deck/ramp needs some work.  

top rails of ramp damaged
Solution: install new rails

Problem: Door work needed. Bedroom closet door needs new knob.
Solution: install doorknob on bedroom closet door.

Problem: bad switch in laundry room, does not always switch off
Solution: shut off power and repair/ replace switch

Problem: Toilet leaks when water is turned on to it. . Right now the water is shut off, so it is not currently leaking. The problem is in the supply line/tank connection.
Solution:
Shut off water. Install new shut-off valve, supply line, and tank connection.  

note- home has another bathroom

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install one

Problem: T- 111 plywood siding is water damaged.
Solution:
Set Circular saw depth to the thickness of the plywood siding. Cut off 2 or 3 feet of siding and replace with new. Call Clifford or go out there to make sure you get the right thickness and reveal on the sheets of t111.

Caulk the places where the sheets meet. Paint.

Problem: window sill damaged
Solution:
Remove window trim, sill, window. Make new sills and trim and reinstall window. caulk and paint.

the window is 25 1/4" wide x 39 1/4"tall

Problem: leak around chimney.
Solution: tar around chimney.

Problem: paint is peeling on Clifford's house.
Solution:
After replacing some T111 plywood out back, repaint the whole house. Consult with Clifford about color. install drop cloths, etc and do a neat job.

Make sure to use low- VOC paints because Clifford is chemically sensitive, from years of working on furniture.

Problem: Some deck boards need replacement
Solution: replace 10 or so deck boards

Problem: screen doors requested. old ones have torn screens
Solution: replace screen doors. one is 78" x 34 3/4", one is 81" x 32".

Problem: In Clifford's back yard, an old barn was burnt down. He needs help cleaning up the site.
Solution: remove trash, remove nails and metal, clean up area.

Problem: Laminate flooring needed in living room
Solution: install about 400 square feet of laminate flooring. Note- there is a hump in the floor which may require some kind of threshold

Problem: Mr. Wallin's refrigerator was broken.
There is a leak in the kitchen ceiling. (Reported by Blaine from GR staff after being at the home with a group from St. Paul's Edenton.)
The wall in the right corner of Mr. Wallin's bedroom is leaking. (Reported by Blaine from Glory Ridge staff after clean up with St. Paul's Edenton.)
Back porch has rot and a hole.
Solution: see repair 794- same job

Problem: front deck has a hole
Solution: Remove damaged deck board replace one or two deck boards

Problem: Floor damaged around back door. This resulted from a leak in the exterior light fixture, which got in the wall.
Solution: Todd has stopped the leak but the floor still needs to be repaired, remove damaged subfloor material and put back new plywood.

Problem: Exterior door busted. It still functions; hole covered by duck tape
Solution: Replace door. Mobile home size- slab is 75 "x 32 3/4". As you stand on the outside deck, the door opens to outside, knob on left.

Problem: Window in bedroom is missing a pane on the inside. Still works but single- pane.
Solution: Replace window. Opening is 36 x 53 3/4".

Problem: Underpinning needs work. It has holes in it. . Wild cats are getting underneath trailer.
Solution: replace about 1/2 of the underpinning. Use old roof metal.

Problem: Todd's lawn mowers are broken at assessment time.
Solution: Rent mowers and mow. Call General Equipment Rental in Weaverville

Problem: Roof shows signs of leaking. A couple of seams on the sheet metal of the roof seem to be splitting. Floor damaged caused by leak.
Solution: Apply roof caulk to split seams. Check penetrations for damage. Caulk and apply roof cement.

Problem:
New flooring requested in living room, hallway. 150 square feet.

floor is now bare plywood.

laminate recommended.
Solution: Install flooring. Get the homeowners to help you.

Problem: Paint requested in living room- ceiling, walls
Solution: put down drop cloths and paint ceiling. Consult homeowners for color

Problem: There is an old building on site that needs to be torn down
Solution:
De-construct building, removing the nails and screws. Salvage 4x4 posts, 2x4's , and roof materials.

Take unusable material to landfill.

pick up all nails and screws and dispose of

stack up reusable materials neatly

Problem: co detector needed
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Steps are under-framed, treads need replacement
Solution:
add an additional stringer and new treads, or replace steps entirely  

hand rails are in good shape

make a concrete pad at the bottom

Problem: Kitchen sink leaks.
Solution: Replace drain and traps under sink. The baskets don't seem to be leaking.

Problem:
Electrical problems. There is no power to lights or outlets in 2 rooms and a hallway. Breakers are not tripped.  

Yvonne says that some went out 6 months ago and some went out 2 weeks ago, after she plugged in a vacuum cleaner.
Solution: Get an electrician to diagnose and repair.,

Problem: Wood stove does not have a proper chimney. It is currently single wall black stove pipe through the roof with not enough clearance to combustible materials.
Solution:
Install class A pipe with proper clearances.  

Install ceiling box, roof boot, storm collar, and top.

Problem:
There is a leak in the porch roof, towards the outside.  

Porch roof is shingled. Slope is very low. (1/12 pitch)  

This is the only roof leak reported.  

Trailer roof has been kool-sealed on a regular basis  

Porch roof is 8' w x 28' long.
Solution:
The porch roof leaks mainly because it it too flat and the shingles do not work on such a low slope. The seam between the trailer roof and the shingle roof has been well tarred and doesn't leak. "Stove room" leaks where roofs meet, see other repair.  

Apply roofing cement to area that leaks.

Problem: Client requests a handicap ramp
Solution:
Remove steps and build a ramp with handrails. This would be on the driveway side, leading into her " stove room". The wood stove would have to be removed for adequate handicap access. . The washer and dryer may also need to be moved around. The ramp would need to be 35 feet long to meet code since it is 35" from the ground to the door threshold. There is plenty of room to build the ramp, it would go out into the driveway, which is fairly level. A slight bend may be required in the ramp, but it could mostly go straight out. build a concrete pad at the base of the ramp.

Yvonne has a meeting scheduled with Lori Massey at Independent Living for Tues, Jun. 27. to discuss the ramp.

Problem: Co detector needed
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Big, double paned picture window has fogged glass and a hole in one pane. Sill is rotten.
Solution: Replace window. It is a fixed window, 64" wide and 59" high. Install new window trim and new sill.

Problem: No handrails on front porch steps
Solution: Build handrails. Note- concrete steps and part of porch

Problem: Handrails wobbly out back
Solution:
Reinforce by installing 4x4 posts set in concrete.

install new top rails on back deck.

Problem:
Porch roof has a bad leak. Viewed from above, there is a place that is noticeably sunken in. The leak has caused damage to the porch roof sheathing and probably the framing as well. The leak has rotted parts of the porch floor, and framing may be damaged underneath as well.

Marie did not report any other leaks in the roof besides the porch.

Shingles here look fairly new, but they may be as old as 15 yrs.

There is another place on the roof, higher up on the same side as the porch, where there is a high spot. Sheathing could be pulling up beneath the shingles.

There are 2 layers of shingles.

The porch has a section that is poured concrete. This section is between the steps and door, so right now Marie can get in and out easily, and there is another exit out back.
Solution:
The first thing to do is repair the porch floor. There is a rock ledge that holds up the framing next to the house. A complete tear down/ rebuild may be necessary. The porch roof will need temporary supports while you do this.

Once the porch floor is solid, remove ceiling material. Repair framing from below so that the roof can be safe enough to stand on. Once the roof framing is solid, roof repair can commence. Since the sheathing needs repair, you will have to remove the 2 layers of shingles. You will probably have to remove at least half of the shingles on one side of the house. It may be more efficient to tear off everything on this side.

Repair sheathing. Install tar paper, shingles.

Put a tarp down below to catch old shingles and nails during tear-off.

Dumpster rental reccommended

Problem: Back door has a shattered glass panel. There is still one pane intact, the stained- glass looking one.
Solution:
This door could be repaired. Remove old glass fragments. Install a piece of plexiglass that is 21 3/8" x 35 3/8".(you may have to go to a glass company in Asheville to get this). Use clear caulk to stick it to the window frame. install glazer points to hold the plexiglass in, which can be removed after the caulk dries.

The other option is to replace the door entirely. The slab measures 31 3/4"wide x 79" high. Knob on right, opens in.

Problem: Anew hot water heater was recently installed (in the kitchen). It is slightly bigger than the old one. As a result the cabinet does not fit around it.
Solution: modify the cabinet to make it fit the water heater.

Problem: There is some drywall missing around the (newer) electrical box
Solution:
Install and finish drywall around box (it's in the kitchen).

you may have to add some pieces of wood to screw the drywall to

watch for wires

Problem: not enough airflow in bathroom
Solution:
cut power

remove old light

install fan/ light combo

use existing switch

Problem: There are some dark stains on the bathroom ceiling. Since this is the only room in this house with theses stains, it is probably due to excess moisture.
Solution:
This should probably be done after the fan/light is installed.

Clean ceiling tiles- Marie says 409 works best.

paint ceiling with Kilz paint

Problem: No CO or Smoke detector in home
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem:
No flooring in living room  

Sandra called 6/7/17 to let us know she had to rip up all of her carpet due to flea infestation. She has been walking on subfloor for "a while" and it is irritating her feet.
Solution: Install vinyl or similar flooring. Sandra does not want carpet.

Problem: Makeshift underpinning, install approx 30 years ago, is just plywood. His father had planned to stucco it but never did. It is rotten.
Solution: Gerald requests removal and reinstallation of proper underpinning.

Problem: Hole in kitchen wall
Solution: Repair hole, unsure of extent of damage or exact solution, this was not on original assessment, Viola called to tell us about this hole that appeared after roof installation.

Problem:
Dark hallway paneling  

Robbie's bedroom hasn't been painted in many years
Solution: Paint hallway and bedroom with light colored (white) paint. Consult with Robbie on color.

Problem:
Kitchen floor needs work. The old tiles (unknown material) are missing in some places. Floor has some weak places, especially near the refrigerator. New flooring and subfloor repair is needed.

Temporary patches could be installed in the worst places.
Solution:
Remove furniture and refrigerator.

Remove floor tiles. Note- these could be asbestos, the dust from which can be hazardous. If removing, use proper safety precautions.

There is a layer of particle board under the tiles.

Not all of the flooring needs to be taken up; only a 12' x 16' space needs new flooring.

I recomend installing a layer of 1/2" plywood under the floor material to level it up with the existing floor.

Problem: Back steps are rotten
Solution:
Tear off steps and rebuild. Hand rails needed. Build a concrete pad at the bottom ,or use blocks.

Stringers are 10' long.

Problem: Electrical problems. No lights in bathroom. No overhead lights in bedroom. Some outlets do not work. Stopped working 3 months ago. Wiring is trailer wiring from 1965. Sons have changed fuses in the fuse box but that has not solved the problem.
Solution: Send an electrician to check it out. There may be some bad outlets or wiring. Upgrade recomended.

Problem: A tree limb has fallen on the corner of the house where the porch is. It has damaged the fascia and soffit and the roof leaks as a result.
Solution: Remove tree limb.

Problem: Yard is extremely overgrown with multi-flora rose and various weeds. A deck and exterior steps are blocked .
Solution: Cut multiflora with machetes or heavy duty weed eater. Clean up yard. Clean deck and provide an exit out that way.

Problem: Gutters not cleaned in a long time. Grass growing. Moss growing on roof.
Solution: Clean out gutters. Roof can be accessed without a ladder if back steps are repaired first. Clean off moss.

Problem:
The soffit and fascia are rotten in several places.

This is due to gutters not being cleaned and a tree limb that fell on the roof.
Solution: Repair soffit and fascia. Materials needed will vary depending on the location.

Problem: There is a leak around the wood stove chimney.
Solution:
Gladys wants to remove this chimney. It is re- usable.

There are 2 wood stove chimneys. One she wants to keep.

As an alternative you could apply caulk or roof cement around the chimney boot .

If you remove the chimney then patch hole with plywood, shingles, roof cement

Problem: Billy Joe's springhouse has fallen into disrepair. He has a good reservior.
Solution:
Repair springhouse. A new roof and door are needed. There is some damage to the roof framing. The place will need to be cleaned out- low skill. Weed eating and clearing should be done around there .

You may need battery- powered tools because it is a ways to the springhouse.

Problem: Dryer vent is not hooked up properly. There is a hole in the floor for a vent, but I could not find an outlet.
Solution: install a dryer vent kit

Problem: Roof leaks visible in bedroom
Solution:
Parts of the roof have new metal. Tony claims that patching has been attempted and has not worked on the older part of the roof.

It might be worth replacing the old roof nails with screws, caulking around the penetrations, and replacing the ridge caps with wider material. Then if it still leaks, replace metal.  

Roof metal here is reportedly 28 yrs. old. If new metal is put on , you will need 1470 square feet of metal

Problem:
Tony has a hard time getting in and out of his bathtub because of his knee and back issues.  

There is also a slow toilet leak around the bottom.
Solution: Walk-in shower requested. Install new wax ring for commode.

Problem: no smoke or Co detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: No handrails on part of deck around back (42" high)
Solution: build rails

Problem: There are several small trees growing close to the back side of the house. Tree limbs overhanging and touching the roof . Lots of leaves on roof.
Solution: Prune limbs and / or cut trees down. Caution- roof is a 3/12 or 4/12 pitch,and the leaves are slick.

Problem: A log on the back side of Che's house is pretty rotten.
Solution:
Saw out log with a sawsall or chainsaw and replace with a log or other material (cinder blocks?)

note- before removing rotten log, check the inside of the house for wires or other stuff that could be damaged by removal  

this log is close to the ground.

Problem: Porch rails rotten. Deck boards rotten.
Solution: Remove busted deck boards. They are 7/8" thick., so roughsawn oak lumber from Ramsey's will match up here. Install new deck boards.Not all need to be replaced, just the ones that have been getting wet. Install new rails. Use the rails that have been recently repaired as a guide for the new ones.

Problem: There is a rotten bridge timber.
Solution: Remove rotten timber. Install a 4x6x12' treated bridge timber in its place. Drill pilot holes and nail down.

Problem: Bedroom floor has a weak spot.
Solution:
Vols. put a board over this spot, but it is bouncy. Apparently Devin likes to jump up and down here.

Take up some flooring. There may be a loose joist. Reinforce framing and put new flooring back flush with the old floor material

Problem: water heater does not work right
Solution: This could just be an element, the water is lukewarm. A new water heater may be a good idea because this one is at least 15 years old.

Problem: propane heater is not working, Che requests a new, smaller unit. Propane tank and hookups in place
Solution: new heater

Problem: covered GFI outlet does not work on porch.
Solution: Check breaker box. Could be that it's just tripped. Otherwise have electrician check it

Problem: Yard work needed
Solution:
weed eat (she does not have one).

clean up yard

bust wood

Problem: steps on back porch in bad shape. This is the covered porch with the oil tank. The framing that supports the steps (2x12porch band) is also rotten.
Solution: Tear off steps. Replace rotten framing(2x12 pressure treated). Replace steps.Make a concrete landing pad or put the stringers on concrete blocks. Deck height is 32". Build rails onto the steps and all the way around the porch.

Problem: Steps around the side have no hand rails. The entrance has suffered water damage because the back entrance is not protected from the weather and there are no gutters back there. Floor damage inside. Door in rough shape.
Solution:
Install new exterior door. Door is 78 1/2" x 31 7/8". Door opens in, hinge on left. Some floor repair may be needed inside. Shore up steps and build a hand rail (elderly resident). Entrance is 27" off ground.

Ideally, a small roof should be built to keep the entry and steps dry.

Gutters and drainage would also help with this problem.

Problem: roof leaks. Shingles are 35+ yrs. old according to Sidney
Solution:
Sidney wants to install a new metal roof over the top of the old shingle roof. Part of the problem is that part of the roof has a shallow pitch, so a metal roof is a good idea here. There are a couple of valleys on the roof, so some cuts will be required, but Sidney is confident.  

roof is approximately1600 square feet  

Before planning this project, go up in the attic and inspect the framing. If needed, add collar ties and reinforce to carry the extra weight.

Problem: Wood stove chimney has cracked blocks on the outside. There is an inner ceramic flue in place.Chimney needs cleaning.
Solution:
Sidney suggested Sure-walling the outside of the chimney.  

Tar around chimney after the cement dries.  

Clean chimney

Problem: Monitor heater not working right. Homemade oil tank and hookups in place.
Solution: have heating man service monitor

Problem: Water heater is not working properly . water not hot enough.
Solution: This is a large, 2 element model made in 1992. It is in decent shape for one so old, so you may be able to just replace the elements. If finances permit, I have priced a new one. Check to be sure heater is adequately wired.

Problem: Client has requested a walk- in shower because of mobility issues
Solution: Remove existing tub/shower unit, surround, faucets, etc. Install a walk in shower. Bathroom is in good shape except for the water heater.

Problem: Client has mobility issues and may need a ramp soon
Solution: Build a ramp off her front porch. Porch is concrete.The porch is around 20" high. There is a small step up from the porch into her door opening. Follow building code. Ramp should be 48" wide and drop only 1 inch per foot. Build rails. Make a solid concrete landing at the bottom.

Problem:
The sliding glass door that opens to the back deck will not operate properly. It goes off the track.

This is the only other exit other than the front door.
Solution: This may be able to be repaired by cleaning the tracks and adjusting the rollers. If not you may have to replace some parts or replace the door. Tobie really likes the existing door because of the view.

Problem:
The breaker that serves the dryer trips often, and has gotten hot according to Tobie.

Client does not use dryer anymore.

The wiring in this section of the home is circa 1974, trailer-style.
Solution: Have an electrician diagnose the problem and fix and/or upgrade

Problem: Bathroom floor weak due to water damage caused by leaks in shower faucet and bathroom sink.
Solution: Remodeling needed. The floor seems ok under the commode, but is more than likely damaged under the tub. The bathroom sink cabinet should be probably be removed to get rid of mold and to see if the floor is bad under it, it has been leaking a while. Tear up floor, replace bad plywood, reinforce joists. A new tub surround, possibly a new tub, new vanity cabinet will be needed at the very least. Consider a walk in shower because of Tobie's knee problems. Install new tub faucet. The shower faucet is fairly new. install new sink drain. The tub is a trailer style- 28" x 54". The bathroom is 7' x 8'.

Problem: Porch rails wobbly, missing pickets
Solution:
Carfully remove existing pickets. Pull nails so you can re-use the pickets.

Remove 1x4's.

Build back sturdier rails. Install 2x4's instead of 1x4 to hold pickets.

You will need a couple new pickets. Not sure if they sell these or you have to make them.

Problem: Tobie's bedroom floor is in rough shape. The carpet has been removed and her dogs have damaged the subfloor (press-board). There are some weak spots.
Solution:
Tobie wants tile here. Vinyl tile is what she has in some other rooms in the house. Ceramic tile would last longer. Plus there would be no fumes from the glue.

A layer of 1/2" plywood will need to go on top of the subfloor to strengthen it. Then add cement board, mortar, and ceramic tile. Grout and clean floor.

Note- This job requires removing the baseboard and door trim, or cutting the door trim with a special saw. When the tile job is done put back the baseboard and trim or get new if you bust it during demo.

Tobie's son, Patrick, and his girlfriend may be able to provide leadership on this project if given notice.

The room is 13' x 12'.

Problem: There is a heat register in the bedroom that is not fastened down, is rusty and a tripping hazard. The register is no longer used.
Solution: Remove a 32"x32" section of carpet around the register. Remove register. Put some 2x4 scabs in the hole to support a piece of plywood to fill in the hole. Screw down a piece of plywood. Install new floor material and threshold strips to cover the transitions.

Problem:
Bathroom sink drain leak. The water lines here were recently repaired, but there is still a drain leak.

Mold inside bathroom sink cabinet
Solution:
Tightening up the drain components did not seem to work. You may have to replace some drain parts.

The plumber who repaired the water lines under here, Britton Pack, has been contacted and informed of the drain leak by Tobie.

She will try to get him to come out and fix it soon.

Note- this bathroom is going to need a complete remodel which may include removal of the bathroom sink and cabinet to get rid if the mold.

Problem: Closet Bi- fold door missing
Solution: buy a bi- fold door to match the one that is already there and install

Problem: Client has no dryer
Solution: Rig up clothesline in backyard. . Buy materials from Mars Hill Hardware

Problem: Nina has called about a bubbling in the yard, and some standing water. She believes a septic pipe may have cracked when someone drove into the yard.
Solution: Investigate issue and take steps to repair/replace pipe or any parts as needed.

Problem:
Floor in Wanda Sue's bedroom is weak and uneven. She has stumbled here a time or two.  

  

  

My theory is that the damage here happened due to a drainage problem which allowed water to get in the back side of the house. I suspect there may be termite damage.

There is no crawlspace access to the underside of the bedroom.
Solution:
Remove furniture. Remove carpet. Remove some or all subfloor. Watch for plumbing lines and wires. Repair or replace joists. Repair subfloor. Install new flooring (hi- quality laminate).

Room is 120 square feet

Fix drainage problem; see other repair

Problem: Back porch has some rotten floorboards and a rotten outside sill.
Solution:
This porch is 14' x 7'. A rebuild is probably necessary. You will have to brace up the porch roof, which is sound and can stay, while you demo the porch. This will be a high skill job, but Tim can help.

remove porch flooring and rails.

Install a temporary beam under the roof structure. It will have to be at least 20' long.

demo frame.

rebuild porch. pressure treated will last longer.

Note- there is some 1950's siding that looks like asbestos that covers the porch rails. You will have to remove this stuff so follow safety precautions.

Tim has some plans to pour a slab underneath, install drainpipes, and re-grade around here, and he talked about building block walls under the porch (he has blocks) .

Consult with him about the plan before purchasing materials.

steps not included

Problem: Tim's chimney is in rough shape. The top three 16" masonry blocks are cracked. There is no inner ceramic flue. Tim's home insurance will not cover this repair.
Solution: New chimney or liner. Get a quote from Sun Heating or Black Mtn Stove.

Problem: Some yard work is needed.
Solution:
Weed eat yard. Weed eater needed.

Split firewood.

Problem: Back door knob needed.
Solution: install locking exterior knob

Problem: old washer and dryer on property. Other junk in storage shed.
Solution: Haul to landfill. Consult with Jennifer.

Problem: Limbs overhanging roof need to be pruned
Solution: set up an extension ladder and prune limbs.

Problem: Water damage in bathroom extends under the wall and into the pantry/dining area. One corner is noticeably sunken.
Solution: remove old floor covering. remove damaged plywood. reinforce joists. install new plywood. install new flooring if finances permit.

Problem: weak floor in hallway around back door.
Solution: Take up floor and repair with 2x4's and plywood. you may want to install new flooring if time and $ permits

Problem: Drier vent improperly run. it goes under the bathroom.
Solution: This job can go along with the bath remodel. There is an existing dryer vent outlet, next to the water htr. closet on the outside

Problem: No water pressure. Water dirty and foul smelling
Solution: Determined water system has softner system in place that needs to be flushed and serviced. Have to have certified technician to do the work. Can only find one certified contractor in the area, Ferguson Well.

Problem: Kitchen faucet does not work, leaks water. Bath faucet does not work at all. Water pressure issues, maybe caused by pressure tank failure or lack of water filter. Home is on a spring.
Solution: Replace faucets

Problem: Old shed falling down. It is the red one.
Solution: remove old tobacco sticks from shed and store in barn, Nathan will show you where. Tear down shed and take debris to landfill.

Problem: Meredith needs new gutters on the front side of her house. Old ones leak bad.
Solution:
Remove old gutters and dispose of

install new gutters and downspouts. 40' of gutter needed.

Seamless gutters installed by a pro are always the best, but if installed properly the 10' section can work well.

Make sure to pitch the gutters correctly. The current system has 2 downspouts, so the low point will be in the middle.

Problem: Meredith's septic line was recently dug up and replaced. More work is needed, but her family is helping her with this and it should be complete soon , but some associated yard work may be needed.
Solution: rake, plant grass seed, etc.

Problem: clean-up needed around shed
Solution: weed eat, prune. etc.

Problem: The roof is leaking between the main house and the enclosed porch.
Solution:
Remove old flashing. You will have to remove some shingles. Install new flashing with sheet metal screws and roof caulk. Use good metal flashing, not the cheap aluminum stuff. Add new shingles. The new flashing should be wider than the old.

Meredith's neighbor George works for CHC and has lots of roofing experience. Her other next door neighbor does too. Take advantage of these resources.

Problem:
Meredith's reservior for her gravity- fed spring water system needs work. She would like to have it cleaned. Overflow clogged.

The area around there is overgrown.
Solution:
It is about 1/4 mile hike up the holler to get to the reservoir.

Weed eat and clean up area around reservoir. Throw away old roofing metal near there.

The reservoir must be drained first. Talk to Meredith about how to do this. She is familiar with the system.

Remove reservoir top and clean reservoir. Meredith wants to use bleach to clean the inside. If bleach is used to purify water, use only 1 teaspoon per 10 gallons. If bleach is added to the reservoir, you will have to figure out how many gallons the tank holds by measuring.

The overflow pipe is clogged up somehow. Work with Meredith to fix this.

Problem: no CO Detector
Solution: install

Problem: Driveway/access issues.There is no gravel at the top section and it is deeply rutted out. He can't get his van up to his house and emergency vehicles would not have access to the house.
Solution: Grade road and add gravel and road- bond. Call Danny Collins (gravel Dump Truck). You may have to spread some gravel by hand.

Problem: The old front door is coming apart. 32" x 72"
Solution:
Install new door ,trailer size. Call Discount Mobile Home Supplies.

Note- A new door was installed recently from the porch to the living room. If the deck is improved and safe access for Jerry is established, you could just take the door out and wall over it, if this is ok with the homeowners.

Problem: The smaller bathroom that is closest to the driveway, adjacent to the bedroom,has a walk-in shower that works but is currently being used as a closet. The commode is working in this bathroom. The vanity is not plumbed.
Solution: Get the shower working and plumb the vanity.

Problem: Back steps need work
Solution: Tear off old steps and build a new set. This time make 3 steps that are less high instead of 2. Build rails. Deck height is 26".

Problem: Ramp and steps get slick in wet weather. She does not use the ramp at this time.
Solution: install asphalt tread tape or asphalt shingles. Glue them on with construction adhesive or Nail them to the steps.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Roof leak. Walls are getting wet. Kitchen wall has a hole. Not many stains in ceiling, but roof metal is rusty. Kool seal attempted.
Solution: Membrane or metal roof. preferably with some kind of overhang. The roof has one furnace stack (operational), and two 1 1/2" plumbing vents.

Problem: Bathroom work needed. Faucet drips. Showerhead leaks only when running.
Solution: Install new vanity faucet. Install 2 toilet seats. Try taking apart the shower head and re-taping it, or replace shower head.

Problem: Loose outlet in bath wall
Solution: replace outlet, box

Problem: Floor is getting soft in a few places near the walls
Solution: This is not too dangerous at this time but will need attention as soon as the leaks can be stopped.

Problem: drafty back door
Solution: install weather stripping

Problem: Kitchen floor needs new flooring. The old vinyl tile has peeled up
Solution: Approx.. 120 square feet. Install vinyl laminate flooring suitable for wet locations.

Problem: Kitchen faucet leaks
Solution: Replace faucet

Problem:
Bernice wants to move into a trailer that they own just down the hill from their current residence. The home has been unoccupied for at least 6 months. Here are the major problems:  

  * No power.   

  * There is a septic system according to Bernice, but the kitchen and laundry are not hooked up to it. Drain lines would have to be plumbed to septic.   

  * No water. There is a reservior that could supply gravity water, but I could not see where the water line came into the house.   

  * The plumbing under the house appears to be in very bad condition. It is uninsulated pvc . You would probably need to re-plumb the whole house.   

  * No underpinning   

  * Driveway needs lots of work. At least 8 tons of rock and 8 tons of road bond. The drive is about 120' long.   

  * There is a decent walk in shower unit, but the floor under it seems to have suffered lots of water damage and is weak.   

  * The trailer has a noticeable lean to it. Bernice wants it jacked up.   

  * The back door has no steps, it is 32" off the ground.   

  * The front deck has no steps. There is one safe entry- around the side there is a ramp  

  * Some siding is missing in some places, exposed 2x4 framing  

  * framing damage under back door  

  * Back door damaged  

  * There was some evidence that the roof had leaked. Part of the trailer has been roofed over with metal, the other part is still the old trailer roof.
Chimney is cracked and should be replaced. This is the one in the living room that is for the main wood heater.
Solution:
Tear out old chimney. Replace with a new stainless steel unit.

This should be done along with the roof job.

Problem: A handrail is very loose. The ramp is too steep.
Solution:
Build a new ramp with better handrails. Make it 16' long.

Make the ramp terminate on a 4'x3' concrete pad.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Francis (Greensboro);
St George's Episcopal Church

Problem: Hole in floor next to back steps
Solution: patch hole with plywood.

Problem: Wall damage resulting from chimney roof leak.
Solution:
Tear out wall material and repair framing if needed . Replace wall covering material on inside and outside. Outside material is 1/2" x 12" press board material. Replace with hardi board. Inside material is 1/4" wood paneling.  

This should be done after the roof is repaired and along with the chimney replacement.

Problem: Bridge is in bad shape. .Unsafe to drive across.
Solution: There is a plan to repair this bridge. One of Margaret's sons is supplying the materials. Contact Margaret after May 1 to see what work has been done

Problem: Trailer siding dirty
Solution: Paula requests pressure washing crew

Problem: no CO Detector
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: Bathroom needs to be remodeled. Sink drain not plumbed right and leaks. Sink pulling loose from wall. Tile cracked. Toilet does not flush right. Bathroom needs cleanup before work starts.
Solution: Clean trash out of bathroom. Scrape gunk off floor and clean floor. Remove bathroom sink. Replace the sink with a sink/cabinet unit. Floor under tub seems stable but the tub will need a new surround, valves, and faucets. Toilet should be replaced. Hot water heater seems ok. Shower/tub surround needs replacement. Some structural repairs to the floor may be needed so this is a very rough estimate.

Problem: No rear exit. There is a door (servicable) but there are no steps. The door is about 40" off the ground. This area is pretty choked up with weeds, briars, etc. There is an old matress in the path going around there.
Solution:
As of July 3, Roger and his neighbor, Lawson (206-1223), were starting to weed- whack a path around the house so that you could get to the back door.

Clean up trash around back.

Roger says the ground is solid rock back here. You may want to pour a small concrete pad at the bottom. Attach a 2x8 band to the block wall with Tap-Cons and build a set of steps out the back door. Build hand rails.

Build steps to code (at least 36" wide, 8" max riser, 11" treads. , 3 stringers.) Install hand rails at 36".

Problem:
A hole in the kitchen floor has been repaired, but the subfloor is still weak in front of the sink.

New (1/2") plywood has been installed here but the job is not finished
Solution:
Floor joist reinforcement is needed. Remove a couple of pieces of plywood and cut a hole in the old subfloor that is big enough to reach down and sister new framing(probably 2x6) to the old joists, which have probably rotted due to water damage. Remove rotten materials and reinforce floor framing.

Note- floor repair will have to take place from the top because there is little or no access from below.

Tile should not be installed here because the floor is not strong enough.

The subfloor must be reinforced before any finished materials are installed over it.

Remove refrigerator and remove old floor material from underneath. Note- the fridge is leaking.

Roger does not want to move his china cabinet. Cut around it with an oscillating multi-tool.

Install the rest of the plywood .It is outside

Note- there are electrical wires under the kitchen floor. Be careful when cutting.

install new sink and cabinet

Re- do plumbing under sink.

Roger has said that he and his cousin were going to attempt this job, but he could use all the help he could get.

High Skill job.

Problem: Trash in yard and inside house prohibits free movement and thorough assessment of floor
Solution:
Clean up yard. Bag up materials in contractor strength trash bags. Take construction trash to landfill with dump card number. Clients have volunteered use of their truck.

Clean up crew should consider renting a trailer and bring a vehicle with a trailer hitch and ball.

A dumpster and Port-a Jon can be rented from Jethro's Johnnies (828-281-4549).

On the inside, bag up trash in contractor bags. Throw away old matresses, etc.

Clean out refrigerator. Use gloves

Problem: Front door has no knob and will not close right.
Solution:
Replace door. The trim is in good enough shape that you could just replace the door slab. Family has requested one with a window in it. Check Coates salvage in Weaverville,

Knob is on the right and opens in.

Install a new locking door knob.

Problem: Ramp is unsafe
Solution: Michael and Roger have torn down the ramp. Roger would prefer to leave the stone steps but needs handrail. Stepping stones might be nice. Now that steps can be seen, they should be evaluated for safety.

Problem: Porch floor needs repair (holes)
Solution: Clean all trash, debris, and other items off porch. Remove old plywood, repair framing if needed, and re- deck the porch with 1" porch boards. Deck is approximately 12' x 28'.

Problem: Stove burners need replacement.
Solution: Replace burners. She has the parts on site.

Problem: Window missing on outhouse
Solution: Install new window pane (Ember has it on site, as well as points). Caulk pane.

Problem: Trash in yard- tires etc
Solution: Haul trash to landfill- get dump card number from Etta's brother.

Problem: Vinyl siding dirty.
Solution: Wash siding

Problem: There are 3 doors in the home which need to be trimmed out
Solution: Use scrap wood to pack out doors. install 1x4 trim. caulk and paint

Problem: Soft spot in kitchen floor.
Solution: Remove floor covering. remove plywood, reinforce joists, replace plywood. There may be old plank subfloor here.Etta has replacement vinyl tiles , which she and her granddaughter have volunteered to install when the time comes

Problem: Etta mentioned water issues (low pressure). She has a spring.
Solution: She said that her grandson would be coming up soon to do some maintenance on her spring.

Problem: Front porch leaks.
Solution: Replace the old roof metal with new. 2 pieces of modern roof metal should replace 3 pieces of older metal. Use roof screws and roof caulk.

Problem: Bedroom floor is noticeably sunken in one corner.
Solution: This could end up being a major repair, depending on the damage underneath. The furniture will have to be removed and the floor torn up to assess damage- very little crawlspace room- termite damage suspected-

Problem: Back porch needs reinforcement. One joist has come loose.
Solution: Push the joist back up and re-nail or screw. Install joist hangers to reinforce porch framing. Re-nail some floor boards. Use galvanized nails and deck screws

Problem: Roof leak ( back porch). It looks like water is getting in between the porch roof and the main roof.
Solution: Install aluminum flashing (30') . It should go under the roofing on the main part of the house and over the porch roof. Caulk screw holes.Replace roof nails with new roofing screws

Problem: Electrical work needed. The living room does not have enough outlets. Etta is running too many devices on one circuit.There is some sketchy- looking wiring on the porch
Solution: Install new circuits in living room. The service panel (in bedroom) is modern with room to add new breakers. Clean up wiring on porch. Replace old wiring on porch. Stabilize porch light. New light fixture with pull chain switch needed in bedroom.

Problem: There is a hole in Etta's bathroom floor. It is in front of her bathtub.
Solution: There is an old metal tub here. It seems stable, so you could probably leave it, but if finances permit, a full remodel may be a good idea, especially if it is determined that the floor is starting to rot beneath the tub. The surround needs to be re-caulked at the very least.. Replace a section of floor about 3'x4'. Reinforce framing and replace plywood. plywood thickness will be either 5/8" or 3/4". Install new vinyl plank flooring.

Problem: Water heater closet floor rotten from years of water leaks.
Solution:
This repair should go along with a complete bathroom remodel. The water heater is 14 yrs. old. The heater is propped on the outside rim of the water heater closet, accessible from outside, so it is stable for now, but should probably be replaced when the bathroom is remodeled, since it must be removed anyway.

The existing water heater is a 30 gallon unit. 21" wide, 29" tall.

The water heater closet dimensions are 22" x 27" . Closet is 38" high.

Problem: electrical shorts reported. Water heater breaker trips.A couple of outlets are loose
Solution: Have an electrician assess the situation. It appears that a light fixture is needed in the bedroom, a couple of outlets need to be replaced, and the water heater may be not wired with a big enough wire because the breaker trips.

Problem: Back steps are unsafe. one step has a 12 1/2" rise. Handrail needed.
Solution: The deck is structurally ok and rails are in place. A better rail will be needed for the steps. Tear off old steps and replace with steps with an 8" rise or less. Treads should be 11". Build handrail. Deck height is 40".

Problem: The smaller bathroom (4 1/2' x 8') needs to be remodeled. The floor here has gotten wet due to drain leaks and water line leaks. These leaks have caused the belly liner under the house to fill with water, resulting in water soaking the floor. A section of floor has been patched but is still wet and spongy. Tub surround in poor condition. Faucets broken. Vanity has a drain leak.Toilet leaks and runs.
Solution:
Poke a hole in the belly liner that is holding water. Drain water in buckets and dump away from house. Allow to dry. Stop plumbing leaks. Remove tub and surround. Remove commode. Take up floor material. Tear up pressboard subfloor material that has been wet. Reinforce any damaged framing. Install new subfloor (plywood).

The shower/bath plumbing is accessible through the bedroom closet.  

Note- The second bathroom is larger and the floor there is in better shape. If the larger bathroom is remodeled the 3 dwellers of the home will have one good, working bathroom. This, the smaller bathroom, can be temporarily closed off, as long as the plumbing leaks were stopped, the pipes capped off, and subfloor was fixed. Then it could be remodeled later.

The price given is for reinforcing framing, replacing the subfloor, and capping off plumbing.

Problem: The second bathroom in the home is in poor condition. Although the floor in here appears to be sound, the tub is cracked. Faucets broken. Toilet has broken flush handle.
Solution:
This bathroom is 8' x 11' . Remove tub/shower and surround and associated plumbing fixtures. Inspect floor and reinforce if needed. Install new tub/surround. The old tub is 40" x 54" with a CENTER DRAIN. Note- there is a closet wall in this room that could be removed to allow more room for a standard size bathtub, which may save money. A normal tub, however, does not have a center drain. You might find a center-drain tub by calling Discount Mobile Home Supply- see above. Otherwise the drain will have to be redone.  

Install new faucet valves, surround and faucets.

Fix toilet handle or replace toilet with newer model  

Repairing this tub/shower could enable the homeowners to have one working bathroom in the home. The other one could be remodeled later.

Problem: Water heater leaks. Floor weak underneath.
Solution: Heater works but is old. Cut off water. Remove heater. Repair floor. Install new heater with new plumbing.

Problem: The home has poor drainage. Homesite is not graded properly. There is a steep bank behind the house and when it rains water flows under the house and ponds up.
Solution:
Install French drain.  

Find out where all buried cables, water lines, and drain lines are by asking Mable or her son, who lives next door.

Dig a ditch around the back side and around the gable ends. Total ditch length 130'.

Add gravel. Order gravel from Danny Collins and have him deliver it. His number is 828-777-6352. Install drainpipe with holes. Add more Gravel. hook up gutter downspouts. Add solid drainpipe and allow water to drain to the lowest point which will be going toward the creek bank.

Problem: gutters are falling off
Solution: clean debris out of gutters and install new gutter screws. Make sure all downspouts are hooked up right and secure

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Gerald's water heater and pipes inside the bathroom are not insulated
Solution:
Gerald has a plan to insulate the exterior wall where the water heater is.

Make a removable panel for the water heater. Insulate exposed pipes in the bathroom and cover with a panel.

Problem: Front door in bad shape. Hinges broken. bottom of door is water damaged.
Solution:
Install new exterior door. The old one is 32" wide x 77 1/4" high. The storm door is 31 1/2' x 79 1/2".

If you are standing on the front porch looking at the door, the storm door knob is on the right and it opens out. The main door has its knob on the right, and it opens in.

Problem: Back steps unsafe. Handrails wobbly.
Solution: Build a 4' x 4' landing with steps and rails. Make a free standing deck whose frame slopes away from the house. Follow state building code.

Problem:
Gerald has done a lot of plumbing recently. It is PEX but is not insulated.

The main water line coming up from the ground has a good shut-off valve but is not insulated.

Underpinning is missing or in poor condition. Pipes could freeze.  

There is no insulation in the floor under the house.
Solution:
Insulate pipes (1/2" PEX). Gerald has some pipe insulation.

Replace underpinning. Get it from Discount Mobile Home Supply.

There is some intact underpinning, it is the metal kind. There is a metal track in place to attach the bottom of the underpinning.

An access door should be built to get under the house if needed. Old one is rotten.

Problem: The roof is leaking in one place between the porch roof and the main trailer roof. Although this is a 1972 trailer, this was the only leak mentioned by the family. Keep it on the radar for a future membrane roof (it has some pitch changes).
Solution: Add aluminum flashing , caulk, and roof cement

Problem: Old furnace is not used. Gerald wants to remove it and make a closet.
Solution:
The furnace has a chimney that should be removed as well.

The roof will need to be patched with sheet metal when this is done. Gerald has sucessfully patched his roof this way before.

The floor may need some work after the furnace is removed.

Problem: no steps for a second back door
Solution: Although seldom used, a set of steps should be built here for safety. The door is 18" off the ground. No handrail required.

Problem: Water comes down the hillside and is running into and under Gerald's house
Solution: Dig a 100' long ditch behind the house. Consult Gerald for specs.

Problem: Corner porch post is unsupported
Solution: Make a form and put concrete or a concrete block under the post

Problem: drywall is falling down on porch ceiling
Solution: remove drywall. pull nails/remove screws. dispose of old drywall.

Problem: A gutter on the porch is failing
Solution: Remove gutter. water coming off the porch drains to the downhill side.

Problem: water is getting in window
Solution: caulk

Problem: Bathroom needs to be painted
Solution: consult family for colors, etc

Problem: No working CO or smoke detector
Solution: install combo unit

Problem: Client has trouble walking and may need a handicap ramp eventually. She did not mention this as being a need but it should be kept in mind for the future
