Solution: It would be fairly easy to build a ramp on the back porch as it is not very high off the ground. There may be a step down from the kitchen to the back room which would lead to where the ramp would be. This situation should be considered while planning any ramp project.

Problem: No CO Detector
Solution: install

Problem: Some recent plumbing work was left exposed and could freeze.
Solution: These water lines feed the kitchen. They are somehow seperate from the bathroom plumbing. In other words, if this plumbing freezes, the bathroom plumbing is still OK. Re-do the the kitchen plumbing to make it come up underneath the house. Insulate pipes and protect from freezing. If Bill is available in person or by phone, talk to him because he is probably the one that did this job and will have input on the process.

Problem: Roof Leaks. Metal is circa 1957. It has been patched and painted but still leaks. Stains are visible on ceiling material in the home.
Solution:
New metal roof. Square footage is about 1480.

Replace metal. Flash around both chimneys.

There are 3 roof pitches. 3 :12, 1 1/4" : 12, and 3/4" :12. Note: 1 1/4" : 12 and 3/4" : 12 is a very low slope roof. Reccomended roofing materials for a low slope roof are either a standing seam metal (not sure if Madison Metals sells this type of roofing) or an EPDM membrane. Standing seam costs more than standard metal roofing.

You could probably get away with a standard metal roof on the main part of the house (3&12) and the attached front porch.The lowest slope part of the roof (less than 1/12), the back addition, will require a different roof system.

Best place to order metal is Madison Metals, it is less than 4 miles away.

Problem: The storm door lets in cold air in the winter
Solution: Creatively apply weather stripping; some attempts have already been made. Exterior door works fine.

Problem: The roofer took of the range hood vent on the chimney and didn’t put it back.
Solution: Shirley says this has not caused a problem but mentioned it

Problem: In one of the bathrooms, the floor around the toilet is starting to get soft. It looks like the damage happened due to a leak in the old heat pump on the other side of the wall.
Solution: Although not quite to the urgent stage yet, the floor will need reinforcement soon. Remove the toilet and replace plywood around the toilet. Install floor material (24 square feet) on part of the bathroom floor. (the bathroom is 100 square feet total.) Install a threshold to transition between the rest of the floor. Reinstall the toilet. Note that clients have another full bathroom.

Problem: Roof leaks between porch and house.
Solution: This is a very low slope roof (less than 2/12) ; that is probably why it leaks..According to Shirley, the roofer who installed the roof was Eddie Cochran and the metal roof is 8 yrs. old. To repair the ceiling material one or two sheets of metal will have to come off. Better flashing, caulk, and tar could be applied to stop the leaks. The gutters, which are not cleaned regularly, may have to be removed in order to make the repair. The siding may also have to be partially removed on the gable above the porch roof. New OSB will be needed.

Problem: Rob has no Running Water.
Solution: Install a well. It will need dedicated circuit.

Problem: The porch roof is leaking. plywood and rafters have water damage. Currently covered by tarps
Solution: Tear off porch roof and rafters. Re-frame a new porch roof and install metal roofing. the porch is approximately 8.5' wide by 16' long.

Problem: Rob currently gets electricity via extension cords to a temporary power pole.
Solution: Rob will need power. He has spoken to Ryan Cody about permits. He will need a dedicated circuit for his well.

Problem: Rob's only bathroom is a tiny camper-style bath with a miniature shower. Both apparently work , he uses the toilet by bucket-flushing. He takes baths outside, where he has to haul water. He heats water on the small propane stove in the kitchen of the camper. A long term solution is needed.
Solution: Once the addition is built, Rob will need a bathroom and a hot water heater. Work with him on plans for this.

Problem: Camper roof has some leaks.
Solution: Rob has some metal. consult with him for plan.

Problem: Lots of trash and scrap metal littering yard.
Solution: Bag up trash, make scrap metal pile . Haul materials to the dump, landfill, or metal recycling facility. Rob has a big truck and trailer.

Problem: Rob is planning to build an addition. The plan is to build the addition and remove the camper. He has done some foundation work but needs help due to his physical disabilities.
Solution: Dig holes. These holes will contain Sono- tubes, metal and concrete. Add post anchors. Follow Rob's plan. He has an electric jackhammer. UPDATE: holes completely prepped by Friendly Ave. of Greensboro on 7/31/19, just need concrete. 50 - 50lb bags of concrete on site and Rob has a mixer.

Problem: Rob would like to have part of his shop torn down
Solution: Tear down part of building according to Rob's instructions

Problem: Rob's drain field is overgrown with weeds and small pine trees. He would like to have it cleaned up so roots won't clog septic, etc
Solution: Cut down or uproot small trees, move stumps, clear land
Volunteer or Groups:
Forsyth United Methodist Church;
Friendly Ave. Church (Greensboro)

Problem: Rob has no CO or smoke detectors
Solution: install battery powered unit

Problem: roof leaks
Solution: It appears that the roof is leaking mostly around the penetrations for the bathroom vents and the woodstove chimney. Add Roofing cement and/or replace boots.

Problem: No water
Solution: Re plumb bathroom, kitchen

Problem: There are some electrical problems. The lights in the kitchen and in a bedroom do not work.
Solution: Get an electrician to assess and repair

Problem:
The back porch has been used as a dog lot and there is a piece of plywood preventing safe exit.

Porch and steps are stable but leaning.
Solution: This back porch needs to be made into a safe emergency exit. Haul off trash on porch. Remove plywood that is blocking exit. Once the porch is cleared off then it can be further assessed. Replace any bad boards and reinforce as needed. Build temporary hand rails on steps. After a reasonably safe exit has been established then the ramp project on the front porch can start. Later, tear down and rebuild the back porch.

Problem: The front entrance to the house needs work. There are some porch floorboards that need to be replaced. The steps are steep. The entryway is narrow.
Solution:
Tear off porch roof. Tear down deck and rebuild a wider one. Build a wheelchair ramp. Build handrails and guard rails. Ramp must be 36" clear width and have a slope of 1 in 12 or less. Build a porch roof to protect the entrance.  

Note- before a ramp is built the door should be replaced with a door that opens in instead of out. This would make it easier for wheelchair access.  

Note- a safe alternateive exit must be established first

Problem: The front door has a broken hinge. It is coming apart on the inside.
Solution:
Replace door. The door is a trailer size door , 32" x 76". The existing door opens out but the new one should open to the inside of the house. This would block the washing machine or dryer but would make access easier.

A storm door here is not necessary.

Problem: There is a lot of trash and unsafe debris in the yard. Repairs on the house cannot be done until the place is cleaned up.
Solution: Clean up yard. Use contractor trash bags to bag up and haul to the dump. Construction trash must be taken to the landfill. Landfill hours on Saturday are 8 am to 12 pm.

Problem: The front porch roof is pitched the wrong way and does not cover the entrance
Solution: Tear down the old porch roof . Build a new porch roof later.

Problem: Melissa has several dogs. There is a dog shelter attached to the house, but the roof leaks on it. The dog lot is small.
Solution:
Repair the roof of the dog shelter and put some straw down for the dogs.

There is also a plastic doghouse outside in good shape. Put some straw in it.

Melissa would like to expand the dog lot. Install posts, fencing, and gate. Make sure to put fencing next to house to keep dogs from busting through the underpinning.

Friends of Madison County Animals (828-649-9798) will buy 150' of dog fence, fenceposts, and a gate. Client must fill out an application and proof of low income.

Problem: There are 2 broken windows in the home.
Solution: Replace windows. There are a few salvaged windows under the house. These could be used if the measurements are the same. If not, install double pane replacements. One broken window is in the kitchen.

Problem: The main water line is open to the weather.Underpinning in general is in poor condition.
Solution: install underpinning to prevent freezing. New vinyl stuff can be used, or recycled roof metal.

Problem: Melissa does not have a working cook stove.
Solution: Remove old stove and install a new one. The old stove is 30" wide by 26" deep. Check electrical needs.

Problem: Woodstove in home is no longer needed.
Solution: Remove stove. Rena says she will talk to Derek, Melissa's ex boyfriend, about coming and getting the stove on March 18. Leave the wood stove chimney in place.

Problem: Handrails are wobbly
Solution: reinforce using pressure treated lumber and screws

Problem: Porch roof is leaking.
Solution:
The porch is leaking because although the shingles are not that old, the added-on porch has a very low pitch. The solution would involve tearing off the shingles and installing a rubber membrane. The porch roof was not accurately measured, a rough guess would be 8' x 8'. use termination bars to fasten the membrane to the sides and caulk and tar the seam between the two roof materials.

Some plywood may need to be replaced.

Problem: Client has trouble getting in and out of shower.
Solution: Install a grab bar.

Problem: New floor material has been requested in the bedroom and in the living room. Carpet is worn and there was a flea infestation. Candy also states that she has breathing issues and it may be related to the carpet.
Solution: Remove furniture, tear out carpet, and replace floor material. 370 square feet will cover both rooms.

Problem: There is a leak under the house. There is a steady drip. It looks like it may be coming from the main water line.
Solution: Remove underpinning and determine the source of the leak. Shut off water and repair leaky pipes.

Problem: No CO or smoke detector
Solution: Install CO and smoke detector

Problem: New floor covering needed in living room.
Solution: Install laminate floor - 190sqft

Problem: All rooms of the house are very cluttered and mold has soiled most of the furniture. Ants and roaches have infested the home.
Solution: Extensive clean up needed. Consult with Beulah about what to throw away. Clean up crew will need masks, gloves, and other PPE. Get a professional pest control guy in once the clean up is completed (Edens Pest Control)

Problem: t-111 siding rotten on the bottom of the side where the septic is.
Solution: Replace siding, paint.

Problem: Roof leaks. Old 5v metal.
Solution: Metal has not been replaced maybe ever; it has been aluminum - tarred but needs new metal. It goes from about a 5/12 to about a 2/12 pitch. Approx. 1300 sqft. The area over the bathroom could be patched to fix the immediate leak until a full roof replacement could be done.

Problem: Asbestos siding is cracked and missing mainly around the back side.
Solution:
Replace siding on the back side - 200sqft - paint - caution - asbestos.

Replacement siding that matches the old asbestos shingles can be purchased. They look the same but are made of cement-board.

When doing this job wear a respirator and soak the area to cut down on dust. Put old shingles in contractor bags and dispose of properly.

Problem: There is a place where the wall has separated from the ceiling. Floor is sunk in noticeably.
Solution: An inspection of the basement revealed that some foundation work was done. New pressure treated posts were installed. This might have stopped the settling. The rest of the foundation seemed ok - there is a rock perimeter.

Problem:
In the bathroom, the floor is soft under the 18-yr old water heater.  

Water heater is no longer working.
Solution: Replace water heater and repair floor.

Problem: Client requests new flooring in bedroom.
Solution: remove furniture and carpet, add new flooring 130 square feet

Problem: There is a noticeable crack in the ceiling.
Solution: This is where the two halves of the double-wide are joined together. Client says that it happened soon after the trailer was installed, so it seems to me that this happened due to settling of the foundation. Caulk and paint.

Problem: Client would like to have laminate flooring installed in the living room. They are concerned that the 8 yr. old carpet is too dusty for Ed's health.
Solution: Remove furniture. Remove carpet and install laminate flooring (260 square feet)

Problem: Client complains that the gutters don't work.
Solution: clean gutters and monitor. If that dosen't work then re caulk or replace gutters.

Problem: One of Ed's toilets is leaking around the bottom.
Solution: Remove toilet and replace wax ring. Trish said that this has been tried several times without success. Maybe the flange needs to be moved or spacers added?

Problem: hot water hooked up to toilet
Solution: switch with cold water. This is in the second, 5' x 7' bathroom.

Problem: Ceiling material in bedroom is visibly sunken due to old roof leaks
Solution: Tear out old ceiling material. This will be a dusty job, so protect the rest of the house from too much dust by installing plastic sheeting. Haul debris to dump. Reinforce ceiling joists if neccessary. There may be rodent nests. Electrical work will be needed in conjunction with the demo to deal with light fixtures and wiring. Install new insulation. Replace ceiling material with new drywall.

Problem: Patricia says her floor is in bad shape under the sofa next to the wall.
Solution: Remove sofa, remove flooring, remove damaged plywood, reinforce joists if needed, replace plywood, install new flooring in room.

Problem: Floor is spongy in front of front door (trailer door).
Solution: Remove flooring, remove spongy plywood, reinforce joists, put in new floor material

Problem: There is not adequate access to the new door installed by Highland. Right now Patricia has a piece of plywood down.
Solution: build a ramp between the old ramp and the new porch. Build rails and make it wide enough for a wheelchair.

Problem: No smoke or CO detectors
Solution: install

Problem: Electrical problems
Solution: Several outlets and switches do not work.

Problem: Water runs under house. Behind the house is a swampy area
Solution: Dig a ditch to divert water flow away from back side of house

Problem: Lots of trash in yard
Solution: Haul off- contact relatives for truck

Problem: There is little or no underpinning or insulation under the house
Solution: Work on this after the plumbing is fixed.

Problem: At least 5 windows in the house are broken and/or will not open/close. They have been covered in plastic.
Solution: New windows

Problem: Roof is leaking. Several large brown stains can be seen in the ceiling of the living room, kitchen and bedroom.
Solution: Membrane. Trailer measures 12’ x 54’. There are several penetrations and the roof has a “step” to it; see photos .

Problem: The wood stove had a pipe that runs out a window that was filled in with sheet metal. The stove may need repair- bad grate?
Solution: Repair stove and have a heating man install a safer stovepipe.

Problem: There is a break in the septic drain line
Solution: This would be a pretty easy fix using 4” sch. 40 pvc. The place that needs repair is just outside the house ; it looks like someone ran over the exposed pipe with a lawn mower

Problem: Plumbing issues- In the bathroom, water has been cut off to the toilet. She bucket-flushes. The tub works but it is stained all over with a brown color; Debra says there is a lot of iron in the water. The water froze last winter. Her son repaired some stuff.
Solution: Install a safer water system and repair or replace plumbing in the whole house

Problem: Back door will not close and has a broken window in it. The back deck (4’x4’) is unstable.
Solution: New back deck and door

Problem: No water in kitchen. She gets water from the bathtub. A neighbor brings her drinking water. She uses an electric frying pan, a small oven, and a hot plate to cook on.
Solution: The water comes from a well underneath the old yellow block house on the property. She says this house is in bad shape; I did not thoroughly look at it.

Problem: There are 2 bad holes in the living room. A couple are hard to see because the floor has given way under the carpet. There are also holes in the kitchen, hallway, and bathroom.
Solution: Remove remaining floor covering and put a layer of plywood over the existing subfloor

Problem: Front porch unsafe. The bottom step up to her porch is bad. The porch floor is rotten in front of her door. The added- on porch roof leaks badly.
Solution: The most dangerous part of this porch , in front of the front door, could be temporarily patched up with some lumber, but there is damage to the framing. Tear off and rebuild porch and porch roof. Make a smaller one. The existing frame is 2x8 framing and 2x6 decking. Lumber should be bought from Pangle on Meadow Fork. (622-7279)

Problem: soft places in living room and hallway floor
Solution: remove floor covering and replace/ repair subfloor. reinforce joists and install new plywood. install laminate flooring.

Problem:
Bathroom needs complete remodel. Soft places in floor. Toilet loose. Shower faucet broken. Cabinet coming loose from wall. Tub cracked.

this bathroom is 60 square feet.

NOTE- there is another bathroom in the home. The other bathroom is in decent working order, will need a new tub surround soon.
Solution:
Remodel bathroom.

Remove washer and dryer.

Remove tub and surround. The tub here is a full size (30" x 60").

Remove toilet. The old one works but is loose. Good time for upgrade.

Remove floor covering. Remove damaged subfloor.

Install new plywood subflooring, reinforcing joists where needed

Remove cabinet from wall

Replace ceiling material that is falling down

install new tub and shower faucet.

install new tub and surround

reinforce wall where cabinet was

repair or replace cabinet

install laminate vinyl or linoleum flooring

Problem: floor in second hallway needs work.
Solution: The floor here has a high spot in the middle. This will require a creative solution if laminate floor is to be installed.

Problem: Floor in bedroom has several soft spots.
Solution: This room is 14' x 12'. Remove furniture,. Remove old floor material. Remove damaged subflooring. Reinforce joists. Add new plywood. Install new floor covering (laminate).

Problem: Roof leak on porch
Solution:
The roof is leaking between the porch roof and main roof. You can see the rotten board from underneath. The main roof overhangs the porch roof but not by much.

An old furnace chimney can be removed entirely from the roof. Put a sheet of metal back over it.

Replace plumbing vent boot ( 1 1/2"). Use quality roof caulk.

Remove the screws from the bottom of the main roof and the top of the porch roof. Slide flashing underneath the main roof and over the porch roof. screw back down.

Problem: The old trailer furnaces do not work, one has been removed. The only heat in the house is a large, old Ashley automatic wood stove.The bottom grates are worn out. Lindsay closes off parts of the house in cold weather.
Solution: Repair or replace wood stove. Metal stovepipe system still good.

Problem: light fixture in bedroom is loose, hanging down.
Solution: replace light fixture

Problem: Second bathroom needs work. The only part of this bathroom that is used is the commode. If the first bathroom is remodeled, a portajon will not be needed because folks can use this one.
Solution: Since only one person lives here, this is low priority. The tub and sinks are not in working order.

Problem: cabinets falling down in computer room.
Solution: replace cabinets

Problem:
Back deck needs repair or replacement. The steps are unsafe, although seldom used. The home has three other enty/exits.

Deck is approximately 4' x 4'. .
Solution: Replace deck , build rails and steps. Some materials could be reused.

Problem: Walls in hallway are bowed due to water damage.
Solution: Put new paneling over top of old, bowed stuff. There is an example of this in the living room where they put 3/16" bead board plywood over top of the original trailer paneling. There may be some places that are so bad that you have to remove the old paneling. If you do that then check for damage to the framing.

Problem: Throughout the house, the ceiling material is water damaged. Some is coming loose, some can just be repainted. The worst place is in the hallway where there is a missing piece, and in the bathroom where a piece has come loose.
Solution: replace some material ( existing is 1/2" fiber-board) with 1/2"drywall. tape, mud, finish and paint.

Problem: Soft spot in floor due to water damage. This is in the doorway closest to where you park.
Solution: Remove damaged flooring and subfloor. Flooring material is some kind of white, 12" x 12" vinyl tile. Replace damaged plywood and reinforce framing if necessary. If you cut into the floor set your saw depth so that the saw will not cut into wires, plumbing or duct work.

Problem: Hole in bathroom floor next to wall. Floor around commode weak. Wall damaged dure to water.
Solution:
The roof should probably be fixed before this bathroom is worked on to remove water from walls and floor.,

Remove some flooring. Remove damaged subflooring. Remove commode. Repair framing or scab if necessary. Install new plywood (usually 3/4" or 5/8").  

Install new flooring(existing is vinyl tile).  

Repalce wax ring, reinstall commode.

Note- looks like the walls here have been repaired at one time, you can see the newer drywall.  

Water is getting in the walls here, that is what caused the floor damage.

Problem: Back deck was not built correctly. It is wobbly. The steps (pre- manufactured) should be replaced. There are no rails.
Solution:
Tear down deck. Build a new deck that is smaller. Follow the state building code. Make the deck free standing and not attached to the house. Make the deck surface slope slightly away from the house so that water will find its way away from the structure. 1/16 inch per foot is a good drop.  

Build steps. Deck height is 34" at the high point.

Build hand rails and guard rails.

Prices given for a 6' x 8' deck.  

If care is taken during demolition, most of the materials can be re-used. Prices reflect the use of some recycled material.

Problem: The front deck/ ramp is sloping towards the house. It is attached to the trailer framing, which has caused damage to the building. The doorway has water damage and the floor is soft. The deck has no rails.
Solution:
Tear down the deck and rebuild. There is a concrete walkway leading up to the deck. In order to build a proper deck that will not continue to rot the house, you may need to put the level of the deck below the concrete walkway. Build the deck according to code. It should slope away from the house so that any water that falls on the deck will drain away from the building. Make the deck free standing so that it does not touch the house. Build guard rails. The existing deck measures 8' x 8'.  

Some materials are still in good shape and could be re- used if care is taken during demolition.

Problem: Back door will not open or shut properly. The trim and the jams have been water damaged.
Solution:
The slab is in fairly good shape, but it may be easier to replace the whole unit with a storm door and new jams included.

If you are standing on the back deck, this door opens to the inside. the knob is on the right, the hinge is on the left. The storm door opens to the outside, with the hinges on the left.

Problem: Front door needs work. Jams are starting to rot and the door is loose. Door does not lock.
Solution:
The door slab itself is in ok condition but it may be easier to replace the entire door with jams. Otherwise you will have to build the jams. Install new door. The existing door is 31" x 79".  

As you look at the door from outside, the doorknob is on the right and the hinges are on the left. The door opens outward.

The existing door does not appear to be a trailer door, which is typically shorter than a standard door. You may be able to make a standard size door work here if it will fit. That would be cheaper.  

Discount Mobile Home Supply in Weaverville would be a good place to get a mobile- home size door. The number is 828-484-7095.  

The existing door does not have a storm door with it. If you could find a door with no storm it might be cheaper.  

Install new doorknob and dead bolt.

Problem: This trailer is suffering from water damage because water is travelling down the walls and rotting the door jams on the front and back door. One wall where a window is is also also damaged. Sheila has complained of mold and has been trying to clean moldy areas. Mold is visible on the ceiling in the bedroom.
Solution:
It may be possible to get up on the rioof and caulk split seams and caulk around the roof penetrations to stop leaks. Otherwise, the trailer should have a new roof , preferably with built-up overhanging eaves, to stop the water from getting in the walls. A membrane or metal roof would work.

This roof is 57' x 14'.  

There are two 1 1 /2 " plumbing vents that penetrate the roof.

Problem: kitchen faucet drips and is old
Solution: replace faucet

Problem: kitchen sink drain is held together with duct tape
Solution: Although it does not appear to be leaking, this should probably be redone. Install new sink strainers, trap and drainpipes, hook up to existing ABS drainpipe. Strainer may be leaking slightly.

Problem: outlet in living room does not work. Nothing is tripped or off in the service panel.
Solution: replace outlet.

Problem: Loose sheet metal on outside of trailer
Solution: Use 1/4" sheet metal screws to re-attach sheet metal to framing

Problem: Tub surround needs to be caulked
Solution: Thoroughly dry out the area, remove old caulk, and apply new bathroom caulk.

Problem: Monitor heater has some kind of electrical problem and cuts off. Someone has to re- set it when this happens.
Solution: Right now the Anna is able to do this herself because she is there most of the time, but a heating guy should probably look at it. Did not mention this issue to Floyd.

Problem: no carbon monoxide detector in home
Solution: install CO detector

Problem: One of the outlets in the bedroom does not work
Solution: Hire an electrician to replace the outlet

Problem: Bathtub faucet is leaking. you cannot shut it off and there is a 1/4" size stream of water running out of the faucet.
Solution: Replace or repair faucet.

Problem: Back deck needs reinforcement
Solution: Replace some boards and add screws and braces. Reinforce and repair hand rails.

Problem: Front deck needs work.
Solution: Remove deck boards in front of main door. This section, which is about 6' x 6', needs to have some framing added and reinforced. After that is done, install new deck material (5/4 treated ). Reinforce handrails. The rest of the deck is in ok shape.

Problem: There is a hole in the bedroom floor near the doorway. It is covered by carpet. This room is 11' x 12'.
Solution: Remove section of carpet. Remove damaged subfloor material. Reinforce joists if necessary. Add new plywood - 5/8" or 3/4". Install new floor material over the damaged section, and install a threshold or carpet strip. If finances permit it might be a good time to install new flooring in the entire room.

Problem: The back side of the house is overgrown with briers and weeds. Access is needed for oil tank, window repair, and trash clean-up. Drainpipe needed to direct water from downspout to side of yard.
Solution: Cut briars and weed eat. Clean up trash. Install black corrugated drainpipe to gutter downspout and direct water away from corner of house.

Problem: Paint is peeling on the exterior of the house.
Solution:
Paint house. Note- since this house is from the 1940's, there could be lead paint present. Before scraping, test for lead paint. If paint is lead, take all precautions while scraping paint or otherwise releasing dust. Use masks, follow proper cleanup procedures, etc.

The square foot coverage needed was not measured accurately but is at least 1000 sft.

Problem: kitchen sink cabinet has a hole in the bottom of it ( main floor ok).
Solution: cut a piece of plywood to fit the bottom of the cabinet. Just put it over the existing cabinet shelf.

Problem: Home is expensive to heat. Clients use 2 electric space heaters. Although the house is small, their power bill is $200/ a month in winter.
Solution:
Install a new efficient heater . They are set up for oil heat and have a tank, they just don't have a monitor.

New windows would make it easier to heat. All the windows in the house are single pane and old.

More insulation could be added to the attic space. I did not look in the attic.

Katrina knows about Community Action Opportunities. I told her they may be able to help with weatherization.

Problem: There are 2 broken windows. They are currently covered with plastic or fabric to keep cold air out.
Solution: Replace the 2 old, single- pane windows with double pane, single- hung windows. They measure approximately 54 1/2" high x 28" wide. Repair or replace trim.

Problem: The bathroom floor has a hole in the floor. The floor damage extends under the fiberglass tub. The shower/ tub surround is water- damaged and blackened. Vanity faucet handles are broken and not used. Tub faucet leaks.
Solution:
Bathroom remodel needed. This bathroom is about 43 square feet.

Remove bathtub. It is 30" x 60". Remove damaged subfloor materials. reinforce framing if needed. (Note- there is access from below in a 4' high crawlspace). Install new tub and surround according to manufacturer's instructions.

Install new tub and shower faucets.

Remove surround materials. Walls may be water damaged.Reinforce/ repair wall framing. Install new insulation.

Remove old vanity faucet. Replace with a new one.

The toilet seems ok as is the floor around it. However, the toilet is old and this may be a good time to upgrade.

Problem: The concrete front steps are crumbling in some places.
Solution: Clean damaged area with a wire brush. Patch with high strength mortar mix.

Problem:
There are 2 holes in the porch floor. The flooring here is plywood.

There is a loose porch handrail.
Solution:
Add new, pressure treated plywood. Do not use deck boards because the porch floor covers the crawlspace which needs to remain covered to keep the pipes from freezing.

Reinforce guard rail with screws.

The porch is 7' x 24'.

Problem: Shower valve isn't working
Solution: Replace shower valve

Problem: Step needed between bedrooms.
Solution: Build step

Problem: Closet door needs work. Track bent.
Solution: Get a new track and re- hang the door.

Problem: Tracy is low on firewood
Solution: NIN or DSS firewood

Problem: Tracy complains about high heating costs. She has a central heating system that was installed by her husband.
Solution: I did not notice any loose ductwork, etc. Have heating man look at the system.

Problem: Trash and building debris in yard.
Solution: Tear down shed. Remove nails and screws from salvageable boards. Take unsalvageable materials to the landfill. Get Dump# from Tracy.

Problem: Vinyl siding is dirty
Solution: Wash Siding.

Problem: Crawlspace doors need work; they won’t shut tightly. They are made of 7/16 OSB.
Solution: Make better doors out of thicker plywood. Add door stops and some weatherstripping.

Problem: Mysterious roof leak
Solution: You can see on the inside where the ceiling drywall has water damage. However, there are no visible leaks in the fairly new metal roof. One idea would be to replace the roofing screws- the rubber washers on the screws seem to be wore out and there are a couple missing. The new screws should be installed in the old holes. Tighten the screws so that the washer is barely compressed.

Problem: Leak around water filter. It seems like the gasket is leaking.
Solution: Tracy has a new water filter. Remove insulation and check thoroughly for leaks. Turn off water and replace filter. Replace insulation. A relative replaced a valve recently. There are several crawlspace access points.

Problem: Back deck needs some repair. Handrails and guard rails are wobbly. Steps need repair.
Solution: She does not use this deck much but it should be repaired as a safe exit. Reinforce rails and steps, build handrail on steps, remove/ replace nails that are sticking out, etc. 28” height.

Problem: Front Deck has rotten boards. There are holes.It seems that pressure treated wood was not used for the decking material. The framing, however, seems to be in sound shape.
Solution: This is a big deck.(approx..16’x 24’) There are 2 options here- 1)Tear down the old deck and rebuild a new, smaller one out of the salvaged materials and some new materials. It can be as small as 8’ x 10’. This option would be more labor- intensive but cheaper. Build new steps and rails. 2) Replace deck boards. Repair or replace steps. Reinforce or rebuild handrails.This option would be less labor, but the materials would be more expensive due to the size of the deck. Deck height is 38”. Get material from DT Ramsey. Decks should be built so that they slope away from the house and are free- standing. Follow building code.

Problem: Battery needed for CO detector
Solution: Install 9v battery

Problem: New flooring needed in kitchen. The floors, althoughs sturdy, have some dips and humps.
Solution: Install vinyl laminate flooring (160 square feet). Get the flexible vinyl stuff because of the unevenness of the floors.

Problem: Bugs get in top of house
Solution: Put a screen over the gable attic vent.

Problem: Attic fan does not work.
Solution: I did not investigate this thoroughly- there is a living space upstairs and a small attic above. Sonny says it is hot up there and his fan does not work any more. Get new attic fan.

Problem: Old oil furnace stopped working
Solution: This looks like it was a good furnace at one time. It could possibly be repaired, or replaced with a Monitor. Not sure which exterior wall would be best to put a monitor? This could be another CAO job

Problem: Sonny’s stovepipe needs cleaning
Solution: Take apart single wall black pipe and clean inside with wire brush. Homeowners said they would take care of this.

Problem: Sonny is low on firewood.
Solution: Not sure if the neighbor is bringing more- Social Servces or Neighbors in Need are resources- bust and stack wood

Problem: House is hard to heat. Sonny has a medium sized wood stove. He also has some electric space heaters. They cost a lot to run un the winter. Sonny says there is no insulation in the walls of the home. The crawlspace is closed up well, but the floor is not insulated. The ceiling has some insulation in it.
Solution: Insulate the walls of the house. It has old painted wood siding. You could pull the siding or drill holes and blow in insulation. Or add blue board on top of the existing siding, then install new siding over top of that. Sonny does not like the idea of vinyl siding. I mentioned Community Action Opportunities to him.

Problem: Exterior of House needs to be painted
Solution: Paint exterior of house

Problem: No window trim or corner boards
Solution: Install once the siding is done

Problem: Back door is 10" off the ground.
Solution: Install a step.

Problem: There is no siding or damaged siding on several parts of the home's exterior.
Solution: The existing siding is mostly 1/2" MDF. Some is rotten at the bottom. Cut out bad sections and replace with 1/2" T111 plywood siding that has a 5" profile (see photos). Around the back side, there is a gap between the slab and the siding. Cut off about a 3' section, remove old, damaged siding, and repair framing if needed. Put back good insulation and put up new siding. Caulk and paint. On the exterior of the bathroom, the walls are bare OSB. Install vapor barrier (tarpaper), and install 1/4" hardi-board type siding. Some of this material has already been installed by trhe homeowner's family, so you can use the existing stuff for reference. It is 1/4 " thick and has 8" spaces between the grooves. Caulk, paint, and install window trim.

Problem: Broken window pane- kitchen area
Solution: Replace window pane or entire window. The pane is approx. 23 5/8 x 23 5/8". Entire window measures about 28" wide x 54 1/2" high. the existing window is a single pane with a storm.

Problem: There is a hole in the floor under the kitchen sink. Hole in cabinet. Rats getting in.
Solution: Unhook drain and shut off water lines. remove cabinet, countertop, and sink. repair hole in floor with plywood. reinforce framing if necessary. Replace cabinet, countertop , and sink. the existing cabinet and countertop measure 66" x 34". Buddy, her son, has a new kitchen faucet. Sink is normal size- 2 bowl 22" x 33". Put plumbing back together; make good connections that don't leak.

Problem: Kitchen floor has a sag to it and is bouncy.
Solution: Under the house there are block pillars with shims on top that support the framing. Some of these could be shored up. One has a broken piece of wood that may be causing the floor to sag. This repair would involve jacking up the floor just enough to reinforce the block pillars. You would not be taking the sag out entirely but reinforcing the floor in place. If you jack it up too much, doors and windows might get stuck and the drywal could crack.

Problem: Family has requested a walk-in shower for Florence
Solution: Her existing set up is a metal tub, 30" x 60". There is a surround in decent shape. Floor seems ok. Family say that she has a hard time getting in and out. The ceiling height is 7' here.

Problem: Water has damaged the ceiling material in the bathroom.
Solution: Once the roof leak is fixed, nail the 1/4" plywood ceiling material back up. Then caulk and paint the ceiling. Another option would be to install 3/8" drywall on top of the plywood.. If you put up drywall make sure to screw into the joists; the plywood will be too thin to hold it. It looks like there has been drywall here before. Install new trim around ceiling. Ceiling is 7 1/2' x 11'.

Problem: There is a roof leak in the bathroom. The shingles were installed on a low pitch roof- less than 3/12, which often leaks.
Solution: Some attempts have been made to patch the roof. There is some damage to the roof boards under the tarpaper, so you will have to repair that also. The boards are 1" rough sawn. Shingles need to be torn off, framing repaired, roof insulated, and then heavy underlayment installed before reshingling entire area.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Gutters clogged
Solution: Clean. bring 16' extension ladder.

Problem: There is some painting to be done in some rooms inside.
Solution: Ask Linda for details.

Problem: Exterior painting requested.
Solution: Square footage of the outside of the house is approx. 1200. Linda has a good 6 foot stepladder. Her extension ladder has a missing rung, so bring your own 16' extension ladder.

Problem: There is no window in the bathroom.
Solution: Remove part of a shelf and install a new double hung window. Linda will show you where. The new window should be 26 1/2" wide by 24 1/2" high.
Volunteer or Groups:
St George's Episcopal Church;
St. Francis (Greensboro)

Problem: Another bedroom window needs replacement.
Solution: The old window is 32" w x 29" high. You could get a smaller window to fit better ,but then you would have to re- trim the outside. Note- this window is partially covered on the inside by a corner cabinet.
Volunteer or Groups:
St George's Episcopal Church;
St. Francis (Greensboro)

Problem: Bedroom window is leaky, single pane.
Solution: Replace window. The old window is 24 1/2" wide x 53" high.

Problem: Storm door isn't closing right .
Solution: Install chain. install threshold to keep cold air out. install weather stripping., install a new door latch. Move strike plate.

Problem: Front door is sticky.
Solution: Remove door and cut a little off the bottom.

Problem: black deck slippery when wet
Solution: clean black slime off back deck. Use a wire brush and warm water to get the grime off.

Problem: Tony's front deck (concrete) has some places that need patching.
Solution: The top part of the deck is in good shape. The sides, however, have started to crumble in some places. Patch with heavy- duty mortar mix.

Problem: Tony's back deck needs work. There is one weak corner.
Solution:
Tony wants to tear down part of the back deck and rebuild it back smaller. He has his front porch, so a smaller (6 1/2" x 8') deck would be adequate. Talk to Tony about this downsizing idea.

The other part is still good but needs cleaning. Hand rails needed.

Steps can be removed and re- used.

Problem: Tony's front porch has no rails. There are some old metal ones but they are loose.
Solution:
The porch is concrete. it is 10' 2" x 20' 4" .

Install guard rails. Use the tall, black metal post bases and 4x4 pressure treated posts.

Install hand rails on steps(concrete).

You could install metal or wood rails. Price is for wood rails.

Problem: Bathroom needs some work. Tub surround is loose and the floor is worn.
Solution:
This bathroom is 55 square feet. The subfloor seems to be solid.

Install new tub surround. The tub is an old, fiberglass model but seems in decent shape. It measures 54" x 27". Install a new 3 piece surround and caulk. Structural repairs may be needed to the wall if it has gotten wet.

Install new water resistant laminate flooring material.

Problem: There are two more places where the floor is weak. One is under the kitchen sink, the other is between the kitchen and bedroom. The linoleum floor is worn out.
Solution: Remove linoleum and remove damaged plywood. This may be hard to do under the sink so you might consider replacing the countertop and cabinet. reinforce joists and put back new plywood. In the area between the kitchen and bedroom, it looks like the plywood is fairly new but is not supported by a joist. you will have to take up the plywoood, add framing, and put it back. Watch out for plumbing and wires as you cut away damaged material. The kitchen is 90 square feet.

Problem: hole in bedroom floor
Solution: Remove furniture from room. Remove carpet. The carpet is less than 5 yrs. old so you may be able to peel it back and put it back after the subfloor is fixed. Remove damaged plywood. Shore up joists. install new plywood . Put back floor covering.

Problem: Roof leaks. Several noticeable stains on ceiling
Solution: Membrane. This is one of those 70's trailers with a "hump" in the roof line so a metal roof would be difficult- there are very few chimneys to deal with. The roof measures 12' x 58'4". There are 5 plumbing vents and 1 fan vent. the fan vent will have to be taken loose and re- installed. Membrane can be draped over the porch roof. The level of the porch roof is below the roof line of the trailer.

Problem: In the laundry room, there is a place where the switch box has come loose from the wall.This is above a heat register. There is also some drywall damage right above the register. See photos
Solution: Once the roof repair is complete, patch the drywall, turn off circuit, and secure the electric box.

Problem: There are a couple weak places in the floor in the master bathroom and adjacent closet.
Solution: patch subfloor with new plywood.

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Roof leaks and/ or condensation are causing several stains on the ceiling. These are mostly in the bathrooms where it is most moist. The drywall is not yet damaged to the point of falling . There are some stains that indicate leaks, others that may be due to condensation. There are 3 plumbing vent boots that are old and leaking.
Solution:
Patch roof. Carefully scan the whole roof for nail holes, missing nails, and cracked roof cement, Replace all bad plumbing vent boots. replace some roof vents. Roof shingles are 17 yrs old so it may be time for a new roof anyway. Note- if a new roof is put on the old oil furnace stack can be removed because it is no longer used. The roof is approximately 2200 square feet.

Note- there may be some kind of condensation problem due to inadequate insulation or lack of ventilation. This problem should be discussed with roofing pros if a new roof is going to be put on so they can factor that into the job.

Problem: Toilet runs in front bathroom. Water has to be kept off.
Solution: Replace flush kit.

Problem: Kitchen faucet leaking.
Solution: Replace faucet.

Problem: Soft spot in floor of addition.
Solution: remove rotten material, replace plywood, repair framing

Problem: Lots of trash in yard. Glass, building debris, etc.
Solution: Haul trash to dump. Bag up loose trash and take unusable building materials to landfill. Use Dump Card #.

Problem: No insulation in ceiling of addition. Old stuff removed due to rat infestation.
Solution: Once the rodent problem is controlled, install new insulation and drywall . Not sure if the rats are gone yet or not; Nathan has some small dogs that may chase 'em off. 248 square feet of r13 insulation will be needed. Double up the insulation in the top half; there will be room. There is a light fixture that needs to be replaced here as well.

Problem: Pipes freeze due to inadequate underpinning
Solution: At least 2 sides of the house have adequate underpinning. Some old underpinning has been removed. Before closing it up, insulate all pipes under the house, Nathan has done some of this.

Problem: Small set of steps needed on third deck around the back. Plywood porch floor is starting to rot. This is where Nathan keeps his firewood in the winter.
Solution:
Support roof of porch with 2x4's (Nathan may have some the right length). Remove one post. Remove old plywood. Install some 5/4" pressure treated deck material. Put post back and secure. Support other side of porch roof and remove other post. Remove rest of plywood. Install rest of pt decking. install post. Build steps. Nathan has a pressure treated 2x12, but cinder blocks could also be used as steps (Nathan may have some). Secure posts. Height of deck is 20". Deck size is 4' x 7'.

Nathan has the deck boards for this job, they are in his shed. He also has galvanized nails and deck screws. 2 posts may be needed if the old ones are in bad shape.

Problem: Back deck needs work.porch roof is wobbly. posts rotten or split. Entire deck is unsafe to walk on.
Solution:
Remove porch roof. Remove posts and rails. Tear down deck. If done carefully, the 2x6 deck boards can be reused. The steps can also be reused. Rebuild deck. Rebuild porch roof. Make sure the porch roof is below the trailer roof. Add metal flashing between metal roof and trailer roof. Make sure that the roof pitch is at least 2 in 12. Build rails.Brace posts.

This deck is 5' x 10'.

Nathan has some roof metal on site. It looks like it has never been used. It is thicker than the normal stuff and should be cut with a metal cutting circular saw.  

There are some materials on site left over from NHN that can be used. A list of materials still needed is below.

Problem: Threshold is water damaged and loose. Floor is starting to rot out.
Solution: To keep the area dry, a small porch roof should be built to cover the doorway. A 4'x6' roof would be a good size, although it would not cover the whole deck. This way you could build a decent roof pitch into the porch.

Problem: Front Deck needs work. Threshold has water damage and is loose. Rotten deck boards are a safety hazard.
Solution: Replace damaged deck boards.Framing seems OK. Build rails.

Problem: Floor damage in bedroom . It is next to the wall behind the bed.
Solution: Move bed . Remove old carpet. Remove damaged plywood. repair framing. Replace plywood. Install floor material. The room is approximately 144 square feet.

Problem: The kitchen sink drain has some leaks.
Solution:
Shut off water. Unhook plumbing and drains.Take out sink with countertop attached. Faucet is still good and may be reused. Remove cabinet. Repair floor damage with plywood and framing if needed.

Nathan has a sink and cabinet that are in good shape that he would like to have installed.They are in the old house on his property. Go down there and get the sink and cabinet, unhook from plumbing, and carry up to Nathan's. Clean up sink/countertop unit . Note- this countertop is smaller than the one that is in Nathan's house currently. A shelf, seperate countertop , or some modification will be needed to fill in the hole.

Once the floor is fixed you can install the countertop and sink. Replace basket drain in sink.Replace drain pipes.

Problem: Tub surround is water damaged
Solution: Replace tub surround. existing tub is 54" long. It is an old metal tub that could be reused.

Problem: Bathroom sink is not plumbed correctly. New PVC drain parts needed.
Solution: Install a new 1 1/4" to 1 1/2" elbow in this sink drain.

Problem: Toilet is leaking. Tank is cracked and leaking due to freezing.
Solution: Replace toilet. Replace wax ring.

Problem: Wood stove has an unsafe chimney. Old burn damage visible.
Solution: This stove, according to Nathan, is only used in very cold weather. The chimney is damaged. it may be possible to repair the masonry but a new, stainless steel stovepipe would be better.

Problem: Gutters needed. Old ones leak at the seams and are 40+ yrs. old. Leaks are causing water damage to foundation.
Solution: install new gutters

Problem: ~~New roof needed. Shingles are 30 yrs old . Roof is know leaking and there are some ceiling stains. Some shingles have blown off and some boots are in need of replacement.~~
Solution: I ~~nstall new shingle roof. Install boots, flash around chimneys, etc.~~

Problem: Laminate flooring in kitchen has been water damaged due to a plumbing leak (repaired)
Solution: install new laminate. use flooring rated for kitchens (vinyl laminate)

Problem: Drywall work needed. To be done after the roof fix
Solution: tape , mud, and paint unfinished drywall

Problem: Water damage to siding
Solution: Build a porch roof on one side of the house, protecting the doorway and porch from water damage. This should be done after the main part of the roof is fixed. Use leftover metal from the roof project.

Problem: Trash cleanup needed. Christine has a truck and trailer, just needs workers to load it up. Take to landfill.
Solution: Clean up trash. bag up regular trash. De-nail and organize re-useable construction materials. Take construction trash to landfill

Problem: Some of the siding near the front door has started to rot. This is a result of water splashing up on the deck.
Solution:
Remove water damaged siding, inspect and repair framing. Put back new framing, plywood, and tarpaper. Add flashing next to deck. install new siding. Existing siding is roughsawn weather board.

To prevent this problem from happening again, a porch roof should be built to keep the area dry. See seperate repair.

This estimate is for one side of the house; more siding repair will be needed on other parts of the home.

Problem: Some deck repair is needed. There are a few loose boards that could be dangerous if not fixed soon. There are also some missing handrails.
Solution: Inspect the deck thoroughly and repair as needed. install 34-38" high rails where the deck is 18" or more off the ground. Posts are already installed in most places.

Problem: Wet, black stained material could pose a mold danger.
Solution:
Remove all stained materials from room. clean area with bleach water. Drywall will have to be removed as well as wet insulation.After this material is removed, it may be easier to spot the source of the leak. Once the leak is repaired, new insulation and drywall can be installed.

Christine is planning on tackling this job herself during the week of 1-23-17. She has purchased a haz mat suit and respirator, and is aware of the safety precautions needed for this job. Materials will be bagged and disposed of at landfill.

Problem: There is a roof leak that has caused a large stain in one bathroom. The drywall has a hole and water has started to leak through.
Solution: Roof repair needed.Although no obvious leaks are visible from above, if one large section of the roof is replaced using new metal, that should fix the leak. Christine has a plan for re-framing a section of the roof with 2x4's to make it easier to install the metal. Order metal roofing (Galvalume) and lumber from DT Ramsey.

Problem: knob needed on another interior door
Solution: install door knob

Problem: Interior door needs replacing.
Solution: This door is 28"x78". knob needed.

Problem: Toilet is loose and leaking.
Solution: Eugene has shut off the water here so it is not wet. He has another bathroom to use. Remove toilet, replace damaged wood, replace floor covering. Consider replacing the toilet. Install new wax ring.

Problem: Back steps unsafe
Solution: Build a permanent set of free-standing steps with 7" or less rise with rails. Build these first so Eugene can go in and out of the home while the front deck is rebuilt.

Problem: Back door will not close right
Solution: install new knob and strike plate

Problem: Front deck is rotting. Handrails are loose and boards are rotten.
Solution: Tear down deck. De-nail the re-usable boards and dispose of the rest at the landfill. Rebuild a new deck. Eugene is fine with a smaller deck. 16'x8' would be good. Build rails and steps. Follow building code for decks. Make the deck free standing to avoid rotting the side of the house. Also, make the deck slope gently away from the house to keep water away.

Problem: Electric furnace is not working. Client has gas logs but no money for propane.
Solution: Chris talked to Bullman who recommended replacing the 20 year old unit. Chris claims ductwork under the home is still good.

Problem:
The main problem here is that the septic drain field has failed. Jamie thinks the problem has existed ever since the family moved in 2 years ago. Jamie said he paid someone (he is pretty sure it was Mike's Septic (785-4364) $500 to dig up part of the yard to expose the septic tank. It was then determined that the drain field was not working.

The house is located on a small piece of property between Hwy, 23 and California Creek. There is a steep drop-off to the creek at the back side of the house. There is not much room for a new drain field. There is also a water line in the way (Home is on city water).
Solution: I told Jamie to contact the Health Dept. to get a permit. It seems that there would be a way to put a new drain field in , but it would have to be under the driveway.

Problem: bathroom ceiling stained
Solution: patch and paint after the roof is repaired

Problem: Yard clean up needed
Solution: Haul unusable material to landfill. David's truck is available. Get Dump Card number.

Problem: Vinyl siding dirty
Solution: wash vinyl siding

Problem: Before building the ramp, David wants to re-do his water line because it will go under the new ramp. He has a specific plan for this job. It involves digging up the old water line, installing pvc drainpipe, and putting 1/2" pex water line in it to avoid having to dig it up (under the ramp) if problems ever arise with his water lines. Although there are no current problems with the water system, doing this job will save a lot of trouble in the future.
Solution: Turn off and drain water. Dig up old water line. install pvc drainpipe. Bury line. Consult David for job specifics.

Problem: David has requested a wheelchair ramp, mostly for his wife, Ida's use. I did not meet her , but David says she has difficulty walking due to overweight and a knee replacement. If the ramp is built, it will have to be 32 feet long because the door threshold height is 32". David wants it to come off the left side of the deck, come to the end of the house, then turn straight out, perpendicular to the house, towards the road. I mentioned Independent Living to him.
Solution: Build a ramp. It will need to parallel the left side of the house for 16 feet, then come to a flat landing, then go out another 16 feet, perpendicular to the house. This ramp should have no more than a 1/12 slope. Build hand rails. Build a set of steps straight out from the door. Consult David for job specifics. There are some re-useable pressure treated materials at the site. Boards are in good condition but will need to be de-nailed. There are a lot of 45" long deck bards here. De nail boards first, then make your materials list based on what additional materials will be needed.

Problem: Electrical problems. There are 3 switches that do not work. David's son has replaced the switches but they still don't work. David says the bulbs burn out quickly. Light in kitchen does not work.
Solution: have a pro electrician diagnose the problem.

Problem: roof is leaking. stain visible in bathroom.
Solution: The roof is less than 10 yrs old so the shingles should still be good. Inspect the entire roof carefully, Remove all nails that are sticking up. Patch nail holes with roof cement. Apply roof cement and/or roof caulk around the plumbing vents.

Problem: Needs wheelchair ramp for Carol.
Solution: Install ramp at door and off deck

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: In two bedrooms, the corners have been water damaged and look moldy .
Solution: Wait until after the water problem is solved. Dry out area and clean. These rooms both have stuccoed block walls.

Problem: ~~~~The walls in this room have been water damaged.This happened due to a chimney leak. The chimney has been removed and the hole roofed over. There is a window here (vinyl) that can be re-used. The wood around it is rotten. A noticable hole in the wall around the window lets weather in.
Solution:
This cannot be done until water issues have been resolved. Remove all furniture from room. Tear off plaster and wall covering in the corner that is damaged, allowing cinder blocks to dry out.Tear up rotten floor. this room has hardwood floor and a wood subfloor. Repair/replace bad framing, subfloor. install new flooring material.

This room is 92 square feet. Access is possible from underneath.

Remove vinyl window (it is loose). Remove all wood around the opening in the cement block wall. Clean area and install pressure treated wood framing around the opening with concrete screws. Frame up for the window. Install window and trim inside and out.

Problem: The band and other framing on the back side of the house is damaged. Some of the framing that contacts the concrete foundation wall is wet and not pressure treated.
Solution: Replace water damaged framing. Pressure treated should be used due to the wet location. This job could involve jacking up the house.Access thru basement or from above (cut hole in floor).

Problem: ~~Edge of roof is getting wet.~~ Gutter work needed. Existing gutters are coming off and a new gutters will be needed ~~after the chimney is torn down~~. Make sure the drainpipes that the downspouts connect to are not clogged.
Solution:
Add some framing to the underside of the roof where the new gutters will go. Tap con a pressure treated band with a beveled top to the block wall to fill in the hole, then put a couple rafter tails in.

Repair any wood that looks too rotten.You may want to install some flashing. Install gutters with gutter screws and sleeves. You will need a new piece of wood to fill in the space created by the chimney removal. Make sure the gutters slope downward towards the outside edges of the house. hook up downspouts.

Problem: Roof leaks around chimney. There are 2 16" masonry chimneys put together. Chimney is no longer used.
Solution: Tear down chimney. Install new joist scabs, plywood or roof boards, and patch the roof.

Problem: Water is getting into the back side of the house. Basement is wet. Sills and some joists are wet and have been damaged.
Solution: French Drain. Dig ditch, add gravel and perforated drainpipe with fabric.. Find out where plumbing, electrical and fuel lines are before you dig. Connect to gutter drainpipes.

Problem: Scott would like to have an addition built on the home. This would be a bedroom for one or two kids. The parents are concerned that there is not enough space for all of them in the single-wide.
Solution: This addition would be built on the back side, the side that faces away from the road. Talk to the Carvers about the location and other specific needs. First, make sure there are no water lines or power lines around. Then frame up an addition floor on pressure treated posts. L L $1500.00 16  Make the level of the floor be one step below the level of the floor in the main house, so that the roof can have a decent slope. The ceiling height can be as low as 6 feet on the back side. This will also help with roof slope. The dimensions of the addition should be about 8’ x 16’. Make a back door. After you get it dried in, cut a hole where the back window is. Watch for plumbing and electrical wires. Use the old window that will be removed in the new addition. Price given for a dried- in addition- framing, roofing, and siding only.

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: install

Problem: Window pane broken
Solution: This is part of a double pane window. It measures about 28 ¼” x 29”. Get exact measurements and call Mars Hill Hardware.

Problem: Drywall damage next to fridge.
Solution: Patch drywall. This is probably 3/8” drywall, thinner than most, and hard to find. Patch a place that is about 2’x4’. Sand, paint,etc.

Problem: Water is leaking in through the windows. If you look at the top of the windows, you can see a place where it looks like water can get in around the vinyl siding.
Solution: Install flashing above the windows (This problem is only happening on the side of the trailer facing the road) The best place to get this flashing will be Madison Metals (see below). Get them to make you some custom pieces.

Problem: Some of the old deck boards are starting to rot
Solution: Replace deck boards

Problem: The front deck, built in 2004, is well built but water is getting into the doorway. The deck is sloped away from the building but water is still finding its way in. The existing deck is 16’x 12’.
Solution: Build a covered entry way over part of the deck. The deck is too wide to build a roof over the whole thing, so just make a roof that is 6’x16’. This would be the same length of the deck but cover about half the width. If you  build a roof this way,  the roof rafters can have enough of a slope to shed water. The idea is to protect the side of the house next to the deck to stop any more water from getting in.          Attach a ledger board to the side of the house above the door but below the roof line. Make sure you have enough clearance to install the roof metal below the level of the existing roof. Also make sure the storm door clears the bottom side of the rafters. It is ok to have the low side of the porch be around 6 feet tall.

Problem: need CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: There is no grass growing in most places around the house. Kenneth has sprayed to keep down weeds.
Solution: Plant grass seed . Talk to Kenneth.

Problem: There is a set of steps down to the basement that is way too steep (12” rise. Kenneth wants to tear them down and change this into a closet.
Solution: Tear down steps and put up floor joists. Add plywood sub floor and insulation.

Problem: Siding needed. The back side is the 1950’s era asphalt siding(see photos). There is a place where there is no siding up high. On the front there is also a place up high where siding is missing.
Solution: Install siding (vinyl or rough sawn boards.) 350 square feet on the back side. The front will need white vinyl to match the old aluminum siding(30 square feet). Kenneth has the vinyl siding on site for this project.

Problem: Owner requests bathroom window replacement. Old window is single pane.
Solution: Replace window with double pane. Call Kenneth for measurements

Problem: There is no “P” trap For the shower drain (sewer gas can come in). there is a “T” where water could come out of the kitchen sink drain.
Solution: Install 2” P trap.  Replace T with elbow.

Problem: There are soft and uneven floors in the kitchen and living room. This is due partially to settling and partially due termite damaged floor joists.
Solution: Remove linoleum and subfloor in kitchen in front of the sink. Replace existing joists (approximately 4 joists) with pressure treated 2x6 and support as necessary. Install new subfloor and floor covering.

Problem: The french drain on the side needs to be redone.
Solution: Install new french drain along the side of the house and connect to existing drain line. Kenneth knows how he wants this done.
Volunteer or Groups:
St. James (Hendersonville);
Forsyth United Methodist Church

Problem: The back side of the house was leaking until Kenneth painted it with black  roof sealant. Age of roof metal unknown.
Solution: Replace roof metal on this side of the house. Part of the roof is 3/12 and part of the roof is 6/12 (approximately).600 square feet. There is a vent that can be roofed over. Other than that there are no roof penetrations.  The existing metal is 5v. You could use the more modern painted galvalume (3’wide) on this side. If you use this type of metal you will have to get transition flashing. Madison Metals can answer questions about transition flashing.     Order  metal from DT Ramsey       (656-2754) or Madison Metals (689-4057). Both outfits deliver. The 5Vstuff from Lowes will be much more expensive.

Problem: Roof leaks around chimney. Water is getting around it, running down, and is starting to cause some damage to the sill underneath the house. Entire roof is old 5V metal and leaks intermittently.
Solution: Remove existing metal. Remove existing rotten roof slats. Install new slats and metal roof. Install fascia. Replace all flashing.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: New gutters are needed on the front of the home
Solution: Install 40’ of aluminum, 6” gutters. Install a 4x6 downspout.

Problem: Missing piece of siding above back door
Solution: Install siding(rough sawn). Paint.

Problem: There is a rotten piece of plywood attached to the side of the house that needs to be torn off , it was used to keep kindling dry.
Solution: Tear off, inspect siding for rot

Problem: The back door does not have good steps
Solution: Door opening is 24” off the ground. Install a set of pressure  treated steps with a simple handrail.

Problem: The south wall of the house contains a lot of single pane windows. The roof has leaked on the corner and water has damaged the trim, siding, windows, and likely the framing as well. This happened due to a lack of overhang.
Solution: Remove gutters. Remove window trim. Remove windows. There are 12 panes that are about 30” x 40”. One is broken. It is OK with Bill to have 2 less windows in the finished wall.  Have tarps nearby in case of rain. Build an overhang at least 12” using 2x4’s. Some should be tied back into the existing rafters. Add fascia board. Add plywood. Install tar paper and shingles. Remove rotten siding. Remove rotten framing if necessary and re frame parts of the wall. Re-install windows, siding and window trim. Paint.  Note- the last time the house was re roofed according to Bill’s recollection, was 30 yrs. ago. However, there are no leaks reported other than the one on this side of the house.

Problem: Deck is slippery. Siding is dirty.
Solution: Pressure wash deck. Hand- clean siding.

Problem: Co and smoke detector needed.
Solution: She has a new CO detector with a battery. I helped her decide where to plug it in and she says she will do it.  Smoke detector needed.

Problem: In the well house, there is a pressure tank that is leaning to one side. It has started to come off its block supports.  The water is working and there is enough pressure.
Solution: Drain tank and prop up the tank by moving the blocks under it.

Problem: There is a big refrigerator that she says dosen’t work because the plug wire is cut. She has another dorm- size fridge.
Solution: Remove fridge and plug up rat holes

Problem: HVAC  issues, The heat vent covers do not fit. There is debris in the vents. They are not properly closed in. House is hard to heat. About 25% of the floor insulation has fallen out underneath the house.
Solution: Jeri has been referred to Community Action for weatherization services. Vacuum out vents from the top. An HVAC man or other qualified person can seal up the ductwork using metal tape and sheet metal. Install new covers.

Problem: Electrical issues. Several outlets and lights do not work. Breakers are not tripping. She mentioned that the wire to the range (240 v) had been chewed on. She had someone come and fix that, and does not use that stove because the varmints have chewed out the insulation.
Solution: Have an electrician check for bad outlets and breakers.

Problem: cleanup needed
Solution: Vacuum up mouse droppings, insulation, etc. Jeri has a shop vac but it needs a filter. Wear gloves and other protection.

Problem: There is a 2” hole made by rats near the sliding glass door.
Solution: Patch hole with plywood. Cut out a square hole , put some framing underneath, and screw it together.

Problem: The house has a bad rat and mouse infestation. They have chewed some holes and may have chewed wires. There are piles of material, (insulation, etc)  that they have chewed up. She has talked to some pest control people and got a quote from Terminix but is unable to afford their services. She has installed electronic repellants; they haven’t worked. She has not tried the big wooden rat traps
Solution: Jeri  needs help blocking up holes where the rats could get in. She will need help moving furniture and appliances to get to some of these places.  I suggested using  a combo of spray foam insulation and wire screen. In addition, work needs to be done around the outside of the house. Holes under the porch should be filled in with dirt and packed. Additional  metal underpinning  could be installed over the old stuff ( it is rusty).  Use sheet metal screws to attach and repair metal underpinning.  Then set rat traps, the big wooden ones. Rat poison could also be used but make sure that pets can’t get at it.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install

Problem: Erosion around back side of house.
Solution: French Drain. Dig ditches around at least 2 sides of the house and apply drain pipe. Hook up downspouts. Add gravel.

Problem: Gutter coming loose
Solution: Clean gutter. Add gutter nails.

Problem: Small Leak in porch roof
Solution: Apply roofing cement

Problem: One end of the porch needs repair.
Solution: This porch is built of “Rough sawn” material. Posts and lumber can be purchased at DT Ramsey Lumber (see above).  There are some posts that need to be replaced as the supports for them have given way. Pour new footers (or use solid concrete blocks) Add new framing and flooring.

Problem: Ceiling paint needed in kitchen above fridge
Solution: Move fridge or climb on top of it, paint

Problem: Second bathroom has a tub that has a hairline crack.
Solution: The tub and surround will need eventual replacement. The tub is 53” x 27” (trailer size). It will need a surround. Call Discount Mobile Home Suppy (Weaverville Hwy.)to get a tub this size. Otherwise the bathroom is ok. There seems to be no floor damage yet

Problem: Another bedroom needs work. The heat registers are rusted and loose in here.
Solution: Paint walls and ceiling. Install laminate flooring. Again, the carpet has already been ripped up. This room is 9’ x 11’.

Problem: Bedroom has no floor covering. The carpet has been ripped out. Billy wants to finish painting this room and make it his bedroom. He says the bed he has now in another room is uncomfortable.
Solution: Paint ceiling, finish painting walls. Billy Joe has paint. Install laminate flooring. Install baseboards. This room is 12’ x 11’.

Problem: Second bathroom is not used. Tub cracked, lavatory in rough shape. Older model commode is missing some parts
Solution: Remodel the bathroom. 33 square feet. Remove old commode, remove vanity. You may be able to remove some wall panels and make more room for a standard- size tub. Check for floor damage. Install laminate flooring (waterproof vinyl planks ). Existing tub is 53” x 27”. It will need a surround. Install new tub, commode, vanity, and associated plumbing. Paint room. Note- there is another, working bathroom

Problem: CO/Smoke detector needed in kitchen. Batteries in the smoke detectors should be checked.
Solution: Install detector, check batteries

Problem: chimney needs cleaning
Solution: Elizabeth has a real good chimney brush. She will tell you how to do it.

Problem: possible leak in chimney
Solution: Get up on roof and check for leaks. Tar if necessary.

Problem: Heat doesn’t stay downstairs.
Solution: Elizabeth requests insulation and drywall between ceiling joists to prevent heat from all going upstairs. This would be in the sewing room. It measures 9’ x 13’.

Problem: Dining room window needs window glazing
Solution: Glaze exterior of this window. It is single-pane and she wants to keep it.

Problem: Owner requests window replacement in room with wood stove.
Solution: Existing window is single pane.36 3/16” wide x 61 ½” tall. Odd size, Order from Summit (682-9841)

Problem: air leaks through exterior door
Solution: caulk door stops

Problem: Door between bathroom/sewing room won’t shut right.
Solution: Remove hinge pins, take outside, and cut door. This one probably has lead paint, too.

Problem: door won't shut - needs knob
Solution: Remove hinge pins, take outside, and cut door. Existing door is 36 x 80. Warning- lead paint

Problem: screen door won't shut correctly
Solution: Tighten up hinge screws. If that doesn’t work replace screen door. It is 31 5/16” w x 79 5/16 “high.

Problem: kitchen faucet leaks
Solution: install new faucet - see photos

Problem: The old kitchen countertop  has started to rot.
Solution: New countertop. The old one is 64 ½”x26 5/8”. Sink is 22”x 33”.

Problem: Gutters needed. Water comes off the roof and has damaged the siding. Water could get in the house band and framing. Drain pipes may be clogged.
Solution: Put gutters on garden side. Need 32’. On entry  side, install 14’ of gutters. Drain into buried black pipe. Check all drain pipes, especially around back (woodstove room w/ flat roof) to make sure drain pipes are clear. A French drain was installed here  20 yrs. ago.

Problem: Spring behind house could cause moisture problems.
Solution: Clean out existing ditch to divert water around house.

Problem: Bed is too high- owner falls out
Solution: Independent Living suggested foam “noodles” under sheets

Problem: Upstairs bedroom  and bathroom does not have enough outlets or lights.
Solution: Install outlets and lights. One outlet needed in each bedroom, one in the bathroom. Put a switched overhead light in each room upstairs.

Problem: No guardrails on some parts of the deck. Back Steps need hand rails.
Solution: Install approx.. 50’ of deck guardrails. Install stair handrails. See photos for design.

Problem: Gravity-fed spring water system needs maintenance.  Mice have been getting in the reservoir and drowning.
Solution: Clean out spring. Make a better cover for it. Patch concrete reservoir (5’x 5’). Make a better lid for it that keeps out varmints. Use plywood, glue on insulation board

Problem: Elizabeth has trouble getting in and out of her bathtub.
Solution: The thing that might work here is called a “ super-bar.”.It works like a shower curtain rod only vertically, mounted beside the tub. I could not find a local source but it could be ordered. There is not much space beside the tub. This is an old, deep , claw-foot, and she does not want to part with it.

Problem: Interior staircase is steep(9”rise) and has no handrail on the outside. Owner has difficulty climbing.
Solution: Install handrail, or possibly re-do stairs to make them less steep. Re-doing the stairs would require tearing out the old steps entirely, and would also take up more space in the room (longer run). I have priced adding handrails to the existing stairs.

Problem: Water freezes in cold weather. Very little insulation under house. Inadequate underpinning.
Solution: Install rigid foam insulation between joists. Extruded polystyrene should be used. This stuff is expensive. Builders Express in Mars Hill (689-5920 or 689-2818) can get it in any thickness. Order ahead. Re-Insulate water pipes and drains. Put plastic down in crawlspace. Install new underpinning on one side of the house. Create a way to ventilate crawlspace in dry weather. The space that needs to be insulated measure approximately 30’ x 32’. Spacing between floor joists varies, approx. 20”.

Problem: Paint needed- Ray had someone paint the interior but more is needed.
Solution: Repaint interior. Note house built in 1957 – old paint could be lead

Problem: 2 electric stove eyes not working
Solution: repair/replace stove eyes

Problem: need more fiberglass insulation
Solution: Add R-19 . approx.. 850 sft.

Problem: no CO/smoke detector
Solution: install - Note that Ray's wood cook stove can be smoky by nature

Problem: old electric fusebox
Solution: No electrical complaints were reported here, but if problems happen due to the age of the system, Ray has an electrician, Sam Lloyd at “Wired Up”, who has done electrical work there.

Problem: rusted-out oil tank
Solution: Get new tank and fill. This was recommended by Buckner Oil (689-4199), who would not fill the tank due to the leak. Ray has a good  Monitor Heater.

Problem: No Water. Water is not filling the reservoir. The spring is uncovered and there is a cow pasture above it. Intake pipe was not found.
Solution: Drill Well, install pump. The old system consisted of an above- ground spring that gravity-fed water into a  concrete reservoir. The water was then pumped to a well house, where there is a pressure tank. The problem with fixing the old system is that there is a cow/horse pasture (not on Ray’s land) directly upstream and above where the spring-house should be built. There also seems to be some mechanical issues with the pump. A new similar pump has been purchased, but is not installed. There is not enough fall between the reservoir and the house, so a gravity- fed system is not an option. Ray had a man from Clearwater Well Drilling come out and mark a spot for drilling a well. He gave a quote of $5000, according to Eileen. Not sure if this includes plumbing., hooking up to house, etc.

Problem: Soffit and fascia damaged on road side on old section of house
Solution: replace and repair

Problem: No insulation in floor of newer addition. Installing insulation would make the place much more energy efficient.
Solution:
Remove fishing poles and stuff from ceiling, staple up faced fiberglass batts, 480 sf space, 15” centers, 2x12 “I” joists.

Price is given for R19 insulation, R30 would be better but a coulple hundred dollars more.
