Problem: soffit and fascia work needed
Solution: After siding is installed , install fascia and soffit (there is none.)Note that the work will take place high up off the ground(18’) so tall ladders and / or scaffolding will be needed. 2x6 rafters 24”oc.

Problem: siding work needed on newer addition
Solution:
I-joists are sticking out of the house. The siding never was finished on this house. Joists should be cut off flush and new siding should be put over top of the 1- by boards that were originally installed horizontally. There are gaps in between the boards, so new siding should be installed over the boards. Roughsawn board and batten or T-111 recomended. Total sf of siding needed is about 720.Roughsawn pine can be purchased from DT Ramsey 656 2754

Assessment update 12-6 - 18. I joists are still sticking out in some places. House wrap is in place (installed by relatives). See photos.

This job will require at least 2 extension ladders. Ask the family if they can get one in the community, they used one to hang the housewrap.

Vertical board and batten might work well here.

Problem: rotten corner by porch - rats getting into house
Solution:
Take off some siding , repair framing ,replace insulation, replace old press board siding with new cement board,caulk, paint

Homeowners have covered the area with some plastic stuff to prevent further damage.

there may be extensive rot here, be prepared to "open up a can of worms", repair framing, old siding beneath frame, etc.

Problem: siding is rotten
Solution:
Replace 1950’s press-board siding with cement board( Hardi- plank or other brand). Repair all rotten wood underneath. 100 sf cement board, ½” thick by 8”wide planks, paint

Siding and window paint was tested for lead with a negative result. There may be some other siding under the press- board material, however.

Problem: rotten corner needs work
Solution: This is the corner on the opposite side from the road, next to an exterior door. Remove rotten material and replace with pressure treated. This should go along with siding replacement

Problem: Front porch needs work. Wobbly handrail. Posts are not plumb. Deck surface is worn and uneven. Porch is framed with non- pressure treated I- joists, one of which is decaying.
Solution: Make some structural improvements to the deck. This may involve new posts, diagonal bracing, new rails, and a new sheet of plywood.Build a new, sturdier handrail. Total rail length needed is 26’ long’x 36” high.Use pressure treated wood.

Problem: broken window facing trailer in old part of house
Solution: replace window .36"hx25" w r.o

Problem: replace two windows in kitchen
Solution:
Install double pane insulated windows. They should be ordered to fit a 33” wide by 52” high rough opening. Take out window, take out trim, repair rotten places around window, build up R.O., install window, re-trim

note signifigant rot around windows. some siding and framing repairs may be needed around this window

Problem: ceiling in living room needs work
Solution: nail up loose trim, repair loos 2x4

Problem: Flooring sags. One place, in the kitchen, is very weak. Rot and/ or termites suspected.
Solution:
Best way to repair is probably to remove all appliances and furniture from the kitchen and start cutting out the kitchen floor. This could be opening a real " can of worms" because the condition of the floor and sills are unknown. Material under the existing floor cover is unknown.

The kitchen section of the house is built low to the ground, thus it would be very difficult to shore up this part of the foundation. Other parts of the foundation could be worked on, however. There are some cracks and settling ,and part of the foundation is dry- stacked block. Use caution while jacking and shoring up. Note that this job should be done before installing windows.

Problem: Celing work needed  after the roof has been fixed
Solution: patch drywall, paint

Problem: roof leaks in old part of house
Solution: Replace old metal roof. Flash and tar around chimney, flash between old and new part of house, replace boot around bathroom vent (3”id pipe). This roof is not too steep or high. (3-12 going to 5-12).

Problem: Hard-wired smoke detector has been removed. No CO detector.
Solution: Re-install smoke detector with fresh 9v battery. Install CO detector.

Problem: Upstairs window will not open and close right
Solution: Repair or replace- double hung 34 3/4” w x 71 1/4” tall double pane window

Problem: Water heater has a small leak in the top
Solution: Not urgent- she has a neighbor that can do this

Problem: Drainage work needed. There is a spring behind the house that seeps towards the foundation when it  rains  a lot
Solution: Dig a 40' ditch from this spring to the creek. There is an old drainpipe here where this job has been done before. Install a new drainpipe with a screen to catch debris.

Problem: Gutters are failing
Solution: Remove gutter on west side. Remove gutters on dormer.  Replace gutter on east side. There are drainpipes here, make sure they are clear. Gutter needed 40'. use 6” gutter to catch more water

Problem: Roof leaks, mostly around the chimney. The leak is not obvious, but somehow water is getting in and rotting the siding around the chimney. There is also an active leak on the porch. Shingles are 25+ years old. Nails are coming up through the shingles. There is moss growing on the shingles around the dormer. Some shingles are missing.
Solution: This roof could possibly be patched, but ideally should be replaced. There are some places where it looks like the plywood may be coming up and for this reason a tear-off is recommended. Repair plywood, re-shingle. This roof is slightly less than a 9 and 12 pitch. It is also a 2-story house, so it will require    safety equipment. A professional roof contractor should probably do this job. Square footage of this roof is approx. 1880. There is a 2” vent which will need a boot and flashing around the masonry chimney.

Problem: sewer trail line leaking
Solution: replace

Problem: Roof leaks. The worst leaks are near the chimneys. Wall damage has resulted. The pitch is approximately 5 in 12.
Solution: needs professional repair/ replacement.Approximately 1650 square feet of metal will be needed

Problem: ceilings need paint
Solution: paint

Problem: water problems at rear of house
Solution: install french drain

Problem: house needs guttering. Fascia board damaged
Solution:
Replace fascia boards. Install new guttering and down spouts.

George got a quote from Eddie Rice to do the gutter job. $758 materials.

Problem: outside siding is rotting. It is the old wafer-board stuff, 1/2" x 12".
Solution: replace with hardi- board

Problem: floor joist sagging
Solution: jack up joist and reattach

Problem:
There are no steps to the side exterior door.

The siding is missing under the doorway.  

Framing repairs needed here as well.
Solution:
Repair framing under doorway. This can be done from outside.  

Build steps. Height of doorway is 24".

some siding will be needed-(hardi board) see siding repair job

Make a concrete pad under the steps, or support with concrete blocks.

Problem: Floor rotten and sagging
Solution: Remove flooring, re-enforce joist, replace sub-floor and install new flooring

Problem: No smoke or CO detector
Solution: install combo unit

Problem: Better grab bar requested in bathroom (old one came off one time)
Solution: Install sturdier grab bar

Problem: Bathroom needs new flooring.
Solution: Vinyl laminate recommended. 100 square feet.

Problem: Overhanging limbs touching roof
Solution: Prune. Bring extension ladder.

Problem: Kitchen sink cabinet has a hole in the bottom of it. Damage happened due to an old leak (fixed).
Solution: Shut off water to sink. Disconnect  faucet and remove sink. Remove countertop. Replace cabinet, the old one is 60” x 24” .Put counter, sink and faucet back (they are in OK condition).  Make leakproof connections.

Problem: Siding is starting to rot on the bottom in some places.  Some exterior trim needs work.
Solution: The existing siding is ½” MDF (press board). Replace with ½” T111 style siding. It should have an 8” profile(looks like 8” boards). Relace rotten trim with new. Caulk and paint.

Problem: The gutters all around the house are failing.
Solution: Seamless gutters are there but are coming apart and sagging. It may be possible to repair but gutters are sometimes hard to take down without destroying. Pro gutter job may be needed (Dotson’s or A1). 80 feet of gutters needed.

Problem: Step handrails are loose and broken on her front porch.
Solution: Reinforce handrails with tap/con screws or a metal bracket. Steps are concrete. Replace top rails. Note- client may need a ramp soon due to disabilities. Ramp would have to be 40 feet long (the porch height is 40”)and have a 180 degree turn. Build ramp according to the state building code. Code requires max. 1/12 pitch.

Problem: Back exit unsafe. Client fell one time. There are 2 2x6’s stacked up on top of each other below her back door.
Solution: Remove 2x6’s. Build a pressure treated platform (6’x6’) 6 inches below the door opening so that there will be an easy step-down for Shelby. The platform should be almost level , sloping gently away from the house both ways. Build a step down into the yard on  the steepest side. See photos.

Problem: Celina wants to install new laminate flooring in one of her rooms.
Solution: She has the laminate flooring and prying tool. Consult with Celine about what to do.

Problem: Soffit has started to rot.
Solution: Install drip edge and flashing. You may be able to get this from Madison Metals near Mars Hill. They may be able to make a one- piece drip edge that would also cover the fascia board, which would be ideal. The fascia board is good. Remove gutters and replace rotten or stained soffit material ( ½” plywood.) Put gutters back up.

Problem: Outside spigot froze and busted.
Solution: Replace spigot. She has one but it doesn’t look like the right kind.

Problem: More yard work is needed in connection to the drainage project.
Solution: The jobs that she would like to have done are these: 1) Plant grass seed( she will get) 2) Cut up firewood, stack 3) Weed eating and mowing 4) Replace rock flower bed 5) Work on patio that was torn up during project

Problem: Celina’s drainage system has been torn up due to the recent septic work.
Solution: Dig ditches, Re- install drainpipes , bury pipes, hook up to gutters, etc. Celine has or has agreed to purchase drainpipes, etc

Problem: The oldest part of the house has 2-prong outlets. Breakers trip a lot. She did not report any shorts.
Solution: Electrical upgrade. She needs a better service at least in this part of the house so she can run modern appliances. Change outlets and add new circuits.

Problem: No CO or smoke detector
Solution: Install CO and smoke detector

Problem: Door work needed
Solution: Repair strike plate (back door). Install knob on front door.

Problem: There is no front steps or deck
Solution: Dewayne has a recycled deck in the yard (see photos) reinstall this one or reuse the materials to make a free standing deck and steps with hand rails.

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: The leaks are not too bad; there are some water stains on the inside edges of the ceiling. Kool- seal.

Problem: Bad road
Solution: Add gravel. ( Call Danny Collins to deliver) It looks like there is a spring that floods the road where you turn to go up Dewayne’s driveway. Maybe install a culvert here? (vols) Talk to him about this because he has grading experience.

Problem: Condition of plumbing unknown
Solution: Turn water on and see what leaks

Problem: Toilet needed in one bathroom.
Solution: Add plywood layer. Install laminate floor (70 sft).and install a toilet. You will  have to raise up the toilet flange or possibly replace it so it will work with the new floor thickness.

Problem: Bedroom and adjacent bathroom both have a hole in the floor. Dewayne has removed the floor covering in both rooms, exposing the chipboard subfloor.
Solution: Cover both rooms with a layer of ½ “ cdx plywood. 195 square feet for both rooms. Add laminate floor to bedroom.

Problem: Hot water heater/furnace closet floor is in bad shape.
Solution: This is probably due to old water damage. Take out old furnace and water heater, replace floor with ¾ plywood, and replace water heater. The closet is 3’ x 4’.

Problem: Foundation work needed (see photos)
Solution: The trailer is supported on cinder blocks in typical singlewide fashion, but it looks like some concrete footers may be needed . Check code regs regarding trailer footers (depth, width required). There are no straps either.

Problem: no heat
Solution: Old furnace does not work. Dewayne wants to install a wood stove.

Problem: no power
Solution: can't get power until septic is in

Problem: no septic
Solution: I checked at the heath dept. and there is no record of a septic permit for him. I brought him the paperwork for the perk test and septic permit. He has to draw up a plan and deal with Vivian at the health Dept.

Problem: No water. He says he has a covered spring but no reservoir.
Solution: Dewayne plans on having a spring-fed system. Install reservoir, develop spring, bury pipes, etc.

Problem: no CO/smoke detector
Solution: install combo unit

Problem: Drywall patching is needed throughout the home (there is a 2’ hole behind the monitor heater.
Solution: Re- screw, tape and mud where needed. Paint with primer.

Problem: Bathroom needs work.  Volunteers tried to install a shower stall but the pan is cracked. The floor tiles (cheap vinyl) are peeling up.  Not sure if toilet works.
Solution: The framed opening for the shower stall is 33” x 48”(bare studs).  Find a shower stall that will fit, or modify the rough opening. Install new shower pan and walls. Rita has requested a lower shower pan that she can step into easier. Find out if there are any water leaks in the plumbing here before you install the shower stall. (the water is currently off). Remove old tiles and install vinyl laminate flooring (35 sqft.)

Problem: ceiling drywall cracked/sagging
Solution: Re-screw and mud or replace 132 square feet of drywall and finish. Paint.

Problem: new flooring needed in kitchen
Solution: Remove old flooring material to provide a flat surface. Install laminate or ceramic tile flooring .132 square feet.

Problem: The existing  back  door is not an exterior door. Air leaks under it.
Solution: Ideally, replace door. At the least, improve the threshold and add weather stripping. There is a porch roof that protects this door. Door size is 32” wide by 79 ¼ high. Note- door probably has lead paint.

Problem: Moisture in basement. Dirt floor.
Solution: Put 6 mil plastic down over the dirt floor. Install heater or dehumidifier in basement.

Problem: In the bedroom, a ceiling fan hangs down too low and is wobbly. Anyone 6’ tall or taller could hit their head on it. The fan wobbles and has shook the drywall loose.
Solution: Remove ceiling fan. Improve the support for the fan by reinforcing the framing and installing a sturdier electrical box. Install a shorter  down rod and reinstall fan. Re-screw and re- finish the drywall.

Problem: There is a working monitor heater here but the family has no oil. The woodstove  cannot be used because of Rita’s breathing problems.
Solution: Refer to Social Services, Neighbors in Need, or other for heating assistance.

Problem: There are several roof leaks. A hip rafter has been damaged due to improper roof shingling. Another leak is around the chimney. There may be some ridge cap leaks.
Solution: Replace hip rafter (family has lumber on site). This requires carpentry skills.  Re- shingle the place where water gets in. Since the woodstove chimney will not be used, you could remove it and roof over the hole. After these jobs are done, check for leaks and re do the ridge vent/cap if necessary.

Problem: The windows in the house almost all have sill and window trim damage. This is probably due to the fact that there is no overhang on the gable ends. The  windows are old, single pane with storms. Some panes are broken.
Solution: Ideally, the windows, trim , and sills would all be replaced. At the very least, replace glass and repair trim  in two or three windows. In the future, an overhang could be built onto the gable ends to prevent this problem from reoccurring.

Problem: Old paint is peeling and is probably lead, especially the bottom layer. The window trim is where this is obvious; other parts of the house have been re-painted.
Solution: Have the home tested for lead. Note- young kids have been and  will be living in home.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install. Note- wood stove

Problem: Old windows are hard to open.
Solution: Loosen stuck windows

Problem: Leaky oil tank.
Solution: Her son tried to fix this but she says it still leaks a bit

Problem: Window sills have some rot
Solution: Replace rotten wood- the sills are made of beveled 2” thick wood (smoothed). Caulk & paint.

Problem: Water is running down  a post on the corner of the porch (see prob. 1) and has started to rot the floorboards. Floorboards are generally weathered and splintering.
Solution: Take the weight off the post(s). (support with 2x4’s). You may have to remove the post(s), which would involve taking the railing loose.  Remove part of the floor. Check the framing for damage. Replace a 4’ x 16 1/2’ section. The existing flooring is tongue and groove yellow pine, ¾ “ thick. This stuff may be hard to find, try DT Ramsey (656-2754). Rent a flooring nailer (General Equipment Rental in Weaverville). Install flooring. Prime and paint. Warning- you may have to remove a few pieces of asbestos siding during floor repair – use appropriate respirator.

Problem: Water is leaking from the gutters and causing some rot on the soffit and fascia. Gutters are circa 1959.
Solution: Take off gutters. Replace and paint (white) the damaged fascia material. Install new gutters. Joe from Mars Hill Hardware may be a good guy for this, but get him to come out and give an estimate. More downspouts may be needed, she would like to have about 90’ of gutters replaced.

Problem: Back porch floor has a hole and some rot
Solution: Repair with pressure treated material. You may have to temporarily brace the roof  with double 2x4’s to get the weight off of the porch floor.

Problem: Outer edge of the porch roof is leaking; water gets behind the gutters.
Solution: Replace any fascia materials that have rotted. Replace damaged OSB. Replace shingles. Install drip edge (client has this). Install gutters (23’).

Problem: Client requests some trees be taken down on the uphill side of the house. Warning- power line
Solution: Call tree man

Problem: Overloaded circuit with loose breaker
Solution: Consult electrician. They have a relative who is an electrician.

Problem: Room next to kitchen (used as a pantry) has sunk in. Joists are close to the ground.
Solution: This room is 10’ x 11’. There is a fridge and some furniture here that will have to be moved. Tear up the floor and replace or reinforce the joists. There is probably termite damage. Install new plywood and flooring (don’t get the cheapest stuff; it doesn’t last). Good volunteer job.

Problem: Spongy floor in bathroom. A handicap toilet and a walk- in shower have been installed. The floor has been repaired where the shower is but it needs work under the toilet.
Solution: Remove floor material and  toilet. Remove bad subfloor. Reinforce joists and add new plywood. Install vinyl plank flooring. A 55” x 72” section of floor will need replacement.

Problem: roaches
Solution: pest control

Problem: Co/smoke detectors needed
Solution: install CO/smoke detector

Problem: Radon test requested
Solution: Radon test

Problem: Newer part of the house was never finished. 3rd bathroom (upstairs) toilet, vanity and shower are there but not installed. There is a small water heater in the 2nd bathroom. This bathroom could be made into a good bathroom, as it appears to work. No floor covering on 2nd floor
Solution: At the very least, plug up exposed drains to keep cold air out. It is questionable whether this part of the house should be finished at this point. There is no heater in the newer part of the house.

Problem: Cook Stove shorted out , probably due to rats chewing the wires. Breaker tripped when attempted to plug in. She has not used the kitchen in 7 yrs.
Solution: Repair or replace stove. It is a propane stove that also plugs in . She has a 20 lb (grill size) propane tank hooked up to run it but says it never worked right. The refrigerator works.

Problem: House is hard to heat
Solution: This is a tough problem. There is too much house for 1 person. One idea might be to install a sink in the lower part of the house (there are two 2” drains sticking out of the wall that you could hook up to a sink) and close off the rest of the house so it wouldn’t have to be heated in the winter. This idea should be discussed with Debra.

Problem: Rusty wood stove pipe
Solution: Replace. Need about 8’ of  6” pipe and 1 elbow

Problem: Oil heater needs to be serviced. She has not run it in 3 yrs
Solution: Service heater. It is a “Laser 73”. She claims to have a full tank of oil. Service guys- Von Hamby 273-1535 or Rusty Earley 712-6346

Problem: Big rat hole in drywall
Solution: Patch drywall

Problem: House is extremely cluttered. Rat and dog waste in house.
Solution: Massive cleanup. Dispose of waste, remove trash and haul to dump. Talk to Debra about making some kind of dog fence to keep them from messing up the house.  Get rid of rats (Eden Pest Control in Marshall).

Problem: Mold in bathroom
Solution: This is probably due to the toilet leak, or drainage issues outside. Fix toilet, clean gutters on outside. Clean room with bleach water and re- paint

Problem: Water is leaking slowly around toilet. Float mechanism doesn’t work right (1999 toilet)
Solution: Replace toilet and wax ring.

Problem: Bathtub faucet leaks and is unstable
Solution: Replace faucet- Price Pfister brand,1999 see photos

Problem: Dryer doesn’t work
Solution: Rig up clothesline outside

Problem: Cold water is not getting to the washing machine
Solution: Detach washer hoses from wall, see if they are clogged, check shut offs

Problem: Inadequate hot water
Solution: We think one element is burned out. See photos for brand and serial #. Water htr. Is less than 3 yrs old. Test to see which is burned out and replace.

Problem: Pressure switch for pump has exposed wires (pump is inside the house).
Solution: Turn power off, rewire pump so that the plastic cover will fit back on it

Problem: Silt in water. Debra claims that the well was never “cased” and gets a lot of silt in it. 2 pumps have been replaced in the last 15 yrs.
Solution: Change water filter. Debra claims to have one. Has not been changed in 3 yrs.

Problem: No working smoke/ co detector.
Solution: Install smoke/CO detector

Problem: Underpinning needed around back
Solution: Install 2x4 pressure treated frame. Add insulation board.

Problem: Old linoleum flooring is worn out in several rooms.
Solution: Install medium- quality laminate flooring. Hallway- 25 square feet Living room- 110 sft

Problem: Outlet on porch doesn’t work. The electrical system is old( fuse box) but no shorts were reported.
Solution: Replace outlet (consult electrician)

Problem: Plumbing vent needs work.
Solution: Twist up the elbow sticking out of the back side. Glue on a stick of 1 ½” pipe to the elbow (there is one on site). Figure out a way to hold it up.

Problem: Back steps need reinforcement.
Solution: Put solid concrete blocks under the stringers. Add pickets to the handrails.

Problem: Bathroom work needed. This is the only bathroom in the house. Floor is fairly solid but has a noticeable dip due to old leaks. Toilet has sunk down.
Solution: Talk to Willard about this. Right now there is a window in the shower stall. The shower faucet is jury- rigged. New tub faucet fixture needed. Take out shower faucet, install new surround (tile or tub surround under window would work here).  The floor may be ok under the tub. Tub is metal (30” x 60”) and seems in good shape. Take out toilet, remove old flooring, reinforce joists, install new plywood, install flooring (24 sft.). install new toilet. Note- the water heater is in this room and has been turned off. Note- you can access the bath plumbing from the back side (laundry/living room).

Problem: Front door does not close
Solution: Replace front door with new door w/ storm door

Problem: Water heater does not work
Solution: Install new water heater

Problem: Water lines are not insulated
Solution: Winterize water pipes

Problem: Heat system and ductwork not working properly
Solution: Install new heat pump and seal duct work

Problem: Underpinning and belly liner missing/damaged
Solution: Install new belly liner and underpinning

Problem: Rear door has air leaks
Solution: Add weatherstripping

Problem: New windows needed. Some are broken, some are single pane with no storm windows.
Solution: Install double pane windows that open. Kitchen windows rough opening size- 1) 32 ½”w x 52” h 2) 32” w x 32 ½” h Living room window- Rough opening is 53”h x 65”w

Problem: Interior needs painting where drywall was replaced
Solution: Finish drywall repairs & paint living room and bedroom. USE ONLY ZERO VOC PAINTS!

Problem: Mold noticed under kitchen sink and in crawlspace
Solution: Repair sink drain leak. Clean out the junk from the crawlspace.

Problem: Kitchen counter and cabinets
Solution: Replace kitchen cabinets and counter (12’). At the very least add a plywood shelf to the cabinet under the sink

Problem: Floor damage in corner of bedroom (soft spot). The floor damage from the kitchen extends into this room.
Solution: Remove old flooring (carpet), remove old plywood, reinforce joists if needed, install new plywood. This room needs new flooring but not as bad as the rest of the house.

Problem: Hole in master closet floor
Solution: Cover hole in floor with plywood. An attempt has been made but this still needs work. Critters can crawl thru floor into wall.

Problem: Plumbing issues at kitchen sink
Solution: Repair kitchen sink drain

Problem: Kitchen floor is spongy. A piece of plywood has been put over a hole. Sink drain leak has caused the floor to rot.
Solution: Repair drain leak. Check for other leaks (right now water is turned off). Remove fridge , stove, etc.  Remove old flooring. Remove old plywood. I am not sure what the plywood thickness is here ; it’s probably ¾ but you should remove some first and measure. (you will probably have to take up ½ of this floor. Scab joists if needed. Replace plywood. Install new flooring. The floor size is approx.. 100 square feet.

Problem: Hall bedroom has mold/water damage
Solution: Remove all moldy sheetrock. Install new sheetrock, repair any holes and paint bedroom. Reinstall ceiling fan.

Problem: Hall bath has bad water damage
Solution: Remove floor covering. Inspect and repair sub-flooring as necessary. Replace floor covering, wall board, vanity, toilet and linen closet. Install towel racks, toilet paper racks and new floor vent. Repair tub surround. Install new bathtub faucets. Re-trim bathroom door.

Problem: Minor deck repair needed
Solution: Install 10 pickets on the guard rail

Problem: Water on floor in bathroom around toilet. Flush box leaking.
Solution: Install new flush box gaskets, bolts, etc. Angela mentioned that Tommy from Mars Hill Baptist was coming to look at this.

Problem: Chimney needed for wood stove. The old flue is cracked. Single wall black pipe goes thru a paneled wall with not much clearance (see photos)
Solution: Tear down old chimney. Install a modern, stainless steel chimney , ceiling box, and new black pipe. You will have to replace some roofing shingles.

Problem: Shower valve has a leak
Solution: Tighten connections. Accessible from the back (uncovered).

Problem: Roof leaks. Cao cut holes in the roof and patched them, but the leaks seem to mostly come from the ends and walls.
Solution: Membrane. Trailer is 15’ wide by 69’ long. There are two 3 ½” vents and one square metal bath fan vent (may have to remove for membrane). Note- this roof is a 4/12 gable (steep for a single wide).

Problem: Moisture can be seen and felt in the hallway wall.Probably due to a roof leak.
Solution: After fixing the roof, Replace wall covering, repair framing and add new insulation if necessary.

Problem: Electrical problems. There are several outlets and switches in the kitchen and bathroom that do not work and there are loose wires sticking out of the wall. The breaker for the bath fan
Solution: Contact electrician ASAP. It looks like this is the result of incomplete volunteer work when they were trying to fix the drywall. They messed with the wiring while they were doing the drywall job and it dosen’t work any more. New remodel boxes may be needed.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Client was concerned about roof leaks. The drywall was sagging in the hallway ceiling and she thought it was caused by a leak.
Solution: An attic inspection revealed no leaks. The drywall has sagged probably due to the screws pulling away over the years. This could be fixed but doesn’t seem like a super high priority.  The roof is pretty old, but does not seem to be leaking anywhere yet. This will be a messy job- use drop cloths and shopvac

Problem: Chimney cap needed for woodstove chimney. Rain can get in stove.
Solution: Get a chimney cap that fits a 16” x 16” masonry chimney. As an alternative, metal flashing could be used to fabricate something to keep the rain out. Make sure to leave plenty of room for the smoke to come out and make it removable for chimney cleaning.

Problem: Client requests more energy efficient windows. Hers leak and are the old single panes, with storm windows. None are broken but some will not open and close properly.
Solution: Replace 3 windows. They are 35” high by 31 ¼” wide. Get double pane, double hung with screens.

Problem: The weatherhead  area for the electrical service looks sketchy. The insulation is missing on the main power line coming out of the weatherhead. There is a wire going out to the well pump that looks sketchy. On the inside there are several outlets that need work. There is some spliced wiring in the attic. The whole house runs on 4 fuses. There are not enough outlets in the house.
Solution: Upgrade needed. New breaker box and meter are needed. Contact Jeremy Wallin or other electrician to work with French Broad EMC to get her an upgrade. Her friend , David, has volunteered to help with repairs.

Problem: Joy’s chicken coop was hit by a windstorm. The roof blew off and it is leaning at a heavy angle. It is still in use, but someone could help her repair or rebuild this building.
Solution: Repair or rebuild chicken house. Salvage existing materials. Talk to Joy about this project.

Problem: Bathroom needs new floor material.
Solution: Install 30 sft. Vinyl planks.

Problem: Bathroom ceiling needs paint
Solution: paint

Problem: Electrical issues in bathroom.
Solution: According to Joy, Kevin Rector (an electrician) did some work that was not satisfactory. Get another electrician to check it out.

Problem: There is a lot of trash inside and outside of the home. The place has been used for storage for a long time. There is a moldy smell
Solution: Clean out and get rid of stuff

Problem: Second bathroom needs complete remodel.
Solution: Tear out tub, toilet, & fixtures. Replace floor, get new tub , toilet . State of plumbing unknown.

Problem: Wet crawlspace; bad drainage around house. Gutters are failing
Solution: This trailer has a concrete and block foundation, seemingly in good shape. Plastic should be put down to reduce further moisture coming up from the ground. The area around the trailer is flat and the downspouts drain out close to the foundation. Some kind of drainage solution should be found , which would involve lots of digging and black pipe. Install new gutters and keep em clean.

Problem: Electrical problem in several rooms
Solution: Consult electrician; may just be a bad GFI  breaker

Problem: No shower head
Solution: Install a shower head once the water pressure problem is resolved.

Problem: Roof has several bad leaks; 2 big holes in porch roof
Solution: The shingles don’t look too bad; this might could be patched instead of totally re-roofed. The pitch of the main roof  is slightly less than 3/12 and the square footage is1224. The front porch sf is 247. The small addition in the back is 100 sf and has a metal roof.  There are two 12” Turbine-style attic vents here, but more roof ventilation is probably needed. There are two- 2” vent pipes and one 2” hole. There is one 6” metal vent pipe. The power pole and the weather head both penetrate the roof. This hole is about 10” x 8”.  All need tar and / or boots.

Problem: There are several weak spots in the floor. There is one place, covered by plywood where there is a good-sized hole
Solution: Tear up carpet, tear out old subfloor       ( probably 5/8 pressboard), reinforce joists, replace flooring

Problem: New toilet needed. The old one is cracked.
Solution: Replace toilet. Joy has a new toilet, it just has not been installed. She has wax ring and bolts.

Problem: There is a steady leak around where the water supply comes into the house (under the water heater). Main water supply is not working right, it will not shut the water off completely.
Solution: Replace main water shutoff. This is a gravity- fed system with a reservoir up the hill. There is a shutoff  there that feeds 2 houses. (talk to Bradley about which one). If this shutoff works then the lower one at the house can be replaced. There may be some other plumbing leaks.

Problem: Water Heater is leaking. It was bought used 10 yrs. ago.  The floor underneath the heater is bad.
Solution: Replace water heater. It is a 2 element , short Envi-ro temp heater. Water goes in and out through 1” galvanized pipes.

Problem: Lots of trash and debris in and around home. The house is very cluttered and this will be a big job. The upstairs of the home also has lots of trash and old stuff.
Solution: Get a truck or trailer and haul stuff off (Joy has a truck but it does not run). Take construction related trash to the landfill (dump card number needed). Consult with Joy about what stays and what goes.

Problem: Floor is bad under water heater.
Solution: Remove old water heater. Replace subfloor and joists if neccesarry.

Problem: It is not known how much insulation is in the attic because there is no access.
Solution: Cut an access hole and look to see how much insulation is up there. Add more blown- in insulation if needed.

Problem: Insulation is missing under the house.
Solution: Install insulation in floor and around pipes. Joists are 2x6 on 16” centers.

Problem: New doorknob needed. This is the doorway from the porch to the kitchen.
Solution: Drill a new hole in the door. Install a new knob and repair the old holes in the door.

Problem: New screen door needed
Solution: Rough opening is 31 ¾” x 80”

Problem: Drainage issues- flat yard, no gutters.
Solution: Grading, drainpipes, gutters. The trailer is 67’ long x 12’ wide with a 24’ x 16’ framed addition.

Problem: Joy does not have good enough water pressure to run a shower. She has a gravity fed system. She says she needs a new water line. The old one is from the 1960’s.
Solution: Bury a new water line. A bigger diameter water line would provide better water flow and pressure. Joy says she will measure length of line needed and provide that info to CHC. It will be at least 500 feet. She recently had her reservoir cleaned out so some silt could have gotten in the line.

Problem: Bonnie is concerned about energy efficiency. DJ says there is very little insulation in the walls. She spends a lot on electricity for heat and cooling. She would like to install more energy efficient windows.
Solution: Community Action opportunities should be contacted for this job- 828-252- 2495. Install windows. Bonnie has 4 insulated windows- they are 46 ¾” x 72”. She would like to replace her single panes with these. Note- the rough opening would have to be made higher somehow. Two windows would go on the front porch and two would go out back.

Problem: Water froze last winter. DJ is repairing the plumbing. Cold air comes in behind shower in second bathroom. This bathroom is not used but she would like to use it again.
Solution: Install underpinning, pipe insulation. Check with homeowner about what progress has been made with plumbing and underpinning.

Problem: Kitchen sink drains into the creek. Joy says it drains very slowly due to a clog.
Solution: Tie drain to septic

Problem: Gutters and fascia board needed. Drainage needed. One fascia board is rotten.
Solution: Install gutters, downspouts, and drainpipe. This may be a good job for a pro gutter man (Joe at Mars Hill Hardware). because of the roof angles. Fascia is 1” x 6 “x 10’.

Problem: Paint Bedroom Living room and hallway to kitchen.

Some places on the ceiling of the porch and inside have water damage and will need repair once the roof is fixed. Tongue and groove material. Warning- Removing old painted material could release lead dust. The bottom layer of paint is more than likely lead since the house was built in 1925.
Solution: Replace t&g material and repaint. The whole house was scraped and painted in 2007.

Problem: Water Heater
Solution: Purchased and Installed

Problem: Oil furnace not working
Solution: Repair or replace- Mayberry Heating?

Problem: Roof leaks. Paint is peeling and wood paneling has been damaged under the porch and inside the house, visible from upstairs. Joy feels strongly that a full on re-roof is necessary. She says that a pro roofer came out and recommended total roof re-shingling. She could not recall his name, however.
Solution: Terry with JAS went out and looked and said it needed a full re-roof because the shingles and flashingswere installed incorrectly.
Contractor: JAS (Mars Hill) Hardware (dba JAS of Weaverville)

Problem: Smoke detectors are old, no CO detector
Solution: Install new co/smoke detector

Problem: Oven door is broken
Solution: Replace oven door.  Ask homeowner about brand of oven. Check on replacement of glass only

Problem: Front door won’t shut right. Screw missing in strike plate.
Solution: Install screw in strike plate, make adjustments

Problem: Gutters falling down
Solution: Install new gutters. Approx. 100 lf needed. Downspouts, black pipe needed.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Drywall patching needed.
Solution: Patch holes with fiberglass tape, mud, drywall and screws. Paint.

Problem: Screen door requested
Solution: Install screen door 32” x 74”

Problem: There is a wall next to the oven that is not well supported at the top.
Solution: Find ceiling joist locations. Install wide trim that buts up against the wall to support it.

Problem: The other bathroom needs paint and flooring.
Solution: 25 square feet flooring needed. Vinyl snap together laminate recommended.

Problem: Bathroom door needed.
Solution: Install a 28” x 80” door with knob.

Problem: The family needs help remodeling a second bathroom. There is a shower stall that they want to remove and install a bigger one(the old one is only 20” wide). The old stall can be donated to CHC.
Solution: Carefully Remove old stall so that it can be reused. Install new shower or tub and surround. It needs to be 54” x 30”. Install a new bathroom sink. They have a cabinet that measures 29 ½”wide x 34” deep. They have a toilet but its condition is unknown. The bathroom is 4 ½’ wide x 13’ long. Flooring , drywall, and paint will be needed here.

Problem: Basement door needs work. Shed roof over basement door needs work
Solution: Install door knob and strike plate, Drill another hole for the doorknob lower down. Rebuild shed roof.

Problem: There is a roof leak between the porch roof and the trailer roof. No other current leaks were reported but an old leak that has been repaired has causes ceiling damage in a bedroom closet. Water is getting into the walls of the trailer and causing damage, especially around the windows.
Solution: The short term solution is to Kool Seal this roof. Two coats are required. Add Roofing cement around all penetrations and over the flashing between the porch and trailer roof. This will not last long, however. A membrane will be needed, or a metal overbuild. The roof measures 14’ x 65’. It is a gable roof with a 3/12 pitch (estimate). There are 2 plumbing vents, 1 ½” and 2”, one 8” furnace pipe, one 6’ fan pipe. Extensions will be needed for the plumbing vents, but everything else has the extra 1 ½” room for a membrane roof with insulation.

Problem: A kitchen light is not working properly; it flickers.
Solution: Check bulb connection. Could be loose wiring.

Problem: There is some exposed wiring in the second, unfinished bathroom.
Solution: Finish wiring and put up drywall

Problem: There is an outlet that is hanging out of the wall. It may need a new box and to be rewired.
Solution: Rewire with box

Problem: Basement steps broken
Solution: Repair or replace steps.

Problem: Lisa says that the electric cook stove sometimes shorts out , causing shocks. They cut off the breaker for safety when the stove is not in use.
Solution: This could be the fault of the stove or an underlying wiring issue. Have an electrician look at it. The stove also has an eye that doesn’t work.

Problem: Basement is cluttered with debris
Solution: Haul off trash, clean up broken glass,etc.

Problem: No insulation in floor
Solution: Install rigid foam or unfaced fiberglass  insulation aprox. 1200 sf.  2x8’s on 16” centers

Problem: Drywall damage in one bedroom
Solution: Patch and paint. Note- this damage is probably due to a leaky window

Problem: Old single pane windows leak air, some are broken.
Solution: Replace all windows with double pane, single or double hung. (caution- exterior lead paint) It looks like all windows measure 27”w x 54”high

Problem: Ceilings and walls are stained with soot
Solution: Clean and Paint interior of house. The living room (where you first walk in ) tested neg. for lead but more lead testing should be done in the interior. House floor sf is 1560

Problem: Hole in Bathroom floor, under tub/shower. Hole in ceiling, above tub/shower.  Tub faucet is missing handles and leaks. Bathroom drainpipe leaks.
Solution: Remove Fiberglass tub/shower unit. Repair framing (2x8). Repair subfloor. Install new tub/shower unit. Existing unit is 29 ½” wide, 59 ¼” long and 6, high. Ceiling height is 7’5”.   Install new faucets and plumbing. Repair/ replace drain. Install new vinyl snap together flooring. Repair damaged drywall. Paint. Square footage of this bathroom is 81.The bathroom is accessible from underneath via a full basement.

Problem: Clean driveway and install road gutters.
Solution: Clear all weed and debris from driveway and dig trenches for road gutters.

Problem: Back door will not open. there are 2 more exits but you have to go thru one door to get to them
Solution: New exterior trailer door. Note- trailer framing is not square or level.

Problem: The woodshed and another shed are cluttered
Solution: Clean out and haul stuff to the dump or scrap yard.

Problem: The Thomas's want to make a new living space in the metal building.
Solution: Pour a 30’ x 70’ slab (insulated with blue board) and begin building on it.

Problem: The plumbing in the trailer is in bad shape.. They bucket flush the toilet and bathe with buckets of water heated on the stove. They have an on-demand water heater but it has not been installed.
Solution: The bathroom needs a complete remodel. New PEX plumbing needed. There is subfloor damage. New tub needed. Re-set toilet. New vanity and faucet needed. Tear out old water heater closet so a regular-sized tub can fit there. Keep in mind the cost as opposed to building a new bathroom in the metal building.

Problem: The family has intermittent water. When it is cold they do not have running water because their water line (on top of the ground) would freeze. They unhook it and drain it in cold weather. They recently spent $4000.00 on a well that came up dry.
Solution: The family needs reliable running water. They have decided not to try drilling again. Instead, Lew has a plan to use the existing spring-fed gravity water system to supply the home. He needs a new reservoir (350 gal order from Parker Farm Supply) which he will install in the new barn to supply the home and the barn, if and when they move into it. He will need some kind of solar-powered pump assist to supply the barn because there is not much fall between the existing reservoir and the barn. He wants to install the reservoir on a raised platform.

Problem: Back steps are sketchy- not attached to building
Solution: Replace steps- about 28” high

Problem: Exterior paint tests positive for lead. Exterior siding is asbestos.
Solution: Cover with vinyl siding 1500 sf

Problem: Roof leaks. Homeowners mention mold on the ceiling and on the living room wall
Solution: Climb up on the roof and patch with roof cement. Look for places where nails have come loose. Add nails or screws or refasten.

Problem: Old fusebox. Two 220-outlets in the kitchen do not work. The fuses did not look like they were blown, however.
Solution: electrical upgrade needed

Problem: Ramp at front entrance is too steep. The Thomases want a less steep ramp so they can roll a wheelbarrow with firewood up to the stove room.
Solution: Tear off old ramp and build a new one. It should be the same width at the top, but it will have to get narrower at the bottom. Try to make it drop no less than 1” every 10 inches.
install
install
Repair

Problem: Weak spot in floor. This is right when you walk in the front door. The family has removed the carpet in the room, exposing the pres-board subfloor material in the original trailer.
Solution: Remove furniture. Put a layer of 5/8 plywood over the top of the old stuff. Mark the plywood so that you will nail into the floor joists. Lew mentioned that he would try to fix a temporary solution to this problem (put a piece of sheet metal over it ).
Clean
Replace
Clean
repair
Needs wiring, repair electrical
Call Von Hamby

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Stains on upstairs ceiling could be water damage from a roof leak
Solution: Repair Roof. There are some stains on the upstairs ceiling paneling and a sunken place on the front porch roof corner. The shingles on the roof do not look 20 yrs. old. The chimneys should be re -flashed or at least patched with tar. Re-roof the kitchen porch (which looks like it did not get shingled along with the rest of the roof last time). The square footage of the porch roof is 200 sf. The rest of the roof was not accurately measured.

Problem: Wobbly handrail -interior- leads to upstairs room.
Solution: Reinforce handrail The staircase leading to the second floor of the house has a wobbly handrail. Use timber-locks and 2x4’s

Problem: The plywood floor of the porch is pretty worn out. Framing underneath may need some reinforcement.
Solution: Replace the plywood with ¾” oak or pressure treated boards. If the material is thicker it could interfere with the opening of the kitchen door. Porch boards must be even with ramp.

Problem: Handicap ramp needed
Solution: Install handicap ramp Ind. Living might do this. The ramp would be built off the back porch. It would be about 24” high. It would have to have a 180 degree turn in it. Build hand rails and make sure the slope does not exceed 1 in 12. The ramp should be 48” wide.

Problem: Bathroom needs work.
Solution: Remodel bathroom. Rosetta is a client of Independent Living and has had a visit from Lori Massey. There has been talk of a complete bathroom remodel including a walk in shower and a higher commode.

Problem: Rotten floor- kitchen
Solution: Replace flooring. Floor underneath kitchen sink is rotten. there are some active leaks (slow). Remove faucet, sink, cabinets. Remove old flooring and subfloor. Check for framing damage and repair if needed. Replace subfloor. You may want to install new floor material at this point. Install a new countertop, sink, cabinets, and faucet. The old countertop is 67” x 25”. The sink is 33” x 22”.

Problem: Leaky toilet water supply line
Solution: Repair or replace water line There is a leak in the toilet water supply line.  It is visible as a drip under the house.  Repair or replace water line. Check for damage to floor

Problem: Drain leak
Solution: Fix drain pipe The 2” drain line from the washing machine has come loose from a “T” that then drains into the septic system. I tried to stick it back together but was unsuccessful. Cut a short piece of 2” drainpipe and glue it in place with a coupling.

Problem: Termite damage
Solution: "Restruct damaged wood One of Rosetta’s bedrooms has suffered extensive termite damage. The oak sills (8”x8”) have been damaged and the floor joists (2x 8’s) are rotten and broken. Cover doorways to this room with plastic to prevent dust getting into other parts of the house. remove furniture. Remove hardwood (oak) flooring. Remove subfloor. Re-structure damaged sill. You may have to jack up some places. Replace joists and/or scab on. Install new plywood. Install new floor covering. Note- damage could extend into the bathroom. "

Problem: No smoke or CO detector
Solution: Install Smoke/CO detector

Problem: Yard work needed
Solution: Patsy needs help with yard and garden work. Outside Jobs- 1) Weeding 2) Weed eat. 3) Help with raised beds 4)Do some maintenance on her garden shed.

Problem: Owner requests 28” x 80” screen door.
Solution: Make door and install.  This can be homemade; not a stock size.

Problem: Back door needs work. this is the one leading to a deck through an enclosed porch. The door is damaged and hard to close.
Solution: Install new exterior door (36" x 80") with jams and an attached screen door.

Problem: Grab bar needed in bathroom
Solution: Re mount grab bar. Patsy needs to have a grab bar re- mounted in her bathroom It is currently on the outside of her shower and she would like to have it on the inside. The shower walls are pretty thin- you may have to get some kind of screw anchors.

Problem: Need grab bar on front entrance
Solution: Install grab bar Patsy needs a grab bar to be mounted where her front door is, so she can step up into her front entrance. Install grab bar

Problem: Roof concerns. There is a bad leak, according to Patsy, in her bedroom.
Solution:
Patsy has a shingle roof. The shingles are about 20 yrs. old. Roof is aprox. 2200 sft. Roof metal on porches is still good.

Patsy wants a metal roof. This is a good idea because of the windy location. Patsy has gotten some quotes. From talking to her, it seems that the price of a new shingle roof would be covered by her insurance policy. However, she has been talking to some contractors and she wants to have a metal roof installed. The insurance money will not cover all of this cost.  

Right now the roof is tarped.

Since insurance is involved, no action is required right now, but I told her to keep us informed of developments.

Problem: Tree Branches crowding roof
Solution: Trim Branches

Problem: Clogged gutters
Solution: Clean gutters

Problem: Unfinished metal roof
Solution: Install metal roofing, color green On top of shingles-last piece must be cut lengthwise

Problem: Missing shingles, old tar
Solution: Patch around chimney, replace shingles

Problem: Water comes down chimney
Solution: Install 2 chimney caps. One chimney is used (could make from scrap metal)

Problem: Rotten porch roof
Solution: Remove old porch posts & roof, replace/re-use posts. Porch floor is solid concrete, roof is aprox. 7’x22’

Problem: Exterior siding needs caulking
Solution: Caulk siding at addition

Problem: Sill at steps rotted
Solution: Replace sill

Problem: Porch post rotted
Solution: "Replace post -Post replaced, cement pillar installed to support porch joists, hand railings and floor boards replaced.  8 4'x4, 12' 1x6, 14' 1x4"

Problem: Flooring damage in living room, hallway, and bedroom
Solution: Replace flooring

Problem: Back deck needs work
Solution: Repair rails with 2x4 pt, Build step handrails. Brace 4x4 posts. Deck height 37”.

Problem: Retaining wall has collapsed in the yard
Solution: Recommended: Backhoe or crew with experience. This is between the house and the road ( Ivy Hill Rd). Don says the state won’t pay for it. See photos

Problem: Small leak in kitchen sink; may be in the basket or around the sink itself
Solution: Fill sink and diagnose leak

Problem: Heating problems.A small propane heater is installed but it does not work. A small electric heater is the only heat they had in the winter of 2016-2017. The heater , when plugged in ,caused damage to the outlet (black marks).
Solution: Repair the propane heater, or get them a new electric unit.

Problem: Bad corner in second bedroom. This is connected to the bad floor in the second bathroom. Lots of “give” in floor
Solution: Remove furniture, tear up floor, reinforce joists, insulate, replace plywood.This bedroom was worked on in 2016 by a group from Glory Ridge. They repaired the floor and installed new floor covering, and new wall paneling. Unfortunately moisture is still getting in the walls here, probably due to a roof leak. The paneling has buckled . After the roof is fixed, new paneling and framing reinforcement should be done

Problem: Roof leak
Solution: According to the homeowners this isn’t a big problem, but the roof is old, and evidence of some leaks was found. This roof looks very “wavy” on top, and may have some structural problems according to Don, who is hesitant to allow anyone to stand on it.Might be a good place to try a metal overbuild? Roof is 4/12 pitch gable roof, trailer is 62’ long, roof is 7’ on either side.

Problem: Insulation in crawlspace is soaking wet in some places. The plastic that holds up the insulation is holding water. I suspect that there is some kind of plumbing leak, possibly around the washing machine, However, I couldn’t tell for sure. It may be that water from a roof leak is getting in the walls and collecting under there. I didn’t hear anything dripping.
Solution: A plumber may be able to diagnose the problem and repair it; this crawlspace is pretty tight, especially on the uphill side.

Problem: Moisture is getting in the back room in the wall somewhere.  Could be due to a roof leak.
Solution: Remove  wall paneling. It is not nailed very well. Replace any damaged or moldy materials. Don says he thinks water has been getting in this wall and caused a short.

Problem: Electrical problems. Lots of outlets don’t work. Some lights work intermittently. A short was reported in the back room.
Solution: Get an electrician out there. Jeremy Wallin or David Caldwell recommended.

Problem: Second bathroom needs remodel. Floor is spongy all around the toilet and tub. The water heater closet floor is totally rotten and the water heater is perched in the outside band of the trailer frame. The first bathroom has a walk in shower and a toilet, but the vanity is not plumbed.
Solution:
Remove toilet, tub, and hot water heater. Vanity works,and the floor under it seems ok, but is old and might be a good time to replace it. Repair floor with new plywood, reinforce joists. Note that the floor damage extends under the bathroom wall and into the bedroom. This bathroom is 6’ x 7’. The ceiling height is 83”. Tub size 27” x 54”x 19” high.

The tub is a trailer size unit, best ordered from Discount Mobile Home Supply in Weaverville.

I reccomend that new plumbing be installed in the bathroom running on the inside of the room. The reason is that the trailer is very close to the ground and really hard to get under.

After the subfloor is repaired, install new plumbing fixtures, plumbing, and a new tub and surround.

install new floor material. approx. 36 sq. ft.

install new commode.

There is a second commode in the far bedroom, so this could be used while the remodel is going on.

Problem: Weak corner in bedroom.
Solution: The bed is very heavy and is sitting on this weak spot. Remove bed. Remove old plywood, repair framing, insulate, and install plywood. An unsuccessful repair was attempted here. There could be some foundation problems in this corner, it is very close to the ground.

Problem: Yard work needed
Solution: Believe this is a pipe leak underground. Statement from St. Stephens says "Dug up and identified leak at Blue House." Will follow up with group leaders and resident.

Problem: leak at blue house
Solution: Identified leak at the Blue House (Additional structure on the property). Believe this is a pipe leak underground. Statement from St. Stephens says "Dug up and identified leak at Blue House." Will follow up with group leaders and resident.

Problem: No smoke/CO detector
Solution: Install smoke/CO detector

Problem: Lots of clutter.
Solution: Help move boxes, etc.

Problem: Washing machine leaks
Solution: Replace machine (she has one on site).

Problem: 2 new door knobs needed.
Solution: One exterior, locking, one with no locks

Problem: Porch repair needed
Solution: Repair porch There is a post and some floorboards that need to be replaced. Steps need to be rebuilt with a hand rail. Temporarily support post, replace floorboards and post. Build new steps and hand rail( 30”). Use on-site rough sawn oak (client requests no pressure treated), which Vicky claims is there.

Problem: Low efficent windows
Solution: Replace with high efficent windows Lots of single pane windows  Refer to Community Action (252-2495)

Problem: Leaky roof
Solution: Patch roof Roof leaks. 25 yr old 3-tab shingles. Main part of roof is about 3/12; other parts are steeper. Patch leaks around the chimney with roof cement. Patch area around vent boot with roof caulk and new shingles.  If that doesn’t stop the leaks, then re- roof. Roof is approximately 1350 square feet. She has 2 long extension ladders.

Problem: Bad stove pipe
Solution: Install new stove pipe Better stovepipe setup needed for wood stove; the black pipe is too close to the ceiling and has damaged it. Install double- wall section of stovepipe; get heating man

Problem: Back door trim rotten.
Solution: Replaced damaged wood around back door.The  floor here is concrete.

Problem: Gutter work needed
Solution: Install more gutter screws on the gutter on the back side. Clean gutters. Vicky has two good extension ladders. Hook up a downspout and a buried black pipe (6’) to the existing culvert/ ditch.

Problem: Rotten siding
Solution: Two windowsills have bad water damage as well. Tear off rotten siding, repair damaged framing, install new siding. The siding is ¾” x 6” rough sawn. There is probably quite a bit of this material on-site, as there are many piles of lumber around. If the wood isn’t there you could get it from DT Ramsey Lumber, 656- 2754. Siding must be painted. There are several areas that need work but mainly the back corner and back side.

Problem: Water is getting into the back side of the house. It runs through a room.
Solution: "Drainage needed, there is a culvert that carries water away and under the house. There is a solar hot water panel leaning against the back side of the house (not hooked up). Remove this panel and check for leaks in the blockwork. Note- this part of the house is block (partway up) with a concrete slab floor. You may have to dig down around the block , let it dry and re- seal.  This would be a good place for a French drain. "

Problem: There is a second- floor porch that is falling down.
Solution: Tear off porch. Leave the 2 supporting telephone poles and the 2x8 between them for the grapevines.

Problem: Electrical problems. Several outlets don’t work. She has turned off several circuits because she suspects rats chewed the wires. There may be a short in a ceiling light.
Solution: Send an electrician to check for shorts and do a safety inspection. Look in attic for chewed wires. She knows Leonard Wilson (Wilson electrical).

Problem: Termites. Damage seen above kitchen stove and around back door.
Solution: She does not want spray. The only other thing that could be done is to remove the wet, rotten wood in the house, replacing moisture- damaged areas in the house.

Problem: Rat infestation
Solution: Vicky has taken steps to fix this problem. She got  a cat, has a rat terrier, and has set out rat traps and poison. She suspects that the rats may have chewed her wiring.

Problem: No co detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Porch ceiling material is damaged due to leak
Solution: Once the roof has been fixed, remove the old plywood on underside of porch rafters. Check for framing damage and repair if necessary.

Problem: Old gutters are clogged and do not work.
Solution: Replace gutters if practical; there is a drainage system in place but I am not sure if the drainpipes are clear. Note that the homeowners will not be able to keep their gutters clean themselves.

Problem: Exterior steps to the basement are busted up.
Solution: Remove block debris. New steps could be made out of block, but I have priced a pressure- treated stairway. The block sides could be used as hand rails.

Problem: Big leak in porch roof. 3-tab shingles are 25 yrs. old.
Solution: Although no complaints were given of leaks in the main part of the home, it is time for a new roof. Tear-off may not be required because the framing is 2x6 on 16” ctrs. with plywood. 1315 square feet. New 2” boot needed. Tar needed around openings. Some new plywood will be needed.

Problem: Unfinished door & siding on north side.
Solution: Install 36 x 80 Exterior door. Install siding (approx.. 320 sf). This side of the house has been covered by a rubber membrane that has not been attached very well. The permanent solution would be to install siding.

Problem: No insulation in floor
Solution: Install rigid foam insulation- 33’ X 24’ space

Problem: Missing siding & insulation- south side
Solution: Install insulation & siding

Problem: Broken storm window
Solution: Replace (34 w x 64 h ).

Problem: Need new stovepipe
Solution: Install new stovepipe and flash onto new roof correctly. Pipe goes straight up.

Problem: Wood stove rusty & has leaks
Solution: Repair or replace with newer stove. Kenneth has another stove available in another building. Existing stove is very heavy.

Problem: Celing needs repair
Solution: Install drywall, retape & mud,paint

Problem: Roof Leaking
Solution: Re-roof with metal (2000 sf). Roof is 34x60 except for one section that is narrower. Owner requests metal, 3 & 12 roof pitch, simple roof with no valleys

Problem: Plumbing under house could freeze
Solution: Remove a couple pieces of underpinning and put some unfaced r-19 or thicker fiberglass insulation under there to cover the exposed plumbing. Use plastic strapping or some pieces of wood to hold it up. You can see where there was a leak here that has been repaired. (I tested for leaks and found none)

Problem: Tub cracked in second bathroom. Faucet does not have good pressure.
Solution: She does not use the tub in this room , and the toilet and vanity faucet work. Not a high priority right now.

Problem: Bedroom windowsill is damaged. There is a 1” hole in one corner of it. This happened due to a lack of overhang on the roof, rain blowing in, etc.
Solution: Build a small gable roof over this window. It is the window on the gable end that is visible when you first pull up in the driveway. Make it match the pitch of the roof, so that water will run off either side of the little roof. Make it 2 feet wide and make the rafters a little less than 4 feet so the metal will cover it. Support it with 2x4 diagonal braces going to the side of the trailer. This would be a good volunteer job if time permits and if the group had decent carpentry skills.

Problem: Moisture is getting in the walls around where the chest of drawers is.
Solution: Remove the chest of drawers and remove the wall covering. Check wall for damage and repair with new framing , insulation , and wall covering. Not sure what the wall covering is- inspect first before buying drywall. This is probably happening due to a small leak in the corner of the roof where the little trailer gutters are. This roof will probably eventually need a membrane. Clean gutters and see if that helps.

Problem: Hole in floor. The carpet is still intact, but if someone steps in the wrong place they could fall through. Weak floor in several parts of the house, mainly in the room where the chest of drawers is (old bedroom) and the area between there and the tub room.
Solution: Remove furniture from room. Put up a plastic barrier to cut down on dust. Remove old blue carpet. Cut out bad subfloor and replace with plywood. It will be either 5/8 or ¾. Shore up joists if needed. When cutting, set your saw depth and watch for electrical wires and HVAC ductwork. You may have to replace at least half of the tub room subfloor, depending on what it looks like when you get into it. Estimated new flooring material needed is 180 square feet. As a temporary fix, I talked to Pat about putting a piece of ½” plywood over the hole. She will talk to her daughter and to the local handyman about making this happen.

Problem: Cabinets and counter in Kitchen need work.
Solution: Need new cabinets and counters.

Problem: decks needs work
Solution: The back steps need to be reinforced and a handrail added. The front deck needs work as well- The steps need reinforcement and the posts need to have some braces added. Handrail needed. it looks like the family started to build a porch but never finished- they really need a place to keep stuff in the dry outside. In order to make a porch roof, however, the deck level may have to drop down so that the roof can have enough fall, and that the rafters can be tied correctly into the trailer. Deck size may have to be reduced so this can happen.

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: Install Membrane. There are 5 2” vents. See photos for typical roof vents. Trailer roof is 14’ x 65’ 10”

Problem: Front door needed
Solution: 32” w x 73 1/2” high

Problem: 2 Window panes broken
Solution: Replace window 53” x 36”. Other window not measured

Problem: Electrical work needed. Short reported in bedroom. Wires are exposed but taped
Solution: Have electrician check it out

Problem: Plumbing leak under house
Solution: Repair leak.There is a drainage ditch dug under the house. Recommended plumbers- Darrel Rathbone or Roland (boss) (A1 plumbing) 776-0530

Problem: Floor is weak under the washing machine, which can’t be used because of a leak.
Solution: Remove washing machine, repair leak, remove old plywood, reinforce joists, replace plywood

Problem: Bathroom unusable
Solution: The second, larger bathroom is unusable due to holes in the floor and missing toilet. The drainpipe to the sink is not hooked up to the septic and drains under the house. The damage to this room has extended under a wall to the adjacent room.  Re- structure floor and completely remodel the bathroom. The room is now locked so kids can’t get in there. This bathroom is 75” x 84”.

Problem: Holes in bedroom
Solution: 2 holes in bedroom. Several holes in bathroom. Soft place in floor under water heater. Hole in kitchen floor next to stove. Hole in front of sink has a piece of plywood over it.  Tear out floor, reinforce joists, replace plywood

Problem: No co detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Yard work needed
Solution: Mowing, weed eating, and brush clearing. Yard was unmowed as of 3-21-16. Robbie has a riding mower which she can operate, and which runs. It is making a noise, and the blades may need to be adjusted. (they may be hitting the side of the blade guard).
Volunteer or Groups:
St. Patrick's (Lebanon);
CC New Bern/St. Mary's Lakewood, WA

Problem: Pile of cinder blocks in yard
Solution: Move to area above garage.

Problem: Gutters around back need to be replaced
Solution: Approx.. 30’ of gutters are needed. Get the wide kind that carry a lot of water. Drainage is in place.

Problem: Clogged gutters
Solution: Gutters on front side have not been cleaned in a long time.  Clean out gutters and down spouts. Make sure the black drain pipes are working. Use a hose to test. Take downspouts apart if necessary. Note- 20’ extension ladder needed (CHC has)

Problem: Loose boards on deck. Paint is peeling on the back deck.
Solution: Nail them down better or replace. Scrape old paint and repaint.

Problem: Rats are getting in the kitchen cabinets
Solution: She has cats that kill some of them, and she sets traps. This helps, but I think they are opening the doors from the outside. Ideas- 1) clean out cabinets and make sure the rats aren’t getting in thru holes in the back (cabinets have backs) 2) install small bolt latches on the outside of the cabinets; some don’t close tight.

Problem: There is no door to one bedroom.
Solution: She has a door- it is in the bedroom. Install door. You may have to trim the door with a circular saw to get it to fit- measurements are tight. It has hinges and a knob.

Problem: Bathroom needs work. There is a soft spot around the toilet due to a slow leak.
Solution: Remove toilet, remove floor covering, replace bad plywood, reinforce floor joists if necessary, put back good plywood, install floor covering (56 square feet), and reinstall toilet with new wax ring and bolts.

Problem: Cluttered shed
Solution: The shed (garage) next to the house is cluttered and needs to be cleaned out. Some stuff is Robbie’s and some stuff is Shawn’s. There is also a pile outside.  Remove old drywall, hardened mortar mix, and other debris. Bag up what you can ; construction debris must go to the landfill (closed most Saturdays; 649-2311). Landfill must have a dump card number.

Problem: Roof leaks and carpentry work is needed around the back side of the house. The soffit has rotted due to water damage from a roof leak caused by lack of overhang and drip edge. Robbie says this is causing water to get in the house and create a mold smell. A couple of pieces of siding are missing up high. Do this project after the roof is fixed.
Solution: Remove some shingles. Add drip edge. Add some new shingles ( dark grey, architectural), to the roof to extend the overhang a bit.  Soffit looks to be plywood here. There is a piece of vinyl siding lying on the ground here that will probably work for the missing siding. The existing siding is aluminum and is hard to find.

Problem: Robbie needs help moving furniture and other items from her house up to the barn to be stored. Some re-arranging needs to be done, as Robbie talked about turning her husband’s old room into a room for Haley. Here there is a bed with no mattresses. The old mattresses need to be disposed of and the bed needs a new set. The old mattresses are in the barn.
Solution: The barn is right uphill from Robbie’s house. Right now there is a dog lot there, which you would have to go through to access the barn. She says she will talk to her grandson about moving the dogs so she can get stuff moved up there.

Problem: Handrail needs work.
Solution: Replace a 2x4 and some pickets. Tamp the area around the post that is in the ground, or if further reinforcement is needed, install a new pressure treated post. Replaced the plywood that has the number 515 on it.

Problem: Board in front is trip hazard
Solution: Install a threshold over this section, even with the ramp threshold (there is an aluminum ramp installed on part of the steps up to the porch). Threshold should be 34” long by 7” wide.

Problem: Branches hanging over trailer
Solution: Get up on the roof and trim branches

Problem: Trailer is stained green
Solution: Wash trailer. A pressure washer would work but hand cleaning should be done also

Problem: Underpinning has a lot of holes in it.
Solution: Replace underpinning.360 square feet needed. Nina and Robert did this job originally.

Problem: The main water line is not protected from freezing
Solution: Insulate water line. (¾” pvc)

Problem: Water filter needed. Black silt can be seen in both toilet tanks.
Solution: Install a filter. Note-the main water line comes in underneath the back deck of the trailer. In order to install or change a filter, you have to remove as piece of underpinning and crawl about 8 feet under the deck. It may be better to install a filter at the well pump site- get landlord permission. Note- two trailers are served by this well.

Problem: Exterior light is getting wet ( moss growth)
Solution: Porch roof will take care of this problem

Problem: Loose light fixture in hall
Solution: Cut power and try to reinstall the fixture. A new remodel box may be needed.

Problem: Roof leaks intermittently in corner of bedroom ceiling. 3- Tab shingles are 14 years old.
Solution: My suspicion is that it is coming from around the satellite dish, but Nina claims it leaked before the dish was installed. Go up on the roof, seal around the dish and look for other places that it may need caulk or roof cement.

Problem: There are some moisture issues around the home. Since there is no overhang or gutters on the eaves side, water can splash up on the uncovered front and back decks. Part of the door frame has water damage
Solution: The real solution to this is to build a porch roof. It wouldn’t have to cover the entire deck. It could be about 6’ x 8’. Make sure the door will open and that the roof will have a 2/12 or greater pitch. Talk to Nina about this project

Problem: Some vinyl siding is damaged around the front door.
Solution: Replace J- channel and siding

Problem: Front storm door has some bad hinges. It still opens and closes but there is a 1” gap at the top.
Solution: Replace storm door. The door itself measures 34” x 75”. Try Discount Mobile Home supply in Weaverville (828-484-7095).

Problem: Tub drain has come apart in one bathroom. Floor seems ok; they haven’t been using the tub.
Solution: Install a new tub drain.it may be that you could just replace part of this- not sure

Problem: There is a soft place in the hall floor. This happened due to a washing machine leak. Other holes have been repaired (CAO).
Solution: Remove floor covering (thin linoleum). Cut out bad plywood. Replace plywood, scabbing joists if necessary. Install new floor covering in the hall and kitchen ( the existing linoleum is torn up). When cutting out the bad plywood, set saw depth and watch out for wires and HVAC ducts. There is a piece of plywood on site that can be used. Install new floor covering- waterproof vinyl plank laminate recommended. 130 square feet

Problem: Floor is weak in hallway, in front of front door.
Solution: Remove flooring, remove subfloor, reinforce joists, install new plywood.

Problem: Work is needed on the front and back decks. A couple of volunteer groups worked on both decks but more work is needed. Some of the work was not done correctly.
Solution: Move cement blocks under the porch posts, Make the stairs wider. Install hand rails correctly, The awning over the porch does not entirely cover the porch so that when it rains water lands on the porch. The roof also has hardly any slope (less than 1 /12). A new porch roof should be built. Redo hand rails on the back deck. Re-cut stair treads on the back.

Problem: No smoke or CO detectors
Solution: Install smoke and CO detector

Problem: Floor under the water heater is bad.
Solution: This water heater works and does not leak, although it looks very old. A board has been placed under the heater to keep it from falling thru. The best plan may be to wait until it starts to fall, quits working, or develops leaks, then replace it. David has a new water heater, but it is slightly bigger than the old one, so you may have to tear out an interior closet wall when you put the new one in. The heater can be accessed from the outside via a removable panel.

Problem: Back door will not close.
Solution: David has tried to fix this and if a new door is not an option, the knob and strike plate may need to be moved. A new hole may have to be drilled for the door knob.

Problem: New tub faucet needed in second (working) bathroom.
Solution: Install a faucet that sticks out more than the old one. The old one runs out onto the floor.

Problem: Woodstove has a cracked glass front. Otherwise the setup looks good- class A pipe, far enough from wall, etc.
Solution: David has patched this with JB weld but needs a new one . call him about brand and size. The glass must be either ceramic or tempered. Ceramic is more expensive but may be required. The place to get this is Wholesale Glass in Asheville- 254-8665

Problem: Mice and rat infestation
Solution: Get rat and mouse traps. David’s dogs have been killing some. Block up holes in floor to keep them out.

Problem: Spring house needs a new roof. The old one has gaps and is collapsing.
Solution: Check with David for dimensions of the springhouse roof- approx.. 8’x8’.

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: Membrane roof. Dimensions are 67’ x 12’. There are 6 roof vents that will need work prior to membrane installation. There is a furnace stack that will need to be taken off to install the membrane. This furnace is old but it looks like there are new parts, and David says it works. There is a wood stove chimney in good shape, but may need some new parts in order to accommodate the new roof.

Problem: Structural damage – walls and floor have separated in living room . Daylight is visible in some places, David has stuffed some blankets, etc. in the cracks.
Solution: Roof repair is the first step to prevent further damage. Then reinforce damaged framing by cutting out the rotten material and put back sound wood. Replace bad flooring, reinforce floor joists. New flooring can come later.

Problem: Underpinning is missing and falling off. The frame that supports the underpinning is rotten. The plumbing that froze has been 90% replaced with PEX, but it is not protected from freezing.
Solution: Remove old underpinning. Build new pressure-treated frame. Put the old underpinning back and add 2” foam board on the back side of it. Put plastic down under the trailer to keep moisture down.

Problem: Second bathroom has a weak floor. Toilet cracked.
Solution: David has another bathroom that is in good shape. My suggestion is to disable the unused bathroom and cut the water off to it. Remove toilet. Repair subfloor, reinforce joists. Remodel bathroom after more urgent needs have been met. David has enough new vinyl flooring for this room.

Problem: Floor damage in bedroom. There is a patch over part of the room. There is a bad corner.
Solution: Remove furniture and other items. Tear up subfloor and replace bad flooring. Reinforce joists. Install new flooring. This room is 11’ x 9’.

Problem: Siding needs to be replaced on gable end.
Solution: Replace vinyl siding, re-flash against roof

Problem: Damaged wood aroung sliding glass door.
Solution: Repair or replace jambs/trim

Problem: Electrical weatherhead needs reinforcement.
Solution: Cut power-re-reinforce weather head. Experienced electrician needed-power co. will not fix

Problem: No gutters causing rot in front of glass door.
Solution: Install Fascia boards and gutters, downspouts, blackpipe

Problem: Deck needs work.
Solution: Replace wobbly hand rail, replace floorboards, reinforce framing in front of glass door

Problem: Roof leaks. Mising Ridge Cap.
Solution: Replace shingle roof. 6&12 Roof Pitch Need Scaffolding & walkboard’s

Problem: Flooring in living room bad
