Solution: Replace, Request laminate flooring

Problem: Windows leaking(alum. Windows)
Solution: Replace (w/vinyl) 9 ea

Problem: Tree branches are hitting the top of the roof
Solution: Prune. If you use Evoid’s ladder, be aware that one of the bottom rungs is missing.

Problem: The drywall in the living room and kitchen ceiling is sagging and looks rough
Solution: Replace drywall after the roof is fixed. Kitchen is 18’ x 12’. Living room is 14’3” x 24’4”. Note that this project will make a huge, dusty mess. Put down drop cloths over the new flooring. Protect other rooms from dust with plastic barriers. Install drywall. Mud and tape. Sand and paint. Old drywall should be taken to the landfill before 4:00.

Problem: There is a door that is used as a window and partly covered up.
Solution: Bernice would like to be able to use the door. Install hinges (Bernice says she has these) and build steps. 30” high. Note that there are 2 other entry/exits.

Problem: Bathroom remodel needed. The work should be done after the septic is fixed. Note- there is only one bathroom in the home. If you take on this job you should be confident that you can make good plumbing connections and make sure you have time to finish the job. There may be damage to the wall beneath the tub surround.The toilet will have to be removed to install the flooring. You should also consider renting a Port a Jon for the week (Griffin Waste Services Recommended).
Solution: Install new tub surround. Right now the shower stall has a window opening that is covered with plastic and duct tape. Bernice has requested a tile surround and a new vinyl window. Window opening is 24” w x 15” high. It may be cheaper, however, to install a 3 piece surround and vinyl plank floor.The floor seems stable. The tub(28” x 53”) is solid (it is an older metal one). Bernice has a new sink and counter that she requests to be installed .It is 1” too big for the old opening. ( her old counter is 48” x 22”). The new sink is made of some kind of composite material that could possibly be cut with a saw. Install new flooring.install new cabinets under the sink/counter

Problem: The wood heater has a sketchy flue system. The wood cook stove on the opposite side of the house has a similar set-up. The single- wall pipes go out thru the wall where they are surrounded by sheet metal. There are no double or triple wall pipes.See photos.
Solution: Install black single wall stove pipe up to the ceiling then triple-wall thru the roof (straight up). This should be done by a heating professional.

Problem: Water damage on ceiling in two bedrooms (roof leaks).
Solution: After replacing the roof metal,repair the damaged material. One ceiling is osb(should eventually be painted) ,the other drywall. Replace damaged sections.

Problem: Electrical work needed. There are some wires that are not in boxes, loose outlets, and loose fixtures. Covers needed.
Solution: Get an electrician to do some work to make the system safer.

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: Replace roof. Old 5v metal covers entire roof.  The roof is slightly less than a 2/12 pitch. Metal roofing on such a low pitch is doable but certain procedures should be followed. Madison Metals recommends using butyl tape between the seams and installing the screws in the flats. This is a big roof. Total square footage is approx.. 1800. There are some places where the roof is spongy and will require some reinforcement underneath the metal.

Problem: No septic. There is a 1 ½” - 2” drain and a 3” drain going into a small stream beside the house.
Solution: Install septic system. There is a flat yard beside the house, and it seems like it would be doable to install a tank and drain field.

Problem: mold in back bedroom
Solution: clean and disinfect

Problem: Front door needs repair- cold air coming in
Solution: install proper weathering stripping

Problem: ceiling in dining room falling
Solution: repair and paint

Problem: holes in the floor of bathroom
Solution: repair

Problem: no exit at the rear of house
Solution: build stoop with steps

Problem: no water at tubs
Solution: clean lines and springs

Problem: Septic backing up
Solution: Install new tank and drain field

Problem: No working smoke or CO detectors
Solution: Install smoke and CO detectors

Problem: floor rotting and sagging
Solution: Remove flooring, re-enforce joist, replace sub-floor and install new flooring

Problem: New flooringl is needed in bedroom.
Solution: Put new flooring in bedroom. Square footage is 200. This includes the space made by removing the tub and vanity.

Problem: 2nd bathroom needs work.
Solution: Remodel needed (Note- they have another bathroom). Robert has a specific idea about this remodel. He has requested removal of the old large bathtub and removal of the shower and vanity. The remaining space can be a bedroom expansion; although I think it would be a good idea to have a vanity here. Whoever does this will have to talk to Robert about plans. As this is being done, the subfloor will need to be worked on ie plywood replacement and joist reinforcement. A new wax ring is needed on the toilet ( Robert says a relative will do this). New flooring is needed(24 sft.)

Problem: Floor is weak in front of bathroom door.
Solution: There was a hole but is has been temporarily patched with a piece of ¼” plywood. Needs to be repaired properly with ¾ or 5/8 plywood, joist reinforcement and new flooring material (40 square feet needed)

Problem: One of 2 old heaters is not working
Solution: Laser Brand

Problem: There is a small roof leak. The roof has been Kool- sealed over the years.
Solution: Robert says he and his son will track this leak down and patch it.

Problem: Screen door bottom starting to rot
Solution: Repair Screen door

Problem: Hot water heater not working right
Solution: Check elements (Notes: 12 years old, Enviro-temp)

Problem: Rotton basement door
Solution: Replace, 54” x 75”  Old fashioned, sloping Use PT

Problem: Hand-pump for water that’s used as a backup doesn’t work
Solution: Repair, replace

Problem: Replace bathroom window with smaller one
Solution: 26” x 40” (existing)

Problem: Busted steps in back, rotten plywood, steps block crawlspace
Solution: Build stoop (3’ x 4’)  36” high Build steps, handrails Replace 2- 4 x 8 x 1/2" plywood Caulk and Paint (Notes: Use PT 2 x 12, 2 x 10, 2 x 4)

Problem: Underpinning is brittle and has holes. Plywood has been used to patch up the missing stuff
Solution: Underpinning needs to be replaced. This would be a good volunteer project, it looks like it might hold up thru the winter.

Problem: Missing soffit, bees get into house...
Solution: Install a vented soffit. 3/8 plywood – 22’ long x 12” wide

Problem: Well pump shelter is about to collapse. Robert is afraid that it will collapse and his water could freeze
Solution: Tear down old well shelter and build a new well house. Make it 6’ x 8’. Put 4 pressure treated posts in the ground with concrete. The floor should be dirt covered with gravel. It should be tall enough that Robert can go in it and do maintenance on his well and pump. It should be insulated and have a door. Make a metal shed roof. This project is #1 according to Robert.

Problem: Gutters missing or damaged.
Solution: Replace/add gutters with blackpipe

Problem: Kitchen sink does not drain.
Solution: Snake drain, if that doesn’t work dig up the line and replace the drain

Problem: Small leak in roof, comes in bathroom
Solution: Put newer metal on roof.

Problem: Back door is in bad shape. Door opens to a 48” drop and a debris pile.
Solution: Tear apart old deck. De- nail and re- use the boards that are still sound. Then make a materials list and get new pressure treated material. Build a new deck approx.. 4’ x 4’ with steps and a hand rail. Make the deck free-standing (not attached to the house) and make sure the deck slopes away from the house. Replace back door. Door slab measures 30 ¾”x 74 ¾”. Robert mentioned that he might could find a cheap mobile home door.

Problem: flooring needed
Solution: Rena has installed new laminate flooring in her kitchen and part of her living room. She may need help finishing the flooring after the subfloor is repaired. Consult her about the type of flooring and quantities needed.

Problem: french drain requested
Solution: Right now there are no gutters or drainage in place. This would be a good problem to address after some of the more urgent needs are met.

Problem: Storm windows are broken or missing. These single pane windows will be cold this winter
Solution: Replace some windows. Call Mars Hill Hardware to order windows. Most windows arte the same size, approximately 29 3/4" x 53". There are at least 6 that need replacement. one window has damaged sills around it due to water getting in.

Problem: Back deck and handrails are wobbly. Deckboards are coming up.
Solution: Tear down deck and rebuild a free standing one that does not touch the house. See the front deck for an example. A 4’x8’ deck would be big enough. Water has probably damaged the place where the deck framing was attached  so repair this area before building the deck (remove vinyl siding and repair wood underneath). Make sure to slope the deck away from the house so the problem does not re- occur. Follow building codes. You can re use some of the materials if you are careful during demolition.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Sliding glass door is sticky
Solution: Clean, Apply silicone spray

Problem: no underpinning
Solution: Underpinning can be constructed using recycled roofing metal that CHC will provide. The metal will last longer and perform better than vinyl. A wooden frame should be constructed of treated lumber to attach the metal to. Also build an access door near the water main.

Problem: Air leaks around front door.
Solution: Owner requests storm door  Install weatherstripping or storm door. The outside of the door frame may need to be cleaned off first, homeowners say that weatherstripping won’t stick.

Problem: The basement door jambs are in need of repair. No threshold, cold air gets in.
Solution: Repair jambs with pt 5/4” material. Build a threshold out of a pt 2x4. Screw down with concrete screws.

Problem: The roof is leaking, mainly around the edges and down the walls. There are noticeable ceiling stains in one bathroom.
Solution: For now, Rena plans to Kool- seal and tar before winter. The long term solution will be a membrane or metal roof overbuild. The trailer is 14 feet wide and 77' 3" long. there are two bathroom fans , a chimney for the old heater, and 2 plumbing vents. Rena mentioned that she has some experience with membrane roofing.

Problem: Front Deck needs more guardrails.
Solution: Build new and reinforce existing guardrails.  This deck is 42” off the ground.

Problem: Wobbly guardrails and deck out back , stairs wobbly.
Solution: Reinforce or rebuild guardrails. Use 4x4 posts in concrete to reinforce midway up the stairs. Add diagonal bracing. This small deck is about 8’ off the ground. Tighten all lag bolts around deck.The homeowners have requested a deck to wrap around to the front deck.

Problem: Basement is damp- mold concerns
Solution: Gutters and drainage will help the water to go away from the house. A dehumidifier, heater or fan could be installed to dry the place out. Clean out basement. Wash walls.

Problem: The floor near the front door and along this exterior wall extending into a bedroom  has some damage  in several places. Damage is due to an old deck that has been removed
Solution: Cut out damaged floor (osb) and replace with plywood, which will probably be 5/8". Some of this Rena has already done herself.

Problem: no heat
Solution: The old electric furnace does not work. Rena says that the FBEMC person is going to talk to her about financing  a modern electric heater. She also plans on installing a wood stove. She has the chimney parts and stove from her camper. One would have to put a fireproof material on the walls and floor, and reinforce the floor. There is an oil tank and a propane hook up but no propane tanks.

Problem: no water
Solution: There is a well but the power will have to be turned on to assess plumbing and well.

Problem: no power
Solution: Rena says that a French Broad EMC person is going to come by soon and tell her what needs to happen to get her power turned on. There is a septic system in place that was recently pumped. She needs 4 switches and 1 outlet with boxes. Her neighbor, Shane, works with MB Hanes Electrical.

Problem: Rotted out front porch post that holds up the corner. Water from the drainpipe has spilled on it for years.
Solution:
Replace post. Add black drainpipe to divert water into yard. There may be a pressure treated 4x4 on the property that is useable.

This could be done simply by temporarily shoring up the post, cutting the bottom off , then adding concrete blocks underneath.

Problem: broken boards on porch
Solution: There are a couple of broken boards on the porch floor.  Repair with new 1x4 material. True dimensions are ¾” x 3 ½”; get oak or yellow pine for strength ( joists are 24” oc ).

Problem: Pileated woodpeckers have damaged the exterior wood
Solution: Replace trim with new rough sawn material (painted white). Make sure the wood has been properly dried so then paint will stick.

Problem: Insulation is missing under the house
Solution: Tim has quite a bit of R19 fiberglass insulation but it may be faced. Unfaced is best in a crawlspace.

Problem: Floor is springy in the living room
Solution: Add a post to support a few joists under the house.

Problem: There is  an addition that was started but not finished.
Solution: The room is 88 square feet. It needs wiring, insulation,drywall, paint and trim. Trim and paint also needed on outside of room.  It is dried in with a good roof.

Problem: Tim says the attic does not have much insulation
Solution: CAO or get blower & insulation

Problem: The windows in the home are uninsulated, single- pane. He is concerned about energy efficiency.
Solution: I told him about Community Action.  Most of his windows have newer storm windows. Some need paint.

Problem: Need co/smoke detector
Solution: Install co/smoke detector

Problem: out dated wiring in home. The wiring in the house is very old. There is an old fusebox. Tim mentioned that  fuses sometimes blow. They are running a lot of modern appliances with extension cords. No shorts were reported, however.
Solution: Upgrade system with a new breaker box and new circuits

Problem: Insulation falling out of 1972 side
Solution: Staple back, add insulation where needed.

Problem: Water pipes can freeze. Right now Mary lets the water run but needs pipe insulation.
Solution: Install foam wrap-around insulation on water lines. 1” and 1 ½” lines

Problem: ceiling tiles are falling. The kitchen ceiling has 12’ x 12” tiles; Tim thinks they could be asbestos. There is a fluorescent light fixture on the ceiling.
Solution: Test tiles for asbestos. Remove light fixture. Be careful because the fluorescent tubes contain mercury and could release it if broken. If you can find the ceiling joists and determine if they can hold the weight, Put a layer of 3/8 drywall over the top. Mud, Tape, finish and paint. Re-install or replace light fixture. The kitchen is 135 square feet.

Problem: Missing gutters on front side of house.
Solution: Install gutters. Need 42’, 1 downspout, black pipe. Need downspout and black pipe for porch drainage.

Problem: No gutters on back side of house
Solution: Install gutters. Need 65’. Make the high point in the middle. Install downspouts and black pipe on either end, and drain away from house.

Problem: Kitchen sink faucet has a  leak. The cold water and hot water supply to it has a small leak. The countertop is damaged. The cabinet has water damage. The leaks have caused part of the subfloor to rot. If you go underneath the house you can see the rotten place around where the water lines go up to the sink area.
Solution: Shut off water. Remove faucet. Remove sink. Remove old water lines and drain lines. Remove cabinet. Cut out rotten floor and install new plywood.  Repair cabinet with a piece of plywood. Reinstall cabinet. Install new countertop, new  sink and new faucet. Install new water lines and drain lines.

Problem: The shower surround is leaking and water is getting around and underneath it, and could damage the floor. The drain may be leaking. There is also a leak in the water line underneath the house in this location.
Solution: New surround. Owner requests tub/ shower surround  (currently only a shower). The shower surround is now 33 ½” 48”. However, if the plumbing was moved and the chase around it was removed, you could fit a tub in there because then the opening would be 62 ½” instead of 48”. It would be cheaper, however,  to just replace the shower surround. Repair leak under the house.

Problem: no smoke/ CO detectors
Solution: install

Problem: Some outlets don’t work. Breaker sometimes trips.
Solution: Replace outlets; Get electrician to check it out

Problem: Toilet leaks. She keeps the water turned off to it. Floor seems sound but check it for water damage during toilet replacement.
Solution: Replace wax ring and possibly toilet. Note- tile floor

Problem: Gutters do not drain properly. They are not sloped enough towards the downspouts. They hold water and that may be part of the reason why water is getting in the walls.
Solution: The existing gutters are in decent shape, and could possibly be re-used. There is only one downspout on each side of the roof for an 80’ long trailer, which is not sufficient. Reinstall the gutters (or get new ones), making the high point in the middle. Add another downspout on either side with black drainpipe.  Get quote from Joe at Mars Hill Hardware. He has worked with volunteers before.

Problem: Roof is leaking especially around skylights
Solution: An attempt could be made to patch the roof; it looks like some leaks are happening around the roof penetrations. However, the shingles are at least 20 years old and a new roof is probably needed. The roof is approximately 1280 square feet.

Problem: Wall has started to rot. The bottom plate and the studs are damaged. The water is probably getting in because of a roof leak, and/ or lack of overhang on the roof. The vinyl siding on the outside of the trailer on the other side of the wall where the leak is is stained black.
Solution: Fix the roof and gutters. Then tear out the bad section of the wall and floor. Be cautious of wiring that could possibly be in the walls.  Replace the damaged framing. There is a hardwood floor here, hopefuly you won’t have to replace the subfloor. The trailer is framed with 2x4’s on 16” centers. Mary has some bead- board paneling to cover the walls

Problem: CO detector needed.
Solution: Install CO detector.

Problem: Gutters clogged, trash in gutters.
Solution: clean

Problem: Missing or damaged screens on some windows
Solution: Make screen frame from scrap material and a roll of screen. Use the existing homemade frame for reference.

Problem: New Flooring requested in two bedrooms
Solution: Install new flooring.  Bedroom 1- 156 sft. Bedroom 2- 72 sft.

Problem: The exterior vinyl soffit material is dirty
Solution: Clean old soffit material or replace with new . Reinstall material that has fallen out.

Problem: The crawlspace is moist and there is some mold on the black insulation covering.
Solution: Install 6 mil plastic on ground. Install unfaced r19 insulation where it is missing. Crawlspace dimension is approx.. 1320 sf.

Problem: drywall repair, paint needed in bathroom
Solution: Patch drywall, paint .A small (12” x 12”) section was damaged   due to an old roof leak (now fixed).

Problem: insulation falling out
Solution: Staple back, add insulation where needed.

Problem: Dryer vents directly out onto wall . Could be a fire hazard.
Solution: Install a new dryer vent. Run it through the floor, through the crawlspace, and to the outside. Approx. 10’ of 4” ductwork needed.

Problem: Needs a storm door
Solution: Replace storm door

Problem: siding rotting at back deck
Solution: ~~Remove back deck~~. Remove bad siding. ~~Inspect and repair framing as necessary.~~ Install flashing .Replace siding(T-111). Paint siding.. Re-build deck, possibly reusing some of the old Pressure-treated materials. Build back a (6’x10) deck. Material estimates below are for a bigger deck size (6x16). Build steps, or reuse the recently built set. Build hand rails and guard rails. Height of existing deck is 36”. Build the deck free- standing (not attached to house). Make it slope away from the house 1/8” per foot. Also, make the deck about 7" lower than the doorway to facilitate the eventual building of a roof. Build a roof over it to prevent further rot(Roof metal can be ordered from DT Ramsey Lumber Co. 656-2754. Pangle’s construction, which includes a sawmill, is nearby .828-380-9892
Volunteer or Groups:
Grace Church Cathedral/ St. Pauls;
Holy Trinity

Problem: Needs covering over front door
Solution: Build a front covering – 8’X10’

Problem: sewage leak
Solution: Remove 1-2 pieces of vinyl underpinning from front of house. Remove waste with shovel and wheelbarrow. Put down plastic. Clean pipe and re- glue, or replace drain pipe.

Problem: Window glazing fallen out, some broken
Solution: Install glazer points and window putty. These are old, uninsulated single panes but could be fixed.

Problem: No insulation in floor or walls
Solution: Install insulation (Rigid foam in floor) stud/joist spacing unknown

Problem: Rotten siding
Solution: Install new and paint, siding is ¾” thick by 5 ½” wide

Problem: Front porch needs repair
Solution: Patch hole with ¾ ext. plywood, repair steps. Fix w/6’ long PT 2x12 treads, 1x6 risers

Problem: kitchen cabinets need replacing
Solution: install or build new cabinets

Problem: need new interior doors
Solution: install 2 interior doors

Problem: Breaker trips a lot
Solution: Install new circuits and breakers

Problem: Remove Stove
Solution: Wood Burning Needs To Be Removed.

Problem: outbuilding falling
Solution: shore up

Problem: Back porch needs repair and ramp
Solution: Fix rotten boards, install wheelchair ramp and handrail

Problem: rotten siding
Solution: replace T-111 at addition

Problem: Roof leaks around walls.
Solution: Install insulation and roofing membrane.

Problem: no smoke or CO detector
Solution: install smoke and CO detector

Problem: Leaking Roof
Solution: New roof, existing is metal

Problem: Interior door requested.
Solution: Install door - 32' wide

Problem: needs ceiling drywall repair and painted
Solution: repair drywall, paint after roof replacement

Problem: Gutters have no down spouts.
Solution: Install downspouts and black pipe to direct water away from house.

Problem: windows won't close
Solution: re-work windows

Problem: missing insulation under trailer
Solution: install insulation

Problem: Window replacement requested
Solution: Replace 2 windows. There is a company in Newport,TN that makes windows(Cocke County Glass & windows 423-623-7338).. One is 39 ¼” high, 46”wide.The other is 20 ½” high, 46” wide.

Problem: missing/bad underpinning
Solution: install new underpinning

Problem: roof leak
Solution: Re-roof trailer with rubber membrane with rigid insulation

Problem: Owner finds it difficult getting in and out of tub
Solution: Requests shower unit. There is room to put one in 48” x 48” when the left sink is removed. 2x4 walls will have to be built.

Problem: Rotten place in bathroom floor.
Solution: Remove plywood, check joists for rot,replace plywood.  Use ¾ plywood

Problem: One sink is cracked, the other's faucet has problems
Solution: Make 1 good sink from 2 bad sinks

Problem: Sketchy lights and wiring
Solution: Replace or fix- contact electrician

Problem: Rotten Sill
Solution: Tear out and replace with pressure treated

Problem: Rotted wall behind the Monitor heater.
Solution: Demo rotted area, watch out for the copper fuel line. Reframe and reinsulate, rehang paneling.

Problem: There is a weak place in the corner of one bedroom. This is probably due to the roof leak traveling down the walls to the floor.
Solution: Remove flooring in this corner, replace damaged subfloor, reinforce joists, add new plywood, talk to Louella about new flooring in this room.

Problem: The furnace stack will probably have to be moved or replaced because of the new roof height.
Solution: According to the homeowners, Community Action did some repairs to the duct work a while back. The furnace still works but I am not sure about the height of the chimney stack. Since the roof will be 1 1/2 “ higher it may interfere with the intake?

Problem: Roof is leaking. Several dark stains are visible on the ceiling inside.
Solution: This roof is a standard singlewide metal roof, but two porch additions have been built on. Both porch roofs(metal) extend above the trailer roof (see photos). This will require some extra work to make sure the roof doesn’t leak between the porch and the main part of the roof. Also, the furnace stack may need to be moved(see below).       The roof is 52 ½’ x 12’. There are 5 vents that are 3” in diameter with metal “hats” over the top. There is a 5” chimney (this is probably a bathroom fan). The furnace stack is about 12” in diameter.

Problem: Vinyl underpinning needs repair
Solution: Repair

Problem: Needs railing on back porch
Solution: Repair

Problem: Floor at rear door and bedroom rotted
Solution: Repair

Problem: Trailer roof leaking
Solution: Kool-seal-caulk-cracks

Problem: All windows leak
Solution: Rescrew+caulk

Problem: Old attic access hole in the ceiling needs to be closed up, patched, and painted.
Solution: Patch with 3/8 drywall, tape, mud, and paint

Problem: Gutters need work and cleaning.
Solution: I recommended removing gutters on downhill side because they are high up and hard to clean. Edna wants another downspout on the other end of the front gutter. One section of gutter is starting to fall, they all need cleaning.

Problem: Range hood boot is leaking
Solution: This may be another condensation issue; replace boot anyway ( 4”). Note- steep roof

Problem: Sink does not drain quickly. Ground gets wet around one place in the yard. Edna says that the sink drain is not plumbed into the septic drain, but rather into the pvc drainpipe that drains the French drain behind her house.
Solution: Find the other end of the drain (it drains into a corrugated pipe that then goes to the creek). Make sure it is not blocked up ( you could snake it or dig it up. Plumb the kitchen sink drain into the septic. Everything is pvc , various sizes

Problem: Water leaks through Bathroom fan.
Solution: The fan is inaccessible through the attic; you would have to take it apart from below, or even take a piece of metal off the roof. Caution- skilled job. You cannot see the ceiling joists because everything is covered in blown insulation. Baffles must be installed correctly.

Problem: strange leaks around heating vents
Solution:
She had a new heating system put in a year ago. It is a modern HVAC system and the main unit is up in the attic. Edna says the contractor was TD Builds- Tony Dickenson. The system ductwork looks good, there is tons of blown-in insulation, but she says that when it gets cold, water comes out of the heat vents. The roof is around 10 years old and looks good from the top; no obvious leaks. The only thing I can think of would be excessive condensation in the attic space. She has 2 gable vents but they are small and may not be enough. The edges where the eaves are, are blocked up by insulation, so there may not be enough ventilation.

First, Get HVAC man to look at it. Create a way on the eave sides to allow air to circulate.You can get those thin foam insulation baffles (check rafter spacing). I told Edna to keep an eye on it and try putting a fan up there to circulate air and reduce condensation.

Problem: A storm back in the spring knocked over several power poles going up to Edna’s house.The power company came and fixed the poles. The electricity works fine in the home, but when the poles fell the weatherhead, which goes through the roof, bent. The roof penetration is now leaking and the weatherhead leans over. FBEMC (Power co.) will not pay for a new weatherhead. Edna says that water is now leaking onto her porc and beneath into the basement where her pressure tank is.
Solution: Have FBEMC turn off the power and get an electrician to install a new, galvanized metal weatherhead. Install a new boot around it and seal with caulk. If it is going to be a long time before the electrician can get there , apply roofing cement around weatherhead penetration. Note- the current weatherhead sticks up beyond the roof about 50”. A shorter weatherhead would be better. You may have to remove some siding frosm the porch ceiling and reinforce the framing

Problem: Deck is aging and slick when wet
Solution: Owner requests pressure wash and stain deck and ramp

Problem: Pane of glass needed for kitchen window. There are several windows in the house that are single pane. Some have storm windows.
Solution: Mars Hill Hardware will cut single pane glass. Get measurements.

Problem: Sherlena has been having problems with her septic system. She says that when she does several loads of laundry the system overflows and comes up out of her recently- installed cleanout accompanied by a foul odor.
Solution: Sherlena had some work done last year on her system by Carter Septic. Copies of Carter’s receipt and the original septic paperwork from 1970 are with the photos. The system was pumped out and a  new riser kit and cleanout were installed.  Despite the work,  the system still overflows. Since the tank and drainfield are old, they are probably failing. A new system is probably needed. Call  Vivian at the health Dept. to get a septic permit.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: install CO detector

Problem: Client requests new paint on the bedroom walls. In this room some of the ceiling tile is falling down. There is also a hole in the wall in the corner of the room.
Solution: White paint requested. Repair ceiling tiles. Repair paneled walls.

Problem: A side room could use laminate flooring
Solution: replace floor. 95 sqft.

Problem: A living room has some worn- out linoleum. This room has acoustic ceiling tiles that are starting to fall down. Ceilings could also use paint.
Solution: The ceiling tiles should be fixed first. Some repairs have been made using special screws to re-fasten the tiles. I have not done this particular repair. Install laminate flooring. 185 square feet. Paint ceiling.

Problem: Kitchen wall need to be painted. Room is dark.
Solution: Paint walls a light color. Use low VOC paint.There is also an eye missing on the stove.

Problem: no gutters on back of house
Solution: Install gutters and a downspout. Use big gutters that hold a lot of water. The downspout can drain into a solid corrugated black pipe that would go beside the house and down hill. Note- the ditch has already been partially dug.

Problem: The next door neighbor, Robert, is having septic issues. This affects Jackie because the drain field is in her back yard.
Solution: Glen says he will talk to Robert, who is renting  a single wide next door from this family, about getting help from CHC with this problem. It sounds like a new drain field is needed.  Jackie’s house is on the Hot Springs town sewer system and there is nothing wrong with her septic. The mobile home, however, is not. According to Glen, efforts to run the mobile home septic into the town sewer have been unsuccessful due to politics.

Problem: The front steps are steep. Although Jackie seems quite mobile at this point, Glen has requested a ramp. The deck height is 31”.
Solution: Build a ramp. Include hand rails. You will probably want to start off with a landing then turn 90 degrees and come the rest of the way down. If you go straight out the ramp would go into the parking area. Please follow the building code for ramps. The ramp cannot be steep. It should only drop one inch for every 1 foot of length. Therefore the ramp will have to be 31 feet long. Get a copy of the building code for ramps. The landing should also slope gently away from the house . Make it 48” wide.

Problem: Roof metal is probably over 50 yrs old.
Solution: Glen recently added a black roof coating over the whole roof. He says it does not leak now but a new roof will be needed soon because that stuff probably won’t last long. The roof looks like about a 5/12 pitch. There is a 16” x 16” masonry chimney and a 3” plumbing vent. 1461 square feet.

Problem: Porch will need a rebuild soon.Deck boards and some framing should be replaced. Paint is peeling on the porch and on the posts.
Solution: Boards are 6’ long 1x6 yellow pine material. Replace boards,Reinforce or replace some or all framing, paint.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Insulation is missing under the trailer
Solution: Replace insulation. Joists are 2x6 on 16” centers

Problem: Water line leak
Solution: There is a steady drip under the house. It is in the supply to the unused bathroom. If this end of the house gets closed off you could just plug this.

Problem: Back door knob not working properly
Solution: Move the strike plate or replace knob

Problem: Front door is hard to open and close.
Solution: This could be because the trailer appears to be settling. You could take off the weatherstripping from the bottom of the door.

Problem: Bathroom needs work
Solution: The second bathroom , although serviceable, needs work. The tub drain is loose and there is a soft place in front of the lavatory. 54 square feet  Repair soft spot. Remove floor covering, repair plywood. If time and money permits, a new shower/tub surround should be installed as the old one’s drain has leaked and could be causing floor damage. It is also showing signs of wear. New floor covering needed. Handicap access should be considered.

Problem: The power pole where the meter box is attached is leaning and propped up with a forked stick. Power still works.
Solution: Progress Energy serves this area. They are responsible for the meter but not the pole. They would turn the power off at the transformer and an electrician would have to repair the pole. Get an electrician to look at this job.

Problem: A bedroom is unusable due to bad floors. There is a lot of clutter in this room. The bathroom next to it is has not been used in a long time. Water is still hooked up, but I saw no leaks in there.
Solution: Repairing these 2 rooms would require taking all the stuff out and replacing all the subfloor in both rooms. Bedroom needs flooring, bath would need a complete remodel. Doing all this would be very time consuming and expensive, so I think the simplest thing to do here is to close off this bedroom and the adjacent bathroom. Connie has offered to help remove stuff from these 2 rooms and take to the dump, but she will need help. Use extreme caution because the floor is unstable. Since So-So lives by himself these rooms are not necessary. Take the old, unused furnace out and a put a new hot water heater in that closet ( the old one, circa 1992, leaks).

Problem: Back deck unsafe. There is an old, unattached set of metal steps here.
Solution: Tear down and rebuild a free standing deck, with ramp or steps. This deck is4’ x 8’. Build rails.

Problem: The front porch posts are leaning noticeably. The porch roof leaks where it is attached to the trailer. Water is getting into the walls as a result. The porch floor slopes towards the home noticeably. This roof has been Kool sealed. No leaks were reported except for where the porch roof joins. So So will eventually need a membrane.
Solution: Tear off porch roof. Tear down deck. Some material can be reused. Rebuild a free standing deck that is 12’ x 6”so that you can build enough slope into the roof. The storm door must be able to open, so make sure it doesn’t hit the rafters. Build a properly sloping ramp, guard rails and hand rails. Independent Living could be a good resource. The porch is 16’ x 8’. Deck height is 37” at the highest point. Rebuild porch roof. Reuse old metal roofing.

Problem: no CO detector
Solution: install CO detector

Problem: Client requests removal of an old AC unit.
Solution: Remove AC and install a storm window (on site).

Problem: Client requests new screen door
Solution: Existing door slab is 29 ¼” x 80”

Problem: vinyl siding is dirty
Solution: Wash. Use ladder and a bucket of soapy water with a scrub brush.

Problem: One window needs replacement. It has peeling l paint (more than likely lead) on it and a broken storm window.
Solution: Order a window from Mars Hill Hdw. that will fit a 27 ¾” x 55” rough opening. Re-trim, possibly using existing trim.Vinyl J- channel surrounds this window.

Problem: Windows need work. Broken panes should be replaced. Some of the screens have come loose or don’t fit right.
Solution: Phyllis has 4 storm windows sitting on her porch. These can be used to replace the broken ones. 2 broken ones are around back.,one needs a new pane, about 5 ½ “x 24”. Mars Hill Hardware can cut panes of glass.

Problem: Outdoor spigot requested for garden irrigation
Solution: T into water line. Phyllis will show you where.

Problem: one monitor heater needs work
Solution: Phyllis says it needs an ignitor( $80). She has a guy who worked on her stove before but can’t recall his name. She has another monitor that is hooked up, on loan from her brother. He will need it before winter.

Problem: wobbly ceiling fan
Solution: Turn off power. Take off top piece of trim and inspect electrical box. It should be metal, securely attached to framing. Reinforce framing and box if needed.

Problem: Kitchen sink leak. One or both sides of a shut off valve has a leak. Floor weak under the sink.
Solution: Turn off water and fix leak. This is ½” copper line. Access possible from below, in basement. Floor is damaged underneath the sink and should be repaired. Tear out rotten material and replace with ¾ plywood. Jigsaw needed.

Problem: Tile requested in kitchen
Solution: new kitchen flooring. 320 square feet

Problem: Audrey requests ceramic tile in bathroom
Solution: She has some tile and mortar, but not enough. The room is 59 square feet. She has 37 square feet of tile and a small bag of mortar.

Problem: New flooring requested in bedroom.
Solution: replace flooring 160sqft

Problem: New floor covering needed in living room. The old stuff is peeling up
Solution: 350 square feet of laminate flooring. Follow directions for concrete floor installation.

Problem: Leaky old windows
Solution:
Replace windows to improve energy efficiency. The low cost solution is to replace only the broken panes. There are three window panes that are broken. Measure and have the glass cut at Mars Hill Hardware (689-2818).

The windows in this house are all single pane. There are 12 windows that are 48” x 48”. One window in the living room is 48” x 96”. Measurements are approximate.

Problem: Roof leak
Solution: A new roof is needed. There are a couple of leaks on the porch and a couple of leaks inside the house. The roof is old 5V metal. It is 2100 square feet. There are a couple of pitches on it, my guess is 3/12 and 5/12 (not too steep). There are two chimneys and a couple of plumbing vents.

Problem: Porch Gate needs work. There is a spring and the latch broke.
Solution: repair gate

Problem: There is a shed door out back that is off its hinges and needs to be replaced.
Solution: You will have to create a rough opening by attaching treated material to the existing concrete opening. Use Tap-cons or cut nails. Build a new door that will fit the opening and hang it. Caulk and paint. Use old hinges. The existing opening in the concrete building is 28 1/2” x 57”. ¾” plywood and 1x4’s could be used. Install knob or rustic door closer.

Problem: There is some damage to the soffit material. Several pieces are rotten. Birds are nesting in her attic as a result.
Solution: Repair soffit material with plywood. There are several places around the home that need this type of repair. On one corner, add a piece of metal flashing to stop water infiltration. Caulk and paint.

Problem: Electrical problems. Ceiling fan wire is not connected. In one kids' room, there is a fan that got covered up with duct tape. Looks like this room used to be a bathroom.The fan still runs. An outlet in the living room dosen't work. A switch in the bedroom does not work. No breakers
Solution: Rewire fan, replace if bad. Remove the fan in the kids' room. Install an electrical box with a cover. Replace drywall etc. Fix outlets and switches.

Problem: House is close to busy road and it is dangerous for kids to play outside
Solution: install fence and gates. Consult homeowners about the type of fence, gate, etc.Note this job has not been priced.

Problem: Floor is spongy in front of kitchen sink
Solution: remove old floor covering, subfloor. reinforce joists, install new plywood, install new floor covering. Note that this might be a good way to access the drain pipes under the trailer. Most old trailers have 5/8" press-board as subfloor material, but this should be checked.

Problem: Coons getting under house
Solution: Seal up crawlspace

Problem: Missing insulation under house
Solution: Install r19 unfaced 24” fiberglass

Problem: Roof cement around chimney is cracked.
Solution: Re-tar

Problem: One downspout drains onto the wall/foundation.Existing gutters are clogged
Solution: Install 24’ of gutters, rerout drainpipe, add downspouts and drain pipe . insure drains are working right .Clean gutters.

Problem: Child’s bedroom has peeling, damaged paneling due to an old leak. Peeling paint tests negative for lead.
Solution: Replace paneling, paint. Check for damage underneath.

Problem:
Bathroom tile cracked, suspected floor damage. Old shower unit probably leaks . Adjacent closet has shown water damage underneath the wall.

Vanity faucet old, leaks.

Bathroom is about 50 sq. feet
Solution: Tear up old tile and check for floor damage. Repair damage, replace plywood, and replace floor covering. Replace shower unit (36” x 36”). . Repair & replace plywood. Replace floor covering. There are no obvious holes here, but due to the cracked tile and “give” in the floor, this probably needs doing.

Problem: Air leaks thru window. A satellite cable has been run thru the window opening so that it won’t close.
Solution: Drill hole in wall and re-run cable thru. Caulk holes.

Problem:
single pane trailer windows are not energy efficient.

Note- these windows are in a spare room and have plastic over them. Room is currently unheated.
Solution:
Replace trailer windows with double pane insulated ones.

1\. 41”high x 32” wide(including metal flange.)

2\. 54 ¾” high x 24” wide (including metal flange.)

3\. 36” high x 24” wide (not including flange).

4\. 2 @ 52” high x 24” wide (rough opening). .

Problem: New deck needed for access around back.
Solution: Build a free standing deck approx. 4’x4’. Drop the deck floor down about 6” below the door threshold. Slope the deck away from the house. Build steps and handrails. Height of door threshold approx.. 36”.

Problem: Ceiling material fallen down in an unused room. There are 2 big holes here.This probably happened due to an old roof leak that was fixed when they put a new roof on.
Solution: Tear off drywall, check framing and roof plywood for soundness, replace old insulation, replace drywall, finish, paint. This room could potentially be turned into a nice kid’s room. The roof is under-framed and probably should have 2x2’s added to the 2x4 rafters so that more insulation could be added.This room is 10' x 15'

Problem: Kitchen drain leak .
Solution: Replace kitchen drain pipes, traps, etc.

Problem: Exterior and interior door work needed. There is only one exterior access to this house.
Solution: Work on 2 doors. One door opens to the outside to a 3-foot drop. It has only a deadbolt. Replace with locking knob once a stoop or deck has been built. The other door which leads from the laundry area to the room that is unused, will not close. It needs a new knob and strike plate (interior door).It is 31 ¼” w x 71 ½” high. A third door, leading to the outside, looks ok but is blocked. It is in the unused room with the fallen ceiling.

Problem: Front door will not close and is drafty. Missing pane in storm door.
Solution: Replace entire door/storm door/ jambs/ knob and deadbolt. If that proves too costly then the jamb could be repaired. This door slab measures 31 7/8” w x 73 ¾” tall. 5/8” thick jambs.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Crawlspace door needed. Existing osb cover is starting to deteriorate.
Solution: Build a removable door approx. 36”x 36” and put insulation board on the back side. Fill in area under the doorway so critters won’t get in.

Problem: Rotten Fascia boards. This is not super urgent but should be done soon. Gutters work, but have been glued to the fascia board in some places and may have to be replaced.
Solution: Remove gutters, Remove old fascia, replace with 1x8 painted wood (white).

Problem: Home is not very energy efficient. It currently has R13 in the attic and R19 in the crawlspace. Ground is damp. The house measures 45’ x 23’2” (1044 sft)
Solution: Add unfaced R19 fiberglass insulation to the attic. Add R19 unfaced fiberglass insulation (320 sft) where it is missing in the crawlspace. Add 2” rigid foam extruded polystyrene insulation (friction fit) in the crawlspace. The metal trailer framing members are approx.. 48” apart so this would be good for 4’ x 8’ panels. Remove old jars, etc.and install 6 mil plastic on the ground in the crawlspace. Note- Crawlspace is about 36”, so working here would not be too difficult; CAO / volunteer job?

Problem: Bathroom is in need of at least a partial remodel. There is a soft place around the toilet, which wobbles. The tub surround (cheap plastic) has come loose and water can get into the walls.
Solution: I gave Sherri the number of Independent Living (670-3377); she says she knows Lori Massey. Replace toilet, replace tub surround. Sherri has a piece of linoleum that is the right size to install for floor covering. Replace plywood, shore up framing, install linoleum. This room is 90 ½” high and the surround is 60” x 30”.

Problem: Back door should be replaced. Slab is beat up and it won’t shut right sometimes. The storm door is missing a pane. Front door is borderline; it opens and shuts ok but the jambs are starting to rot and slab is coming apart on the bottom. Front door has a decent screen door.
Solution: Replace front and back door. Front door is right hinge, opens in,,79” high x 35 ½” wide (slab size). Back door is right hinge, opens in, 32” x 80” (slab size).

Problem: Old windows leak
Solution: Replace windows- There are 10 trailer-style windows that measure 36” wide by 51 ¼” tall. A kitchen window is 35 ½” x 30”.

Problem: Sherri says she spends $400-450 a month on electric bills and goes through 100-150 gallons of oil a month in the winter. Main heater is a 1974 “Armstrong”oil furnace. The heating ducts on one side of the house do not work; she has to run space heaters in the winter. She has 5 air conditioning units (in windows). Her house is located in a very sunny place with no shade.
Solution: Newer Heat and air conditioning system needed. Contact Mayberry Heating or other HVAC contractor. I gave Sherri the number for Community Action opportunities (252-2495), and told her to tell them to communicate with CHC about this issue. More insulation in the crawlspace and attic would help this problem (see prob. #5).

Problem: Portion of back deck is failing. Summer afternoon sun causes home to overheat.
Solution: A porch roof on the west (sunny ) side would be hard to build because the deck is 10 feet wide. You would have to start above the roof and do an overbuild, clients have good gutters. The main function of the roof would be for shade, tin could be used for sheeting. 4x4 posts should go all the way to the ground as deck does not need to hold this weight.

Problem: Floors in hallway, kitchen and Master bedroom are falling through.
Solution: Replace subfloor and install new floor.

Problem: Need laminate installed
Solution: Install laminate installed. Family has laminate on site

Problem: Needs gutter on back of trailer
Solution: Install new guttering

Problem: Need hand rail on main deck
Solution: Install hand rail

Problem: Deck needs rework
Solution: Replace 6 posts under deck

Problem: Exposed heat ducks
Solution: Repair heat ducks. Check insulation and heat ducts under trailer.

Problem: Roof Starting to leak on the front side
Solution: Replace roof

Problem: Glass needed in kitchen door
Solution: Replace glass in kitchen door.

Problem: Commode leaking
Solution: install new wax ring.

Problem: Light in living room not working
Solution: check wiring connection on light.

Problem: Broken storm door
Solution: Repair storm door.

Problem: Exposed outdoor wood
Solution: Paint front porch/Stain front steps. Pressure wash back porch & stain. Paint Shutters.

Problem: Kitchen cabinets need refinishing
Solution: Refinish kitchen cabinets

Problem: Crack in floor at hallway.
Solution: Bolt floor at hallway.

Problem: Mold and mildew in addition
Solution: Clean, paint with Kilz and new paint. Roof venting should reduce moisture issues.

Problem: Metal roof old and leaking
Solution: Install new metal roof. Approx. 1500sq feet. Install ridge vent with new roof.

Problem: Interior drywall has water damage from leaking roof
Solution: Replace and repair any damaged drywall and repaint. Need to wait until roof is repaired.

Problem: No CO detetor
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Deck floor needs a coat of paint
Solution: Scrape old paint and repaint

Problem: The back porch handrails are wobbly and rotten in places
Solution: Replace handrails. User pressure treated. Save the old decorative pickets- they are good

Problem: Broken window. Window does not shut right.
Solution: Replace window with a new one. The old dimensions are- 32” wide x 38” high.

Problem: The porch roof leak has caused water damage to the drywall in the kitchen ceiling, causing dark stains. There is a fluorescent light here.
Solution: Once the roof is fixed and everything is dry, refinish and paint the drywall.. Be careful working around the fluorescent light, You may want to turn off the breaker and remove the bulb.

Problem: New gutters will be needed on the back side of the house and porch.
Solution: Install gutters. Clean old gutters. Check to see if drains work and hook gutters up to them

Problem: Soffit and fascia are damaged. The overhang framing will need to be reinforced. The overhang was built onto the outside of the house seperately from the trusses.
Solution: Remove old soffit and fascia. Save vents. Make sure framing is still good. Replace soffit with 3/8 plywood. Replace fascia with pressure treated 1x6.Paint soffit.

Problem: 1 Back porch roof leaks. She catches water in big buckets. The rafters show considerable bowing. The shingles are 20+ years old according to Cindy. The roof is still leaking around the chimney. The plywood is also damaged there. I gave Wayne (Mary's son) a bucket of roof cement to try and patch.
Solution: Remove Gutters. You will have to remove all the fascia board because it is rotten. Remove plywood soffit material that is damaged. Remove porch roof (the existing roof is about 8’ x 18’). Dispose of materials at the landfill. Build back the porch roof. This time, attach the new rafters to the old ones instead of putting them above. The outside band where the other end of the rafters will sit will need to be lower than it is now in order to create enough roof pitch. Cut off posts and make a new band out of 2x6 and 2x4. The high side will be 7’ 5” and the low side should be 6’ or even lower. Frame up 2x6 rafters on 24” centers. Plywood, tar paper and shingle. Follow instructions for a low slope roof (more shingle overlap), or use a membrane.

Problem: No CO or smoke detector
Solution: Install CO and smoke detector

Problem: Unsafe water supply.
Solution: This home and Jerry’s brother’s home next door run off a gravity fed reservoir. There is a pump in the reservoir that pushes the water up to the houses. The reservoir is covered and in good condition, but the source of the water going into it was a creek running through a cow pasture. (See photos) From there it was collected in an old bathtub, then ran to the reservoir.  Jerry and Patricia do not drink the water. I talked to Jerry about finding a better source, such as a good covered spring up in the holler. They said there was a good one there, but it serves two other houses, including Jerry’s mom’s. The concern was that there would not be enough water. They said to talk to Ray who was familiar with the system and the land.

Problem: Laundry drain line is broken and not plumbed in to the septic.
Back door needs work
Solution: One hinge needs new screws, new handle needed on storm door. Pane missing. New latch needed.

Problem: Awning over back entrance has two supporting posts that are not well supported
Solution: Replace posts. There is a 12 foot long 4x4 post on site. A 10 foot 4x4 post will be needed. Make good footers with concrete.

Problem: Gas Cook stove has had wires and insulation chewed by rodents
Solution: New Stove

Problem: Home is not set up for disabled person
Solution: The bedroom and bathroom doors are not wide enough. Jerry sleeps on a sofa in the living room that is propped up by cinder blocks so that it is high enough for him to grab his walker. The toilet is too low. There is a shower chair but the tub is too small (trailer size). Toilet chair needed.  I talked to Lane at independent Living. I gave them Patricia’s address and phone # and told her about the situation. The homeowners do have a good ramp. Contact Independent Living.

Problem: Heating issues
Solution: They have a good wood stove but the chimney is cracked. . The block part of the chimney only extends a couple inches above the roof. They have an old oil furnace, which Patricia says works, but the ductwork is bad.

Problem: In the bedroom the ceiling is visibly sunken and several places where leaks have been can be seen.
Solution: An attempt could be made on the flat section to make a somewhat higher ridge. Put new metal on the section with a better overbuild. Approximately 280 linear feet of new roofing metal will be needed.

Problem: The toilet leaks around the bottom. Water is under the trailer. Floor damage has happened. Floor is soft around toilet. Patricia mentioned that the tub moves when someone gets in it, indicating a bad floor.
Solution: Remove tub and toilet, repair subfloor, bathroom needs complete remodel.. 48 square feet.

Problem: Jerry requires assistance getting into the bathroom. His wheeled walker will not fit in the door opening. Patricia helps him from there.
Solution: Re-frame the door opening and leave the door off. Higher toilet needed.

Problem: Electrical problems. Lights and outlets do not work in the bedroom side of the house. Breakers sometimes trip. An outlet is loose in the bedroom.
Solution: Mice and roof leaks have likely caused these problems. Patricia has a neighbor, Ronnie Wallin, who is an electrician. Pretty sure this is Jeremy Wallin’s (another electrician) dad.

Problem: Floors are bad in bedroom. Several places in the corners are visibly sunken in. Jerry cannot get in his bedroom because of the narrow door opening and sleeps on the sofa. The bed is propped up by boards.
Solution: Remove bed. Install new plywood. Try to repair some framing if possible. You might just put plywood over the existing floor. The room is 10’ x 11’.

Problem: An addition that was converted to a porch by Highland still needs work.
Solution: Improve porch by tearing up floor, installing pressure treated joists, cap blocks, and a new deck floor. Make it level with the other deck. This porch is approx. 8' x 20'.

Problem: Lois is raising a garden and may need help with weeding and yard work- weed eating etc. Her grandson helps with this.
Solution: Weed eat, mow,etc.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Electrical system should be upgraded. There are not many outlets. She did not report any shorts, but the wiring is probably old and needs work.
Solution: Have an electrician check it out

Problem: The bridge across the creek needs repair. Right now you can only walk across it, and it has a hand rail on one side. The steel I beams and foundation are still good. Lots of big timbers would be needed to repair this bridge. There is a right-of way over this bridge and through Lois’ property.
Solution: The bridge is 40’ long x 12’wide. If it becomes necessary for vehicles to drive across, Pangle’s construction would be a good resource for this job. He has a sawmill and heavy equipment. Another local resource is Harold Finley- he does grading work. I have priced materials for another hand rail.

Problem: Handrails needed on front porch steps and on the section below. The hand rails at the bottom of the steps need reinforcement.
Solution: There is a long stairway leading up to Lois’ house. Because of her arthritis, she needs good handrails to get up to her house from below. She may eventually need better access. Build new rails and reinforce the old ones.

Problem: There is some siding missing.
Solution: The old stuff is asbestos. Be very cautious because the dust from these shingles is carcinogenic. Protective suits, respirators, etc. should be used when doing anything with this siding. Get a person who is trained to deal with this material.

Problem: Drainage work needed around back. Water is collecting on the back side of her house and damaging the walls.
Solution: The water that comes off the hill behind her house should be directed away from/ around her house to the downhill side. A French drain would be good here. An old drainage system is in place. Start digging up old drainpipes and connect them to new drainpipes. Add fascia board and gutters. If you dig a French drain, get gravel and pipe with holes in it.

Problem: There is a missing window. The window opening is blocked up by a piece of blue- board insulation. There are some windows with broken panes. Some windows have storm windows and some do not.
Solution: Community Action would be a good resource for window replacement- all windows are old, single- paned. At least, there are 4 windows that need replacement. They measure approximately 28” x 53”. If replacement does not work out, you could replace the broken panes. Gentry’s Hardware in Hot Springs cuts glass.

Problem: Drain leak.
Solution: If you go into the basement you will see the old, 4” metal drainpipes. On the back side, beneath the commode, there is a “T” that has a leak. It is not a huge leak but needs to be fixed. It would probably be best to replace the old metal stuff with Sch. 40 plastic drainpipe. Install a clean-out as well.

Problem: Work needed in bathroom
Solution: New tub / shower surround needed. Tub is metal, old but good. It measures 29 ½” x 60” and has a built-in sliding glass door. While replacing the tub surround, check for framing and floor damage. Repair where necessary. Floor seems sound but check under the tub. Plumbing seems good here- no leaks noticed. Drywall finish and paint will be needed once roof is fixed. Her son- in law has plumbing skills and lives in Haywood County.

Problem: Ceiling material loose, damaged
Solution: Once the roof is fixed, re attach drywall on the ceiling , mud and paint.

Problem: In the kitchen and adjacent room, the ceiling material has come loose due to a roof leak. Homeowner reports catching water in a basin near the wood stove
Solution: The shingles on the roof ( asphalt 3- tabs and architectural) do not look that old. I am trying to find out when the shingles were installed. According to Lois, Eddie put them on but she can’t remember when. I told her to get me in touch with him about the roof since he may have some useful info about it. There were no visible leaks, although the chimneys could use some tar. The roof is about a 6-12 and it is about 1500 square feet. Patch roof or replace shingles. If you add a layer of shingles over top of the old, make sure to inspect the roof framing to see if it will hold the extra weight. Attic access panel is on the ceiling inside.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Water filter has a small leak in the basement. There is a drain here.
Solution: I tried to tighten the filter but that didn’t work. New fittings may be needed.

Problem: Soffit needs work. Leaking gutters caused rot to rafter tails and soffit materials.
Solution:
Scab on 2x4 rafter tails. loosen or remove gutters. Install fascia board. Install soffit material. .Hang gutters back. Check all gutters and make sure they are securely attached. Clean guttters. Hook up downspouts.

Most materials to do this job are on hand. Lori had someone lined up to do the work but he did not show up.

Problem: The deck next to the kitchen with a ramp has some old, splintery boards. Rails in rough condition.
Solution:
Replace deck boards. This deck is 5’ x 10’. The ramp does not meet code (too steep), but is in ok shape and usable (client is not disabled). The framing should be good still, and the deck is free- standing.

One of the supporting posts may need work.

Problem: Commode , circa 1959, should be replaced (rusty bolts). The floor is getting soft around there.
Solution: Replace commode, bolts and wax ring. Inspect floor for damage.

Problem: The porch is concrete, and slopes towards the house. The porch is uncovered and over the years has cracked and slumped down near thee doorway. This has caused water to begin to rot the framing where the back door
Solution: In order to correctly solve this problem you would have to bust up the concrete porch. You may need to rent some tools, such as a Bobcat or Demolition hammer, from General Equipment Rental in Weaverville (828-658-2334) Remove debris and repair wood framing on the house. Then rebuild a wood deck with steps, sloping away from the house. Make sure to communicate with Betty about this, she is not too psyched about it.

Problem: Basement door will not close
Solution: Move strike plate

Problem: Client requests septic pumping. I noticed that the basement drain was not draining very quickly, and she says that sometimes the toilet won’t flush right. However, an odor has not been detected. She says that the tank was almost full when she had it checked last 4 to 5 years ago.
Solution: Pump septic, or it could be a drain problem. Rooter King?

Problem: Wood stove chimney needs cleaning
Solution: Remove chimney cap and clean. Client owns chimney brush with long handle.

Problem: The basement steps need reinforcement. There is a crack in the stringer and the framing that supports it.
Solution: Add some pieces of 2x4 and 2x6 material to the top part of the steps.

Problem: Laminate floor has messed up edges and is coming apart in some places
Solution: This seems like a minor problem, but could get worse.This looks like the cheap stuff. If budget permits replace flooring. Call Keith for square foot measurement

Problem: Keith says his furnace is giving off a kerosene smell. He says it has given him trouble before.
Solution: Inspect furnace and repair.

Problem: Keith has noticed a mold smell under his kitchen sink.
Solution: Clean out underneath the sink and shine a light under there. Check for leaks, spray mold with bleach water and clean.

Problem: Deck needs some reinforcement.
Solution: Keith stuck a cinder block under there.  Jack up here and there and add 4x4 pt supports, brace. The deck is not very far off the ground (1-2 feet).

Problem: Vinyl siding dirty
Solution: Pressure wash or hand clean siding

Problem: Windows are hard to open and shut. Keith seems to think that the house has settled, but the doors work good and I didn’t see any cracked drywall.
Solution: Try adding a lubricant such as silicone spray.

Problem: Shingles are missing on the ridge of the roof. Keith claims the roof is not leaking but that shingles keep blowing off.
Solution: I got Keith up on the roof and talked to him about how to fix this. Remove the metal flashing that someone put under the ridge and replace the ridge-cap. Ideally, a ridge vent should be installed here, but I told them if they could get 2 bundles of 3 tab shingles and make ridge cap shingles out of those, that would work.

Problem: Underpinning is vented vinyl. It has lots of holes in the bottom of it where rocks have busted thru due to a weed eater.
Solution: Build a pressure treated 2x4 frame and put some kind of solid underpinning such as roofing metal or pt plywood. Make a couple of access panels. Rigid insulation could be added to the underpinning in the inside. The house is 55’ long and 23 ½’ wide. The down hill side underpinning is aprox. 4 ½’ and 32” on the back side.

Problem: Pipes froze last winter. Water supply comes into the house very close to the outside , where the underpinning has holes.
Solution: Build an insulated chase around the water line. Pipes under the house appear to be Pex, and although they froze, did not seem to be leaking. They are also insulated under the trailer.

Problem: Siding is missing on both sides of house.
Solution: Talk to resident/put eyes on the house. Sections of the house are enclosed but missing exterior siding.

Problem: Work needs to be done on heating system- ductwork , radiant floor hookups
Solution: Install radiant floor. Consult John- this is a highly technical job

Problem: Brush needs to be cut along driveway.
Solution: Prune and clip. CHC has a pruning saw, clippers, and work gloves, Follow Loretta’s direction.

Problem: Road in bad shape
Solution: Add gravel. Dig ditches and install waterbreaks

Problem: Drainage needed in yard
Solution: Install culvert. The ditch is mostly dug, but hand digging will be needed.. Contact Loretta about the type of culvert needed for this project. They have requested $ assistance with the culvert and other outside materials. It can be purchased at Parker Farm Supply (689-4808).

Problem: Drywall needed in pantry
Solution: Hang drywall and tape

Problem: Handrails needed on deck approx. 20 x 30
Solution: Call Independent Living. I gave John the number for Independent Living for handrails and bathroom modifications.

Problem: Bathroom Remodel in progress
Solution: Remove toilet, repair floor. Hang drywall. Install shower pan. Tile floor and shower walls. The Mullets know how to do this.

Problem: Drywall in living room is not finished.
Solution: Remove or cover furniture, Tape and mud drywall. Talk to the family about the type of finish desired. Approx. 1600 sf

Problem: Bedroom and bathroom have exposed insulation and need drywall to be hung on the ceiling.
Solution: Remove or cover furniture, Hang drywall and tape.

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: New roof.

Problem: Carolyn needs help with yard work
Solution: Weed, mow, etc.

Problem: Gutters clogged
Solution: Clean gutters

Problem: Corner boards missing
Solution: Add corner boards (1x4’s)

Problem: House needs to be painted. There is some mold here and there on the siding.
Solution: Remove plastic shutters. Clean the siding. Let dry and paint the house. The square footage of the exterior of the house is approximately 1300.

Problem: Water heater leak
Solution: Water heater leaking and needs replacement

Problem: Busted step out back
Solution: Replace tread with 2x6 pressure treated

Problem:
Walls have moisture damage around window sills. It is probably seeping in due to leaks on the sides or on the roof of the trailer.

Leak around stovepipe.

Leak above fridge
Solution: Membrane or metal roof needed. The trailer has a 3/12 pitched roof so metal may be a good choice. The trailer roof is 54' x 15'. There is a woodstove chimney, a 1 1/2" plumbing vent, a square roof vent, and a furnace vent (approx. 8" round)

Problem: Old appliances in back yard.
Solution: There is an old dryer and 2 old water heaters. Dispose of appliances at the landfill.

Problem: Underpinning needs some work
Solution: Overall, the place has good underpinning. Some holes in the ground under the underpinning should be filled in with dirt to keep critters out. Use sheet metal screws to re-fasten sheets of metal underpinning.

Problem: Water filter needed.
Solution: Install a new water filter. Wrench needed.

Problem: Bathroom needs work. There is a hole in the floor right in front of the toilet. Lavatory Faucet leaks and is missing handle. Bathroom fan missing. Paint needed.
Solution: The floor seems ok under the tub and vanity. Remove toilet. Put a layer of plywood (5/8) over top. Since you are raising the level of the floor you will need to move the toilet flange or add spacers. Install laminate flooring (vinyl). Reinstall toilet. Replace

Problem: Kitchen sink leaks. Cold water doesn’t work. Countertop has started to rot, sink falling through. .
Solution: Shut off supply lines. Unhook drain and water lines. Remove old sink and countertop. Remove cabinet. Cut out rotten floor and walls. Reinforce joists and repair walls, floor, subfloor, wall covering. Install new cabinets. Install new counter top and sink. Re- attach plumbing, repairing leaks if needed (there is one water line that leaks a little).

Problem: Kitchen floor also has some weak places.
Solution: Remove furniture and appliances, One of the holes is under the stove. Locate and mark joists. Install a layer of plywood (5/8”) over top of the old plywood and linoleum. Install new floor covering.

Problem: Living room floor has some weak spots. You might fall thru if you step in the wrong place.
Solution: Remove all furniture from room. Cover the entire living room with sheets of 5/8” plywood. The room is 13’ x 14’. There is no floor covering here. Install laminate flooring.

Problem: ramp/deck needs reinforcement (shaky)
Solution: Reinforce deck with diagonal bracing

Problem: No smoke and CO detector
Solution: Install smoke and CO detector

Problem: Busted board on front porch. Deck repairs needed.
Solution: Replace board (pressure treated 5/4 x 6). Shore uop and repair other parts of deck.

Problem: Hallway floor covering peeling up
Solution: Replace floor covering (50 square feet)

Problem: Hole in front of back door. Water has got in, possibly due to deck slope.
Solution: Remove flooring, reinforce joists, replace plywood. Since water is getting in here, a long term solution needs to be found to address that (build new deck that drains water away, or a porch roof)

Problem: Holes in bedroom floor. There is mold here on one of the walls. Strong mold smell.
Solution: Remove furniture, take up carpet, remove old subfloor, reinforce joists, replace subfloor, install new flooring. Tear out moldy drywall and replace damaged materials. The bedroom is 11’X12'

Problem: Bathroom floor is in bad shape.
Solution: Remodel bathroom. 42 sq. ft. Take out shower unit, toilet and vanity. Remove old pressboard flooring, reinforce joists, replace plywood. The existing tub is 54” x 27”, but there is enough room to put back a 30” x 60” tub/shower unit and surround. However, the plumbing will have to be moved. Toilet and vanity could be reused. Install new flooring.

Problem: No Water.
Solution: Have a plumber assess and estimate. May be best to replace all plumbing under there. According to Kin, the pipes burst not because of freezing, but because they were old and brittle.

Problem: No CO or Smoke Detector
Solution: Install CO/Smoke Detector

Problem: Oil heater in need of maintenance.
Solution: Clients given an application to CAO. Wood stove cannot be used because of health issues.

Problem: Insulation needed under Addition
Solution: Install 15” x r13 unfaced insulation- 2 bundles

Problem: New bathroom door needed
Door work needed. Homeowners request new front and back doors, although the existing doors could be repaired.
Solution: Exterior door is 30” x 74”. New knobs and work on strike plate will be needed.

Problem: Fix rotten walls on addition
Solution: Remove old plywood, repair framing if necessary, and install new plywood, install window, paint.

Problem: Leaky single pane windows
Solution: Install double pane replacements- talk to window co about exact measurements and costs. 3 @ 40” w by 46” H 1 @ 26” w by 29” H 1 @ 14” w by 26” H 2 @ 27” w by 45” H 1 @ 45” w by 39” H

Problem: Bay windows need to be replaced
Outbuilding Roof slopes toward house-rain runoff has caused damage to wall
Solution: Install gutters, fascia and rafter tails on 1 side of outbuilding. Length of gutter= 26’

Problem: Drainage issues. A lot of water goes under the house when it rains
Solution: Install new gutters on the porch roof. 30 feet will be needed. Tie in to existing black drainpipe after verifying that is goes all the way under the house and is not clogged up. Install gutters on uphill side of house (over the porch). 60 feet will be needed here. Get the large- capacity aluminum gutters. Dig a ditch on the side of the house with the oil tank and put a black drainpipe in. watch for underground pipes, etc. Dotson Seamless gutters is recommended if you want to hire a

Problem: Porch floor is sagging. Framing is probably rotten underneath. Plywood floor.
Solution: Remove at least half of the plywood and replace /repair damaged framing. Replace flooring with 5/4 treated deck boards. You may have to replace all the deck so that the floor will be flat and level. You may have to put some blocks under the porch framing. The deck should wind up level with the ramp so that there is a smooth

Problem: Back porch needs a new set of steps. The existing ones are too hard to climb for disabled individuals.
Solution: Build a new set of steps with no more than a 7” rise per step. Make the steps 48” wide. Build hand rails.

Problem: Ramp needs work. Volunteers improved it in 2015 but it is still too steep and the plywood surface becomes slick when wet or icy.
Solution: Build a new, less steep ramp on top of the old one. The other option is to build forms and make a concrete ramp. If improving the wood ramp, Use 3 16’ long pressure treated 2x6 for the frame, these will have to be cut with some complicated angles on them to fit right. Then deck it with 5/4 deck boards. Install non- slip tread tape . Fill in the low spot at the end of the ramp with bagged concrete and gravel. Make a handrail extending along the entire length of the ramp.

Problem: The circuit panel looks old and the main power to the outbuilding runs along the ground in a heavy wire. Ralph says several outlets are loose and sometimes spark when something is plugged into them. New outlets should be installed and a general safety check performed. The main power pole is leaning and loose.
Solution: New pole needed. It is a short pole. French Broad EMC will need to come out and have a look. Fix or replace outlets. Get the wire off the ground. *Need to check with FBEMC

Problem: No CO/smoke detectors
Solution: Install CO/smoke detector

Problem: Missing and moldy siding
Solution: Install remaining vinyl, clean existing siding

Problem: Unpainted OSB ceilings in 2 rooms
Solution: Paint

Problem: Homeowner has requested window replacements.
Solution: The existing windows are single pane trailer windows. No windows have screens. Making screens might be a good project if new windows are too expensive.

Problem: Old toilet has issues (runs)
Solution: Replace guts of toilet or replace toilet

Problem: Septic needs clean-out
Solution: Call service for cleaning

Problem: No decking outside door
Solution: Install a small, free-standing deck (4’x4’?)with steps.You can’t just put a set of steps here because it would block the crawlspace access. Install rails. Warning: the septic tank is back here. If you dig holes watch out for drain lines. The electrical service comes in near here; watch out for this, too.

Problem: Exterior door not working
Solution: The rough opening is 29” wide x 74” high.  Remove door and modify the rough opening (i.e. replace framing with thinner material) , or cut door if possible.

Problem: Back door damaged due to roof leak
Solution: Replace door. It is an exterior trailer door , 32” x 72 ½”.

Problem: Water freezes in winter
Solution: Block up crawlspace vent hole(s) ( at least in the winter) with a piece of foam board insulation. The hole is less than 2 feet. It looks like cold air can get through this hole.

Problem: Outlet has been getting wet. This is dangerous especially because it is 240 v. Another outlet in the house does not work, and a light fixture needs work (it hangs down by the wires).
Solution: Fix roof. Get electrician to come out.

Problem: Walls have been damaged in the room where the roof leak is. Paneling is warped.
Solution: Fix roof, then tear off paneling and assess damage. You will probably have to replace framing, insulation, and paneling. There are wires in this wall.

Problem: Ceiling damage due to roof leak.
Solution: Make sure the roof doesn’t leak, then repair ceiling. Ceiling is 7/16 OSB plywood. Cut out bad place along ceiling joists and replace osb and insulation., checking framing for

Problem: Roof leak. Mortar mix was left around the masonry chimney and could have caused the metal around the chimney to deteriorate.
Solution: I told Vergie to call me next time it rained to see if the roofing cement stopped the leak. If it didn’t, then apply

Problem: No CO detecter
Solution: Install CO detecter

Problem: termites
Solution: This problem was discovered while repairing the rotted walls. Although the walls have dried out, damage has been done over the years. Contact Edens Pest Control or Terminix.Viola has been informed of the situation.

Problem: Bathtub needs work. Water can get through the tub surround. Note- this tub is not used at this time.
Solution: Remove old tub surround. Check for leaks in the plumbing if possible. Repair rotten wall material and studs if necessary. Put a new tub surround back.

Problem: Floor damage in corner of bedroom. This has been temporarily fixed but might need work in the future
Solution: Take up flooring and subfloor in that corner and replace bad plywood.

Problem: Canning shed where pressure tank and well plumbing is located has a door whose bottom is starting to rot out. A piece of trim should be replaced. There is a small hole.
Solution: Repair door and hole to keep cold air and varmints out.

Problem: The siding on this trailer is rotting
Solution: Replace rotten siding with t-111. Since this will go up under the gutters, it should be probably be done first.

Problem: Gutter work needed. There are gutters between the trailer roof and the addition roofs, which actually hold water and contribute to the leaks between the porch and trailer (see photos). The gutters on the back side of the carport are falling off.
Solution: Remove unnecessary gutters. This job should go along with the roof repair. Re install new gutters (the old ones are in ok shape but might get torn up during demo) around the perimeter of the house, not between the trailer and additions like it was before. The carport gutters can probably just be screwed back up.

Problem: Leaky roof
Solution: A couple of stains inside, and the fact that this is a 1984 trailer, indicates possible leaks. A leak has been noticed above the sink in bathroom #2.There is a leak above the front door.
