Both porches leak, due to improper flashing and low pitch on a shingle roof (approx..1/12).  Membrane roof . Roof is 14’ wide, 57’ long. The carport roof is metal and the porch roof (facing the road) is shingle. The membrane should overhang the porch roofs by at least 1 foot to prevent leaks between the trailer and porches. To fasten this overhanging membrane edge, use roofing caulk. Let the edge of the membrane hang into the gutters so that water will drain off the roof properly. There are 2 – 2” vents. There is a wood stove chimney (8” with storm collar and a 14” metal boot), and another furnace chimney(8”).

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Vinyl siding is dirty.
Solution: Clean siding.

Problem: Drafty windows (trailer style). Window is not broken.
Solution: Replace window and trim out.Opening is 53” high x 75 ½” wide

Problem: New faucet needed in bathroom.
Solution: See photos for type.

Problem: Walls need paint
Solution: Paint living room.

Problem: No gutters on back
Solution: Install gutters, downspouts, and black drain pipe. Make the middle high and put a drain pipe and down spout on each end. This will help the problem of Water splashing up on the deck and getting into the house.

Problem: Front steps in bad shape
Solution: Use pt lumber. 30” height. Build hand rails.

Problem: Electrical issues.A short happened here in the outlet where the AC was plugged in. The AC is now unplugged but the breaker is on because it runs some other stuff. A new outlet is needed.
Solution: Get an electrician to check it out. Ben Houser is fairly local. Kenneth mentioned that Mindy’s brother was an electrician.

Problem: No heat in son’s room. Kenneth suspects a clogged duct (previous owners allowed debris to get in there).
Solution: Try vaccuming out the duct with a powerful shop vac. If that doesn’t work consult a heating technician. (Bullman’s?)

Problem: Holes in floor. This problem was caused by water getting into the threshold, splashing up from the improperly- built deck.
Solution: Repair the subfloor. Flooring material has been removed. Cut out plywood and replace, fix joists if necessary. Install laminate flooring and underlayment, which Kenneth has purchased and is already on-site.

Problem: Back deck caused water to get in house
Solution: Tear down the deck. It is 4’ x 8’. It has no steps or hand rails, and it is currently 34” high. Re-build a free standing deck with steps that does not touch the house. Drop the deck height 6”. Build the frame so that it slopes away from the deck 1/8” per foot. Code does not require a rail but one should be built because of the client’s mobility issues.

Problem: In the kitchen, there is some material behind the kitchen that has water damage due to an old leak (fixed).
Solution: Replace material. It is faux- tile paneling. See photos. Approx. 1’ x 5’ section.

Problem: There are at least 3 windows that will not shut right. They are old single panes and should be replaced. Note- Block building. You will have to add pressure treated wood to the inside, making the rough openings smaller. RO’s are given including this extra framing.
Solution: ROUGH OPENINGS 1) 22 ½” high x 34” wide. 2) 33 ½”h x 32 ½” wide 3) 46” h x 82” wide. This could be 2 windows side- by side. All windows should be single or double hung, double panes.

Problem: Concrete spillway has a busted section
Solution: Patch with mortar mix

Problem: Basement and can house under porch need to be cleaned out and organized.
Solution: Talk to Nancy about what stays and what goes. Tammy has a pickup truck for dump runs. Get dump # .

Problem: Gutters need to be cleaned.
Solution: Clean gutters. Tall ladder (24’) needed. Talk to Tammy, she may be able to provide a fire truck with ladders as a training exercise for vol. firefighters.

Problem: Old, dented gutter.
Solution: New gutter and downspout needed on corner.  Hook up to existing 2” drain pipe. It runs to spillway (see below).

Problem: No soffit or fascia on back side.
Solution: Install soffit, fascia. Paint. Install gutters. Run drainpipe along side of house and direct into drainpipe near front porch.

Problem: Porch ceiling is unpainted. Soffit paint is peeling. Door paint is peeling. Siding of addition is unpainted.
Solution: Scrape old paint. Caulk and Paint.

Problem: Install lattice under the addition to keep out varmints.
Solution: Nancy has 4x8 sheets of lattice and some pressure treated lumber for this project.

Problem: Exposed water pipe. Underneath the addition around back, there are some water lines and a drain pipe for the washing machine that could freeze.
Solution: Insulate water pipes better. Build a plywood chase around them to keep off wind.

Problem: Hole in front of house. There is an 8’high x 10’ wide opening on the front of the house that is covered with boards and other material. This area needs to be closed in and insulated.
Solution: Install insulation board and siding. Paint.

Problem: There are 2 double doors to the basement that won’t open.
Solution: Dig dirt away from door opening. Adjust the hinges so that the doors will open and close easily. Paint doors.

Problem: On the back porch, the pressure-treated wood ramp has a 2x4 handrail but it is not very secure and there are no pickets.
Solution: Put new posts in the ground for the ramp around back, and install pickets, Nancy has pickets stored under some metal around back.

Problem: The metal guard rails on the front porch are loose and there are no step hand rails.
Solution: Tighten up metal guard rail using concrete screws. The existing screws are not holding so you will need longer ones. Use a hammer drill to pre- drill holes. Install a new hand rail (metal or wood) on both sides of the front steps.

Problem: New flooring requested in living room and kitchen.
Solution: Total Square footage is approx.. 325. Remove carpet and linoleum and install new laminate flooring.

Problem: Window screens torn
Solution: Install new screens. Not measured. Mars Hill Hardware may be able to get screens. I have priced the adjustable kind at Lowes.
Volunteer or Groups:
Grace Church Cathedral/ St. Pauls;
(old) Western North Carolina Servant EVENT

Problem: New attic access panel needed.
Solution: Take a scrap of drywall ( 1’ x 2’ ) and cut it the same size as the old, cracked one.

Problem: A couple of window panes are broken
Solution: Sizes are approximately 24” x 32” and 20 ½” x 34 ½”. You may have to remove small pieces of trim to get the exact measurements. Mars Hill hardware cut glass.

Problem: Iron filter is no longer used.
Solution: Take it out of the house. Talk to Karen about disposal.

Problem: The bathtub has a hole in it.
Solution: New tub and surround. The existing one is 58 ½”long by 32” wide. It is 70” tall. There is plenty of room height-wise but if the new tub is longer you will have to modify the closet that buts up to the tub. Make sure you have the skills to fix plumbing if something breaks or leaks during tub installation.

Problem: Bedroom door is coming apart
Solution: Replace door. It is 32” x 80”.Install door knob.

Problem: Hole in interior closet door.
Solution: Replace door. It is 20” wide and 80” tall.

Problem: Electrical work needed. There is an electrical box on the porch that has no outlet, just wires covered with tape. A couple of switches inside do not work.
Solution: Turn off power to applicable circuits. Install a GFI outlet on the porch. Install one or two new switches.

Problem: Drainage work needed.
Solution:
Remove half of the nails from the existing gutter in the front of the house.

Try not to damage the gutters as they are seamless and still in good shape. Pull the gutter downwards so that the high point is in the middle. Install some new gutter nails or screws. Install a downspout on the end closest to the drive. Dig a ditch from the steps, or under the steps, leading out into the yard, where it will join with another drainpipe that is buried in the yard. Make sure to consult with Karen on the location of the drainpipe. Install 4” black drain pipe and “T” into the other pipe. The same job could be done on the opposite side of the house. Karen may have some drainpipe- ask before buying.

Problem: There are a couple of small roof leaks that can be seen from inside in the bathroom. Roof cement around the chimney and vents is cracked. A few shingles are missing, and looks like they have been blown off. Karen has requested a new metal roof because of her windy location. The shingles are about 18 yrs. old.
Solution: Install new metal roof over existing roof. Install perlins, then metal. The existing roof is about a 5/12 pitch and is about 1720 square feet.

Problem: The handrails on the deck are loose and falling down. The deck boards are old and splintery.
Solution: Tear down old handrails. Remove deck boards. Replace handrails and decking. Use 2x6 pressure treated for decking. Deck height approx.. 30”. The framing is probably still good.

Problem: Trash needs to be hauled. family has a trailer full .
Solution: Hook up the trailer to Josh or Wayne's truck and haul it to the landfill.

Problem: No rear entrance/exit. There is a door but no steps .
Solution: Build a small (4'x4') deck with steps. Build hand rails if deck height is over 30".

Problem: Doorway has water damage
Solution: Build a porch roof to keep the entrance dry. (8' x 8'). Posts are in place to support downhill side of roof.

Problem: Drywall needs replacement. daylight can be seen thru a hole in the drywall where there is no exterior siding.
Solution: Wayne has removed a lot of old, moldy drywall. He has a stack of 3/8"drywall that he plans on using to replace what is damaged

Problem: Roof leaks
Solution: Kool seal and tar around penetrations for now. A membrane or other solution will be needed in the long run. the roof is 14'8" x 68' long. 3/12 roof pitch.

Problem: No heat
Solution: Wayne says he has a monitor heater that he plans to hook up.

Problem: Bathroom #2 needs work
Solution:
Bathroom #2 is larger; it is the one with the walk in shower. There is a seperate room where the toilet is.

Remodel bathroom. Plumbing condition unknown.

Problem: Bathroom #1 is 4 1/2' x 7 1/2'. The tub and surround should be replaced. good vanity, toilet condition unknown.
Solution: Remodel bathroom.Existing tub size is 54" x 90" (trailer size). plumbing condition unknown

Problem: Floor is bad underneath walk- in shower.
Solution: Remove walk in shower(it is still in good shape) and repair the floor underneath. remove old plywood, reinforce joists, replace plywood, and reinstall shower.

Problem: Holes in floor
Solution: The worst places are in the living room near the wall, in the bedroom in a corner, at the front door, and in the utility room.The good news is that the floor is 5/8 " plywood, not the standard press- board. Remove damaged plywood , reinforce floor framing, and replace plywood. - Note- Wayne is working on this and has enough plywood to cover the floors in the whole house. .

Problem: Siding has lots of water damage. there are some places where there is no siding on the house, leaving it open to the elements.
Solution: Replace siding on entire trailer. Wayne has priced 2 different kinds of siding. Consult with him before purchasing siding materials. Remove old stuff (MDF), install vapor barrier, then run siding.

Problem: The outside walls of the trailer do not have enough support under them; some of the metal framing arms have been damaged.  Walls have water damage . framing needs to be replaced and rebuilt. Walls missing on one section of the trailer.
Solution: Pour a footer all the way around the perimeter of the home and build a frame with 4x4 and 2x4 pressure treated material. this would serve as support for the outside wall as well as something to nail underpinning to (there is none). Note- Wayne has about 10- 10' 2x4's on site.  Reinforce exterior walls by either rebuilding or scabbing on 2x4's. Job in progress.

Problem: No water
Solution: Wayne plans to use the track hoe to dig a ditch for a water line out to the well on the property. then a water line can be installed and plumbing can be assessed.

Problem: No power
Solution: Get power turned on. Wayne has a temporary line out from Josh's to run a few things such as power tools. The septic would have to be approved then the power co. could come and install a meter base. After that the family would be responsible for wiring from the meter base to the circuit panel inside the house.

Problem: No septic hooked up
Solution: Inspect and hook up septic system. There is a septic tank in place, and they have a permit, (has not been inspected yet) but there are no drainpipes leading from the home to the septic tank. Wayne has access to a track hoe that he plans to use to dig ditches for drain lines. However, the track hoe has a bad fuel pump. for bathroom, right now they use Josh's bathroom or use a bucket.  Once the tank is inspected and the ditches dug, install drain pipes from toilets , sinks, etc to the tank.

Problem: Need CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Missing vinyl soffit material on gable end
Solution: Install vinyl (solid ok) and trim

Problem: Sara wants to replace her old carpet in the living room and Hallway.
Solution: She has some flooring (pre finished hardwood), but not enough. cheaper to install laminate. Living room is 210 square feet. Hall is 49 square feet.

Problem: Sara has requested a new deck. The old one is 6' x 6' with steps. It is in good condition, she just wants a new one that is bigger.
Solution: If a vol. group wants to build a new deck , she wants it to be 8' x 28'. Height is 24". She wants 2 sets of steps and rails. There is also a big covered porch in the front.

Problem: Smoke and CO detector needed. She has a CO detector but it needs a 9v battery.
Solution: Install smoke detector and get 9V battery.

Problem: Jeanette would like some new windows in the addition. All of the windows in this room are fixed ( will not open) and are single pane. Water is starting to damage a couple of sills.
Solution: I gave her the number for Community Action (weatherization services). Here are the measurements for 5 windows: 1) 30 ½”high x 18 1/4” wide 2) 30 ½”high x 18 1/4” wide 3) 30 ½” wide x 18 ¼” high (installed the other way). 4) 55” high x 14” wide 5) 55” high x 14” wide

Problem: Window screens broken (front porch).
Solution: She needs 3- they are 52 ½” x 44”. You can make your own screens if you get the frames and screen.

Problem: Vinyl siding is dirty.
Solution: Clean siding with buckets of soapy water and scrub brushes. (Pressure washing makes a big mess).
Volunteer or Groups:
Forsyth United Methodist Church;
St. Mary's (Kinston)

Problem: Back porch floorboards are dirty and some are damaged. Rails and posts needs to be painted.
Solution: The floorboards are currently unpainted. You will need to replace a few boards here( Back porch not measured). Clean the floorboards with a wire brush and warm water. Scrape and paint the rails and posts. They are white.

Problem: The front porch floor has a couple of pieces of plywood that are damaged. The porch rail tops have warped and should be replaced.
Solution: After the roof is fixed, Remove the 2 pieces of plywood(1/2 “) that are the most damaged and replace with new plywood. Paint entire porch. Porch floor is 320 square feet. Remove porch rail tops, reinforce with ripped- down 2x4’s, and replace rails with thicker material.

Problem: Roof leaks. The main leaks are on the front and back porches. There is also a leak in one bathroom. Some parts of the roof have less than a 2/12 pitch. There is some plywood damage. The shingles could be around 16 years old.
Solution: The first thing to do is go up with roofing cement and patch around the plumbing vent that is the closest to the back porch. It is obviously leaking. Patch or re- roof. The roof leaks because shingles do not work well on a pitch less than 3/12. A metal roof would be better but would cost more in labor and materials because there are a lot of hips and valleys on the roof. Not all of the roof would necessarily have to be replaced, just the shallow part where there is a problem. Note that some plywood is damaged and will take time to repair before the roof goes on. You may have to remove the gutters to repair damaged areas on the edge of the roof.

Problem: Heater is making a funny noise and heat pump is sitting in a puddle.
Solution: Have a heating guy inspect the furnace and raise the outside unit up onto blocks.

Problem: CO/ Smoke detector needed
Solution: Install

Problem: Higher toilet requested
Solution: Install- ind. living

Problem: Handicap rails needed in bathroom
Solution: Install- ind. Living

Problem: Ramp needed from driveway to deck
Solution: Build ramp 3’ wide x 30’ long

Problem: Water is starting to damage front doorway.
Solution: Build a small cover over door. This is a north- facing entryway so snow can be a problem.

Problem: Porch flooring is cracked and warped
Solution: Replace porch flooring

Problem: Need CO/smoke detectors
Solution: Install CO/smoke detectors

Problem: New front door needed. Cannot lock/secure door. Difficult to open.
Solution: Install new, trailer-size exterior door. Storm door is 31 3/4" x 74 3/4".

Problem: Broken window panes
Solution: Remove plastic trim. Take out broken glass-2) 36 3/4" high x 29 1/4" wide window panes. Replace panes and caulk or glaze if the trim won't go back in.

Problem: Roof leaks. Black stains noticeable on ceiling.
Solution: New metal roof. Trailer roof is 14 1/2' wide and about 70' long. . There is a woodstove chimney, a range hood chimney, and 2 bathroom vents. Extend bathroom vents, the other penetrations can be flashed around. Roof is gable style, approx. 3/12. The wood stove chimney may have to be extended , but that can be done after the roof. Add rigid insulation to prevent condensation resulting in roof leaks.

Problem: Insulation missing in floor. R19- 15".
Solution: Install unfaced fiberglass or rigid foamboard.

Problem: Water line needs to be insulated. Some underpinning is needed. Randie says the line is not buried deep enough, and problems have been reported with water freezing.
Solution: Insulate water line. Add underpinning. Randie has some stashed away. Talk to Randie about the water line. He is planning to dig it up and bury it deeper. Water comes from a neighbor's well.

Problem: Floor repair needed in one bedroom.
Solution: Remove furniture. Tear up old carpet. repair subfloor, or put a layer over top like they have been doing. Install new flooring. Aprox. 200 sft.

Problem: Other floor work is needed. Randie and Darlene have put a layer of 7/16 OSB over 75% of the floors in the house. Flooring is needed.
Solution: Move furniture and install laminate flooring. The living room and kitchen is probably about 600 square feet. Call Randie for exact measurements.

Problem: The second bathroom has a hole in the floor and the toilet needs work. Job is in progress.
Solution: Remove toilet. Put plywood down. Reinforce joists if needed. Put vinyl flooring down. Bathroom is 5' x 10'. Randie has a wax ring and new flange.

Problem: The first bathroom has a broken tub.
Solution: Replace tub and shower surround. Existing tub is 60". Floor seems good in here. there is a good toilet and vanity

Problem: Back deck is wobbly and has no steps or rails.
Solution: Repair or replace deck, it is 6 1/2' x 4'. Install decking, and build rails and steps. Deck height is approx.40". Build decks to code including slope away from house. Decks should be free standing (not attached to house).

Problem: Front deck seems structurally ok, but has some boards missing. There are no guard rails or handrails for the steps.
Solution: Install decking and build rails. Deck height approx. 40". Existing deck is 6 1/2'x 93". Build decks to code including slope away from house. Decks should be free standing (not attached to house). Consult the attached document for deck rebuilding rules.

Problem: Needs old flooring hauled off
Solution: Help haul off old flooring

Problem: CO detector needed
Solution: Installed CO detector

Problem: Gutters need to be cleaned. Underpinning and lattice need to be put back up correctly.
Solution: Clean Gutters. A couple pieces of underpinning need to be repositioned and screwed back up. I talked to Wilma about getting her relatives to accomplish these tasks.

Problem: Steps need TLC
Solution: Replace some treads and add a stringer

Problem: 12’ x 12’ deck in need of repainting
Solution: Scrape and paint deck

Problem: Thresholds need to be installed throughout home.
Solution: Install three 36” and one 60” thresholds.

Problem: Owner requests new floor covering in Bedroom.
Solution: Remove old carpet and install laminate flooring. Square footage is 200. Haul off old carpet

Problem: Toilet is wobbly. It does not appear to be leaking.
Solution: The flange is probably too high. Remove toilet, unscrew flange from floor and reposition flange. You may have to crawl underneath to work on this. The toilet is old so this would be a good time to replace it if finances permit. The floor seems sound but you may find some damage which should be repaired if you do this.

Problem: Some volunteers built a porch roof incorrectly. The top of the metal porch roof is higher than the bottom of the shingled main roof. There are gutters between the roofs. Water rains down between the 2 roofs in front of the doorway. The area around the doorway could get water- damaged.
Solution: The long term solution (high-skilled) would be to tear off the roof metal, perlins, rafters, and supporting band ( it is under-framed). Cut off the posts , reframe the roof with better framing (use 2x6 band instead of 2x4), and rebuild roof with a steeper pitch (lower the downhill side). Make a seamless transition between the porch and shingle roof. As a temporary measure, the gutters could be cleaned and better, wider flashing installed to eliminate or at least reduce the amount of water that gets between the porch and main roof.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: The house is very cluttered.
Solution: Gary inherited some furniture, etc. plus there is a lot of his brother’s old stuff. He is trying to sell some of it. He may need help hauling some of it to Beacon of hope or Goodwill.

Problem: Gary has requested help with some painting, trim, baseboard, tile, and laminate flooring. He says this work is necessary so that he can get a “reverse mortgage”.
Solution: Gary has most of the materials for these projects, just needs help with labor. (He can’t do much because of his shoulder.) Consult with him about plans for finish work.

Problem: 5 Screen on gable vents is torn
Solution: Install new screen

Problem: Heating issues. The home’s radiant floor system is not working right. Some rooms are heated, some not. The space is hard to heat because it is so big.
Solution: Gary wants to install a wood stove. He has the stove and the triple wall pipe. He needs help installing it and getting the right parts. A hole will have to be cut in the roof. Concerning the radiant heat, he mentioned that draining the pressure tank for the heating system would help but he is not sure how to do it.

Problem: There are some doors and windows that are giving Gary some trouble. The windows stick and one door needs to be replaced.
Solution: Apply silicone lubricant to some window sashes .Adjust window closings. Adjust strike plates. Gary would like new windows and doors, but windows are all double pane insulated, so replacing them would be expensive. Replace door. Gary has a door, just take hinge pins out and replace door slab.

Problem: Gary has noticed some mold on his exterior windows. These windows are unfinished and are on the north side.
Solution: Clean with bleach, let dry, and apply low VOC clear wood finish. (Gary is very sensitive).

Problem: Outlets are getting hot.  Gary says the house was not wired properly and should be inspected by an electrician
Solution: Have an electrician check the place over. Check outlets especially in Kitchen

Problem: Drainage around the house could use improvement. The yard is flat and the downspouts drain right onto the ground in the corners of the house.
Solution: Cut off downspout and hook up a solid black corrugated pipe to it. Run it alongside the house behind the storage shed. Tie it into the downspout on the front side. Dig a 12’ ditch and bury the drainpipe. On the opposite side, do the same thing, just run the pipe alongside the house. Bury 15’ of pipe.

Problem: Dripping faucets in 2nd bathroom
Solution: Replace gaskets

Problem: Bathroom sink has a small leak. The sink is too small for the hole in the countertop.
Solution: If budget permits replace vanity countertop, sink and faucet. Otherwise fix the leak with a gasket or new faucet.

Problem: Kitchen faucet leaks when turned on. Howardette deals with this by keeping a basin under the sink.
Solution: Replace Kitchen faucet. Re- do connections from the shut-offs to the faucet. See photos for type of faucets needed.

Problem: Deck has a broken step tread and rotten floor boards.
Solution: Install a couple of 2x4 diagonal braces to reinforce the 4x4 posts. Install bolts thru the band into the posts. Replace tread and replace floor boards. Use pressure treated. Billy and Howardette’s nephew say they have the skills to do this. They want to widen the steps ( add another stringer).

Problem: Bedroom window has a sash that does not fit in the casing. Cold air gets in.
Solution: Replace window. It is 30” w x 53” tall. It could be that you could replace one sash .

Problem: Roof leaks. The shingles are fairly new but the vents look like they are leaking.
Solution: Replace vent boots. Take a bucket of roof cement and seal around the penetrations. You may have to remove some shingles to do this correctly.

Problem: There is a very weak spot in the bedroom floor. This is more than likely due to a roof leak. Water has leaked thru a vent, run down the wall and damaged the floor. A bed covers this area so it is not likely that someone will step here. The wall is damaged also.
Solution: After the roof is fixed, remove carpet and cut away bad subfloor. Reinforce joists if needed, install new plywood. Remove wall covering, check for damaged framing and repair. Note- there is an outlet in the wall here.

Problem: There is a hole in the floor right as you enter the house in front of the washer and drier.
Solution: This is about a 3’x8’ place where the floor is weak. There is a piece of solid plywood laid over the area now which makes it a lot safer. This will need a more permanent solution, however. Remove the washer and dryer. Remove the plywood patch and inspect the floor for damage. Set up a plastic barrier to cut down on dust in the rest of the house. Remove old, damaged subfloor, reinforce joists if needed. Set your saw depth so as not to risk cutting wires, heating ducts, etc. Replace plywood (thickness unknown). Install about 25 square feet of laminate flooring. There is also weak and sagging flooring in the living room. The carpet is also wet and molded. The drywall in this area also looks to have some water damage.

Problem: No CO2 detector
Solution: Install battery powered co detector.

Problem: Windows need some work. air leaks in.
Solution: This problem may be able to be solved with some elbow grease. The windows are double pane and it would be a shame to replace them. The latches may need some adjustment, and weather stripping could be used to keep some

Problem: Basement needs some insulation in the floor.
Solution: Install 400 square feet of R30 unfaced fiberglass insulation

Problem: Basement sliding glass doors do not work properly.
Solution: Family requests the sliding glass doors to be removed, the space framed in, and an exterior door and window to be installed . The rough opening should be around 70" x 80 3/4" when the SGD is removed.

Problem: Entire exterior of house needs painting.
Solution: Some sections have one coat and some are bare wood. Paint. The surface to be painted is approx. 1875 square feet.You will need several extension ladders, the tallest of which should be 24'.

Problem: Siding that was under the old deck is rotten. Framing is ok.
Solution: Replace siding. It is 5/8" T111. caulk and paint.

Problem: Storm door is in bad shape.
Solution: Replace. Existing storm door is 38" wide x 82 1/2" tall including the flanges.

Problem: Stair tread broken. Loose handrails.
Solution: Deck is 24" off ground but needs rails because of client's balance issues. Deck is 7' x 10' .

Problem: Need front deck entrance. Deck has been torn off. The front deck has been removed because it was causing damage to the building. There is a sliding glass door where the deck was. It stays locked and there are boards in front of it, but she needs a better exit. The only other exit is down through the cluttered basement.
Solution: Build a deck and steps with guard rails and hand rails. You will need to replace some siding first. Follow building code regarding wood decks. The sliding glass door is 9 feet off the ground. The deck must be sloping away from the house. Steps should be less than 8 inches high and at least 11 " wide. Steps will go off to the left as you face the building. Deck should be 5'wide by 8' long. A free standing deck would be best here because it would not be attached to the house ,possibly leading to water damaging the side of the house like it did before. Since it is so high off the ground it should be braced really well. Brace posts according to code.

Problem: Need CO2 detector
Solution: Install battery powered combo unit

Problem: Deck needs TLC. Boards are dirty & worn. Handrails wobbly.
Solution: Install a 4x4 left of the steps. Make it go down into the ground about a foot then tamp the dirt around it. Screw to rails. Clean the deck with a wire brush and warm water. Take some screws and screw back loose boards. This deck is 8' x 8'

Problem: Skylight trim fell down into the bathtub
Solution: Nail back up. Nail back up. The wrong nails were used. Go ahead and take down the other 3 pieces of trim and reinstall with 2” finish nails. Drill pilot holes.

Problem: Spongy floor between kitchen and living room
Solution: Replace plywood (you will have to cut out a small section to determine the correct plywood thickness). Shore up framing if needed. Approx.. 3’x 3’ section. There is currently linoleum

Problem: Spongy floor where the old leak was in the dining room-corner of house.
Solution: Move dining room table and other furniture. Tear up a corner of the carpet. . Repair subfloor where damaged, check floor and wall framing for damage. Replace plywood (you will have to cut out a small section to determine the correct plywood thickness). put carpet back. If finances permit this room could be re-floored, but fixing the corner should take care of the urgent need.

Problem: Toilet leaks. The tub has the water shut off to it.
Solution: The toilet has the water shut off to it so it is not actively leaking. The subfloor around the toilet has been repaired where it was water damaged, but the toilet never got fixed. This is an old commode so it would be a good time to replace it. Remove toilet, tear up old carpet, install vinyl laminate flooring on part (15 square feet)or all(70 SFT) of the floor, then replace the toilet with a new wax ring. Note- client has another bathroom in good condition.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install CO detector

Problem: Windows cracked , leaky
Solution: Replace at least two windows

Problem: Floor work needed in bathroom. There is a closet here that a water heater could go in.
Solution: The floor around the toilet seemed stable. Flooring will be needed, get better insulation for pipes. This is a small bathroom approx. 40 sq. feet.

Problem: Front door broken
Solution: Replace. 32” x 73” door and knob

Problem: Electrical issues
Solution: Upgrade needed. Clients have old fuse box. Blows fuses when overloaded . Upgrade needed. Box is hard to get to.

Problem: Heating issues
Solution: Multiple. I told Brenda to contact Social Services for heating assistance. Have a heating man come check out the heater. Greg may have his brother come out. They also have an oil furnace that someone gave them that they say works but do not have the skills to install it. They have a 100 lb. propane tank. They also have an oil tank but it is on the ground.

Problem: Hot water heater has bad leak.
Solution: Replace water heater with one that is a similar size. This is a small, 20” dia. X 21”” high water heater. It is in a closet. The floor is wet so there will probably be damage to the floor. Replace plywood or put a piece of plywood on top. Clients have a water heater in their barn that they say is good, but it would not fit in the closet (it is 25” dia. X 32” high). Replace water heater with one that is a similar size. Clients say they will donate the one in the barn. You might could fit the bigger water heater in the bathroom closet. The plumbing for the house, according to Greg, is all PEX and is run on the inside of the house to help it not freeze. The pipes next to the outside wall have been covered loosely with various insulation materials.

Problem: Leak in kitchen ceiling. The ceiling material is missing and the trusses are damaged. Water is leaking where the kitchen light is. There are several other leaks in the roof.
Solution: Overbuild roof frame and install new metal. Greg tried to repair the damage in the kitchen but it is not sound. He scabbed on some 2by material and put some kool seal on the roof, which might hold for a while but it is not a long term solution. A membrane is not advised because walking on the roof is too dangerous. Overbuild roof frame and install new metal. Trailer is 10’ wide and 52’ long. Build off porch framing.

Problem: Back side of house siding rotted
Solution: Replace old siding and paint

Problem: Living room and kitchen needs paint
Solution: Primer/Kiltz ceilings and paint

Problem: 3 windows need replacement
Solution: Install new windows 3-2/8x3/0"

Problem: Hand railing missing on front porch
Solution: Install new hand railing

Problem: Kitchen floor sagging
Solution: Kitchen floor built close to ground. Replace old sub floor with p.t. plywood, install new floor covering.

Problem: Roof needs repair/replace
Solution:
Repair: Replace damaged nails or screws with 1.25 roofing screws. Flash around chimney and kool seal roof.

Replace: demo and install new metal and screws, ridgecap. Jack stated an older portion of the roof is more than 60 years old. Replacement would be the better option.

Problem: Front porch needs repair
Solution: Replace Deck boards

Problem: Back door has no steps
Solution: Build 4' x 4' landing and steps. Make the landing slope away from the house. it should be free- standing.  Height is 20" off the ground.

Problem: Electrical work needed. A bad short recently happened. Outlets are "trailer- style" push-in outlets.
Solution: This job is in progress. Charles has an electrician (Andy Banks) who has replaced 2 outlets and plans on replacing more. Follow up with Charles.

Problem: Floor material needed in kitchen. (linoleum has been cut).
Solution: Install water resistant  flooring after the subfloor has been repaired. 100 square feet.

Problem: Hole in kitchen floor in front of sink. Due to a plumbing leak.
Solution: The leak has been repaired but the hole is still there. Cut out a section of the old floor and replace with plywood. add 2x4 framing.

Problem: Unsafe porch, holes and rooted wood.
Solution: A complete rebuild is needed, but you could save the porch roof. Install temporary supports (double 2x4's) to hold up the porch roof. Remove floorboards. Remove brick and framing materials (some could be reused). Install new foundation posts, re-frame, install new decking. Replace posts if the old ones cannot be reused. Install hand rails (steps are concrete). Warning: lead paint is on the posts and on all of the siding. Temporarily, a piece of plywood could go on top of the porch from the door to the steps. Porch is 7' wide by 35' long.

Problem: Roof leaking
Solution: Replace entire roof. Repair any damaged wood and install new gutters on the back side

Problem: Plumbing needs upgrade
Solution: Replace existing pipes with pex and replace/repair fixtures as needed.

Problem: No CO detector
Solution: Install a CO detector

Problem: Wood cook stove not working
Solution: This will require a chimney and roof repair (this is where the leaking roof patch is mentioned above in problem #2).

Problem: Bad light switch
Solution: The back side of the outlet box is exposed.  Get an electrician to come out and take a look.  Bad light switch connection in son's bedroom.

Problem: A stream of water runs under the corner of the house (could damage corner post)
Solution: At one time, an attempt was made to contain the water in a 6" drainpipe. Some of the water now goes in this pipe, but a lot of it goes around and under the house. One idea is to dig another ditch, another idea is to make the drainpipe work again.

Problem: A second set of steps is non-functional
Solution: Tear off the steps. Take the screen door off. Fill in the space with hand rails. Debbie is okay with this.

Problem: Back steps are not in good shape
Solution: Tear down steps. You could use the old stringers for patterns and re-use some materials. Pour footers and/or stack block to support the bottom of the stringer. Add hand rails on both sides and pickets.

Problem: Porch posts have shifted.
Solution: About 6 posts that are 4"x4" need to be shore by straightening and adding concrete. Brace them with 2"x6" pressure treated in all directions. Braces should be installed at 1/3 the length of the posts according to code. Some of the posts underneath the house need this bracing.

Problem: Wood heater stove pipe is rusty and stained. There is no ceiling box.
Solution: Replace black single-wall pipe. Add chimney box and stainless steel insulated chimney. Re-use the old chimney cap. Add boot and storm collar. This is 6" stovepipe

Problem: Roof is leaking.
Solution: Repair roof. This is a difficult problem.  Although the roof is metal and it is in good shape, a large section of this roof is very flat (3/4" in 12", with screws in the flats). With this lack of slope, it could be leaking almost anywhere, and traveling to other places.  There is one patch (above the stove pipe hole in the kitchen) that is leaking, and could be fixed by installing a whole new sheet of metal.  The metal is an unusual kind, it is 3' wide, but has a different profile than your standard roof metal.  The short-term solution would be to replace the metal as stated above, and re-flash around the wood stove chimney (which also needs work).  This would not fix all the leaks.  The long term solution would be tear off the flat section of roof metal and re-frame the roof.  Call Madison Metals in Mars Hill with metal questions.

Problem: Access issues.
Solution: Add gravel. Seems to be Debbie's main concern  Add several tons of gravel and road bond to the road and flatten it out.  Have gravel delivered.  Danny Collins (dump truck) 828-777-6352. McCrary Stone (649-2008). Add waterbreaks.  jennifer at Glory Ridge knows where to get metal waterbreaks.

Problem: Front porch leaking over door
Solution: Trim porch roof metal over gutters and add flashing to direct water into the gutter and prevent water from running between gutter and porch roof.

Problem: Rats ate wall in daughters closet and behind washing machine
Solution: Remove carpet from closet. Remove damaged drywall, first 2' up from the floor. Checking and repair framing as needed. install new drywall and paint. May need to use a cleaner to remove rat urine smell.

Problem: Toilet leaking and will not flush
Solution: Replace wax ring and flush mechanism. Sandra has the wax ring and flush valve replacement parts. Just needs someone to install. Currently she has to keep the water off so that the floor doesn't rot.

Problem: heat pump unit not working
Solution: Have Rutherford Heating and Air fix

Problem: No Gutters
Solution: Install gutters

Problem: No power
Solution: Beulah had this cut off because of her high electric bill. She claims it was $300/mo. She has an electric stove but no electric heaters to my knowledge; hard to say what caused this bill to be so high - septic pump?

Problem: Septic problems. There are a couple of plastic tanks outside; the waste goes into these and up - see photos.
Solution: Danny says the pump that pumps the wastewater uphill to the drain field got hit by lightning. He says a replacement pump would cost $3,000.

Problem: Water is not cut on, state of plumbing unknown.
Solution: Check for leaks after water gets cut on.

Problem: Chimney for the wood stove is cracked.
Solution: Replace masonry chimney with better stovepipe.

Problem: Monitor heater has some problems, cuts on and off.
Solution: Take it in for service or have someone come look at it; may just need cleaning.
